BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
RAF College, Cranwell, or civilian universities. There is also a scheme in all
three Services for the award of University Cadetships, which enable young
men to take a degree before commencing their Service training. There are
also schemes for the entry of graduates and other qualified specialists.
Selected officers of all three Services who have had previous staff training or
have been to the Royal Naval Staff College, Greenwich (London), the Army
Staff College at Camberley (Surrey), or the Royal Air Force Staff College
at Bracknell (Berkshire) go to the Joint Services Staff College (to be re¬
named the National Defence College in 1971) at Chesham (Buckingham¬
shire). Here particular attention is paid to the inter-Service aspect of staff
work. A few specially selected and more senior officers from the Services,
the Civil Service, and from the Commonwealth, the United States, and
allied European countries are sent to the Imperial Defence College (to be
re-named the Royal College of Defence Studies) in London. Considerable
training is done through Joint-Service and inter-allied exercises, on which
increasing emphasis is being placed.
In the defence estimates for 1970-71 ^27 million is allocated to Reserve and
Auxiliary Formations.
The Regular Reserve consists of various categories of former full-time officers
and ratings liable to recall in emergency. The Volunteer Reserves comprise
the Royal Naval Reserve (with its associated women’s reserve) and the Royal
Marines Reserve; they carry out regular part-time training and man a number
of operational minesweepers.
The Royal Naval Auxiliary Service, a civilian organisation composed of
men and women volunteers, is responsible in time of war for minewatching
duties around the coast and the waterways, and other duties.
Men who have completed the Colour portion of their service with the Regular
Army are retained on the Regular Army Reserve to complete a total engage¬
ment of seven or 12 years, according to their initial commitment; they are
liable to recall to the Colours. Thereafter they are transferred to the Long
Term Reserve (LTR) where they remain until the age of 45 and are liable to
recall in an emergency. The Army General Reserve consists of certain former
National Service specialists.
The Territorial and Army Volunteer Reserve (T & AVR) consists of
independent and sponsored units. Independent units are raised on a terri¬
torial basis and each is based on one or more training centres. Sponsored
units consist of specialists and have to be recruited on a nation-wide basis.
These units are divided, for administration purposes, into Group A which
have a liability for call-out when warlike operations are in preparation or in
progress; and Group B, which consists of miscellaneous units (for example,
University Officer Training Corps) with various liabilities.
In January 1970 recruiting began for the Ulster Defence Regiment, a
locally recruited, part-time force under the General Officer Commanding,
Northern Ireland, whose role is to support the regular forces in the Command.
The annual cost will be some ^1 million, and numbers will not exceed
6,000 officers and men.
The Regular Reserve consists of former full-time officers and airmen, of
whom a few are detailed for specific tasks in emergency and the remainder
DEFENCE
”3
have a statutory liability for recall. The Royal Auxiliary Air Force, consisting
of three maritime headquarter units which would, in an emergency, reinforce
Strike Command (see p. in), and the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve,
which includes the 16 University Air Squadrons, are liable for part-time
training and for recall in an emergency.
HOME DEFENCE The Government decided in 1968 to put civil defence arrangements on a care
and maintenance basis. The physical assets of civil defence organisations are
being preserved so far as is practicable, and training and planning continues
at the minimum level required to maintain knowledge and techniques and to
enable more active preparations to be resumed if this should appear to be
necessary. Total annual public expenditure on civil defence is expected to
remain at between ^7 million and £8 million.
The arrangements being maintained include an emergency system for
decentralised governmental control and communications, and the United
Kingdom Warning and Monitoring Organisation, including the Royal
Observer Corps, which would provide public warning of an attack, of the
location and power of nuclear explosions, and of the distribution and level of
radioactive fall-out; also planning for the police and fire services. Central
training courses are provided at the Civil Defence Training Establishment,
near York.
NATO COMMITMENT
The new strategy of the North Atlantic Alliance, adopted in December 1967,
recognises that while the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) must
be ready to use nuclear weapons if necessary, the capability of its conven¬
tional forces has to be maximised and their number maintained in western
Europe at a level which would give NATO an alternative to a nuclear response
against anything but a major deliberate attack. They have to be sufficient to
gain time for negotiations to end a conflict and for consultation among the
Allies about the initial use of nuclear weapons should negotiations fail.
Britain makes a major and essential contribution to the forces which NATO
needs. Virtually the whole of the Royal Navy is earmarked for assignment;
the British Army of the Rhine (BAOR) and RAF Germany (a tactical air¬
force) are assigned; and most of the air and ground combat units based in
the United Kingdom are also formally committed to NATO. The British
Army has had more recent and varied fighting experience than any other
European army; the Royal Air Force is well advanced with a major re¬
equipment programme involving some of the most modern combat aircraft
available; while the size and striking power of the Royal Navy is second
only to that of the United States within the North Atlantic Alliance.
DEPLOYMENT
In January 1970 forces (including locally enlisted troops and the Royal Navy
at sea) were distributed in the following proportions:
Britain, 237,500; European continent, 60,200 (nearly all in Germany);
Mediterranean and Near East, 19,600; Middle and Far East, 44,750
(including Gurkhas); and elsewhere, 37,000.
The deployment of forces is summarised below.

The Western Fleet operates in European sea areas; frigates, submarines and
coastal minesweepers carry out training, trials and fishery protection, and
ships of all classes spend periods at home for refitting. All major ships have
NATO commitments in the Channel, Eastern Atlantic, and Mediterranean;
a frigate is assigned to the Standing Naval Force Atlantic. Submarines of the
British Polaris force are on continuous deterrent patrol.
The majority of the field force headquarters and units stationed in the
United Kingdom are in the Army Strategic Command. This includes the
land elements of the United Kingdom Mobile Force (of which No. 38 Group,
Royal Air Force, provides the air element), the British contribution to the
land element of Allied Command Europe Mobile Force (Land), and 22 Special
Air Service Regiment, all of which have roles in support of NATO. Other
field force units and training organisations are stationed in the United King¬
dom together with units engaged on logistic tasks.
The combat units of the Royal Air Force in Britain are provided by Strike
Command and Air Support Command. The former provides strike and air
reconnaissance squadrons, interceptor squadrons for the air defence of
Britain, and long-range maritime reconnaissance squadrons. It also provides
forces for maritime air defence and strike as part of the plan for the transfer
to the Royal Air Force from the Royal Navy of the responsibility for fixed
wing operational maritime support. These forces are all committed to NATO.
Air Support Command is responsible for both strategic and tactical transport
forces, and for the force of Phantoms and Harriers in No. 38 Group designed
for the close support of the Army in the field. The Phantoms and short-
range transport aircraft in No. 38 Group provide the RAF part of the UK
Mobile Force which is committed to NATO, while the Harriers provide the
British contribution to NATO’s Allied Command Europe Mobile Force
(Air). There are also units of the Royal Air Force Regiment, responsible for
airfield defence.
Ground forces in the Federal Republic of Germany consist of the British
Army of the Rhine (BAOR) and an independent brigade in Berlin. BAOR
is organised as a corps of three divisions each of two brigades, plus corps
troops including two artillery brigades and an armoured reconnaissance
force. The BAOR brigades are in the process of reorganisation to produce a
better balance between armoured units and mechanised infantry. Royal
Air Force Germany is a tactical air force including tactical strike, tactical
reconnaissance, and air defence aircraft, all assigned to SACEUR. During
1970, further surface-to-air missiles and light anti-aircraft squadrons were
deployed for the defence of RAF Germany’s airfields.
In the Mediterranean Britain’s maritime presence generally includes an
aircraft carrier or a commando ship or an assault ship; two frigates and a
guided missile destroyer which are earmarked for assignment to SACEUR;
and a frigate for the NATO ‘on call’ force.
Royal Air Force units in the area consist of strike, maritime reconnaissance,
photographic reconnaissance, fighter and transport squadrons; surface-to-
air missiles; and RAF Regiment squadrons. These forces are based in Cyprus
and Malta. RAF support for NATO is provided from the forces in Malta,
while support for the Central Treaty Organisation comes from forces in both
locations. Britain also supplies at its own expense over 1,000 men for the
United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (about 30 per cent of the
total). There are small garrisons in Malta and Gibraltar.

In January 1970 British land forces consisted of infantry supported by
artillery, armoured cars and engineers stationed at Bahrain and Sharjah.
RAF forces were also based at Bahrain and Sharjah and included ground-
attack and fighter reconnaissance, tactical transport and long-range maritime
reconnaissance aircraft. Royal Navy frigates and mine counter-measures
vessels, based at Bahrain, operated in the Gulf.
Britain maintains combat units in Malaysia, Singapore and Brunei, and a
garrison in Hong Kong but no longer declares forces to the contingency plans
of the South-East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO). Britain also maintains
joint training facilities with Australia and New Zealand, and British units
will continue to train in the area. The reduction of the Brigade of Gurkhas
has continued towards the level of 6,000 men to be reached by the end of
1971.
Naval forces in the Far East Fleet contain most types of warships and fleet
auxiliaries, including amphibious ships, destroyers, submarines and frigates.
These forces operate in the Indian and Pacific Oceans and undertake patrol
duties in the Mozambique channel. Ships of the Royal Australian and Royal
New Zealand Navies operate with the Far Eastern Fleet. The 3rd Commando
Brigade, Royal Marines, is stationed in Singapore.
The Far East Air Force is made up of units of the RAF and Royal Australian
and Royal New Zealand Air Forces. The Royal Air Force contribution
includes fighters and associated ground environment radars, long-range
maritime reconnaissance aircraft, support helicopters and a medium-range
transport squadron, together with a squadron of the Royal Air Force
Regiment.
Two frigates, equipped with helicopters and carrying a detachment of Royal
Marines, operate in the Caribbean. A small Royal Marine force and a hover¬
craft unit are maintained in the Falkland Islands, and the Navy’s ice-patrol
ship, HMS Endurance, operates there seasonally.
A small Army garrison remains in British Honduras. Some Royal Engineers
are stationed in Anguilla.
COMBAT FORCES
Combat forces are functionally divided into six major groups, as described
below.
Responsibility for the British contribution to the Western strategic deter¬
rent now rests with the Royal Navy Polaris submarine force whose four
nuclear submarines—Resolution, Repulse, Renown and Revenge—are opera¬
tional. Each has indefinite underwater cruising range, and carries 16
Polaris A3 missiles with a range of about 2,500 miles and thermonuclear
warheads.
The Polaris and other submarines are supported by the Clyde sub¬
marine base completed in 1968. Britain also provides facilities for a depot
ship for United States Polaris submarines at Holy Loch on the Firth of
Clyde.
Britain’s nuclear strategic force is assigned to NATO. Within the Alliance
Britain has played an active part in the discussions designed to associate
the non-nuclear members of NATO with the Alliance’s nuclear planning.
Il6 BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Procedures for consultation on the possible use of nuclear weapons have also
been refined.
The cost of nuclear strategic forces for 1970-71 is estimated at £32 million.
European The European theatre ground forces consist of the BAOR and an independent
Theatre Ground brigade in Berlin. Their cost in 1970-71 is estimated at £211 million.
Nine armoured regiments have been equipped with the Chieftain main
battle tank, which incorporates new features in protection and mobility
and mounts the fully stabilised 120 mm. gun. Armoured regiments are also
being equipped with Swingfire anti-tank guided missiles on a version of the
armoured personnel carrier. The field artillery has been re-equipped; its
weapons now include the 105 mm pack-howitzer, the British Abbot self-
propelled 105 mm gun, and the American self-propelled 155 mm and
175 mm guns; the issue of the new Field Artillery Computer Equipment
(FACE) gives improved accuracy and response times, as does the Cymbeline
light-weight mortar-locating radar. Surface-to-surface tactical nuclear
support is provided by the Honest John free-flight missile and the 8 in.
(203 mm) howitzer. Infantry mobility has continued to improve; infantry
battalions have tracked armoured personnel carriers (FV 432), some of
which are converted to carry the 81 mm mortar or the Wombat 122 mm anti¬
tank gun. The Stalwart (high mobility cross-country load-carrying vehicle)
has come into service. Mechanised infantry battalions have been equipped
with a new light anti-tank rocket during 1970. Surveillance and target
acquisition capability has been improved by a new drone (unmanned recon¬
naissance aircraft) and by the issue of ground surveillance radar and additional
night-fighting devices. Air defence is provided by Thunderbird and Rapier
anti-aircraft guided missiles, both systems are fully mobile. The field trunk
communications system, Bruin, has proved valuable and effective, and is
being extended.
The naval general purpose combat elements of the Fleet comprise the
following: amphibious forces; aircraft carriers and squadrons; submarines
(excluding the Polaris force); cruisers, destroyers and frigates; mine counter¬
measure forces; and support and other ships. Any of these forces can be sent
to other theatres if needed in an emergency, either as reinforcements or to
carry out joint operations with the Army and Royal Air Force. Their cost,
including aircraft and overseas bases, in 1970-71 is estimated at £295
million.
Equipment The aircraft carriers HMS Ark Royal, having been refitted to carry Phantom
aircraft, and HMS Eagle were in service during 1970; HMS Hermes is being
phased out from the fixed-wing flying role. The carrier-borne strike and
air-defence aircraft consist of the Buccaneer, Sea Vixen and Phantom. The
Buccaneer Mk 2 is a long-range, low-level strike aircraft, equipped with the
Bullpup air-to-surface missile. The Sea Vixen Mk 2 is an all-weather inter¬
ceptor/ground attack aircraft, and carries Firestreak and Red Top air-to-air
missiles in its air defence role: the Phantom, an advanced interceptor, is
equipped with Sparrow and Sidewinder air-to-air missiles.
Amphibious forces are provided by the commando ships HMS Albion
and HMS Bulwark, with Royal Marine Commandos, helicopters and landing-
craft, and the assault ships HMS Fearless and HMS Intrepid, both of
which have been fitted with a communications satellite terminal, working
through the Skynet system. The command-helicopter cruiser HMS Blake

is in service, equipped to carry a squadron of Wessex 3 helicopters; HMS
Tiger's conversion, to equip her to carry Sea King helicopters, is in progress.
The County class series of eight guided missile destroyers is being com¬
pleted; they are equipped with Seaslug and Seacat ship-to-air guided
missiles (both of which have a capability against surface targets), an anti¬
submarine helicopter, and underwater detection equipment, and four 4-5 in.
(124 mm) fully automatic quick-firing guns with appropriate control equip¬
ment. Twenty-four Leander class frigates will have been completed by the
end of 1970, and a further two are under construction; they are equipped
with advanced anti-submarine equipment, including sonar and mortars;
they and the Tribal class carry Wasp anti-submarine helicopters and Seacat
anti-aircraft guided missiles. All ships of frigate size can carry helicopters;
the Wasp and Wessex 3 (with an advanced anti-submarine system) are at
present in service. The Sea King is being deployed during 1970 on the
carriers and major fleet units: the WG 13 (see p. 119) is expected to replace
the Wasp in the mid-seventies. These helicopters have an anti-submarine
role and a capability against surface vessels.
Progress is being maintained on the three classes of surface ships to be
introduced during the seventies: the first of the new frigates (Type 21) and
the first of the new destroyers (Type 42) to carry the Sea Dart surface-to-air
missile (with a surface-to-surface capability) are under construction. The
construction of HMS Bristol, the Type 82 guided missile destroyer, with
Sea Dart and Ikara, an anti-submarine missile, continues according to
schedule. Some of the Leander class frigates are being equipped with Ikara.
A new type of cruiser, to carry helicopters, with a ‘through-deck’ design
giving the option of operating V/STOL aircraft, is being designed; it will
also be armed with Sea Dart.
Four nuclear fleet submarines (hunter-killer) are now in service—
Dreadnought, Valiant, Warspite and Churchill. HMS Conqueror and HMS
Courageous have been launched; three more are under construction. A force
of 24 conventional patrol submarines is also in service.
Maintenance and repair facilities are provided by submarine depot ships,
a heavy repair and maintenance ship, and mine counter-measure support
ships—all manned by naval personnel. Ships of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary
Service provide afloat logistic support such as fuel, food, ammunition, stores
and spare gear. These ships fly the Blue Ensign and are manned by Mechant
Navy officers and seamen. The dockyards at Portsmouth, Devonport, Chat¬
ham and Rosyth provide the Navy with major repair and supply facilities in
Britain.
Army general purpose combat forces consist of the ground forces deployed
outside Europe; the Army Strategic Command; and other front line units in
Britain. Their cost in 1970-71 is estimated at ^143 million.
Army Strategic Command’s (see p. in) primary role is in support of
NATO, but the forces in the command also form part of the general capability
for deployment elsewhere.
Equipment is in general similar to that of the European Theatre Ground
forces. The standard NATO general purpose machine-gun and the 81 mm
mortar have been introduced. Some infantry battalions have the Combat
and Wombat heavy anti-tank guns, while others are equipped with Vigilant
anti-tank guided missiles.
The Army’s force of helicopters is being increased and will be equipped

with the Anglo-French Gazelle (SA 341) and WG 13 helicopters (see p. 119).
Canadian Beaver light aircraft are used for liaison purposes. The Landing

The Royal Air Force general purpose combat forces comprise all front line
formations and units except those designated Air Mobility Forces (transport
and tanker forces). They fall into five main categories: air defence, ground
attack and fighter reconnaissance; tactical strike and reconnaissance; mari¬
time reconnaissance; headquarters; and general support. Their cost in
I970_7I is estimated at £365 million.
Interceptor squadrons are equipped with the Lightning, which is supersonic
and can carry Firestreak or Red Top air-to-air missiles. Bloodhound and
Tigercat surface-to-air missiles are also available for air defence. The
air defence system is fully co-ordinated, with ground radars. New military
radars and centralised data-handling equipment are being installed in
Britain as part of the integrated plans for air defence and national air traffic
control (the Linesman/Mediator system). The Ballistic Missile Early Warning
Station at Fylingdales would provide warning of a missile attack on Britain
and also detects, tracks and identifies objects in orbit.
The first Phantom FGR 2 and Harrier squadrons have been formed in
Air Support Command; further squadrons are being formed in RAF
Germany during 1970 and 1971. The Harrier with its unique vertical take¬
off and landing capacity will concentrate mainly on quick reaction close
support, while the Phantom will cover the longer range ground attack and
reconnaissance functions. It is planned that a ground attack version of the
Anglo-French Jiagwar (see p. 119) should release further Phantoms from this
role to replace in turn the Lightning interceptors. The Buccaneer MK 2
which is already in service in a maritime strike role, will deploy to RAF
Germany in early 1971 to start replacing the Canberra in the tactical strike
and reconnaissance role. The Shackleton is available for long maritime
reconnaissance and in an anti-submarine role. It is being replaced gradually
by the Nimrod, the only land based jet maritime reconnaissance aircraft in
service in the world, which entered service with the RAF in 1969.
Phantom FG 1 squadrons are now operational in Strike Command, in the
maritime air defence role; the Royal Air Force’s first Buccaneer 2 squadron
was formed in late 1969 in the maritime strike role.
Air mobility forces are made up of the strategic and tactical transport forces,
tanker aircraft to refuel combat aircraft in flight, support helicopters and
communications aircraft. Their cost in 1970-71, together with that of
associated stations and other support, is estimated at £105 million (which
includes £4 million on civil charter).
The strategic transport force is equipped with Comet 4C, Britannia, Belfast
and VC 10 aircraft. Tactical transport support over medium ranges is
provided by the Hercules and the Argosy, while for short-range tasks the
Wessex and Whirlwind helicopters and the Andover aircraft are available.
Also the Anglo-French Puma support helicopter will enter service late in
1970 to supplement the Wessex. A force of Victor tanker aircraft is available
for in-flight refuelling.

DEFENCE PROCUREMENT AND SUPPORT
Responsibility for the supply of aircraft, guided weapons, nuclear weapons
and certain radar and other electronic equipment lies with the Ministry of
Technology. The Ministry of Defence is responsible for the procurement of
other weapons, stores and equipment.
A substantial part of the equipment used by the Services is developed and
produced in Britain, some by private industry on a contract basis and some
by the Royal Ordnance Factories, the Royal Dockyards and other establish¬
ments operated by the Ministry of Technology and the Ministry of Defence.
Because it is too costly for Britain or any other European country to
develop all its own defence equipment, a balance, which reconciles economic,
industrial, and political objectives with defence requirements, is maintained
between national development, development in collaboration with allies,
and foreign purchase.
There has been continued progress towards increased European co-operation
in the development and procurement of defence equipment. The most
important collaborative venture at present is the multi-role combat aircraft
(MRCA) in which Britain is co-operating with the Federal Republic of
Germany and Italy. Successful collaboration continues with France on the
Jaguar strike-trainer, the Martel air-to-surface missile, and the Gazelle
(SA 341), Puma (SA 330) and WG 13 helicopters. Britain is collaborating
with the Federal Republic of Germany on a 155 mm towed gun; with
Australia for the Ikara anti-submarine missile; and with Australia, Canada
and the United States for the Mallard trunk communication system.
Regular consultation takes place between Britain and her European allies
to harmonise the tactical doctrines on which joint operational requirements
for weapons systems are based.
The bulk of research work is carried out in the 26 defence research establish¬
ments under the control of the Ministries of Defence and Technology;
these establishments also evaluate the development work undertaken by
private industry for the Government. Consultation and collaboration be¬
tween Government and industry is secured through the National Defence
Industries Council and the Defence Scientific Advisory Council. The
establishments are being organised increasingly on a functional rather than
on a single service basis. Research and development work is in six major
fields—aircraft, guided weapons, military space, electronics, ship con¬
struction and naval weapons, ordnance and military vehicles.
Since 1967 efforts have been made to reduce the resources directed to
defence research and development, to make increased resources available for
civil research and development (see p. 190). The 1970 estimate for defence re¬
search is J222 million, a reduction at constant prices of about £25 million on
the 1969-70 estimate. Analysis of the implications of policy is made by the
Defence Operational Analysis Establishment. The Chief Adviser (Projects
and Research) (see p. no) is responsible for the oversight of the whole
equipment research and development programme, and exercises control
through the Defence Research Committee, the Operational Requirements
Committee, and the Weapons Development Committee, which evaluate the
options on the various weapons systems required by current strategy and
defence policy.

Over 30 major projects are at present in hand, including the MRCA, the
Sea Dart and Sea Wolf ship-to-air guided weapons, Clansman, a net radio
system for field communications, the adaptation of hovercraft for naval
purposes, and Scorpion and Fox, two air-portable armoured combat recon¬
naissance vehicles. The defence research establishments also undertake
civil work, and publicise the many industrial applications of their research.
In addition to research and development, there is support of a general nature
supplied in Britain to the Services as a whole. The major items include:
general training; the overhead costs of naval dockyards, ordnance factories
and repair, maintenance and storage units; Ministry of Defence and local
administrative services in Britain; and military pensions. Work continues to
rationalise and reorganise these support services. The total estimated cost for
1970-71 is £838 million.

5 SOCIAL WELFARE
STATE AND VOLUNTARY SERVICES
In Britain the State is responsible, through either central or local govern¬
ment, for a range of services covering family allowances, national insurance,
help for war victims, financial assistance when required, health and welfare
services for mothers and young children, the sick, mentally disordered,
elderly and handicapped and for families in difficulties of various kinds, and
the care of children lacking a normal home life (all described in this chapter);
and for education (see Chapter 6) and housing (see Chapter 7). Public
authorities in Britain are spending nearly £9,360 million a year on this range
of services, that is, over £168 a year per head of the population.
Voluntary organisations, especially the Churches, were the pioneers of
nearly all the social sendees. They provided schools, hospitals, clinics,
dispensaries, and social and recreational clubs before these were provided by
the State. They made themselves responsible for the welfare of the very young
and the very old, the homeless and the handicapped. Gradually the State
accepted the primary responsibility for the major services, supplementing the
voluntary services and developing a comprehensive structure that ensured a
minimum standard of living and well-being for all citizens.
State and voluntary social services are now complementary and co-opera¬
tive. The State may work through voluntary agencies specially adapted to
serve particular needs and ensures that necessary standards are maintained.
The officers of central and local government, in carrying out their duties,
co-operate with the workers of many voluntary social service societies, while
the residential provision made by the State and by local authorities for the care
of children, the chronic sick and the aged is supplemented by voluntary homes
of various types. Most of the sick and elderly receive State pensions or benefits.
The Charity Commission, a government department, gives free advice to
trustees of charities, making schemes to modify their purposes or facilitate
their administration when necessary; it maintains central and local registers
of charities which are open to public inspection; and it works to promote
co-operation between charities and State sendees.
Voluntary
Organisations
The number of voluntary societies and institutions in Britain runs into
thousands; they range from national organisations to small individual local
groups. Most organisations, however, are members of larger associations or
are represented on local or national co-ordinating councils or committees.
Some are chiefly concerned with giving personal service, others in the forma¬
tion of public opinion and exchange of information. A number are concerned
with giving help to immigrants. In recent years there has been an increase in
organised service by young people.
Organisations concerned with personal and family problems include the
voluntary family casework agencies like the Family Welfare Association,
Family Service Units, and the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty
to Children; marriage guidance centres affiliated to the National Marriage
Guidance Council; the National Council for the Unmarried Mother and her
Child and the Samaritans, who help people near to committing suicide.
Voluntary service to the sick and disabled in general is given among others
SOCIAL WET.FARE
T23
Social Workers
Urban
Programme
by the British Red Cross Society, the St. John Ambulance Association and
Brigade, the Women’s Royal Voluntary Service and the Leagues of Hospital
Friends, but an increasing number of societies exist to help people with
particular disabilities and difficulties, such as the Royal National Institute
for the Blind, the Royal National Institute for the Deaf, the National Associa¬
tion for Mental Health, the National Society for Mentally Handicapped
Children, the Spastics Society, the constituent members of the Central
Council for the Disabled, Alcoholics Anonymous, Narcotics Anonymous
and their Scottish equivalents.
Bodies working on a national scale whose work is specifically religious in
inspiration include the Salvation Army, the Church Army, Toe H, the
Committee on Social Service of the Church of Scotland, the Church of
England Children’s Society, the Church of England Council for Social Work,
the Young Men’s Christian Association, the Young Women’s Christian
Association, the Society of Friends, the Crusade of Rescue, the Society of
St. Vincent de Paul, the Catholic Marriage Advisory Council and the Jewish
Welfare Board.
A wide range of voluntary personal service is given by the Women’s Royal
Voluntary Service, which gives help in every kind of practical difficulty, brings
‘meals on wheels’ to housebound invalids and old people, provides flatlets
and residential clubs for the elderly, helps with family problems and assists in
hospitals and clinics, as well as doing relief work in emergencies.
A central link between voluntary organisations and official bodies concerned
with social welfare is provided in England and Wales by the National Council
of Social Service, which brings together most of the principal voluntary
agencies for consultation and joint action, either as a whole or in groups of
those concerned with particular aspects, such as jmuth work or old people’s
welfare. There are also the Scottish Council of Social Service and the Northern
Ireland Council of Social Service, which perform similar functions. The
Citizens’ Advice Bureaux, of which there are now some 500 in Britain,
are steadily increasing in number. The primary role of the bureaux is to give
explanation and advice to the citizen who is in doubt about his rights or who
does not know about the State or voluntary services which could help him.
While the voluntary worker giving full-time or part-time service has done
pioneer work in many of Britain’s social services and continues to play an
essential part, social services of all kinds increasingly depend for their opera¬
tion chiefly on professional social workers, that is, full-time salaried workers
trained in the principles and methods of social work. Most professional social
workers are employed by local authorities (for child care, welfare, mental
welfare and probation work), by hospitals (for medical and psychiatric work),
or by voluntary organisations. Training for many forms of social work con¬
sists of a basic university degree, diploma or certificate course in social
science followed by a university course in applied social studies or specialised
training for a particular service. The Council for Training in Social Work also
promotes the training, in the first instance, of workers in the local authority
health and welfare services and similar services run by voluntary bodies.
Full-time courses lasting two years, which may be taken at colleges of further
education, lead to the Council’s Certificate in Social Work. Advice on social
work training is given by the Social Work Advisory Service.
A four-year urban programme providing for Government-aided local
authority expenditure of some ^20-^25 million was launched at the end of
124
Reciprocity
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
1968 to assist areas of special social need, in particular to relieve problems
resulting from overcrowding, inadequate housing and schools, and other
forms of deprivation. Projects being undertaken include help for play-groups
and the provision and improvement of nursery schools and classes, day
nurseries and playgrounds, language classes for immigrants, in-service train¬
ing courses for teachers, children’s homes and family advice centres.
An experiment in community development has also been started by
the Government. This involves bringing together those services, both
statutory and voluntary, which are concerned with relieving various forms
of social handicap and encouraging the resources of self-help within the
community.
SOCIAL SECURITY
National insurance, industrial injuries insurance, family allowances and
supplementary benefits together with (in a special category) war pensions
constitute a comprehensive system of social security in the United Kingdom.
The Department of Health and Social Security administers these services
in Great Britain; within the Department the Supplementary Benefits Com¬
mission is responsible for the system of supplementary benefits. In Northern
Ireland the first four of these schemes are administered by the Ministry of
Health and Social Services which contains the Supplementary Benefits
Commission for Northern Ireland. Pensions and welfare services for war
pensioners and their dependants are the responsibility of the Department of
Health and Social Security throughout the United Kingdom. Appeals
relating to claims for insurance benefits, family allowances, war pensions, or
for supplementary benefit, are decided by independent authorities.
Although the development of public provision for social security in Britain
can be traced back for several centuries (the Poor Relief Act of 1601 may
be regarded as specially important in England and Wales), the modern system
of comprehensive provision is a creation of the twentieth century. Non¬
contributory old age pensions were introduced in 1908, and the first con¬
tributory pensions for old people, widows and orphans in 1926. A contributory
National Health Insurance Scheme was begun in 1912, and in the same year
a scheme of unemployment insurance was introduced which in 1920 was
extended to cover the great majority of employees. By the beginning of the
second world war social security provision in Britain was among the best in
the world, but lacked co-ordination because of its piecemeal development,
and not everyone came within its scope. In the immediate post-war years a
series of Acts introduced the present comprehensive system, which became
fully operative on 5th July 1948. Statutory provision for the war disabled goes
back to the end of the sixteenth century, but the main lines of the present war
pension provisions were laid down during the first world war.
Family allowances and national insurance and industrial injuries benefits
or allowances, other than maternity, unemployment, sickness, injury or dis¬
ablement benefit, are included in the taxable income on which income tax
is assessed. On the other hand, various income tax reliefs and exemptions
are allowed on account of age or liability for the support of dependants. War
disablement pensions are not taxable.
The national insurance, industrial injuries and family allowances schemes of
Great Britain and those of Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man operate as a
single system. Reciprocal agreements on industrial injuries, family allowances
FAMILY
ALLOWANCES
NATIONAL
INSURANCE
Contributors
SOCIAL WELFARE I25
and most national insurance benefits are in operation with Belgium, Denmark,
Finland, the Federal Republic of Germany, Jersey and Guernsey, Norway,
Sweden, Switzerland and Yugoslavia. Agreements with Cyprus, France, the
Republic of Ireland, Israel, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands and
Turkey cover industrial injuries and most national insurance benefits. With
Australia and New Zealand there are agreements on family allowances and
most national insurance benefits. There are limited agreements with Bermuda,
Canada and the United States. Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man are
also party to most of these agreements with other countries.
Family allowances are provided in Great Britain under the Family Allowances
Act 1965 (which consolidated the Acts of I945-^4)> an(^ Northern Ireland
under its own legislation. Nearly 7 million allowances are being paid in Great
Britain to more than 4 million families, and in Northern Ireland to 137,000
families. The allowances are payable to families with two or more children
below the age limits which are 15 years for children who leave school at that
age, 16 years for certain incapacitated children, and 19 for children who
remain at school or are apprentices.
The rates of the allowances are £o-go a week for families with two children
below the age limits and a further £1 a week for each additional child.
Family allowances are paid from the Exchequer and their object is to benefit
the family as a whole; they belong to the mother, but may be paid either
to the mother or to the father. There is no insurance qualification for title to
the allowances, but there are certain residence conditions.
The National Insurance Acts apply, in general, to everyone over minimum
school-leaving age living in Great Britain. There are similar schemes in
Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man. (The National Insurance Act 1965
consolidated the provisions of the National Insurance Acts 1946-64.)
The national insurance scheme provides benefits in specified contingencies
where contribution conditions have been fulfilled. T. he benefits are paid for
partly by insured persons’ contributions, partly by contributions of employers
in respect of their employees, and partly by a contribution made by the
Exchequer out of general taxation.
The original system was based on flat-rate contributions and benefits.
Contributions varied only with the sex and insurance class of the insured
person and benefits were at standard rates. (In both cases lower rates apply to
those under 18.) Two modifications were subsequently introduced to provide
additional earnings-related contributions and benefits. For retirement,
graduated contributions and pensions were introduced in 1961. For the first
six months of sickness, unemployment or widowhood the National Insurance
Act 1966 introduced a scheme for earnings-related supplements to the flat-
rate benefit and contributions. In November 1969 the graduated contribution
was increased to help pay for improvements in the rates of the flat-rate
benefits. These higher contributions also count towards a graduated pension.
In July 1970 legislation was passed to introduce (from November 1970)
pensions for elderly people who were over pension age when the scheme
started, pensions (from April 1971) for widows aged between 40 and 50, and
an attendance allowance (from April 1972) for severely disabled people need¬
ing constant supervision.
Contributors under the national insurance scheme are divided into three
classes:
126
Contributions
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Class 1. Employed people. Most of those who work for an employer under a
contract of service or are paid apprentices—over 23 million.
Class 2. Self-employed people. Those in business on their own account and
others who are working for gain but do not work under the control of an
employer—about i| million.
Class 3. Non-employed people. All those insured who are not in class 1 or
class 2—about a quarter of a million.
There is a general liability to pay flat-rate contributions according to this
classification but certain people are excepted. These include full-time students,
prisoners and most people in receipt of national insurance benefits. Self-
employed and non-employed persons whose income is below ^3123 year can
apply for exception. Married women can choose to pay contributions and
receive benefit in their own right or not to pay fiat-rate contributions (if they
are working they must pay graduated contributions) and rely upon their
husband’s insurance for maternity grant, retirement pension (at a lower rate),
widow’s benefit and death grant. If a married woman works for an employer
he must pay his full share of the flat-rate contributions even if she has chosen
not to pay fiat-rate contributions.
Flat-rate contributions are credited to students up to the age of 18, and
to most people in receipt of national insurance benefits. People who are
excepted from liability to pay but are not entitled to credits may pay con¬
tributions at the non-employed rate if they wish to safeguard entitlement to
retirement pension and widowT’s benefit.
An employed person ceases to be liable for national insurance contributions
at the age of 70 for men, 65 for women, or when he retires from regular
employment after reaching minimum pension age (65 for men, 60 for women),
whichever is the earlier. If he does any work as an employed person there¬
after, he must pay an industrial injuries contribution; the employer still has
to pay his full share of the flat-rate contribution.
Flat-rate contributions are normally paid by means of national insurance
stamps bought from a post office and fixed, for each contributor, to a single
contribution card. All three classes pay flat-rate contributions (see Table 9).
The stamps for class 1 contributors also include the employer’s redundancy
contribution (to help to provide for payments in certain circumstances to
employees whose work is terminated, see p. 419) and the selective employ¬
ment tax paid by employers (see p. 365); and for all contributors the National
Health Service contribution (which for convenience is paid with the national
insurance contribution although the two services are separately administered).
It is the employer’s responsibility in the first place to see that the class 1
contributions are paid, but he can deduct the employees’ share from their
wages. The self-employed and non-employed must stamp their own cards.
Flat-rate contributions are usually credited for weeks of unemployment,
sickness or injury, or if widow’s benefit is being paid.
In general graduated contributions are payable by employed people
(including married women but not retirement pensioners) aged between 18
and 70 (65 for women) who earn more than £9 a week. The range of graduated
contributions is given in Table 9. Employees whose job provides them with
an occupational pension of at least ^3'48 a year for each year of service
(^2-90 for women) may be ‘contracted out’ of the graduated pension scheme.
Contracted out employees pay graduated contributions at the rate of half
per cent of that part of their weekly pay lying between £9 and £18 and 31 per

The scheme provides payments to contributors in the event of unemploy¬
ment (if normally working for an employer), sickness (if normally working
for an employer or self-employed), and confinement and the weeks immedi¬
ately before and after (for women normally working for an employer or self-
employed and paying national insurance contributions at the full rate).
Retirement pensions are paid to people who have reached 65 (60 for women)
if they have retired from regular work and from the age of 70 (65 for women)
even if they continue to work; widows receive benefit in the first 26 weeks

Amounts
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
after bereavement and subsequently while they have young children or if they
have reached the age of 50 (40 from April 1971) when widowed or when their
children have grown up; and there are two kinds of allowance in respect of
orphan children where a widow’s pension is not payable. The scheme also
provides lump-sum cash grants for two expensive contingencies—the birth
of a child and a death.
For most of the benefits there are two contribution conditions. First, before
benefit can be paid at all, a minimum number of contributions must actually
have been paid since entry into insurance; secondly, the full rate of benefit
cannot be paid unless a specified number of contributions have been paid or
credited over a specified period. There are special rules to help a widow who
does not become entitled to a widow’s pension at widowhood or when her
children have grown up, to qualify for sickness or unemployment benefit in
the period before she can have established or re-established herself in insur¬
ance through her own contributions; there are also provisions to help a
divorced woman who was not paying contributions during her marriage.
The basic amount of the majority of flat-rate benefits is £5 a week which
may be reduced if insufficient contributions have been paid, but is not
affected by other unearned income or the previous level of earnings. Earnings
received while the benefit is in payment, however, may cause its reduction or
withdrawal: unemployment benefit cannot be paid to a person earning more
than a specified amount from a subsidiary occupation; retirement pensioners
under the age of 70 (65 for women) have their pensions reduced in step with
earnings over certain specified amounts; sickness benefit, though not affected
by continued payment of wages during illness, is not normally payable to a
person doing any actual work. Exceptions to the basic flat rate are the higher
rate of £7 a week payable to widows during the first 26 weeks after bereave¬
ment and the increased retirement pension earned by someone who has
continued at work and paid contributions beyond minimum pension age;
and the lower rate of ^3-50 a week unemployment or sickness benefit payable
to married women who pay contributions and the rates for widows below 50
which reduce on a scale to ^1-5 for a woman aged 40 at the date of entitle¬
ment. The standard rate of retirement pension for a woman on her husband’s
insurance is ^3’10 a week.
Standard increases of flat-rate benefit are payable for dependants at the
rate of ^3-10 for an adult (generally a wife), £i*55 for the first or only child
under the family allowances age limits; £0-65 for the second child and ^0-55
for each other child over and above any family allowances payable (see
p. 125). The sum payable to a widow for her children is j£2’45 for each child
inclusive of family allowances.
A guardian’s allowance of 5^2-45 a week is payable to a person who has in
his or her family a child who has lost both parents, one of whom was insured
under the National Insurance Acts. The allowance can sometimes be paid
on the death of one parent. For certain fatherless children there is a child’s
special allowance also of £2’45 a week inclusive of family allowances; this is
payable to a woman whose marriage has been dissolved or annulled and who
has not remarried, if her former husband dies and she has a child to whose
support he was contributing before he died.
The graduated addition to retirement pension is at the rate of £o'Oz\ a
week for each £7.50 of all graduated contributions paid by a man and for
each £9 of such graduated contributions paid by a woman (with, in each case,
the matching amount of graduated contribution coming from the employer).
The earnings-related supplements to flat-rate unemployment and sickness

benefits are one-third of that part of a person’s average weekly earnings

An earnings-related supplement is paid on top of the widow’s allowance to

The rates of grants are varied: £25 maternity grant is payable for a con¬

adult (less for a child, or for an adult who was within 10 years of minimum
pension age when the scheme started).
In general, national insurance payments are paid as long as the situation
requiring them lasts. However, sickness benefit cannot be paid for more than
a year if fewer than 156 contributions have been paid (possible in three years
for a contributor continuously at work) and unemployment benefit is payable
for a maximum of one year. The supplement to unemployment and sickness
benefit is paid for a maximum of six months starting from the thirteenth day
of unemployment or incapacity for work. Maternity allowance begins 11 weeks
before the expected week of confinement and ends after the sixth week
following the expected week or the actual confinement if this is later.
Similarly, a widowed mother’s allowance at the full rate ceases when her
children are no longer dependent on her, though a mother can continue to
receive £5 a week for herself while she has living with her a son or daughter
under 19. The widow’s pension payable to the childless widow, provided she
is over 50 (40 from April 1971) and had been married at least three years
when her husband died (this ‘three year rule’ is to be discontinued from
April 1971), or the similar pension normally paid to the widowed mother
who has reached 50 (40 from April 1971) when her v/idowed mother’s allow¬
ance ends, continues until she has reached minimum pension age and retired,
or at most till the age of 65. If she has satisfied the conditions she then
becomes entitled to a retirement pension.
The industrial injuries insurance scheme, which, in July 1948, replaced the
workmen’s compensation scheme (first introduced by the Workmen’s
Compensation Act of 1897), provides benefits for personal injuries caused by
accidents arising out of, and in the course of, employment, and for prescribed
diseases due to the nature of employment. It covers practically everyone in
class 1 of the national insurance scheme and certain others. Like the national
insurance scheme, the industrial injuries scheme is financed partly from
contributions (see Table 9) and partly from taxation. The legal basis of the
scheme is the National Insurance (Industrial Injuries) Act 1965 which
consolidated the 1946 Act and subsequent legislation. Similar cover against
industrial injuries and diseases is provided by Northern Ireland’s legislation.
Injury benefit for an adult is £7*75 a week plus ^3‘io for an adult dependant,
£1-55 for the first or only child under the family allowances age limits, ^0-65
for the second child and ^0-55 for each other child in addition to any family
allowance payable. It is paid when the insured person is incapable of work as
a result of an industrial accident or prescribed disease, and payment can

continue for a maximum of 26 weeks beginning on the date of the accident or
development of the disease. A person entitled to sickness benefit who draws
injury benefit instead, also receives any earnings-related supplement (see
p. 127) to which he is entitled.
Disablement benefit may be paid (but not at the same time as injury benefit)
when, as the result of industrial accident or prescribed disease, there is a loss
of physical or mental faculty. The amount depends on the extent of the
disablement as assessed by a medical board; it varies from X^‘4° f°r 100 Per
cent disablement to ^1*70 a week for 20 per cent disablement, but for
disablement of less than 20 per cent a gratuity of up to £55° is normally paid.
In certain circumstances disablement benefit may be supplemented as
follows: unemployability supplement, at the weekly rate of ^5; constant
attendance allowance of up to weekly normally, or a special rate of
j£6-6o a week in exceptionally severe cases; an allowance of £3 a week
for a person entitled to constant attendance allowance at more than the
normal maximum rate whose need for an allowance at such a rate is likely
to be permanent; a special hardship allowance of up to £3-35 for a person
who is unfit to return to his regular job or work of an equivalent standard;
and hospital treatment allowances which raise the benefit to that for a 100
per cent assessment during hospital treatment for the industrial disability.
Increases of benefit for dependants are payable with unemployability sup¬
plement and hospital treatment allowance.
If the accident or disease results in the insured person’s death, death benefit
may be paid to the dependants.
For a widow a pension of ^7 a week is payable for the first 26 weeks of
widowhood. In addition she receives any earnings-related supplement (see
p. 129) that would have been paid had she claimed widow’s allowance under
the main national insurance scheme. Thereafter, the widow can receive a
pension of £5-55 a week if she was aged 50 at the date of her husband’s death,
or has dependent children or other special needs; otherwise she receives
£1-50 a week. If she had been living apart from her husband, the pension is
limited to the weekly rate of maintenance he was paying, if less than the rate
otherwise appropriate.
In addition, allowances are paid for children under the family allowances
age limits. For widows, these allowances together with any family allowance
payable amount to ^2*45 a week for each child. For other beneficiaries, the
rate is ^1*55 each.
Certain other dependants, such as parents and other relatives, may be
entitled to pensions (of up to £1 a week), allowances or gratuities.
The Ministry of Social Security Act 1966 provided for a scheme of supple¬
mentary benefits to replace the system which has been administered by the
former National Assistance Board since 1948. The Act established within the
then Ministry of Social Security a Supplementary Benefits Commission re¬
sponsible for guiding the scheme and for determining awards of benefit.
Parallel legislation in Northern Ireland made similar provision.
Every person in Great Britain aged 16 or over who is not in full-time work,
attending school or involved in a trade dispute and whose resources are
insufficient to meet his requirements is entitled to a supplementary benefit.
The benefit takes the form of a supplementary pension for those over the
statutory retirement age, and of a supplementary allowance for others. The
benefit is the amount by which a person’s requirements exceed his available
WAR PENSIONS
AND RELATED
SERVICES
SOCIAL WELFARE 131
resources, both being defined by rules laid down by the Act. The calculation
of requirements is based on different amounts for single people and family
groups (for blind people there are special higher amounts) with, in each case,
an addition for rent. For the old and most other long-term cases a special
addition is made. Available resources include certain income and capital; the
main national insurance and industrial injury benefits, family allowances and
maintenance payments from a husband or the father of the claimant’s children
are taken into account in full but some part of all other resources is dis¬
regarded. There is a right of appeal against the decision of the Commission.
The payment of a supplementary allowance in the case of an able-bodied
person of working age may be conditional on registering at an employment
exchange of the Department of Employment and Productivity and in the case
of fit people under the age of 45 may be limited to four weeks in areas where
there is plenty of work available. The allowance is then paid at the exchange;
otherwise it is paid weekly through a post office.
The Supplementary Benefits Commission also has a duty to influence
people without a settled way of living to lead a more normal life. The Com¬
mission provides temporary accommodation for them in 18 reception centres,
four of which are administered by local authorities on behalf of the Com¬
mission. For men who have been unemployed for long periods and who are
receiving supplementary allowances or are using reception centres, it runs 13
re-establishment centres, four of which have residential accommodation where
they are given help to fit them again for work.
Pensions and allowances for people disabled or bereaved through war or
service in the Forces since the second world war are paid under Royal
Warrants and other instruments administered by the Department of Health
and Social Security.
The current basic pension for 100 per cent disablement for a private soldier
is ^8-40 a week, but the amount varies according to rank and the degree of
disablement. The latter is assessed by comparing the condition of the person
disabled by service with that of a normal healthy person of the same age and
sex. Allowances for a wife and children are paid in addition to the basic
pension. There is a wide range of supplementary allowances, the main ones
being for unemployability (^5-45 a week), constant attendance (up to £3-30
and, exceptionally, £6-6o a week), comforts (£0-63 or /i-25 a week), and
lowered standard of occupation (up to £3 *3 5 a week). An additional allowance
of £2 a week is payable to war pensioners who are receiving constant atten¬
dance allowance at a rate above the normal maximum. An age allowance
(between ^0-38 and £1 a. week) is payable to disablement pensioners who are
aged 65 or over and whose assessment is 40 per cent or more.
Both the basic disablement pension and the supplementary allowances are
free of income tax, and children’s allowances are paid in addition to any
allowances payable under the Family Allowances Acts.
Pensions are also paid to war widows and war orphans. The standard rate
of pension for widows of private soldiers is £6-50 a week, with additional
allowances for their children (a maximum of £2*65), and, in certain cases,
an allowance for rent (up to £2-50 a week). There is an additional allowance
of £075 a week for widows aged 70 or over. Parents or other relatives who
were dependent on a person whose death resulted from service in the Forces
may receive pensions if they are in financial need.
The Department of Health and Social Security maintains a welfare service
for war pensioners and war orphans which is available to help any who
132
PUBLIC HEALTH
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
require advice and assistance. War pensioners have priority for treatment of
their war disablements in National Health Service hospitals subject only to
needs of emergency and other urgent cases.
Many voluntary associations and ex-Service organisations give financial aid
and personal service to disabled ex-Service men and women and their families.
The Department’s welfare officers work in close co-operation with these
voluntary bodies and with the specialist government welfare agencies.
HEALTH
The concern of the State with the nation’s health is chiefly a development of
the years since the passing of the Public Health Act of 1848. The second half
of the nineteenth century was notable for the growth of the environmental
or public health services, such as provision of pure water, sewerage, disposal
of refuse and cleaning of streets, and the first half of the twentieth century
for the development of publicly provided personal health services, as distinct
from environmental services, culminating in the introduction in 1948 of a
comprehensive National Health Service available to every resident. Scientific
discoveries of importance to medicine and health, including the development
of new drugs, and the improved services of the last 60 years, particularly in
maternity and child welfare, school health services and school meals, are
reflected in declining mortality rates (see p. 9) and improved physique. The
infant mortality rate has more than halved since the National Health Service
was inaugurated; this and the maternal death rate are among the lowest in the
world. The health of children has steadily improved and emphasis is now
placed on prevention or early detection of disease or disability. Deaths from
such diseases as tuberculosis, poliomyelitis and diphtheria have fallen so
markedly that they are no longer major health problems. Diseases now in the
forefront of research programmes include cancer and diseases of the central
nervous system, such as muscular dystrophy. Efforts are also being made to
combat some of the most prevalent diseases, which include, besides the
common cold and influenza, bronchitis, rheumatism and arthritis, and heart
diseases.
The Public Health Acts of 1936 and 1961 and the Health Services and
Public Health Act 1968 constitute the present basic public health code in
England and Wales. Local authorities (under the general direction of the
Department of Health and Social Security or the Welsh Office and the
Ministry of Housing and Local Government) have extensive powers for
making and administering by-laws on matters of public health. The local
authorities chiefly concerned are the councils of county and non-county
boroughs, London boroughs and the City of London, urban and rural district
councils and, to a limited extent, parish councils.
Public health services in Scotland and in Northern Ireland have developed
on much the same lines as in England and Wales, although they are based on
separate Acts and there is a different allocation of services between the various
types of local authority (working under the direction of the Scottish Home and
Health Department and the Northern Ireland Ministry of Health and Social
Services). The Public Health (Scotland) Acts 1897-1945 and the Burgh
Police (Scotland) Act 1892 as amended by later statutes constitute the basic
legislation for Scotland. The local authorities concerned are the councils
of counties and burghs. In Northern Ireland the councils of county and

THE NATIONAL

SOCIAL WELFARE 133
non-county boroughs and urban and rural districts are mainly responsible
for administering the Public Health Acts (Northern Ireland) 1878-1966.
The Medical Officers of Health of local authorities are responsible for
investigating outbreaks of infectious diseases and for disinfection and other
preventive measures.
Port health authorities supervise health control at seaports and airports, the
primary object of which is to prevent the introduction of infectious disease
into the country. This health control is undertaken by health authorities using
the services of medical officers, public health inspectors, rodent inspectors
and others.
The purity, hygiene and description of food are controlled by the Food and
Drugs Act 1955 in England and Wales, by the Food and Drugs (Scotland) Act
1956 in Scotland and by the Food and Drugs Act (Northern Ireland) 1958
in Northern Ireland.
In England and Wales the question of the composition, adulteration and
description of food are the concern of food and drugs authorities (county,
county borough, London borough and City of London councils and, generally,
the larger borough and urban district councils) and questions of soundness,
purity and hygiene are the concern of all local authorities, except parish
councils. The Department of Health and Social Security and the Ministry of
Agriculture, Fisheries and Food are the central departments responsible for
giving advice and making regulations. Places where food for sale for human
consumption is prepared, sold or stored must conform to certain hygienic
standards. Authorised officers of the councils may take for analysis or for
bacteriological or other examination samples of any food for sale for human
consumption. Special regulations are in force for certain foods such as milk,
meat and ice-cream.
In Scotland the local authorities chiefly concerned are the councils of
counties and large burghs.
In Northern Ireland administration is in the hands of the county and
county borough health authorities, the central department being the Ministry
of Health and Social Services.
Local authorities are also responsible for the public health aspects of water
supply, sewerage and drainage; street paving and housing; and the abatement
of noise nuisance. They have power to establish smoke-controlled areas to
secure cleaner air, and to arrange with statutory water undertakings for the
addition of fluoride to water supplies to reduce dental decay.
The Acts setting up the National Health Service—the National Health
Service Act 1946, the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1947 and the
Health Services Act (Northern Ireland) 1948—came into force simultaneously
on 5th July 1948.
The object of the National Health Service Act 1946 was ‘to promote the
establishment in England and Wales of a comprehensive health service
designed to secure improvement in the physical and mental health of the
people of England and Wales and the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of
illness, and for that purpose to provide or secure the effective provision of
services’. The service is available to all according to medical need without
regard to any insurance qualification; it was originally free to users but certain
small charges were introduced under subsequent legislation. The removal of

National insurance contributors are required to pay a separate weekly
national health contribution (see Table 9) but contributors and non-contri¬
butors are entitled to the same full range of services. Visitors from other
countries who come to Britain for treatment are expected to pay for it, but
treatment can be given under the emergency provisions of the National
Health Service to any who fall ill during a visit to Britain.
Health Service
Administration
in Great Britain
The services provided by the National Health Service fall into three main
groups1:
1. The hospital and specialist services for which the Secretary of State for
Social Services, the Secretary of State for Wales, or the Secretary of State
for Scotland is directly responsible. These are administered through
20 regional hospital boards and some 450 hospital management com¬
mittees, or, in the case of teaching hospitals in England and Wales,
boards of governors. The three special psychiatric hospitals in England
for people with criminal propensities are directly administered by the
Secretary of State for Social Services and the similar hospitals in Scotland
by the Secretary of State for Scotland.
1 Proposals to integrate the threefold structure of the National Health Service in
England and Wales under a network of area health authorities directly responsible to the
Secretary of State for Social Services were published in February 1970. The health
authorities would be responsible for the hospital and specialist services, the family
practitioner services, the school health service, and many of the health services provided
by local authorities. Local authorities would retain their responsibility for public health
matters and social work services for families, children, the elderly, the physically handi¬
capped and the mentally disordered. Separate proposals have been published for Wales,
Scotland and Northern Ireland.
