157
assumed by local education authorities. Most of it is on a part-time basis,
mainly in evening institutes (day schools used by adults in the evening) which
have a total of well over a million students, and also in colleges of further
education, schools of art, adult education centres, community centres, literary
institutes and youth clubs. There are about 30 short-term residential colleges
or centres in Great Britain maintained or aided by local education authorities,
providing courses varying in length between a weekend and a fortnight. Many
of the courses are practical, but there are widespread opportunities for
academic study.
The Village Colleges pioneered in Cambridgeshire and variously adapted in
Cumberland, Monmouthshire, Leicestershire, Peterborough and Somerset
are a local education authority development mainly in rural areas. The
colleges are secondary schools planned also as cultural community centres,
providing educational, social and cultural opportunities for adults in the areas
served. Community centres in general have a more social character and,
though aided by the local education authorities, are usually managed by
voluntary community associations many of which are affiliated to the National
Federation of Community Associations. The training of community centre
wardens is linked with that of youth leaders (see p. 167).
Seven residential colleges (six in England and Wales, one in Scotland)
provide courses of one or two years, some of which lead to a diploma. The
colleges vary in character, although they all aim at providing a liberal educa¬
tion and do not apply academic entry tests.
In general, courses at the highest levels in liberal studies are provided by
the extra-mural departments of the universities, many of which have full-time
staff appointed for this purpose and can call on the services of other members
of the university staff; and by the Workers’ Educational Association, which
also employs organising tutors and works closely with the university extra¬
mural departments. In 1969 over 272,000 students in Britain attended such
courses. Similar work is also promoted in some of the centres maintained by
local education authorities.
The National Institute of Adult Education provides in London a centre of
information, research and publication for adult education, as well as a channel
of co-operation and consultation for the many organisations in England and
Wales which are interested in this subject. It is mainly financed by contri¬
butions from local education authorities and assisted by a grant from the
Department of Education and Science. The Scottish Institute of Adult
Education is the corresponding body in Scotland.
In Northern Ireland the extra-mural department of the Queen’s University
of Belfast organises and staffs adult education classes which are supplemented
by classes organised by various non-official bodies. The Workers’ Educational
Association is responsible for classes at other than university level and
receives grants from the Ministry of Education.
TEACHERS AND Teachers are appointed by local education authorities or school governing
TEACHING bodies or managers. In 1969 there were about 380,800 full-time and 47,800
part-time (equivalent to 22,490 full-time) teachers in publicly maintained
primary and secondary schools in Britain, an average of one teacher to 22‘6
pupils. The increase in teachers is more than keeping pace with the rise in
the school population so that there continues to be improvement in the ratio
of teachers to pupils; greater numbers are entering the colleges of education
(see p. 161), more university graduates are turning to teaching, and many
married women, formerly teachers, are returning to the profession. Many
158 BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
more are needed if the Government’s aim of eliminating all classes over 30 is
to be achieved. In 1969 there were about 53,500 full-time teachers in grant-
aided establishments of further education in Britain, and many more part-time
teachers. Most teachers in technical colleges have had some industrial and
professional experience.
There are national salary scales for teachers in schools and other educational
institutions maintained from public funds in England and Wales, in Scotland,
and in Northern Ireland.
Teaching Aids Radio broadcasts to schools and colleges of further education are well
and Educational established. In 1969-70 the School Broadcasting Department of the BBC sent
Techniques out about 70 different radio series, some of which were repeated within each
week to make it easier for the schools to arrange their listening times. These
programmes were used by about 31,000 schools in Britain. Television reached
some 21,000 schools and the British Broadcasting Corporation and the
Independent Television Authority between them provided some 21 hours of
educational programmes a week during term time.
Radio provides a great variety of educational programmes for adults, both
vocational and non-vocational; most of them are grouped in the ‘Study
Session’ hourly programmes on five nights a week. Television programmes
for similar audiences have grown fast; they are mostly shown on Saturday
and Sunday mornings and in the evening during the week. There have also
been a number of experimental projects sponsored between the BBC, some of
the independent television companies, universities, local education authorities
and a voluntary body, the National Extension College. (For the Open
University see p. 159).
There has been a rapid development in the use of programmed learning and
its integrated use with other media. Language laboratories (using tape
recorders in individual booths) are being used at all levels of the educational
system. Most universities in Britain use closed circuit television in one or
more of their departments; it is also used increasingly in medical schools,
colleges of education, technical colleges and schools; and a system being
established in central London to link some 1,300 educational establishments is
thought likely to be the world’s biggest closed-circuit network.
Schools and colleges co-ordinate different methods of audio-visual pre¬
sentation, i ncluding radio, television, films, colour slides, wall charts, maps,
models and tape recordings. For example, the BBC’s ‘Radiovision’ pro¬
grammes for schools use coloured film strips synchronised with sound
programmes. The National Council for Educational Technology and the
Educational Foundation for Visual Aids advise all bodies connected with
education and with training in industry and in the Services on the availability
and use of audio-visual aids and other media.
HIGHER The system of higher education includes universities, colleges of education
EDUCATION an(j advanced courses at various colleges in the further education system.
(Advanced courses are dealt with on p. 161 and higher education in Northern
Ireland on p. 162.) The expansion of higher education has been accelerated by
the report of the Committee on Higher Education under Lord Robbins’s
chairmanship (published in 1963, see Bibliography, p. 477), which suggested
that by 1973-74 there should be 390,000 places in higher education in Great
Britain, of which 218,000 should be in university institutions. These aims
have already been achieved—there were 437,000 students pursuing higher
education courses in 1969-70, of which 219,000 were in the universities.

Universities
University Finance
159
There are 44 universities (not counting the Open University) in Britain,
compared with 17 in 1945. Although the Government is responsible for
providing about 80 per cent of universities’ income it does not control their
work or teaching nor does it have direct dealings with the universities. The
grants are distributed by the University Grants Committee, a body appointed
by the Secretary of State to advise him on state aid to the universities; its
members are drawn from the academic and business worlds. Universities as
such are not represented on it.
The English universities are: Aston1 (Birmingham), Bath,1 Birmingham,
Bradford,1 Bristol, Brunei1 (London), Cambridge, City1 (London), Durham,
East Anglia,1 Essex,1 Exeter, Hull, Keele, Kent at Canterbury,1 Lancaster,1
Leeds, Leicester, Liverpool, London, Loughborough,1 Manchester, Newcastle
upon Tyne, Nottingham, Oxford, Reading, Salford,1 Sheffield, Southampton,
Surrey,1 Sussex,1 Warwick1 and York.1 The federated University of Wales
includes four university colleges, the Welsh National School of Medicine,
the University of Wales Institute of Science and Technology and St. David’s
College, Lampeter. The Scottish universities are: Aberdeen, Dundee,1
Edinburgh, Glasgow, Heriot-Watt1 (Edinburgh), St. Andrews, Stirling,1
and Strathclyde1 (Glasgow). In Northern Ireland there is Queen’s University,
Belfast, and the New University of Ulster1 in Coleraine (see p. 162).
The Universities of Oxford and Cambridge date from the twelfth and
thirteenth centuries and the Scottish Universities of St. Andrews, Glasgow,
Aberdeen and Edinburgh from the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. All the
other universities were founded in the nineteenth or twentieth centuries.
There are five other institutions where the work is of university standard:
University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology; the two post¬
graduate business schools which are supported jointly by industry and the
Government—the Manchester Business School and the London Graduate
School of Business Studies, associated with the London School of Economics
and the Imperial College of Science and Technology; Cranfield Institute of
Technology for mainly postgraduate work in aeronautics and other subjects;
and the Royal College of Art.
The Government has established the Open University, which received its
charter in 1969, to provide degree and other courses, using a combination of
television and correspondence courses together with a network of viewing and
listening centres. No formal academic qualifications are required to register
for these courses, but the standards of its degrees (to be awarded on a system
of credits for each course completed) will be the same as those of other
universities. The university is financed by fees and a grant direct from the
Department of Education and Science. Student enrolments began in the
autumn of 1970 and courses (based on the calendar year) will begin in
January 1971.
In spite of the large sums of public money spent on universities they have
remained autonomous institutions, due largely to the existence of the
University Grants Committee. The Committee acts as a link between the
Government from which it receives a block grant and the universities to
which it allocates this grant. In this way the Government contributes over
70 per cent towards the current income of universities and about 90 per cent
towards their capital programmes for building work, purchasing sites and
properties, professional fees and furniture and equipment. Further sums are
raised by the universities themselves.

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In Great Britain the recurrent grants for the academic year 1970-71 are
provisionally estimated at some £182 million, over three times the amount for
1960-61. Capital grants paid out during 1970-71 are expected to be about
^59 million, approaching three times the 1960-61 figure. In 1945 the total
public expenditure, capital and current, on universities was £4 million. The
Comptroller and Auditor General (see p. 361) has access to the books and
records of the University Grants Committee and the universities to check that
the funds entrusted to the universities are efficiently administered. He cannot
question policy decisions or decisions reached on academic grounds.
Courses in arts and science are offered by most universities. Imperial College,
London, University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, the
University of Strathclyde and some of the newer universities concentrate on
technology although they may also offer a number of courses in social studies,
modern languages and other non-technological subjects. About 44-2 per cent
of full-time university students in Great Britain are taking arts or social studies
courses and 42 per cent science and technology: more than 10 per cent are
studying medicine, dentistry and health, and the remainder agriculture,
forestry, veterinary science, architecture and town and country planning.
University degree courses generally extend over three or four years, though
in medicine, dentistry and veterinary science five or six years are required.
The first degree of Bachelor (Master for Arts, in the older Scottish univer¬
sities) is awarded on the completion of such a course, depending on satisfactory
examination results. Further study or research is required at the modern
universities for the degree of Master and by all universities for that of Doctor.
Actual degree titles vary according to the practice of each university. Diplomas
and certificates are awarded after shorter courses in some subjects. A uniform
standard of degree throughout the country is ensured by having external
examiners on all examining boards. In the last decade there has been a
tendency for degree courses to become more broadly based in subject matter,
particularly in the new universities.
University teaching combines lectures, practical classes (in scientific
subjects) and small group teaching in either seminars or tutorials, the last
being a traditional feature of the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge.
Most members of the academic staffs devote time to research and at all
universities there are postgraduate students engaged in research.
Admission to the universities is by examination and selection; there is no
religious test and no colour bar. Women are admitted on equal terms with
men for most subjects, but at Cambridge their numbers may be limited by
ordinance. The general proportion of men to women students is nearly three
to one; at Oxford it is nearly five to one, and at Cambridge eight to one.
A third of all full-time university students in Britain are living in colleges and
halls of residence, slightly under a half are in lodgings, and the remainder live
at home.
Despite recent expansion programmes, applications for places at universities
for arts studies still exceed the number available. Prospective candidates for
nearly all the universities apply for places through the Universities Central
Council on Admissions. The only students to apply directly are applicants to
the Open University and Scottish candidates for the universities of Glasgow,
Aberdeen, Strathclyde and Dundee.
At the beginning of the academic year 1969-70 there were over 219,000
full-time university students in Great Britain. About 38,000 were post¬
graduate. There were also in 1969-70 some 24,050 part-time students, more
Staff
Colleges of
Education
Advanced
Courses in
Further
Education
EDUCATION l6l
than 98 per cent of whom were working for university-level qualifications. A
further 19,560 were admitted to London University’s external first degree
examinations, the main external degree available in Britain.
In 1968-69 there were about 26,070 full-time university teachers in Great
Britain; about 11*5 per cent of them were professors. The ratio of staff to
students was about one to eight, one of the most favourable in the world.
Teachers in maintained schools must hold qualifications approved by the
education departments. In England and Wales the majority qualify by under¬
taking a three-year course at a college of education. Some college students
obtain a degree—Bachelor of Education (B.Ed.)—and a professional qualifica¬
tion by means of a four-year course. For well-qualified older students there
are special shortened courses. Compulsory professional training for people
with degrees and certain other specialist qualifications, hitherto qualified by
virtue of their qualifications, is gradually being introduced. A one-year
training course is already compulsory for those who have obtained such
qualifications since 1st January 1970 and wish to teach in primary schools,
and the same will be required in order to teach in secondary schools for those
who acquire such qualifications after 1st January 1974. In Scotland all teachers
in secondary schools must be graduates (or have equivalent qualifications) and
must have taken a course of teacher training but primary school teachers may
qualify by taking a three-year course at a college of education. The General
Teaching Council has almost complete powers over the profession excluding
salary matters but including the function of maintaining a register of qualified
teachers. Proposals for a similar body for England and Wales is under
consideration.
In England and Wales there are 160 colleges of education 16 of which are
for day students only, 6 departments of education in technical colleges and
polytechnics, 28 university departments of education, 4 colleges for training
teachers for technical institutions and 13 art teacher training centres. In
1969-70 there were about 110,000 students in colleges and departments of
education outside universities (including over 7,500 in day colleges), about
5,900 in university departments of education, and nearly 2,150 in colleges of
education (technical) and art teacher training centres. The total of 118,050
students is nearly three times that for 1960-61. In Scotland there are 10
colleges of education; the number of students in training in 1969-70 was over
12,030 with a proposed increase to over 14,000 in 1970-71. Thus the Robbins
report target of 122,000 teacher training places in Great Britain by 1973-74
has been achieved already.
The education departments, universities, local education authorities and
other bodies provide a variety of short in-service training courses for practising
teachers.
In 1969-70 over 218,000 students in Great Britain were taking advanced
courses other than in universities and colleges of education in a wide variety
of subjects including architecture, art and design (see p. 155), catering,
engineering, natural sciences and business studies. An increasing proportion
of the students were taking courses leading to the awards of the Council for
National Academic Awards. The Council has power to award degrees and
other academic qualifications, comparable in standard with those granted by
universities, to students who successfully complete approved courses of
study in establishments which do not have the power to award their own
162
Awards
Northern

BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
degrees. In 1969-70 there were 271 courses being followed by about 20,116
students in 47 colleges. These courses were mainly in science and technology
but included the arts, social studies, business studies and law, and some
subjects in which there are few or no courses offered in universities.
The Government is concentrating higher education provision outside
universities and colleges of education within 30 major national institutions
being renamed ‘polytechnics’ and formed from some 60 existing colleges.
They will have, ultimately, at least 2,000 full-time students each and will be
comprehensive institutions providing all types of courses (full-time, sandwich
and part-time) at all levels of higher education. By September 1970 28
polytechnics had been designated.
Management studies are provided by universities, polytechnics and other
further education colleges by individual companies and by trade and industrial
federations. (For the two postgraduate business schools, see p. 159.) Certain
independent colleges specialise in management training. Many universities
have introduced management studies into the curriculum and courses for the
postgraduate Diploma in Management Studies are run by some technical
colleges. In Scotland courses leading to the Certificate of Business Adminis¬
tration are provided for students in junior supervisory positions.
Awards to enable students to undertake higher education are made under one
of the most generous grant systems in the world. It is national policy that no
boy or girl should be prevented by lack of means from taking an advanced
course at a university or elsewhere. As a result, over 90 per cent of students in
higher education in Great Britain are aided from private or public funds.
A UNESCO survey has indicated that university students in Britain come
from a wider social background than those in any other western European
country.
In England, Wales and Scotland most adequately qualified British students
can obtain awards from public funds in order to attend full-time at a university,
college of education or major further education establishment. In England and
Wales local education authorities provide awards. In Scotland students’
allowances for advanced courses are granted by the Scottish Education
Department. The amount of these awards depends upon the income of the
student and his parents. Grants for postgraduate study are offered annually
by the Department of Education and Science, the Research Councils and the
Scottish Education Department.
Two institutions provide university education in Northern Ireland—Queen’s
University of Belfast and the New University of Ulster, Coleraine, which
will incorporate Magee University College, Londonderry. The New University
consists of four schools (biological studies, social and economic studies,
physical sciences and humanities) and an education centre with the status of a
school. Technological studies are concentrated at Queen’s University, Belfast.
The report of the committee on higher education published in 1965 (the
Lockwood Report, see Bibliography, p. 477), estimated that the number of
full-time university places required in Northern Ireland by 1980 would be
between 12,000 and 13,000. About 7,000 will be in Queen’s University and the
remainder in the New University. In 1969-70 there were 6,513 students at
Queen’s University, 902 at the New University and 165 at Magee University
College. Between 1959 and 1969 over j£i8*i million was spent on university
building projects and further expansion is planned. Recurrent expenditure
in 1969-70 was estimated at nearly ^4-1 million. Government grants are made

by the Ministry of Education which usually first seeks the advice of the

Teacher training takes place in the university departments of education
and six training colleges, with a total of 2,662 students in 1969-70. In Belfast
there are three general colleges of education which provide three-year
certificate courses and four-year degree courses (awarded by Queen’s
University). In addition, they provide one-year courses for university
graduates and others, including serving teachers. The other three colleges
provide more specialised teacher training courses. A new college, the Ulster
College, is being set up in which much of the higher education provided
outside the universities and the colleges of education will be concentrated.
University and further education scholarships are awarded by local authorities
and postgraduate awards and teacher training scholarships by the Ministry of
Education, the conditions of award being the same as those for Great Britain.
Research into the theory and practice of education and the organisation of
educational services is supported financially by the educational departments,
local education authorities, philanthropic organisations, universities and
teachers’ associations. The Social Science Research Council is an additional
channel for government support.
The great proportion of educational research is done in the universities,
particularly within departments or institutes of education and departments
concerned with sociology, psychology, statistics and problems of physical and
mental handicap. Outside universities, the major research institute is the
National Foundation for Educational Research, an autonomous body which
derives its income mainly from corporate members, including local education
authorities, teachers’ organisations and universities and from an annual grant
from the Department of Education and Science. There are also the Scottish
Council for Research in Education and the Northern Ireland Council of
Educational Research. The Schools Council sponsors a number of projects in
England and Wales.
There is no single central organisation for the co-ordination of educational
research, but the central departments, by their allocation of funds for projects,
exercise some influence on the direction of research effort. At the end of
March 1970 the Department of Education and Science had a total commit¬
ment of about £830,000 spread over 103 projects. Expenditure during 1969-70
exceeded £620,000. The Scottish Education Department’s grant to the
Scottish Council and other research bodies totalled about £60,000.
Among philanthropic organisations that provide generously for research are
the Nuffield Foundation and Ford Foundation, the Gulbenkian Trust, the
Leverhulme Trust, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Carnegie United King¬
dom Trust, the Wolfson Foundation and the Foundation for Management
Education.
There are many opportunities for overseas students to study in Britain and
for British students to study abroad and British teachers are encouraged to
serve overseas for a period.
Students come to Britain from countries throughout the world to study at
universities or other educational institutions or for professional training. In
the academic year 1968-69 there were 69,819 overseas students in Britain,
of whom about 15,975 were at universities, another 13,798 at technical
colleges and the remainder learning English or training as teachers, doctors
164
BRITAIN 197U AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
and nurses, for the law, banking and accountancy, or in industry. About 60
per cent of all overseas students were from the Commonwealth.
A wide range of public and private fellowships and scholarships for advanced
study in Britain are awarded annually to students and research workers from
other countries. Under the Commonwealth Scholarship and Fellowship Plan,
the Governments of certain Commonwealth countries have made awards
available at their own institutions of higher education to men and women from
other Commonwealth countries. At the beginning of the academic year
1969-70, 600 scholarships and fellowships (including medical awards) were
held in Britain. In addition the Commonwealth Bursary Scheme achieved
a total of 550 teachers and others training in Britain. Examples of smaller
government schemes are the Athlone Fellowship Scheme, under which about
40 fellowships a year are awarded to Canadian engineering graduates for up to
two years’ further study, training and research in institutions or industries in
Britain, and the Indian Centres of Advanced Study Scheme in which, as part
of a plan for establishing links between British and Indian universities,
academic staff from 12 Indian universities spend a period with British
universities.
About 500 British Council1 scholarships, tenable usually for one year in
Britain, are offered annually to graduates of overseas universities. Twenty-four
Marshall Scholarships for two years’ study at any university in Britain are
offered annually by the British Government to graduates from the United
States of America and over 60 Rhodes Scholarships are awarded annually to
Commonwealth and United States graduates for two years of study at the
University of Oxford. A further two Rhodes scholarships are awarded to
graduates from the Federal Republic of Germany. Other universities and
colleges themselves offer many scholarships for which graduate students of
any nationality are eligible.2
Fellowships and training awards for study in British institutions are avail¬
able under the Central Treaty Organisation, the Colombo Plan, the Special
Commonwealth African Assistance Plan and British technical assistance
programmes for many other countries. Large numbers of awards for study or
training in Britain are also made under the United Nations Programmes of
Technical Assistance and by the United Nations specialised agencies such as
UNESCO, FAO and WHO.
The Commonwealth Education Liaison Committee supplements normal

The fourth Commonwealth Education Conference was held in Lagos in 1968.
The national representatives in London (Office of the High Commissioner or

about British life in town and country. In term time there are visits to various

Among many voluntary organisations which offer a welcome to overseas

which is administered by the British Council. By the beginning of 1970

Under the Commonwealth Scholarship and Fellowship Plan, a number of
scholarships are made available annually to United Kingdom students by the
Governments of other Commonwealth countries for study in their universities,
colleges and other institutions of higher learning. In 1969-70, 27 awards were
accepted by United Kingdom students in seven Commonwealth countries. In
addition the Study and Serve Scheme enables British students to undertake
a year’s postgraduate study at universities in the developing countries on
condition that they also work for a period in appropriate employment in the
country concerned.
The United States/United Kingdom Educational Commission (still some¬
times called the Fulbright Commission) offers travel grants for postgraduate
study in the United States. Notable among more recently established scholar¬
ships are the Kennedy scholarships, to enable British students to study at three
American universities, and the Churchill travel scholarships, for men and
women in all walks of life. British students are also offered scholarships at
institutions of higher education in 22 European and 10 non-European countries
outside the Commonwealth.

About 2,020 teachers were recruited in Britain during 1969 for posts in
schools, colleges of education, technical colleges and universities in developing
countries, including about 1,780 for posts in the developing countries of the
Commonwealth; almost all of them are supported by public funds. Steps
taken by the Government to help school teachers to serve for a period overseas
have included the establishment of a National Council for the Supply and
Training of Teachers Overseas and the introduction of special measures to
safeguard their interests both while abroad and on their return home. Recruit¬
ment is carried out by the Ministry of Overseas Development, the British
Council and the voluntary teacher recruiting agencies, such as the Catholic
Overseas Appointments and the Overseas Appointments Bureaux.
There are about 1,000 British university teachers serving overseas, most of
them recruited through the Inter-University Council for Higher Education
Overseas in collaboration, in some cases, with the Association of Common¬
wealth Universities and the British Council. Government encouragement also
includes support for a number of schemes of assistance for overseas univer¬
sities which are administered by the Inter-University Council, including the
scheme for Special Commonwealth Awards, which are made to leading scholars
from British universities who are willing to work for a minimum of two years
in important posts in the universities of developing Commonwealth countries.
Outside the schemes, an increasing number of graduate and qualified
volunteers, also cadet volunteers (school leavers), 1,899 1969-70, are going
overseas for one or two years, a large number to teach. Many of them go with
the support of voluntary bodies (co-ordinated under the British Volunteer
Programme) which receive financial assistance from the Government.
Interchange schemes, under which teachers in Britain exchange posts for
a year with teachers overseas, include one with the United States and another
with Commonwealth countries whereby each year over 100 British teachers
exchange posts with teachers from Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Official
exchange schemes also operate between Britain and several European countries
both for teachers and for temporary assistants’ posts for language specialists.
Britain provides, on request, assistance to the developing countries in several
other ways, including the loan of educational experts for technical and
consultant services and specialist missions, through various educational
organisations and the Ministry of Overseas Development. The Centre for
Educational Development Overseas (CEDO) was established in April 1970
and has taken over the activities of the Centre for Educational Television
Overseas, the Overseas Visual Aids Centre and the Centre for Curriculum
Renewal and Educational Development Overseas. It is intended that CEDO
will become the British centre to which those who are concerned with the
modernisation of education in developing countries will apply for information,
advice and assistance.
YOUTH SERVICES
The object of youth services in Britain is to provide for the leisure-time
activities of young people and to offer them opportunities—complementary to
those of home, formal education and work—for discovering and developing
their personal resources, so that they may be better equipped to be responsible
members of the community. Membership of youth organisations is voluntary
and the facilities are sufficiently varied to appeal to every type of boy and girl.
EDUCATION
State and
Voluntary
Partnership
Training
The Voluntary
Organisations
167
A number of youth organisations have spontaneously developed over the last
century, mainly by voluntary effort. These organisations now work in partner¬
ship with local education authorities and the central government in the Youth
Service. There is no attempt to impose uniformity or to create any national
youth organisation. The status of the Youth Service as an essential part of the
educational system of Great Britain was confirmed by the Education Act 1944
and the Education (Scotland) Act 1945; in Northern Ireland, youth welfare
work is promoted under the Education Act (Northern Ireland) 1947, and the
Youth Welfare, Physical Training and Recreation Act (Northern Ireland)
1962.
The education departments provide grants in aid of the administrative and
training work of some national voluntary youth organisations, towards the
expense of training full-time youth leaders and towards the cost of premises
and equipment of youth clubs provided by voluntary bodies.
Local education authorities co-operate with voluntary organisations in their
areas: most give some financial help and lend premises and equipment
(though the local voluntary organisations still raise most of their day-to-day
running expenses by their own efforts). In recent years more and more
authorities have undertaken the building and running of youth clubs. Almost
all have appointed youth committees on which official and voluntary bodies
are represented, and most employ youth organisers to help in the promotion
and encouragement of youth work.
Ministers are advised on the finance and development of the Youth Service
in Scotland and Northern Ireland by the Standing Consultative Council on
Youth and Community Service and the Youth and Sports Council respec¬
tively. Annual grants to the value of over £600,000 are made towards the
headquarters expenses of the national voluntary youth organisations in Britain
and there are special grants for voluntary projects. The Department of
Education and Science authorised a £5 million building programme for
England and Wales for the period 1970-71, compared with £4*5 million for
1969-70. Local authorities’ contributions to the youth service in England and
Wales amounted to some £12-4 million in 1969-70. In Scotland annual
expenditure on the youth services is estimated at about £460,000.
In England and Wales there is a basic two-year period of training for youth
workers, undertaken in conjunction with the training of community centre
wardens. Courses are provided at colleges of education and further education..
There are at present over 1,800 qualified full-time workers. In addition a
youth work option is provided at more than 30 colleges of education in order
that trainee teachers may have the opportunity of achieving dual qualification.
In Scotland the basic period of training for the youth and community
service has been extended to three years. Courses are offered at two colleges
of education.
The voluntary organisations vary greatly in character since nearly all of them
were formed to serve specific groups of young people; some of them provide
educational and religious activities as well as social and recreational pursuits
for their members, and all of them encourage high ideals of personal conduct
and service to the community.
Twenty-five national voluntary youth organisations, all with memberships
of at least 10,000, are constituent members of the Standing Conference of
National Voluntary Youth Organisations, a consultative body which takes
action only in the name of its member bodies and with their consent. A further
168
BRITAIN I97I: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
32 bodies are associate or observer members. The corresponding body in
Scotland is the Scottish Standing Conference of Voluntary Youth Organisa¬
tions, in Northern Ireland the Standing Conference of Youth Organisations,
and in Wales the Standing Conference for Wales of Voluntary Youth Organisa¬
tions. It is estimated that some 3-5 million young people belong to voluntary
youth organisations in Britain.
Among the youth organisations with a mainly religious origin and purpose
are the Young Men’s Christian Association (YMCA) and Young Women’s
Christian Association (YWCA), with about 88,000 and 30,000 members respec¬
tively; the Boys’ Brigade (172,000), the Church Lads’ Brigade (13,000), the
Girls’ Brigade (98,000), the Girls’ Friendly Society (24,000), the Methodist
Association of Youth Clubs (115,000), the Salvation Army Youth Organisa¬
tions (99,000), the Catholic Young Men’s Society of Great Britain (15,000),
the Catholic Youth Service Council (62,000), the Young Christian Workers
(18,000), and the Association for Jewish Youth (25,000).
The Scouts Association and Girl Guides Association have world-wide
affiliations; they are undenominational and non-political, and were founded
by Lord Baden-Powell in 1908 and 1910 to develop character and good
citizenship in boys and girls. Their total membership in Britain under 21
is about 530,000 scouts and 772,000 guides.
The National Association of Boys’ Clubs, with about 2,000 affiliated clubs
and 170,000 members, and the National Association of Youth Clubs, with
nearly 3,500 affiliated clubs and 282,000 members, are concerned mainly with
the 14 to 20 age group. Each affiliated club has its own rules, but all aim at
giving young people opportunities to develop into mature members of society.
A notable trend in recent years has been the growth in voluntary service by
young people to those in need in the community, such as the elderly and the
sick, the mentally ill and the handicapped. Through organisations such as
International Voluntary Service, Community Service Volunteers, Task Force,
Toe H and others, thousands of young people are doing valuable voluntary
work, both within and outside Britain. The Government has set up the Young
Volunteer Force Foundation which controls a team of 40 young people
available on request to assist local authorities, hospitals and other organisations
in encouraging and organising voluntary service.
The pre-Service organisations for boys (the Combined Cadet Force,
Army Cadet Force and Air Training Corps) combine social, educational and
physical development with training for possible entry into the armed forces;
their combined membership is about 120,000. The Combined Cadet Force
(CCF) contingents are based on schools in which education is continued to the
age of 17 or beyond. Training normally begins at 14 and the boys can choose
whether they will join the Royal Navy, Army or Royal Air Force sections.
The Army Cadet Force and the Air Training Corps are for boys in schools
that do not have CCF contingents or for those who have left school. The Sea
Cadet Corps, although not a pre-Service organisation, helps boys who wish
to make their career at sea; its membership is about 18,000. The Girls’
Venture Corps, with about 8,000 members, has an Air Wing offering aviation
courses.
The National Federation of Young Farmers’ Clubs in England and Wales
has about 38,000 members between 10 and 25 years old, the Scottish Associa¬
tion of Young Farmers’ Clubs has over 6,000 and Northern Ireland Young
Farmer Clubs about 4,000 members: in addition to encouraging interest in
agriculture and appreciation of country life, the clubs provide training in the
arts of citizenship and develop ability to serve the community.

Concerned with

The Welsh League of Youth (Urdd Gobaith Cymru) has a membership of
about 43,000; its aim is the ‘development of Christian citizenship among the
youth of Wales’.
The Youth Hostels Associations in England and Wales, Scotland and
Northern Ireland have a network of hostels for walkers and cyclists, particu¬
larly intended for young people of limited means. They seek to promote
knowledge and love of the countryside, and are closely linked with each other
and with similar organisations in other countries.
Adult organisations with youth sections include the British Red Cross
Society, St. John Ambulance Association and Brigade and the political parties.
King George’s Jubilee Trust was established in 1935 by King George V to
promote the welfare of the younger generation. Since its inauguration it has
disbursed over £2 million to the headquarters of the principal voluntary
youth organisations and to many local projects, particularly those of an
experimental nature.
In 1969 about 140,000 young people between the ages of 14 and 21 took
part in the Duke of Edinburgh’s Award Scheme. This scheme is operated by
local authorities, schools, youth organisations, industrial firms and other
bodies, and is designed as a challenge to young men and women to reach
certain standards of achievement in leisure-time activities. There are three
separate levels of Awards—Gold, Silver and Bronze—each comprising four
sections. Three of the sections, entitled service, pursuits and interests, and
expeditions, are common to boys and girls. For the Silver and Bronze Awards
the fourth section is physical activity for boys, and design for living for girls,
though for the Gold Award boys and girls may choose either option. Some 35
Commonwealth countries, including Canada, Australia and New Zealand,
now operate the scheme.
The Outward Bound Trust maintains six schools in Great Britain, five for
boys and one for girls, training about 6,000 young people between 14 and 20
years of age each year. The training on the 26-day course is designed to
challenge a young person’s powers of determination, self-control and initiative,
and to develop his sense of responsibility.
The aims of the Central Council of Physical Recreation, the Scottish
Council of Physical Recreation and the National Playing Fields Association
bring them into touch with many youth organisations (see Chapter 19),

TOWN AND COUNTRY PLANNING
Britain is one of the most densely populated areas in the world: it is, therefore,
essential to plan land use for a satisfactory national distribution of employment
and population, to undertake a programme of urban renewal, to build new
towns and to preserve the amenities of the countryside.
From 1909 successive Acts of Parliament recognised the principle of the
planned use of land, but because the pattern of development over much of
the country had already hardened into large unplanned urban concentrations
the powers granted to local planning authorities were inadequate.
The period between the two world wars—one of rapid social change and of
development in industry, engineering, housebuilding and transport—brought
a greater need for systematic land planning. The Town and Country Planning
Acts of 1932, which remained the basis of the law for 15 years, attempted to
strengthen planning law and to extend the planning powers of central and
local authorities. Although there were improvements in sanitary and en¬
vironmental conditions, the general effect of the legislation was unsatisfactory,
partly because it was permissive and not compulsory and partly because local
authorities wishing to exercise planning control were deterred by fears of
incurring heavy liabilities for compensation.
After studies of the major problems of planning had been conducted in the
years following 1937, the Government introduced in 1947 two comprehensive
Town and Country Planning Acts (one for England and Wales and one for
Scotland). These Acts provide the basis of the modern system of land planning
(the law in England and Wales has been consolidated in the Town and
Country Planning Act 1962). They impose compulsory planning duties on all
local planning authorities (the councils of counties and county boroughs, the
London authorities and, in some cases, joint planning boards) and establish a
centralised planning structure under the Minister of Housing and Local
Government and the Secretary of State for Scotland (and since 1965 the
Secretary of State for Wales).
All local planning authorities are required to prepare development plans for
their areas stating their proposals and objectives, and to submit them for
ministerial approval. The authorities have powers to undertake development
themselves, including the compulsory acquisition of land. Development1
generally is subject to the consent of the local planning authority, with a right
of appeal to the Minister if the consent is refused.
The Town and Country Planning Act 1968 (and a similar Act for Scotland
passed in 1969) provides for a new procedure to reduce administrative delays;
to place a positive emphasis on the provision of pleasant surroundings in
which people can live and work, rather than on negative controls; and to
enable the public to play a greater part in the planning process than hitherto.
1 In planning law ‘development’ includes most forms of construction, mineral extraction
and any material change made in the use of land or existing buildings.
Regional
Planning
The Location
of Industry
New Towns
PLANNING AND HOUSING 171
Structure plans are drawn up by local planning authorities and submitted for
approval to the Minister of Housing and Local Government or the Secretaries
of State for Scotland or Wales. The plans set out ‘broad policies’ for land use
in counties and major towns and relate these policies to transport patterns.
They also indicate ‘action areas’ where development is expected to start
within a specified period. In addition, local planning authorities prepare and
formally adopt (generally without the need for ministerial approval) local plans
containing detailed proposals, including plans for the action areas, within the
framework of the structure plans. All the plans may be amended periodically.
The new procedure is being introduced progressively where the local
planning authorities are suitably staffed and organised to draw up satisfactory
structure plans, as, for example, in Greater London.
The interests of the public are safeguarded in several ways.1 All proposals
for development must be widely advertised and there is a system of appeals
against such proposals. Appeals against major developments are dealt with at
ministerial level, but in England and Wales in order to speed up planning
procedures, the making of decisions on small-scale residential development is
delegated to inspectors. In the case of large development schemes of national
or regional importance or of a technical or scientific nature the Minister
responsible may decide to set up planning enquiry commissions to study the
proposals in depth. Where highway development is proposed, the Minister of
Transport and the Minister of Housing and Local Government (for England
and Wales) and the Secretary of State for Scotland can hold such enquiries as
they consider appropriate.
In Northern Ireland applications for planning permission to undertake
development are decided by local planning authorities, with a right of appeal
to the Northern Ireland Ministry of Development. The future structure and
functions of the authorities are under review.
Advisory machinery for planning on a regional basis has been set up by the
Government (see p. 236). Local planning authorities and the regional econo¬
mic planning councils have consultations before development plans are drawn
up within the framework of the economic planning and development of each
region as a whole. Studies showing the economics and social resources in
all the regions have been made (see Bibliography, pp. 481-82) and certain
areas, where land, communications and facilities are favourable, have been
proposed as places where development should be concentrated.
Provisions relating to the location of industry and offices have been made in
the Town and Country Planning Acts, the Local Employment Acts 1960-70,
the Control of Office and Industrial Development Act 1965, and the Industrial
Development Act 1966. General problems of industrial development are
dealt with jointly by a number of government departments, but the consent
of the local planning authority is, as a rule, required for any new industrial
building, any extension of a building or any change in the use of an existing
building. Financial incentives to encourage the location of industry in particu¬
lar areas have been made available by the Government. There is special
control of office building in south-east England and the Midlands.
The New Towns Act 1946 (now consolidated in Acts passed in 1965 and 1968)
gave the Minister of Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of

State for Scotland (and since 1965 the Secretary of State for Wales) power to
make an order designating as the site of a new town any area of land (which
may include any existing town or other centre of population). The Minister of
Development in Northern Ireland can designate areas as new towns or for
special development under the New Towns Act (Northern Ireland) 1965.
In Great Britain the appropriate minister must consult the local authorities
in the area about the proposal and an opportunity is given for objections to be
made by the public. Once the site has been designated, the Minister appoints
a development corporation (a development commission in Northern Ireland),
to be responsible for the development of the new town, including the pre¬
paration of a ‘master plan’.
The development corporations have powers in general (subject to the
consent of the appropriate minister) to acquire, by agreement or compulsory
purchase, land or property within the designated areas, or, in some cases,
land near to or outside those areas, and they may provide buildings, roads and
services essential for the development of the towns. Ministerial approval of
proposals for development, given after consultation with the local planning
authority, constitutes planning permission.
The capital cost of developing the new towns is advanced from public
funds and is repayable over 60 years out of the income from the property.
The corporations submit annual reports (which include copies of their
audited accounts) to Parliament.
Thirty-two new towns have been, or are being, established in Britain;
twenty-three in England and Wales, five in Scotland and four in Northern
Ireland. Eleven of the new towns in England and Wales (Basildon, Bracknell,
Crawley, Harlow, Hatfield, Elemel Hempstead, Milton Keynes, Northamp¬
ton, Peterborough, Stevenage and Welwyn) are designed to help relieve
housing problems in the Greater London area. Of the others, Aycliffe, Corby,
Cwmbran, Peterlee and Washington are serving the special needs of their
areas; Runcorn and Skelmersdale are helping to meet the overspill needs of
Liverpool and north Merseyside; Telford and Redditch are taking population
from Birmingham; Warrington is being expanded to take people from
Manchester; and as a further measure to ease the housing problems in
Manchester and Liverpool and to provide a growth point for the economy of
Lancashire, a new town has been designated for the Preston-Leyland-
Chorley area. Newtown in mid-Wales is being developed to promote economic
growth in the area.
The Scottish new towns (Cumbernauld, East Kilbride, Glenrothes, Irvine
and Livingston) are helping to house people from Glasgow. They are also to
be centres for industry in the central belt of Scotland. In Northern Ireland,
Craigavon is being developed as a new city and is expected to become an area
of major industrial growth. Other new towns (Antrim and Ballymena) are
also being developed as centres of economic growth. Londonderry and the
surrounding district has been designated as an area of special development.
Four new towns (Crawley, Platfield, Hemel Hempstead and Welwyn) have
been substantially completed and their development corporations dissolved.
Their assets and liabilities have been handed over to the Commission for the
New Towns—a government-appointed agency set up in 1959-
The new towns represent a notable achievement in positive land use. They
are generally recognised as one of the most successful post-war experiments,
both socially and industrially, and as a profitable long-term investment. More
than half a million people have moved into the new towns during the past
20 years; young people form a higher proportion of their populations than of

the country as a whole. An extensive building and civil engineering programme
has provided houses, flats, factories, schools, shops, churches, health centres
and libraries as well as public buildings including town halls and law courts.
Roads, water supplies, sewerage, gas and electricity, police, fire and bus
stations, postal, telegraph and telephone facilities have also been provided;
most of the towns are well equipped with parks and playing fields of various
kinds. All towns have become concerned with the increasingly high level of car
ownership of their inhabitants and are making more adequate provision for
parking and the segregation of pedestrians from motorists.
A number of the more developed towns are becoming regional centres and,
as the populations grow large enough to give the necessary support, offices,
hotels and department stores, as well as arts centres and full entertainment
and recreational facilities (skating rinks, dance halls, bowling alleys,
swimming pools, sports stadia, golf courses and youth centres) are gradually
being provided. The proposed expansion of such large existing towns as
Peterborough—a further development in the evolution of new towns policy—
has the advantage, among others, that many of these facilities are already
available.
Under the New Towns Act 1946 Parliament approved a fund of £50 million
to provide for advances to the development corporations for work on the new
towns. This fund was increased by subsequent Acts and now stands at £1,100
million; a total of some £759 million had been advanced to the corporations
by March 1970.
The Town Development Act 1952 makes provision for the relief of congestion
in large industrial towns in England and Wales (such as London and
Birmingham) by encouraging the transfer of population to areas suitable for
expansion where employment is provided. Schemes have been approved,
providing some 151,000 dwellings in this way, of which about half have been
completed or are under construction. Some of the expanding towns (for
example, Aylesbury, Basingstoke, Swindon and Thetford) are already well
established, providing new opportunities for people from large cities. In some
places, like Cramlington and Killingworth, the expansion is based on relatively
undeveloped areas. The Housing and Town Development (Scotland) Act
1957 makes similar provision for Scotland, where the only congested town
so far involved is Glasgow. Schemes have been approved for some 24,000
dwellings; more than half of these have been completed.
Existing towns and cities are being renewed and re-shaped to meet the growth
in population and traffic. Glasgow, for example, has a programme to rebuild
29 areas accommodating nearly a third of its population and much of its in¬
dustry and commerce; eight areas have been approved by the Secretary of
State for Scotland. The Government believes that greater integration of land
use and transport planning is of basic importance. Integration was the theme
of the Buchanan Report (see p. 335) which assessed the conflicting demands of
traffic and the environment and which has influenced many authorities’ re¬
development plans. In Leeds, where planning policies have also stressed the
importance of integration, development is following the proposals of a plan,
Planning and Transport—the Leeds Approach, published in 1969 in association
with the Ministry of Housing and Local Government and the Ministry of
Transport. The Government is setting up a centre for advanced training in
transport and environmental planning. Research into urban planning prob-

lems is undertaken by a number of institutes and university departments and
by the Centre for Environmental Studies.
Lists of buildings of special architectural or historic interest are compiled, as
required by the planning Acts, by the Minister of Housing and Local Govern¬
ment and the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales; 125,000 buildings
are already listed. It is an offence to demolish or alter any listed building
without special consent from the local planning authority; where consent is
given, the National Monuments Record keeps a photographic record of the
building. Emergency ‘building preservation notices’ can be served by the
local authority to protect buildings not yet listed. The respective Ministers
(on the recommendation of the appropriate Historic Buildings Council) can
make grants for the repair or maintenance of buildings of outstanding interest,
and local authorities can make grants for any building of architectural or
historic interest even if it is not listed. Over 1,690 buildings in Great Britain
have received grants totalling ^8-1 million under the Historic Buildings and
Ancient Monuments Act 1953. The Civic Amenities Act 1967 requires local
planning authorities to designate ‘conservation areas’ of special architectural
or historic interest. Special studies have been made in Bath, Chester, Chiches¬
ter and York of the difficulties of preserving features of historic interest in
ancient towns in the face of commercial development and increasing motor
traffic. The Minister of Public Building and Works and the Secretaries of State
for Scotland and Wales are responsible for the maintenance of royal parks and
palaces and for the protection of ancient monuments of which over 720 of the
more important are in their care and are visited by some 12 million people
annually. The Royal Commission on Historical Monuments (for England) and
similar bodies for Scotland and Wales survey monuments and specify those
worthy of preservation.
In order to restrict the further sprawl of large built-up areas, to prevent
adjacent towns merging into one another, and in some cases to preserve the
special character of a town and the amenities of the countryside, the policy has
been adopted of establishing ‘green belts’ around all or part of certain urban
areas. Green belts are areas which it is intended should be left permanently
open and free from new development.
Local planning authorities have power to protect trees and woodlands by
means of tree preservation orders and to ensure that trees are protected or
replaced on sites undergoing development. Increasing use is being made of
the planting of semi-mature trees for landscaping purposes. The authorities
have powers to prevent mineral workings becoming permanent eyesores by
attaching suitable conditions to planning permissions, to regulate the display
of advertisements in the interests of amenity and safety and to make it an
offence to leave litter, including bulky rubbish such as old cars, on open land.
They may, for health reasons, declare ‘smoke control areas’, in which the
emission of smoke from chimneys constitutes an offence. River authorities
(see p. 271) are responsible for the prevention of pollution of rivers. Govern¬
ment departments are advised about the problems of pollution by a standing
Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution. Government departments
and other public bodies exercising functions relating to land have a legal
duty to keep in mind the desirability of conserving the countryside’s natural
beauty and amenity.
Voluntary organisations are particularly active in ensuring that development

takes full account of considerations of amenity. The National Trust for
England, Wales and Northern Ireland, founded in 1895 and now with some
180,000 members, is the largest private landowner in Britain. For the benefit
of the public it owns and protects from harmful development 420,000 acres
(169,964 hectares) of land, 200 historic buildings and 280 miles (451 km.) of
coastline—often acquired through gifts (sometimes by arrangement with the
Treasury in lieu of death duties, see p. 364). In 1969 over million people
visited Trust properties. The Trust is engaged, with government aid, on
Enterprise Neptune, a £2 million campaign to preserve 900 miles (1,448 km.)
of coastline. The National Trust for Scotland, an independent body founded
in 1931, has some 33,000 members and cares for nearly 100 properties,
covering in all about 80,000 acres (32,375 hectares).
The Civic Trust, founded in 1957 and financed through covenants from
leading industrial firms, encourages high quality in architecture and planning,
and stimulates public interest in the protection of beauty in town and country.
It has produced plans for the redevelopment of town centres and for a re¬
creation area in the Lee Valley to the north-east of London. The Trust makes
use of local initiative; it has separate sections in the north-east and north-west
of England and in Wales and Scotland, and advises some 800 local civic
societies. Other amenity societies dependent upon their members’ support
include: the Town and Country Planning Association; the Council for the
Protection of Rural England, the Association for the Preservation of Rural
Scotland and the Council for the Protection of Rural Wales; the Commons,
Open Spaces and Footpaths Preservation Society; the Ramblers’ Association;
the Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings; the Georgian Group and
the Scottish Georgian Society; the Victorian Society; the Pilgrim Trust; and
the Historic Churches Preservation Trust. The Committee for Environmental
Conservation, comprising many of the main voluntary organisations, acts as a
liaison body and takes action on environmental problems.
Under the Countryside Acts 1967 (for Scotland) and 1968 (for England and
Wales) Countryside Commissions (with an advisory committee for Wales)
encourage the provision and development of facilities for open-air recreation
in the countryside. These include the creation by local authorities (sometimes
in association with other bodies) of country parks within easy reach of towns;
the establishment of camping sites and picnic areas; and the increased use of
reservoirs, canals and other waterways for bathing, sailing and other activities.
By May 1970, 9 country parks and 10 picnic sites had been approved in
England by the Minister of Housing and Local Government. The Commis¬
sions are also responsible for encouraging and promoting measures to conserve
and enhance the natural beauty and amenity of the countryside and may
undertake research projects and experimental schemes, working in con¬
sultation with local authorities and such bodies as the Nature Conservancy
and the Sports Council (see p. 450). Grants to local authorities are available
from the Government for certain approved schemes and the Commissions
have powers to make grants or loans to people working for the same purposes.
The Countryside Commission for England and Wales replaced and assumed
the functions of the National Parks Commission set up under the National
Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949 to select national parks and
‘areas of outstanding natural beauty’ and to make proposals for the creation of
long-distance footpaths and bridleways. Ten national parks have been estab¬
lished: Northumberland, the Lake District, the Yorkshire Dales, the North

York Moors and the Peak District in northern England; Snowdonia, the
Pembrokeshire Coast and the Brecon Beacons in Wales; Exmoor and Dart¬
moor in south-west England. They cover a total area of 5,258 square miles
(13,618 sq. km.), or 9 per cent of the area of England and Wales. They have
various forms of administration, based on representation of the local planning
authorities of the areas concerned, as well as members appointed by the
Minister of Housing and Local Government or by the Secretary of State for
Wales. By August 1970, 27 areas of outstanding natural beauty had been
designated, covering some 4,422 square miles (11,453 sch km.).
The land in the national parks and designated areas generally remains
privately owned, but agreements or orders to secure additional public access
may be made by the local authorities. Steps are taken to preserve and enhance
the landscape’s natural beauty by high standards of development control, and
by positive measures, for which government grants are available, such as
tree planting and preservation, and the removal of eyesores. In the national
parks, other measures for the benefit of the public include the provision of
car parks and camping and caravan areas, for example, and the setting up of
information centres. All national parks and some other designated areas have
warden services. More than 1,400 miles (2,253 km.) of long-distance foot¬
paths and bridleways had been approved by 1970. Large stretches of these
paths are already public rights of way; the 250 miles (402 km.) of the Pennine
Way form Britain’s first long-distance footpath and the South Downs Way,
stretching for some 80 miles (129 km.) is the first long-distance bridleway.
Further routes are being established.
Under the Amenity Lands Act (Northern Ireland) 1965 the Ulster Country¬
side Committee advises on the establishment of national parks and the
designation of areas of outstanding natural beauty. Seven areas have been
designated. Four amenity areas, acquired by the Ministry of Development, are
being managed as country parks. Although there are no national parks as such
in Scotland, five large areas are subject to special planning control under
ministerial supervision. The areas are: Loch Lomond-Trossachs; Glen
Affric-Glen Cannich-Strath Farrar; Ben Nevis-Glen Coe-Black Mount; the
Cairngorms; and Loch Torridon-Loch Maree-Little Loch Broom. Over 98
per cent of the land in Scotland has been designated as countryside within the
jurisdiction of the Countryside Commission for Scotland.
The Forestry Commission (see p. 323) has formed, and opened to the public,
seven Forest Parks in some of the finest country in Britain: Argyll, Glen Trool,
Glen More and the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park in Scotland; the Forest
of Dean and the Wye valley woods on the borders of England and Wales;
Snowdonia in Wales; and the Border Forest Park on the borders of England
and Scotland. The total area of the parks approaches half a million acres
(202,340 hectares). Camping and other recreational facilities provided in all
the parks are used by thousands of holidaymakers each year. The historic
New Forest, in Hampshire, although not a Forest Park, is also open to the
public. Northern Ireland has five forest parks, Tollymore Park, Gortin Glen
Forest, Castlewellan, Gosford and Drum Manor.
Responsibility for nature conservation in Great Britain is exercised by the
Nature Conservancy on behalf of the Natural Environment Research Council
(see p. 202), of which the Conservancy is a component body. The Conservancy
derives its powers from its royal charter and the National Parks and Access to
the Countryside Act 1949, as amended by the Science and Technology Act

177
1965. In Northern Ireland nature reserves are designated on the advice of the
Nature Reserves Committee under the Amenity Lands Act (Northern
Ireland) 1965.
In the reserves wild plants and animals and their environment are pro¬
tected, and facilities for the enjoyment and understanding of nature are pro¬
vided. There are 128 national nature reserves in Great Britain, covering
some 265,100 acres (107,285 hectares); the largest more than 64,000 acres
(25,900 hectares), is in the Cairngorms. Twenty-one local nature reserves are
managed by local authorities in consultation with the Conservancy.
Thirteen forest nature reserves have been created by agreement between
the Forestry Commission and other owners, and the Nature Conservancy
and are managed by their owners for research and conservation.
There are also over 2,000 sites of special scientific interest in Britain
scheduled by the Conservancy and the Northern Ireland Ministry of
Development.
The Council for Nature (established in 1958) is an independent voluntary
organisation of some 450 natural history and conservation societies concerned
with averting threats to wild life in Britain.
HOUSING
There are some i8‘9 million dwellings in Britain: nearly ib-y million in
England and Wales, i-8 million in Scotland and almost 450,000 in Northern
Ireland. Although nationally the numbers of households and dwellings in
Britain are about equal they are unevenly distributed and there is a heavy
demand for housing in the areas of economic prosperity, like London and
Birmingham.
Over 7 million new dwellings have been built in Britain since 1945—over
378,000 in 1969—and more than one family in three now lives in a post-war
dwelling. It was estimated in 1967 that some 6 million dwellings in England
and Wales were more than 50 years old, and these included i‘8 million which
were below the standard considered necessary, of which a million needed
to be demolished (see p. 181).
The provision of housing in Britain is undertaken by both private and public
sectors, the former building houses and flats principally for sale to owner-
occupiers, the latter providing dwellings mainly for renting.
About one-half of all dwellings in Britain are now owned by their occupiers,
while about a third are owned by public housing authorities (in Scotland the
figure is almost one in two). Dwellings rented from private landlords (over
60 per cent of all dwellings in 1947) have now dwindled to about one-sixth of
the total housing stock.
Most of the post-war dwellings in Britain are houses (usually of two storeys)
with gardens; the remainder are flats or maisonettes mostly in blocks of from
two to 20 storeys, although a few may be higher. Multi-storey blocks are
generally built in central urban areas where they replace old dwellings.
The standard of new local authority housing in England and Wales has
improved significantly in recent years, particularly in the floor space provided
and heating systems installed (see p. 179). Accommodation in a house
designed for a family of five people includes one or two living rooms, a
kitchen, a bathroom and a water closet and three bedrooms; in England in
1969 it had a superficial area of about 965 square feet (90 square metres)
and cost an average of 3,194.
Comparative European statistics show that the degree of overcrowding in
178
Housing
Policy
Research and
Development
Standards of
Building
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Britain is lower than in most other countries. Housing costs represent 12-7 per
cent of the total weekly expenditure of the average British family.
Responsibility for formulating government housing policy and supervising
the housing programme is borne by the Minister of Housing and Local
Government in England, by the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales
and by the Minister of Development in Northern Ireland. The execution
of policy is carried out principally by the 1,500 or so local housing authorities,
whose job it is to ensure an adequate supply of housing in their areas. They
are in England, Wales and Northern Ireland the councils of county boroughs,
boroughs, urban districts and rural districts; in London the Greater London
Council, the London borough councils and the Common Council of the
City of London; and in Scotland the town and county councils. Housing is
also provided by certain other public authorities, including most new town
authorities, the Scottish Special Housing Association (SSHA) and the
Northern Ireland Housing Trust (NIHT).1 The SSHA, established in 1937
to supplement building by local authorities in Scotland, now owns about
70,000 houses and builds at the rate of some 3,000 houses a year, mainly in
support of economic expansion in the development areas. The NIHT was
established in 1945 for a similar purpose.
An important part of the Government’s policy is to encourage the provision
by the public sector of houses to let at moderate rents to meet the needs of
those who, because of income or family circumstances, are unwilling or unable
to buy their own homes. About 200,000 new dwellings of this type are built
each year, mostly by the local authorities. More than a quarter of these are of
the single bedroom type, suitable for smaller households including the elderly.
At the same time the Government seeks to encourage the spread of home
ownership, and about half of the new houses built each year are intended for
owner occupation. In 1967 a scheme was introduced by the Government to
help people with lower incomes to buy their own homes (see p. 179).
The Government is specially concerned to ensure the best use of the existing
housing stock. A survey carried out in 1967 showed that there were some
4-5 million old dwellings in England and Wales which were structurally sound
but needed repair or the installation of amenities, such as bathrooms. Under
two Housing Acts 1969 (one for England and Wales and one for Scotland) the
Government has increased financial incentives for the rehabilitation of older
houses and their environment (see p. 181).
Research into building techniques and into new methods of house construction
as well as into the needs of families, is carried out by the Research and
Development Groups of the Ministry of Housing and Local Government and
the Scottish Development Department, the Building Research Station, the
architects’ departments of major local authorities and the research groups in
big constructional firms. All government building research and development
is co-ordinated by the Directorate-General of Research and Development at
the Ministry of Public Building and Works. Advice on ways of increasing
productivity in housebuilding is given by the National Building Agency.
Control of building standards is generally exercised through regulations made
by the central departments, which also give guidance on design and layout to
local authorities in circulars and bulletins.
