T79
The Central Housing Advisory Committee, a statutory body, advises the
Minister of Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of State for
Wales on housing matters. The Parker Morris report, prepared by a sub¬
committee, suggested standards that should be achieved in new dwellings (see
Bibliography, p. 478). Some relating to space and heating have been made
mandatory for local authority housing schemes, and now over 90 per cent of all
new local authority dwellings in England and Wales have central heating to
these standards. For building in the private sector the National House-
Builders’ Registration Council sets standards and enforces them by inspection
and certification.
About 40 per cent of dwellings in the public sector are built by industrialised
methods, which offer the advantages of rapid construction on the site with the
use of fewer skilled workers and greater independence of weather conditions
compared with traditional methods. A number of local authorities work in
consortia to make the best use of industrialised systems (with standardised
components) in their housebuilding programmes.
Loans to enable people to buy their houses by a system of instalment purchase
are available from various sources, including building societies, insurance
companies, industrial and provident societies and local authorities. The local
authorities are expected to concentrate their efforts primarily on helping people
with special housing needs who are unable to obtain loans from other sources.
Building societies, of which there are some 480 in Great Britain, are the
most important of these agencies. They do not build houses themselves but
provide long-term loans on the security of property bought for owner-
occupation. They usually advance 80 to 90 per cent of the value of the houses.
Loans are repayable over periods of up to 25 or even 30 years, by equal monthly
instalments to cover capital and interest. The societies advanced more than
£1,540 million in 1969, the average price of houses mortgaged being £4,775.
In response to the demand for owner-occupation a scheme to help people
with low incomes to buy their dwellings on mortgage was introduced under
the Housing Subsidies Act 1967. Under the scheme borrowers have the option
of either claiming income tax relief on interest payments on their loan (a
system which helps people who pay a high rate of tax more than those who
pay little or none), or of receiving through the lending agency a government
subsidy, which reduces the rate of interest they pay by up to 3 per cent,
subject to a minimum remaining interest charge which in most cases is 4 per
cent.
The option scheme has been extended to include a provision by which
mortgage loans of up to 100 per cent of the valuation of a house (not exceeding
£5,000) may be made to those participating in the scheme.
Since the early 1960s the Government has done much to encourage the growth
of non-profit-making housing associations and societies.
Housing associations have long existed as voluntary bodies set up for the
purpose of providing low-rent housing for people in need. The Housing Act
1957 made money available to local authorities for the granting of 100 per cent
loans to such associations. Encouragement to housing associations to purchase
and convert old houses into new dwellings was offered by the Housing Act
1969 which provided for a 20-year subsidy equivalent to three-eighths of all
charges (capital and interest) on loans raised for this purpose.
Housing societies build dwellings either for co-ownership by a group of
occupants or to let at unsubsidised rents. Following a pilot scheme introduced
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
by the Housing Act 1961, a Housing Corporation was set up under the
Housing Act 1964 to stimulate the formation of such societies. Two-thirds of
the money needed for approved housing society schemes is advanced by
building societies, with the Housing Corporation providing the remainder.
The actual building of dwellings for public housing authorities is mostly
carried out by private firms under contract, although a number of authorities
employ direct labour. The capital cost of houses built by or for local authorities
is met by raising loans; current expenditure, including loan repayment and
interest on loans, is met from rents supplemented by subsidies from the
Exchequer and, in some cases, from the rates (see p. 73). Local authorities
may raise loans for housing on the open market or by borrowing from the
Public Works Loan Board (see p. 74). In Northern Ireland local authorities,
the Housing Trust and housing associations may borrow from the Government
Loans Fund.
Housing subsidies, at varying rates and for different purposes, have been
provided in Britain since 1919, when they were first introduced to enable
local authorities to build houses for letting at moderate rents. Because of the
erosion of the usual flat-rate subsidies by rising building costs and interest
rates, a new kind of subsidy was introduced by the Housing Subsidies Act
1967, which provides a basic subsidy equal to the difference between the
interest charge (at current borrowing rates) on a loan raised to cover the
approved capital cost of a dwelling and the charge if the loan had borne
interest at 4 per cent. Supplementary subsidies are paid for high building; to
councils with insufficient resources to provide urgently needed houses; for
houses required in connection with a major transfer of industry; for expensive
sites; for precautions against subsidence; for building in certain materials;
and for overspill. Similar subsidies are paid in Scotland. In Northern Ireland
annual subsidies are paid to housing authorities and associations and ‘lump-
sum’ subsidies are paid to private people who build dwellings for letting or
owner-occupation.
In selecting tenants for council dwellings local authorities must give pre¬
ference to families living in overcrowded or unsatisfactory conditions. Rents
are generally low in comparison with current building costs. Over two-thirds
of the housing authorities in England and Wales operate rent-rebate schemes,
under which tenants with low incomes or with large families are able to claim
a reduction in the standard rent. In Scotland half of the councils operate
rebate schemes, although rents generally are lower than in England and
Wales. The Government is encouraging the expansion of such schemes so
that housing subsidies are used to help people who need them most.
A declining proportion of the available housing in Britain (about one-sixth)
is rented from individual landlords and property companies.
Rent control was originally introduced in 1915 as a temporary war-time
measure and successive Acts have varied its scope. Under the Rent Act 1957
there was a large measure of de-control but the Rent Act 1965 re-introduced
control over most privately rented unfurnished dwellings—those of annual
rateable value up to £400 in London and £200 elsewhere. Most rent legislation
for England and Wales has been consolidated in the Rent Act 1968. Tenants
have a wide degree of security of tenure and (except for dwellings whose rents
are still controlled by the Rent Act 1957) a fair rent may be fixed on application
by landlord or tenant. Fair rents are determined by rent officers or, if the
landlord or tenant objects to the rent determined by the rent officer, by a rent
PLANNING AND HOUSING
Improvement
of Houses
Slum Clearance
181
assessment committee on the assumption that, for similar dwellings, demand
does not greatly exceed supply. Once determined, the rent is not normally
reviewed for at least three years. For furnished premises under the rateable
value limits a tenant may go to a rent tribunal for determination of a reasonable
rent and may be given security of tenure for up to six months with a possibility
of further periods if the tribunal so decides. Eviction without a court order
from furnished or unfurnished premises of any rateable value and harassment
of occupiers are criminal offences with severe penalties.
Measures of control and de-control also apply in Northern Ireland. In 1951
and 1956 legislation was passed which permitted prescribed increases in the
rents of certain controlled houses. The 1956 Act also released from control
houses with a net annual value of over ^50 (with certain safeguards) and
houses with a net annual value of over ^26 of which the landlord was in actual
possession when the Act came into force, or of which he subsequently
obtained possession.
Private owners in Great Britain can obtain grants from local authorities to
improve their houses by providing amenities such as baths and for carrying
out other works to modernise their properties. Grants are also available for
converting large houses or other buildings into flats. The grant amounts to
half the approved cost of the works up to a normal grant limit of £1,000
(£1,200 in Scotland). If a house of three or more storeys is converted into
flats the upper limit of grant is £1,200 for each flat provided. A Government
contribution amounting to three-quarters of each grant is paid to the local
authority. Aid on a similar basis is given by the Government to local authorities
and housing associations, but this includes the cost of buying properties for
conversion and improvement as well as that of carrying out works.
To enable local authorities to tackle systematically the improvement of
whole areas of older housing, the Housing Act 1969 gives them powers to
declare ‘general improvement areas’. The aim in these areas is to encourage
householders to improve their dwellings with the aid of grants, while the
local authority uses its comprehensive powers to improve the environment.
A Government grant is given of half the local authority’s expenditure on
environmental improvements on costs of up to £100 a house. Grants for
house improvement are also provided in Northern Ireland.
Nearly 2| million people have been rehoused since the mid-1950s as a result
of slum clearance programmes. It is expected that within the next ten years
the great majority of the housing authorities in Great Britain will have suc¬
ceeded in getting rid of all their present slums. In certain areas, however,
particularly the older industrial towns, including Birmingham, Glasgow,
Liverpool and Manchester, clearance may take longer. Local authorities with
major slum and overcrowding problems are being given priority to clear their
slums and to undertake major programmes of urban renewal. Their house¬
building programmes have increased sharply in recent years and in many cases
the designation of new towns nearby has further eased their housing problems
(see p. 171). Housing authorities are obliged to see that other accommodation
exists, or can be provided by them, for people displaced by slum clearance.
The Housing Act 1969 changed the basis of compensation paid to the
displaced owner-occupiers of unfit houses. Those subject to compulsory
purchase orders now in effect receive compensation to the full market value,
while those subject to clearance orders, who retain their land, receive a
payment amounting to the difference (if any) between the site value and the
market value.
8 THE CHURCHES
The Church of
England
Every person living in Britain has the right of religious freedom and may
manifest his faith in teaching, worship and observance without interference
from the community or the State. Churches and religious societies of all kinds
may own property, conduct schools, and propagate their beliefs in speech
and in writing.
Freedom of conscience in religious matters was achieved gradually from the
seventeenth century onwards; the laws discriminating against minority
religious groups were gradually administered less rigorously and then finally
repealed. Heresy ceased to be a legal offence with the passing of the Ecclesias¬
tical Jurisdiction Act 1677, and the Toleration Act 1688 granted freedom
of worship to protestant dissenters. In 1828 the repeal of the Test and
Corporation Acts freed nonconformists from political disabilities and made it
possible for them to be appointed to public offices; Roman Catholics gained
political emancipation under the Roman Catholic Relief Act 1829; the Jewish
Relief Act 1858 enabled Jews to become members of Parliament; while
religious tests that had been imposed on prospective students and members
of the academic staff of the universities of Oxford, Cambridge and Durham
were successively abolished by Acts of 1854, 1856 and 1871. Nowadays, there
is no religious or denominational bar to the holding of public office, except in
the case of the Lord Chancellor, where there is some doubt whether existing
statutory provisions would permit this office to be held by a Roman
Catholic.
In the services administered by the State, such as the armed forces, the
national hospitals and the prisons, the clergy of the established Church of
England or the Church of Scotland provide the principal ministrations and
are paid a salary by the State for this part of their work. Priests of the Roman
Catholic Church and ministers of other denominations may also be appointed
or specially called in as required. Voluntary schools (see p. 149) provided by
churches of any religious denomination may be wholly or partly maintained
from public funds.
There is no precisely accurate or uniform method of assessing the number
of adherents to the various churches in the United Kingdom, since no en¬
quiries are made about religious beliefs in population censuses or other
official returns, and each church adopts its own criteria in counting its
members. The membership figures given in this chapter are therefore
approximate.
The Church of England is the established church, and claims to be the ancient
catholic church of the land. At the Reformation in the sixteenth century, it
repudiated the supremacy of the Pope, but retained the historic episcopate,
and the creeds and sacraments upon which its doctrines are based; therefore
it claims to be both ‘catholic’ and ‘reformed’. Its form of worship is embodied
in the Book of Common Prayer, which was first compiled in 1549.
The Church is uniquely related to the Crown in that the Sovereign, who
must be a member of the Church of England, is called ‘Defender of the Faith’
(a statutory title as protector of the Church) and promises on his or her
THE CHURCHES
Church
Organisation
and Government
183
accession to uphold it. The coronation of the Sovereign is performed by the
Archbishop of Canterbury; prayers for the Sovereign and other members
of the royal family are said in all the statutory services of the Church; Church
of England archbishops, bishops and deans are appointed by the Sovereign
on the advice of the Prime Minister1; and all clergymen take the oath of
allegiance to the Crown.
The Church is also linked with the State through the House of Lords, in
which the archbishops of Canterbury and York and 24 senior diocesan bishops
have seats (see p. 32). This makes it possible for the views of the Church
leaders to be expressed freely on any moral issue raised in connection with the
corporate conduct of the State as well as on specifically ecclesiastical issues—
a matter of particular significance in view of the fact that the clergy of the
Church of England (together with those of the Church of Scotland, the
Church of Ireland and the Roman Catholic Church) are legally disqualified
from sitting in the House of Commons.
The Church must obtain Parliament’s consent2 to change its form of
worship, as laid down in the authorised Book of Common Prayer; canons
(Church rules) cannot be made or amended without the consent of the Queen;
and the Measures of the General Synod (as distinct from its regulations)
also require parliamentary approval and the Royal Assent.
The Church of England is organised geographically into two provinces and
43 dioceses. The Province of Canterbury contains 29 dioceses and that of
York 14. Each diocese is subdivided into ecclesiastical parishes, of which there
are about 14,300. The Archbishop of Canterbury is Primate of All England
and bishop of his own diocese of Canterbury; the Archbishop of York is
styled Primate of England and is bishop of his own diocese of York. Of the
population born and resident in the two provinces, about three-fifths (27-6
million) are baptised into the Church of England and almost one-fifth
(9*9 million) are confirmed members of the Church.
Until 1970 the government of the Church was of a dual nature. Spiritual
authority rested with the Convocations of Canterbury and York, each pre¬
sided over by its archbishop and consisting of an Upper House of all the
diocesan bishops in the province and a Lower House of representatives of
each cathedral chapter, archdeacons and elected clergy. The legislative and
central administrative body was the National Assembly of the Church of
England (the Church Assembly) consisting of three houses: Bishops, Clergy
and Laity. Under the Synodical Government Measure 1969, a new system of
church government is being established in order to strengthen the voice and
status of the laity. A General Synod is invested with the powers of the Con¬
vocations and the Church Assembly, and bishops, clergy and laity become
equally involved in decisions affecting the whole range of the Church’s
concern. (The Assembly ceases to exist, but the Convocations continue to
meet, although less often than before.) Certain important issues must be
referred to the dioceses before they are finally decided by the General Synod,
and they can only then be passed if a majority of the dioceses are in favour.
The General Synod meets several times a year. Administrative measures
which have been passed by the Synod are presented to an ecclesiastical
committee of both Houses of Parliament, consisting of 30 members, of whom
1 A Church commission is considering what constitutional modifications are desirable
and practicable in the present relationship between Church and State.
2 Consent has been obtained for the experimental use of alternative forms, if and when
authorised by the Church.
G
184
Church Finance
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
15 are appointed by the Lord Chancellor and 15 by the Speaker of the House
of Commons. This committee lays the measures, together with a report, before
both Houses, which may reject but not alter them. If both Houses so resolve,
the measures are sent to the Sovereign for Royal Assent, after which they
have the same force and effect as Acts of Parliament.
The General Synod replaces the Church Assembly as the centre of an
administrative system consisting of boards and councils dealing with various
aspects of the Church’s work, such as education, recruitment and training
for the ministry, and Church work at home and overseas. Through the
Schools Council of its Board of Education the Synod is responsible for the
Church of England schools. More than one in nine of the 7-6 million pupils
in the maintained schools of England and Wales in 1968 attended the Church’s
maintained schools. There are also about 40 direct grant and about 45 in¬
dependent Church of England schools.
In 1969 the Church spent million on building and improving its
schools. The Council is in close touch with the Department of Education
and Science, professional and educational bodies and the educational depart¬
ments of other churches; it co-operates with the National Society which is
the Church’s only body for advancing religious education in schools.
There are 25 Church colleges of education in England and two in Wales,
run by independent governing bodies. With substantial grants from the
Department of Education and Science a major programme of expansion,
including the opening of two new colleges, was completed in 1967; this has
increased the number of college places to over 18,500 at an estimated cost to
the Church of over £2 million. Under the Church Assembly a programme
was completed for the modernisation and improvement of theological
colleges and establishments for the training of women in the pastoral work
of the Church. A reorganisation of the theological colleges, which envisages
an amalgamation of the 21 existing colleges to provide a maximum of 14,
was approved by the Assembly in 1970.
The Church of England has its own ecclesiastical courts whose jurisdic¬
tion today consists largely of ‘faculty’ cases, with very occasional cases of
discipline against clergy for moral or ecclesiastical offences. A faculty is the
permission required for various church matters, including any specific
alteration or addition to the fabric or ornaments of a church or to a churchyard.
Parochial church councils were set up in 1921 to associate the laity with
the government of the Church in the parish. The members of these councils
are appointed by the parochial church electors, that is, the people who are
baptised, are not members of any other church, are 17 years or over, and have
applied for membership of the electoral roll of the parish where they usually
live or worship. The estimated number on the rolls is some million.
Each parish is responsible for its own finances, and also contributes an annual
apportioned quota to diocesan funds, and each diocese similarly contributes
to the General Synod. In the diocese, the financial authority is the diocesan
board of finance, which administers the money contributed by the parishes,
and acts as trustee on behalf of the parochial church councils, which have only
limited powers of holding property. The Central Board of Finance administers
the General Synod Fund, supported by diocesan contributions and devoted
to the maintenance of central services, including capital expenditure on
training colleges and theological colleges and the grants for training candidates
for ordination.
Although the State pays for or contributes towards services provided by the
The Anglican
Communion
The Church of
Scotland
THE CHURCHES 185
Church (see p. 182), it makes no direct financial contribution to the expenses
of the Church as such.
The endowment income of the Church (from its assets amounting to over
£412 million in land and investments) is mainly administered by the Church
Commissioners, the body largely responsible for the payment of clergy
stipends and the provision of finance for pensions. The total net income
(£23-3 million in 1968-69) has greatly increased during the past ten years;
in broad terms, this has meant a rise in the stipends of the poorer clergy
and that the Commissioners have been able to embark on schemes of assis¬
tance for providing better parsonage houses, for Church buildings in new
areas of population, and for better pensions for clergy and their widows.
The present basic pension for a clergyman is £650 (and ^325 for a clergy
widow). Retired Church dignitaries receive larger pensions.
The Anglican Communion comprises 21 autonomous provinces in Britain
and overseas and two regional councils overseas with a total membership of
over 47 million.
In the British Isles, in addition to the established Church of England, there
are unestablished Anglican Churches in Ireland, Scotland and Wales: the
Church of Ireland has 14 dioceses; the Episcopal Church in Scotland,
7 dioceses and some 94,000 members; and the Church in Wales, 6 dioceses
and some 160,000 Easter communicants.
The Lambeth Conference for unofficial consultation between all Anglican
bishops meets every ten years; the latest meeting was in july-August 1968.
The conference is presided over by the Archbishop of Canterbury; it has
no executive authority, but enjoys great moral prestige, and its findings on
doctrine, discipline, relations with other communions, and on the attitude of
the Anglican churches to political and social questions are widely studied.
The Anglican Consultative Council is concerned with following up the
resolutions of the Lambeth Conference, particularly in matters of com¬
munication, missionary activities and inter-church relations. It will meet
for the first time in Kenya early in 1971 and then every two years between
the Lambeth Conferences.
The Church of Scotland, established by law, has a presbyterian form of
government. It has been described as ‘the supreme example of a church which
is established and yet is free’. Its position, defined in the Treaty of Union
1707, was further safeguarded by the Church of Scotland Act 1921, under
which it has complete internal self-government within the terms of the
schedule to the Act, ‘Articles Declaratory of the Faith of the Church of
Scotland’.
Whereas in episcopacy church government is a hierarchy of persons, in
presbyterianism there is a hierarchy of courts. All ministers are of equal status,
and each of the 2,126 congregations is governed locally by the Kirk Session,
consisting of the minister and elected elders (of whom there are about
49,000); above this is the Court of the Presbytery, then the Court of the Synod,
and finally the General Assembly, which meets annually and consists of
elected ministers and elders presided over by an elected Moderator who serves
for one year. The Sovereign, when not present in person, is represented at the
General Assembly by the Lord High Commissioner. The Church of Scotland
has complete freedom in all spiritual matters and the right to appoint its own
officers and to decide all matters of doctrine and discipline. Its decisions are
i86
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
not subject to parliamentary debate, modification or appeal to the civil courts.
Women may now be admitted to its ministry.
The training for the ministry, which lasts at least six years, has given the
Church a high reputation for scholarship and has in turn influenced the
standard of education in Scotland. The membership of the Church of Scotland
is estimated at about i'2 million.
The Free
Churches
The Methodist
Churches
The Congregational
Church
The Baptist
Churches
The Unestablished
Presbyterian
Churches
The phrase ‘Free Churches’ is now commonly used to describe those churches
in England which were more generally known in the past as ‘nonconformist’
•churches; and protestant churches in Scotland (except the established Church
of Scotland), Wales and Northern Ireland. The main Free Churches are the
Methodist, Baptist and Congregational Churches, and the unestablished
presbyterian churches throughout Britain. In addition, there are a number of
other protestant denominations in the United Kingdom as well as such
religious associations as the Society of Friends and the Salvation Army, which
have certain links with the main Free Churches.
The word ‘nonconformist’ signifies dissent from certain of the formularies
and practices of the established church. In general, the Free Churches base
their reason for existence on their distinctive convictions regarding organisa¬
tion and worship.
The largest of the Free Churches, the Methodist Church, which originated
in the eighteenth century following the evangelical revival by John Wesley,
took its present form in 1932, with the union of the majority of separate
Methodist Churches. It has some 651,000 adult full members. The supreme
authority is the annual conference and the system of government is in many
ways presbyterian, the leaders’ meeting corresponding to the kirk sessions,
with circuit meetings and district synods resembling presbytery and synod.
One of the characteristics of Methodism is its strong emphasis on lay leader¬
ship. There are over 20,000 trained lay preachers sharing the work of about
4,000 ministers and preaching in many local churches.
Methodist Churches which did not join the union in 1932 include: the
Independent Methodists (over 6,800 members), in which ministerial service
is on a purely voluntary basis and women (many of whom are ministers)
have full equality with men; and the Wesleyan Reform Union (with some
5,000 members) which, while retaining the essential Methodist doctrine, gives
autonomy to each of its 157 individual churches.
The Congregationalists are the oldest community of dissenters in Britain. In
1831 most of their churches were formed into the Congregational Union
(which in 1966 was reconstituted as the Congregational Church in England
and Wales). Local churches have formed county and national unions, whose
secretariat and assemblies have much influence, but no compulsive authority
over them, since great importance is attached to the autonomy of local church
meetings. Adult membership is about 181,000.
The Baptists are for the most part grouped in associations of churches and the
majority of these belong to the Baptist Union formed in 1813. Baptists differ
from nearly all other Churches in that they practise the baptism of believers
only; they do not baptise infants. The 2,200 churches within the Baptist
Union have a total membership of some 210,000.
The Presbyterian Church in Ireland has about 143,000 regular communi¬
cants in Northern Ireland. The Presbyterian (or Calvinistic Methodist)
Church of Wales, which arose from the revivalist movement led by Howell
Harris in 1735, numbers some ii7,oo°- The Presbyterian Church of England
THE CHURCHES
Other
Denominations
The Roman
Catholic Church
187
has some 63,000 members; its highest court is its general assembly; women
are admitted to the eldership and ministry. Other presbyterian Churches in
Britain include: the Free Church of Scotland; the United Free Church of
Scotland; the Free Presbyterian Church of Scotland; the Reformed Presby¬
terian Church of Scotland; the Reformed Presbyterian Church of Ireland;
and the Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland.
Among other protestant denominations in the United Kingdom are: the
Unitarian and Free Christian Churches; the Churches of Christ (known also
in the United States of America as Disciples of Christ), which have been an
organised community in Britain since early in the nineteenth century; the
British Province of the Moravian Church, which is an international missionary
church; the Free Church of England (or Reformed Episcopal Church), which
was formed in 1844 as a direct result of the Oxford Movement; the Society of
Friends; the Salvation Army; the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day
Saints (the Mormon Church); and the Christian Scientists.
The Society of Friends (Quakers) came into being in the middle of the
seventeenth century under the leadership of George Fox. A distinctive
feature is the way of worship: outward sacraments are not observed and there
is no separate ministry. The Society places great emphasis on work for peace,
and their influence in many parts of the world, especially in social reform and
in the relief of suffering, is very wide in relation to their numbers. There are
440 Quaker Meetings in Britain and nearly 21,000 members; and the Society
has nine schools (the pupils and staff of which are not exclusively Quaker).
The Salvation Army, founded in 1865 (as the Christian Mission), is a
religious movement, composed of men and women who seek the spiritual and
social betterment of their fellows, primarily by preaching the gospel to those
hitherto untouched by religious effort. The movement, which is quasi-
military in structure, carries out its work in 71 countries. Internationally it
provides a greater variety and volume of social service than any other single
voluntary society.
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints first came to Britain in
1837 and has some 85,000 members; the Christian Scientists, who emphasise
the Christian ministry of healing, have about 320 branch churches and
societies in Britain.
The Roman Catholic hierarchy in England and Wales, which became
temporarily extinct during the sixteenth century, was restored in 1850; the
Scottish hierarchy became extinct in the early seventeenth century and was
restored in 1878, while the Irish hierarchy never became completely extinct.
The normal government of the Roman Catholic Church, namely the territorial
archbishops and bishops, is once again the rule in the whole of the United
Kingdom.
The central territorial unit of the Roman Catholic hierarchical organisation
is the province or archdiocese under the metropolitan, who is always an
archbishop. A province normally comprises several dioceses, each under a
bishop aided by a chapter of canons and others, and by priests in charge of
the parishes into which the diocese is subdivided. In England and Wales
there are five provinces and archdioceses (Westminster, Liverpool, Birming¬
ham, Cardiff and Southwark), 14 dioceses, and nearly 2,400 parishes (the
chairman of the Bishops’ Conference in England and Wales is the Archbishop
of Westminster); in Scotland there are two provinces and archdioceses (St.
Andrews and Edinburgh, and Glasgow), six dioceses, and about 400 parishes;
i88
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
in Northern Ireland there are six dioceses (several of which have territory
partly in the Irish Republic and partly in Northern Ireland since there is one
hierarchy for the whole of Ireland) and about 170 parishes. In the whole of
the United Kingdom there are some 6 million adherents (including children)
to the Roman Catholic faith.
The Roman Catholic Church attaches great importance to the education of
its children in their own faith, and requires that the children of marriages
between its own members and members of any other denomination should be
brought up as Roman Catholics. Many schools for Roman Catholic children
in the United Kingdom are staffed by members of the religious orders for men
and women, who also undertake other social work such as nursing, child care,
and the conduct of homes for old people.
Jewry Jews first settled in England at the time of the Norman conquest, but were
expelled at the end of the thirteenth century by an edict of Edward I. The
present Anglo-Jewish community dates from 1656, the earliest arrivals being
the Sephardi (from Spain and Portugal). At the end of the seventeenth
century an Ashkenazi community (from Germany and East Europe) was
established, which increased rapidly and spread to the principal provincial
cities. As a result of the virtual destruction of whole Jewish communities on
the Continent during the second world war, the Anglo-Jewish community of
some 410,000 has become the third largest group of Jews in Europe.
The Anglo-Jewish community is divided into two schools of thought, each
of which has its own form of worship and its own services: the Orthodox (the
original groups) and the Reform. The Reform Movement, which does not
insist on the permanently binding character of Jewish law and therefore
attaches less religious importance to some of the traditional rituals and
practices of the Jewish faith, began in 1840. It was followed in 1901 by the
establishment of the Liberal Jewish Movement which made the breach with
the traditional section wider by laying emphasis on the reinterpretation of
traditional Judaism in the light of modern thought and custom. Of the Jews
in Great Britain who belong to any kind of synagogue, about 90 per cent
are Orthodox. The Chief Rabbi is the head of the largest group (Ashkenazi)
within Orthodox Jewry; the Haham is the head of the Sephardi group.
Synagogues in Britain number about 300. There has been an increase in the
number of Jewish denominational schools, which are now attended by about
one in five Jewish children; other Jewish children attend the ordinary State or
independent schools and extra-curricular instruction in Hebrew and religious
subjects is provided at synagogue classes.
Other Religious Many immigrants to Britain from overseas Commonwealth countries and
Communities foreign countries have established centres for worship for their own com¬
munities in the United Kingdom, and especially in London. The Christian
communities include the Greek, Russian, Polish and Serb Orthodox, with
some Estonian and Latvian Orthodox, and also the Armenian Church. There
are also churches belonging to the Lutheran Churches of Denmark, Finland,
Germany, Norway and Sweden, and centres where Estonian, Latvian and
Polish Lutherans worship according to their creed. In addition, the French,
Dutch, Swiss, Hungarian and Polish Reformed Churches are represented in
Britain, the first three having their own places of worship. There are also a
number of other religious sects of British or foreign origin; figures of member¬
ship in Britain of most of them are not available.
The Muslims
The Buddhists
Co-operation
between the
Churches
THE CHURCHES 189
The principal non-Christian communities in Britain, apart from the Jews,
are the Muslims and the Buddhists.
The Muslims are the more widely represented, their number in Britain being
estimated at about half a million, of whom some 90,000 are in London
where the London Central Mosque and Islamic Cultural Centre, the Shiah
Islamic Assembly Centre and the East London Mosque are situated. The
Shah Jehan Mosque is at Woking, Surrey, and there are mosques or Islamic
centres in Manchester, Liverpool, Bradford, Cardiff and in many of the other
larger cities in Britain.
There are several thousand adherents of Buddhism in Britain. The Buddhist
Society has its headquarters in London, with a Shrine Room; there are also
Shrine Rooms in the three Viharas in London, one of which is run by Thai
monks and supported by the Thai Government. In Scotland there is a
Shrine Room at the Tibetan Centre.
The British Council of Churches, composed of official representatives or
consultant observers from almost all the Christian Churches in the British
Isles and presided over by the Archbishop of Canterbury, facilitates common
action between the Churches and seeks to further the cause of Christian unity.
The Free Church Federal Council (which has a concordat with the British
Council of Churches) comprises most of the Free Churches in England and
Wales and aims to promote unity and joint action among the Free Churches
and to provide a channel through which the Churches can communicate and
negotiate with central and local government authorities. The Anglican-Roman
Catholic Permanent Joint Commission explores points of possible unity
between the two Churches. Proposals for union between the Anglican and
Methodist Churches, which have gained a large measure of support, have not
yet been finally accepted. A union between the Congregational and Presby¬
terian Churches has also been proposed.
The Anglican, Presbyterian and Free Churches in the British Isles also
participate in the World Council of Churches, which links together nearly
240 churches in over 70 countries for co-operation and the study of common
problems. The Council of Christians and Jews works for better under¬
standing among members of the two religions and deals with problems in the
social field.
The New English Bible, which was completed in 1970, is a translation
into modern English; in its preparation there was co-operation between
representatives of the Church of England, the Church of Scotland, the Church
in Wales, the Free Churches, the Churches of Ireland and bible societies.
The Sharing of Church Buildings Act 1969 enables agreements to be made
by two or more Churches for the sharing of church buildings.

SCIENCES AND
THE ARTS
THE PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES
The Government is the main source of funds for scientific research and
development as a whole though private industry contributes a larger propor¬
tion of funds for civil research and development. Considerable sums are also
provided by public corporations, independent trusts and foundations, and
learned societies. The Government also keeps under review facilities for
training scientists and ensures that adequate research is directed to matters of
national interest.
THE GOVERN¬
MENT AND
SCIENTIFIC
RESEARCH
The Pattern of
Expenditure
Central Advisory
Council for
Science and
Technology
According to Statistics of Science and Technology Ity6g (see Bibliography,
p. 479) total expenditure in Britain on scientific research and development has
risen from ^657-7 million in 1961-62, £771‘4 million in 1964-65, ^926-3
million in 1966-67 to ^962-1 million in 1967-68, while remaining at about 2-7
per cent of the gross national product at factor cost. Even though there are
various discontinuities in these years the proportions of total research and
development carried out in the various sectors have not changed appreciably
since 1964-65 with the Government (including the research councils)
carrying out 25 per cent and universities and establishments of further educa¬
tion between 7 and 8 per cent. The proportion of research and development
financed by the Government remained at about 50 per cent in 1967-68, a
decline in defence research and development being balanced by the rise in
civil research and development. The total grant-in-aid to the research councils
for 1969-70 amounted to about £96 million.
The Central Advisory Council for Science and Technology was established in
January 1967, under the chairmanship of the Chief Scientific Adviser to the
Government, to advise the Government on the most effective national strategy
for the use and development of the country’s scientific and technological
resources. The Council includes members who are also members of the
Council for Scientific Policy (see p. 191), the Advisory Council on Technology
(see p. 191), and the Royal Society (see p. 193), and independent members.
Under the Science and Technology Act 1965 central responsibility for
basic and applied civil science rests with the Secretary of State for Education
and Science, who, advised by a Council for Scientific Policy in relation to
the natural sciences as a whole, is responsible for directing and financing the
research councils (see p. 191). Responsibility for technology rests with the
Minister of Technology, who is advised by an Advisory Council on Techno¬
logy. Other government departments are responsible for research and
development related to their executive responsibilities.
The Department
of Education
and Science
The Department of Education and Science (see also p. 50) is responsible,
among other things, for Government policy regarding the universities and for
promoting civil science throughout Great Britain. The Department’s relations

In the exercise of his responsibilities for the formulation and execution ox

for Scientific Policy (CSP), which replaced the former Advisory Council on
Scientific Policy. The Council, which was set up in January 1965, consists of
a chairman and 13 independent members. There are, in addition, assessors
from the research councils and from the University Grants Committee.
Among the issues with which the Council is concerned is the balance of
scientific effort in those areas for which the Secretary of State is responsible.
The Ministry of Technology (see also p. 56), which came formally into being
in 1964, took over responsibility for the United Kingdom Atomic Energy
Authority (AEA) (see p. 200) and the National Research Development
Corporation (see p. 205). On the dissolution of the Department of Scientific
and Industrial Research (DSIR) in 1965 many of its functions and resources
were transferred to the Ministry, which in February 1967 incorporated the
functions and responsibilities of the former Ministry of Aviation with the
exception of those civil aviation responsibilities which were transferred to
the Board of Trade (see p. 57). As a result of changes announced in October
1969, the Ministry of Technology absorbed the Ministry of Power, together
with certain industrial functions of the Board of Trade and of the former
Department of Economic Affairs. Its responsibilities now include the sponsor¬
ship of most industries in both the public and private sectors.
The Ministry, among other things, has responsibility for engineering
standards and weights and measures for the British Standards Institution
(see p. 249) and for the Metrication Board set up in 1969 to facilitate the transi¬
tion to the metric system of weights and measures in Britain by 1975 (see
p. 467). It has direct control of a number of research stations and establish¬
ments (see p. 197); it also aids with grants 43 autonomous industrial research
associations (see p. 197).
The Minister of Technology is chairman of the Advisory Council on Tech¬
nology, set up to advise on the application of advanced technology in British
industry. There is a deputy chairman and 14 other members, representing
scientific, economic, trade union and industrial interests.
Three new advisory boards to replace steering committees were created in
1969 in consultation with the Royal Society (see p. 193) an<^ Confederation
of British Industry (see p. 242) to advise the Minister of Technology on
matters relating exclusively to three research establishments. Advisory
committees were also set up to advise on certain research programmes.

A number of other government departments remain responsible for certain
branches of research.
The Ministry of Transport is concerned with research and development
relating to inland transport and ports. Research into road construction,
traffic flow and safety is carried out mainly at the Ministry’s Road Research
Laboratory (see p. 340) at Crowthorne, Berkshire. There are also collaborative
arrangements for research in inland transport with the Ministry of Tech¬
nology. Economic, technical and operational research studies are carried out
in the Ministry of Transport’s headquarters and some are commissioned also
from consultants and universities. The Ministry of Technology is responsible
for sponsoring research and development in aviation.
Research on radio aids for marine navigation is undertaken by the Ministry
of Defence, which is also responsible for inter-Service electronic valve
research at the Services Electronics Research Laboratory. Research on marine
nuclear propulsion is undertaken by the AEA. The Civil Aviation Research
and Development Board was set up in February 1970 by the President of the
Board of Trade in consultation with the Minister of Technology to co-ordinate
research and development work for civil aviation equipment other than aircraft
and engines.
The Ministry of Technology (see pp. 56 and 191) is responsible for research
into safety and health of mineworkers. The coal, electricity and gas industries
are required to settle their general programmes of research in consultation
with the Minister, who is assisted by an Advisory Council on Research and
Development. Similar provisions apply to the British Steel Corporation’s
general programme of research and technological development.
The Ministry of Defence finances the Meteorological Office, which is respon¬
sible for research in meteorology and geophysics, mainly for civil purposes.
The headquarters of the Office and most of its research sections are at
Bracknell, Berkshire. The Ministry also makes grants for fundamental
meteorological research carried out under the auspices of the Royal Society or
in university departments.
The Ministry of Public Building and Works has a Directorate General of
Research and Development (see p. 273) and is responsible for the Building
Research Station, Garston, Watford, Hertfordshire, which is concerned with
the techniques of building design and construction, and the organisation,
productivity and economics of building work.
A permanent Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution, with a mem¬
bership which includes the Chief Scientific Adviser to the Government, was
set up in December 1969 to advise on matters both national and international
concerning the pollution of the environment; on the adequacy of research;
and the future possibilities of the danger to the environment. There is also a
small central advisory unit within the Cabinet Office, consisting mainly of
scientists, to co-ordinate matters related to the prevention of environmental
pollution.
A Clean Air Council was set up in 1956 and an Advisory Council on Noise
in 1970.
The Ministry of Housing and Local Government sponsors certain geo¬
graphical, geological, economic and sociological research relating to the use
and development of land in England. Similar arrangements are made in
Scotland by the Scottish Home and Health Department, in Wales by the
Welsh Office, and in Northern Ireland by the Ministry of Development. A

THE LEARNED
SOCIETIES
Royal Society
Centre for Environmental Studies has been set up as an independent educa¬
tional trust for research into the problems of urban planning and dealing with
the effects of a fast-growing mobile population.
The Post Office undertakes research and development on many aspects of the
science and engineering of communications, both in its own laboratories and
in close association with industry, the universities and government depart¬
ments. The main research station is at Dollis Hill, London, and there are
laboratories at Backwell, near Bristol, at Castleton, near Cardiff, and also at
Martlesham, near Ipswich, where a new research station is being built.
The Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew (founded in 1759), together with its
400-acre estate at Wakehurst Place, Ardingly, Sussex, is administered by
the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and has the largest collection
of living plants in the world. Its research departments are: the herbarium,
concerned primarily with the classification and accurate determination of
plants; and the Jodrell Laboratory, for the study of plant anatomy and plant
physiology, cytology and genetics. There are two museums concerned mainly
with the economic exploitation of plants. The library, attached to the
herbarium, was founded in 1852; it consists of more than 100,000 botanical
books, about 140,000 reprints and separately issued items and a collection of
over 160,000 drawings and paintings of plants. The Royal Botanic Garden,
Edinburgh, founded about 1660, has, since April 1969, been administered
by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland.
A Select Committee of the House of Commons on Science and Technology
was set up in December 1966. It is one of the specialist committees established
to give back-bench Members the opportunity to investigate the policies and
administration of the Government and to participate in the formation of
policy. The Members of the Committee (not more than 15 in number) are
nominated by the House. The Committee has power to call witnesses,
generally takes evidence in public, and reports its findings to the House from
time to time. Its functions, together with those of other Select Committees,
are being re-examined by the Government.
The Parliamentary and Scientific Committee, founded in 1939, provides for a
regular exchange of information between members of Parliament and
scientists. Membership is open to members of Parliament of any party in both
Houses, and also to nominated representatives of such non-profit-making
scientific and technological organisations in Britain as may be affiliated under
its constitution.
Although today most research is conducted under other auspices, the learned
societies have retained their traditional function of facilitating the spread of
knowledge. At present there are over 200 of them in Britain with approxi¬
mately 400 scientific publications. The most eminent of those concerned with
science in its broadest aspects (as distinct from those societies with specialised
interests and activities) are the Royal Society, Royal Society of Arts, Royal
Institution and British Association.
The Royal Society, or, more fully, the Royal Society of London for the
Improvement of Natural Knowledge, founded in 1660, occupies a unique
place in the country’s scientific affairs and corresponds to national academies
of sciences in other countries. Election to it is regarded by scientists as a high
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
I94
honour. The Queen is Patron. There are today three main categories of
Fellowship: Royal Fellows, comprising the Queen Mother and three Royal
Dukes; Foreign Members, of whom there are about 70, and the main body of
Fellows numbering about 730. Election to the Fellowship, which is for life,
was for many years restricted to 25 persons a year and the foreign membership
to four a year but in 1965 the former was increased to 32 with the intention of
awarding some of the new places to applied scientists in both the physical and
biological sciences. The Society is governed by a council of 21 members.
Its activities include the holding of scientific meetings; publication of
research work, mainly in the Philosophical Transactions and the Proceedings',
the presentation of medals; the giving of endowed lectures; and the award of
research appointments and grants. Among its research appointments are the
Foulerton, Wolfson and Sir Henry Dale Research Professorships and ten
other research professorships supported by parliamentary grant-in-aid, The
highest medal awarded is the Copley Medal, for which scientists from all
countries are eligible; there are also three Royal Medals, and the Rumford,
Darwin, Buchanan, Sylvester, Hughes, Leverhulme and Mullard Medals.
There are six lectureships: the Croonian (biology); the Bakerian (physical
sciences); the Ferrier (nervous system); the Wilkins (history of science); the
Leeuwenhoek (microbiology); and the Bernal (social functions of science).
The Society has set up committees, some of them jointly with other bodies, to
promote improvements in education in science and to emphasise the
importance of applied sciences, especially engineering.
Although an independent private corporation, the Society has always had
a special relationship with the Government, which makes grants for certain of
its activities. The President of the Society is consulted on scientific appoint¬
ments to government research councils and Fellows serve on most govern¬
mental advisory councils and committees concerned with research.
The international relations of the Royal Society are extensive. It represents
the United Kingdom in the international unions comprising the International
Council of Scientific Unions and appoints national committees for each of
them. It also plays a leading part in international scientific programmes such
as the International Biological Programme (1965-70), and promotes exchange
visits of scientists with many academies throughout the world. Its Inter¬
national Fellowship Scheme to foster relations with scientists of Western
European and other countries receives financial support from the Government
and other sources.
Royal Society The Royal Society of Arts (properly, the Royal Society for the Encouragement
of Arts of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce) has a character at once scientific,
artistic, technical, industrial and commercial. Since its foundation in 1754, one
of the Society’s principal objects has been to promote the progress and
application to useful ends of all departments of science. Today it fulfils this
purpose chiefly by disseminating new scientific knowledge. The Society
regularly holds lectures, and publishes a monthly Journal, thus providing
effective media for the exposition and assessment by leading authorities of
developments which have a public as well as a specialist interest.
Royal
Institution
The Royal Institution was founded in 1799 as a public body for facilitating
the introduction of useful mechanical inventions and improvements, and for
teaching the application of science to everyday life. Later it undertook the
‘promotion of chemical science by experiments and lectures for improving
arts and manufactures’, and ‘the diffusion and extension of useful knowledge’.

195
British
Association
Professional
Institutions
THE UNIVER¬
SITIES AND
INSTITUTIONS
OF UNIVERSITY
STATUS
Its character, however, was largely determined by the work of Sir Humphry
Davy and Michael Faraday, who established a tradition of research. Today,
the Royal Institution has extensive research laboratories, and lectures are
given on recent developments in science and other branches of knowledge. Its
library includes many early scientific works and manuscripts.
The British Association for the Advancement of Science was founded in 1831
to promote general interest in science and its applications. One of its chief
activities is the Annual Meeting, attended by many young students as well as
by eminent scientists. In addition the Association plans special lectures,
exhibitions and discussions (some designed for young audiences), the publica¬
tion of pamphlets, the organisation of conferences, the appointment of study
groups and liaison with the Press and with sound and television broadcasting
services. The Association has area committees and three lectureships for
young scientists—-the Kelvin, the Darwin and the Lister lectureships, dealing
respectively with the physical, biological and sociological sciences—to
encourage scientists to make their activities known to wider audiences. The
British Association has an organised relationship with over 150 scientific
bodies and learned societies. It has also made an important contribution to the
development of science by taking or recommending action to remove obstacles
to the discovery and application of scientific knowledge.
There are numerous technical institutions and professional associations, many
of which are playing a distinguished part in promoting their own disciplines
or are interested in the education and professional well-being of their members.
The Council of Engineering Institutions, the federal body for the chartered
engineering institutions established in 1965, promotes the co-ordination of the
engineering profession. The Council of Science and Technology Institutes—
a federal body with five member institutes representing biologists, chemists,
mathematicians, metallurgists and physicists—was formed in 1969.
Of total estimated university expenditure on research in the Academic year
1968-69 (over £80 million), the largest government contribution (£52-5
million) was through the University Grants Committee (UGC) (see p. 159).
Scientific research in the universities is also supported through the research
councils. This support takes two forms. First, about half the postgraduate
students in science and technology in the universities receive maintenance
awards from the research councils, through postgraduate scholarships,
studentships or fellowships. These awards are in some cases for periods of up
to three years for training in research work and in others for shorter periods
for advanced studies. The cost of these awards is currently about ^8-3 million
a year. Second, grants are given to the universities by the research councils
for specific projects, particularly in new or developing fields of research. In
recent years the research councils, in addition to making grants of this kind,
have made funds available for expensive items of university equipment
required for specific programmes of research. The research councils’ support
for research in the universities, excluding expenditure by the Medical
Research Council and the Agricultural Research Council on their own research
units within the universities (which remain under the control of, and are
wholly financed by, the councils) amounted in 1969-70 to £277 million.
The other main channels of support for scientific research in the universities
are various government departments, the Royal Society, industry and the
independent foundations. The contributions from sources other than the
196 BRITAIN I97i: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
University Grants Committee amount to nearly a third of the total university
expenditure on research.
Universities in industrial centres have tended to acquire outstanding
reputations in studies relating to their local industries, and on a national scale
close relationships are fostered between the universities, industries and the
Government in numerous joint projects. The Ministry of Technology’s
industrial liaison officers (see p. 204) are based on universities or technical
colleges. Six Industrial Units have been opened (five at universities and one at
the College of Aeronautics, Cranfield) under a Ministry of Technology scheme.
They offer consultancy and research and development resources and are
expected to become self-supporting within a few years.
Statistics of
Qualified
Manpower
Of those in employment in Great Britain in 1966 there were 93,490 persons
holding at least a degree or an equivalent qualification in medicine, dentistry
or health. Of these 74-9 per cent were employed in medical and dental services,
13-8 per cent in distributive trades and 3-9 per cent in education. Of the
192,940 persons qualified in engineering and technology 41-2 per cent were
employed in manufacturing industry, 9-5 per cent in construction, 9-3 per cent
in public administration and defence, 8 per cent in scientific and technical
services and 7-4 per cent in education. There were also 122,790 persons
qualified in science (including agriculture) of whom 417 per cent were
employed in education, 27-3 per cent in manufacturing industry, 7 per cent in
research and development services and 5-1 per cent in public administration
and defence.
SCIENCE
RESEARCH
COUNCIL
The Science Research Council (SRC), which came into formal existence on
1st April 1965 and consists of a chairman and up to 15 other members, covers
all branches of fundamental science other than those for which the other
research councils are responsible. It also supports research projects in the
universities and technical colleges. Provision is made for it to carry out research
and development through its own establishments; to encourage and support
similar research by any other person or body; to provide and operate equip¬
ment for common use by universities, technical colleges and similar institu¬
tions ; to make grants for postgraduate studies; and to disseminate knowledge
of science and technology. Its establishments include the Royal Greenwich
Observatory, Herstmonceux, the Royal Observatory, Edinburgh, the Radio
and Space Research Station, the Rutherford High Energy Laboratory, the
Daresbury Nuclear Physics Laboratory, the Atlas Computer Laboratory, and
the Astrophysics Research Unit at the Culham Laboratory. The SRC also
co-ordinates the British scientific space research programme (see p. 201) and
provides the United Kingdom contribution to the European Organisation
for Nuclear Research (CERN) and the European Space Research Organisation
(ESRO).
INDUSTRIAL The greater part of industrial research in Britain is undertaken in government
RESEARCH establishments and in the research organisations of the larger firms. Research
organisations in industry vary widely between the largest firms employing
thousands of qualified staff and some employing very few; though the
emphasis is on commercial development, some fundamental research is done.
Other main agencies are universities and technical colleges, industrial
research associations, independent institutes for sponsored research and
consultant laboratories.

The Ministry of Technology’s net total expenditure for 1969-70 on its
establishments was about £53-9 million, made up of about £11-6 million for
the ten industrial research establishments and £42-3 million for the eight
aviation establishments; these figures include £o-8 million in respect of the
Safety in Mines Research Establishment. Most of the latter was on supporting
and monitoring contracts with industry for developing defence projects. Of
the Ministry’s total expenditure on research and development (excluding the
AEA) less than one-fifth is spent in Ministry establishments. Its non¬
industrial staff numbered about 25,600 on 1st January 1970 including about
3,100 qualified scientists and engineers employed on research and develop¬
ment. These resources are estimated to represent the largest block of research
and development facilities and manpower available to any government outside
the United States and the Soviet Union.
Besides research and development for industry the industrial research
establishments are engaged on the application of techniques and discoveries to
design, production, quality control, distribution, marketing and sales. In
addition, there are the industrial research associations grant-aided by the
Ministry of Technology.
The scheme by which the Government gives financial help to groups of firms
with similar interests to form organisations known as research associations, to
carry out industrial research co-operatively, was started in 1917 and is now
operated by the Ministry of Technology. There are now 43 such associations,
with a combined income of ^15 million (compared with £5-1 million in 1955),
of which a little more than a quarter was contributed by the Government.
Suitably specialised associations are now available for about 50 per cent of
British industry. The largest are those dealing with ships, production
engineering, electrical manufacturing, cotton and man-made fibres, welding
and scientific instruments. (Particulars of these and other associations are
given in Chapter 11, Industry.) The amounts of the government grants are
related to the contributions made by the industries concerned.
The research associations are autonomous bodies governed by their own
councils, the members of which are mostly representatives of industry,
although the Ministry of Technology is also represented. The councils are
advised in preparing research programmes, for which they have complete
responsibility, by research committees representative of their industrial
members, often with the addition of university or government scientists.
Nearly all research associations admit to membership manufacturers in
Commonwealth countries and many also admit those in foreign countries.
A Conference of Industrial Research Associations was set up in 1969.
Some of the public corporations which run the nationalised industries have
their own research organisations (see Chapter 11), in particular those con¬
cerned with fuel and power, steel and transport. They also give support to
organisations concerned with research on matters of interest to them.
According to Statistics of Science and Technology igjo, expenditure on research
and development carried out within private industry (excluding enterprises of
less than 25 employees) in 1967-68 was as follows (in f million): aerospace
163-1; electronics 105-6; other electrical engineering 30-4; petroleum products
10-9; other chemical products 71-4; mechanical engineering 51-3; motor
vehicles 44; scientific instruments 12-7; food, drink and tobacco 18-1;
textiles io-8. For these groups the increase since 1966-67 was 3 per cent.

MEDICAL

BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
These figures include funds from government sources. Firms in science-
based industries commit large private funds to research and development in
the course of business.
A number of institutes for sponsored research have been established to
extend the facilities for private research for industrial firms by studying
problems which are not within the scope of the average industrial laboratory.
In these institutes research for private firms is carried out confidentially, the
results remaining the property of the sponsor.
A Medical Research Committee was appointed in 1913 to administer the
research funds provided under the National Health Insurance Act 1911. In
1920 the Committee was superseded by the Medical Research Council
(MRC), established under Royal Charter and supported by a grant-in-aid
provided by Parliament, now through the Secretary of State for Education and
Science. The MRC was granted a new charter in 1966.
In addition to financing the MRC, the Government gives substantial
support to medical research through block grants to universities distributed
through the University Grants Committee; and to clinical research through
the National Health Service. Certain government-financed research for defence
purposes, for example, at the Microbiological Establishment at Porton,
Wiltshire, has civil applications related to medical science.
Important contributions to the support of research in particular subjects
are made by industry, especially the pharmaceutical industry, and by private
charities or voluntary organisations, such as the Nuffield Foundation and the
British Empire Cancer Campaign.
The Medical Research Council is responsible to the Secretary of State for
Education and Science and consists of a Chairman, a Deputy Chairman, and
from 10 to 14 other members. Not less than three-quarters must be scientific¬
ally qualified, representative of the different branches of medical knowledge
and actively engaged in research. All members are appointed by the Secretary
of State, the scientific members after consultation with the President of the
Royal Society and the existing Council; and the Chairman and Deputy
Chairman after consultation with the Council.
The MRC’s chief function is to promote research into all aspects of health
and disease. In planning and carrying out its research programme the Council
is assisted by bodies specially appointed to advise on particular subjects.
Three of the more important of these are the Clinical Research Board, set up
in consultation with the health departments to assist the development of
clinical research; the Tropical Medicine Research Board, appointed in
consultation with the Ministry of Overseas Development, to advise on the
promotion and co-ordination of research in this field; and the Biological
Research Board, which advises on the promotion of research in the non-
clinical field. In addition, the MRC is advised by committees concerned with
particular aspects of its work. The MRC’s arrangements for the support of
research fall under four main headings: (1) investigations by members of its
scientific staff, mostly working in its own establishments; (2) short-term
grants to workers in universities and elsewhere; (3) long-term grants in sup¬
port of specific research programmes in university medical departments
(‘research groups’); and (4) fellowships and scholarships tenable both at home
and abroad. The research undertaken ranges from basic biological research at
the molecular level and the extensive laboratory work that forms the scientific

Agricultural
Research

Government

PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS IQ9
basis of the practice of medicine to the study of patients and epidemiological
and population surveys carried out in the field.
The National Institute for Medical Research, at Mill Hill and Hampstead,
London, is the MRC’s main research establishment. Its clinical counterpart,
the Clinical Research Centre is being built at Northwick Park in north-west
London (the first patients were admitted in 1970) as an integral part of the
new district hospital for the North West Metropolitan Regional Hospital
Board. In addition the Council has over 70 smaller establishments, known as
research units, which are in most cases located in university departments,
medical schools and hospitals in Britain.
The MRC also undertakes work overseas and, with additional support
from the Ministry of Overseas Development, maintains laboratories in The
Gambia and units in Uganda and Jamaica.
Agricultural research is carried out by the Agricultural Research Council, the
government agricultural departments and by private industry.
The Agricultural Research Council (ARC), established in 1931, consists of not
less than 15 and not more than 18 members, including the Chief Veterinary
Officer and certain appointments made by the Ministers of the agricultural
departments. In addition to distinguished scientists, the membership includes
people with practical farming experience. The ARC is under the general
oversight of the Secretary of State for Education and Science.
The ARC is responsible for 14 independent state-aided agricultural
research institutes and also has eight institutes under its direct control and
14 units which it has established under distinguished scientists associated with
universities. Also there are eight independent institutes in Scotland financed
by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland with advice
from the ARC on their scientific programmes, staffing and equipment.
The ARC makes special research grants to support promising new lines of
work in university departments. It awards a limited numbei of postgraduate
training awards for those wishing to undertake a career in veterinary research.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food carries out applied and basic
research in its own veterinary laboratories at Weybridge, Surrey, and at
Lasswade, Midlothian, and also at its plant pathology laboratory at Harpenden,
Hertfordshire; while at its infestation control laboratory at Tolworth, Surrey
(with a field station at Worplesdon), it co-ordinates work on the control of
insect pests of stored food and conducts research on the control of harmful
mammals and birds. The Central Veterinary Laboratory at Weybridge has
been appointed by the World Health Organisation (WHO) as the third
international laboratory for biological standards. In Scotland research work
at East Craigs, Edinburgh, by the Agricultural Scientific Services of the
Department of Agriculture and Fisheries is mainly concerned with the
problems of healthy seed potato production, seed pathology, cultivation,
taxonomy and vertebrate pest control. In Northern Ireland the Ministry of
Agriculture is responsible for the promotion of agricultural research and
has research divisions dealing with a variety of aspects.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food maintains four laboratories
for marine, shellfish, and salmon and freshwater fisheries research, and four
marine research vessels. The Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for
Scotland maintains a marine research laboratory and six research ships at
Aberdeen, and a freshwater fisheries research laboratory at Pitlochry.
