NUCLEAR
ENERGY
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
With the guidance of the Chief Scientific Adviser (Food), the Food
Standards and Sciences Division of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and
Food is responsible for formulating the Ministry’s general policy on the
acquisition and dissemination of scientific and technical information about
food and the food handling and processing industry; for furnishing scientific
advice to the other divisions of the Ministry; and for sponsoring or carrying
out experimental work. The division has its own experimental laboratories in
London and Norwich. The Food Research Advisory Committee advises on
food problems requiring investigation or research.
The Forestry Commission undertakes experimental work relating to
silvicultural and allied problems (see p. 325). By means of grants, it also aids
forest research work undertaken by various universities and other institutions,
including the Commonwealth Forestry Institute, Oxford.
The United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority (AEA), set up under the
Atomic Energy Authority Act 1954, is responsible for research and develop¬
ment in nuclear energy. It is answerable to the Minister of Technology, who
is responsible under the Atomic Energy Acts 1946 and 1949 for promoting and
controlling the development of nuclear energy and ensuring that the proper
degrees of importance are attached to its various applications. As an essential
part of the British Government’s nuclear power programme, the AEA has
carried out research and developed new types of nuclear power stations for
the generation of electric power on a commercial scale and for this purpose it
builds and operates experimental and prototype nuclear reactors. Construc¬
tion of commercial nuclear power stations is carried out by industry to the
order of the electricity generating boards which operate them. Two new
design and construction companies, with AEA participation, to design and
construct nuclear power stations were formed in 1968 and 1969. Under the
Science and Technology Act 1965 the functions of the AEA have been
extended so that the Minister may, after consultation, require it to undertake
research and development outside nuclear energy. Non-nuclear work is
absorbing a rising proportion of the AEA’s research resources and includes
research into desalination, hydrostatic extrusion, satellite design, biological
centrifuges, tribology, non-destructive testing, ceramics, atmospheric pollu¬
tion, biomedical technology and carbon fibres.
As at present constituted the AEA has a London office, a Radiochemical
Centre at Amersham (producing and marketing radioisotopes) and estab¬
lishments divided into the Research, Weapons, Reactor and Production
groups.
The Secretary of State for Defence became responsible for the development
and production of nuclear weapons for the Services in 1966; in practice,
however, the AEA produces the explosive nuclear material and assemblies for
nuclear weapons under contract and carries out weapons research.
The Department of Education and Science and the AEA collaborate with
a number of other government departments and with the Radiological
Protection Service on various aspects of health and safety in relation to atomic
energy. Expert advice on radiation hazards is provided by the Medical and
Agricultural Research Councils and by the Radioactive Substances Advisory
Committee, appointed by the Secretary of State for Education and Science.
The Radiological Protection Act 1970, provides for a national Radiological
Protection Board which will amalgamate the Radiological Protection Service
and part of the AEA’s Central Health and Safety Branch. The Act also
provides for the Board to replace the Radioactive Substances Advisory
High Energy
Physics
SPACE
ACTIVITIES
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS 201
Committee. The Board will be funded by the Secretaries of State for Social
Services and for Scotland, the AEA and the Medical Research Council.
The Ministry of Technology and the AEA are jointly responsible for
co-operation with other countries in nuclear energy, partly through the
medium of bilateral agreements with a large number of individual countries
and partly through British membership of bodies such as the International
Atomic Energy Agency and the European Nuclear Energy Agency.
The provision of expensive facilities for research in high energy physics is the
function of the Science Research Council (see p. 196). The SRC establish¬
ments concerned are the Rutherford High Energy Laboratory, Chilton, with
a 7,000 million electron volt (MeV) proton synchrotron (particle accelerator),
completed in 1963, and the Daresbury Nuclear Physics Laboratory, Cheshire,
with a 4,000 MeV electron accelerator, completed in 1966.
Government responsibility for space activities is divided between the Secretary
of State for Education and Science, the Secretary of State for Defence, the
Minister of Technology and the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications.
Total expenditure on space activities in 1969—70 is estimated at about ^35
million; of this, some ^15 million represents contributions to international
bodies. Of these bodies two were set up to give European countries the
opportunity of participating more fully in space research and technology. The
European Space Vehicle Launcher Development Organisation (ELDO) was
established to develop large satellite launchers; the British Blue Streak has
been used as the launching vehicle for ELDO’s Europa rockets. The European
Space Research Organisation (ESRO) was founded to provide facilities for
scientific experiments in space; it has a programme of launchings of sounding
rockets and satellites of various sizes. Under two inter-related international
agreements reached in 1964 in Washington (being re-negotiated), Britain,
together with the US and other countries in Europe and elsewhere, is taking
part in International Telecommunications Satellite Consortium (Intelsat).
The Government announced in April 1968 that it could not undertake addi¬
tional financial commitment to ELDO but would be prepared to accept a
growth rate of up to 6 per cent a year for ESRO.
The execution of the civil scientific space research programme is the
responsibility of the Secretary of State for Education and Science, through
the Science Research Council.
Scientific space experiments are arranged by scientists in the universities
and in government research establishments, under the general supervision of
the Space Research Management Unit of the Science Research Council. The
Royal Society represents Britain in non-governmental international scientific
groups such as the Committee on Space Research (COSPAR) of the Inter¬
national Council of Scientific Unions (ICSU).
In addition, Britain is co-operating with the United States in a programme
which includes the launching of the Ariel series of satellites and the incorpora¬
tion of British experiments in US satellites. The third such artificial earth
satellite, Ariel 3, launched in May 1967, and the upper atmosphere Skylark
rockets used in the British national and the ESR.0 programmes were designed
and produced in Britain, as will be UK—\ due to be launched in I971*
The Ministry of Technology provides technical advice and support in
relation to the space research programme and space applications work; it is
responsible for executing satellite and sounding rocket programmes for
customer Departments and for the development of the space technology

BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
required in support of current and future programmes. The Ministry’s
National Space Technology Programme includes the development of experi¬
mental satellites and a launch vehicle {Black Arrow).
The Ministry of Technology leads the UK delegations to the European
Space Conference and also provides the UK representatives and contributions
to ELDO.
The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, through the Post Office, is
responsible for the use of satellites for civil communications purposes and
undertakes research work in connection with communications systems using
satellites. The Post Office ground stations at Goonhilly in Cornwall are among
the most successful in the world, and British firms have built and are building
such stations overseas.
The satellite prediction centre at the Radio and Space Research Station,
Slough, also the home of one of the three World Data Centres for space
research, co-ordinates optical tracking activities in Britain. Optical observation
of satellites is carried out regularly by many individual observers in Britain
and by the Royal Edinburgh Observatory’s outstation (see below); radio
tracking is undertaken at the Radio and Space Research Station and by radio
telescopes at Jodrell Bank and the Royal Radar Establishment at Malvern.
Large optical telescopes were first constructed in Britain by Herschel and
Rosse in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. The latest addition to the
equipment at Herstmonceux is the 98-inch Isaac Newton telescope, the largest
in Western Europe, completed in 1967. Grants by the SRC to the Radcliffe
Trustees have enabled British optical astronomers to have continued access to
the 74-inch telescope at the Radcliffe Observatory in South Africa for
observations in the southern skies. In April 1967 the SRC assumed responsi¬
bility for supporting and managing this telescope. The Royal Edinburgh
Observatory has been re-equipped with modern instrumentation for use in
stellar spectroscopy and photometry. The British and Australian Governments
are building jointly a 150-inch optical telescope in New South Wales.
Radio astronomy, developed since 1931, is carried out mainly at Cambridge
University, at the Jodrell Bank Experimental Station of Manchester University
in Cheshire, and at the Royal Radar Establishment at Malvern. Britain
occupies a pre-eminent position in this branch of research.
The Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) was established by
Royal Charter in June 1965 under the Science and Technology Act 1965 to
encourage, plan and conduct research in those sciences, both physical and
biological, that relate to man’s natural environment. The work of the NERC
falls into five main groups: the solid earth, its physical properties and mineral
resources (geology, geophysics and geochemistry); the inland waters and their
living resources (hydrology, freshwater biology, ecology and fisheries); the
terrestrial communities, their resources and amenities (terrestrial ecology,
forestry and conservation); the seas and oceans, their behaviour and their
living and mineral resources (oceanography, marine biology and ecology, and
fisheries); and the atmosphere (some aspects of meteorology). The Nature
Conservancy forms part of the NERC which is also responsible for the British
Antarctic Survey, the Institute of Geological Sciences, the Institute of
Hydrology, the National Institute of Oceanography, the Institute of Coastal
Oceanography and Tides, the Unit of Coastal Sedimentation; the Culture
Centre of Algae and Protozoa and the Research Vessel Unit. It is also respon¬
sible for supporting the Marine Biological Association, the Scottish Marine

Biological Association, the Freshwater Biological Association, the Fisheries
Helminthology Unit and the Marine Invertebrate Biology Unit, the Fisheries
Biochemical Research Unit and the Insect Pathology Unit.
Many of the activities of the NERC are related to university research in the
environmental sciences, which it supports by postgraduate training awards,
research grants and fellowships.
Further responsibilities of the NERC include the support of long-term
forestry research in consultation with the Forestry Commission; financial and
policy control of research in seismology and geomagnetism carried out by the
Meteorological Office; and the co-ordination of research in meteorology
generally with that carried out by the Meteorological Office.
The Social Science Research Council (SSRC) was set up in December 1965,
to encourage support and carry out research in, and to disseminate knowledge
about, the social sciences. It provides grants for research projects at univer¬
sities and other institutions, and makes training awards to postgraduate
students. The SSRC’s fields of interest include economics; political science;
psychology; social anthropology; social and economic statistics; sociology and
social administration; social science and government, education; management
and industrial relations; human geography planning and various aspects of a
wide range of other disciplines.
Several government departments have funds allocated for social research
related to their responsibilities, including the Home Office, which has a large
research unit which carries out a wide variety of sociological studies. The
Social Survey conducts sample survey enquiries at the request of government
departments and from time to time also carries out studies in collaboration
with universities and other independent research organisations.
Zoological research is among the activities of the world-famous Zoological
Gardens, extending over 34 acres in Regent’s Park, London, which were
opened by the Zoological Society of London in 1828. A natural zoo of 500
acres was opened in 1931 at Whipsnade, in Bedfordshire, by the Society.
Among other well-known zoos are those at Edinburgh, Bristol, Chester and
Dudley, and a small, private one at Chessington, Surrey.
The British Museum (Natural History) is the principal centre in the
Commonwealth for the general study of natural history; it has extensive
collections of extant and fossil animals and plants and of minerals, rocks and
meteorites. The Science Museum illustrates the development of pure and
applied science in all countries, but chiefly in Britain, which has always held
a leading place in engineering, agriculture, navigation, mining, aeronautics,
and in the development of industrial machinery and processes. The geology of
Britain is probably known in more exact detail than that of any other country
in the world, and the Geological Survey has an outstanding collection of
exhibits in its Geological Museum. These three museums are in South
Kensington, London. Other important collections are those of the Museum
of Science and Industry, in Birmingham, and the Museum of the History of
Science, at Oxford.
The dissemination of the results of research to other research workers and
to ultimate users has become a problem of some magnitude as the volume of
information has grown. The traditional method of scientific publication, in
which results are written up into papers and published in journals, is still
204
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Information
Services
the main means of communication among scientists. The leading learned
societies have for long been important agencies for communicating scientific
information.
A Libraries and Information Systems Branch was set up in the Department
of Education and Science in 1969 to concentrate the Department’s responsi¬
bilities in relation to libraries and information systems. The new Branch
includes the Office for Scientific and Technical Information (OSTI), set up
in 1965 to promote research; develop new techniques and systems; im¬
prove existing services and experiment with new ones; to stimulate training
of scientists for information work and in the use of information sources; and
help to co-ordinate information activities at home and overseas.
The National Lending Library for Science and Technology (NLL) at
Boston Spa, Yorkshire, also within the Department, aims to collect for loan
purposes all literature which is likely to be of interest to the practising
scientist and technologist, covering all branches of science and technology
(including agriculture and medicine) and, since 1967, the periodical literature
of the social sciences. Besides collecting all available translations of Russian
scientific literature the library is responsible for arranging the translation of
some Russian periodicals, books and articles. Details are published monthly
in the NLL Translations Bulletin. The Library acts as a centre for MEDLARS,
a computerised medical literature search service, produced by the US
National Library of Medicine. (A description of general library services which
also cater for scientific needs is given on p. 220.)
Aslib, representing special libraries and information units in industry,
government departments, universities, colleges and other institutions, carries
out research into the collection, utilisation and dissemination of information,
provides consultancy and advisory services and training courses and offers
members an enquiry and reference service covering all subjects. Publications
include directories to sources of information, research reports, handbooks and
monographs on information science. It also operates the Commonwealth Index
to Unpublished Translations.
The National Reference Library of Science and Invention, administered
by the British Museum, is at present divided between two separately housed
divisions. The Holborn Division, formerly the Patent Office Library, is one
of the great scientific libraries of the world. The Bayswater Division has
substantial collections, especially in the life sciences.
An Advisory Committee for Scientific and Technical Information was set
up in October 1965 to advise the Secretary of State for Education and Science
particularly in relation to the work of OSTI and the co-ordination of this
work with other government departments and independent organisations.
The Ministry of Technology and the AEA devote considerable sums to
advisory information services. The former has nine regional offices and
sponsors over 70 industrial liaison centres, based on universities or technical
colleges which make contacts with local industries to promote greater use
of existing scientific and technical knowledge. A Production Engineering
Advisory Service equipped with mobile demonstration units brings knowledge
of new techniques directly to the workshop floor. The grant-aided industrial
research associations circulate research reports and provide information
services to members. Besides information services provided by its various
groups, which include the Ceramics Centre and the Non-destructive Testing
Centre at Harwell, the AEA has an information centre at its London head¬
quarters, and a network of regional advisers on the use of radioisotopes.

In agriculture, the Commonwealth Agricultural Institutes and Bureaux
(see p. 206) provide abstracts and an information service in various branches
of agricultural science. The ARC publishes an Index of Agricultural Research
in Progress, and gives an account of current developments in its annual reports.
The advisory services of the agricultural departments bring research results
directly to the farmer.
Medical research results are communicated mainly through journals and
periodicals; but the MRC issues special reports and includes special articles
in its annual reports.
The National Research Development Corporation (NRDC), an independent
body for which the Minister of Technology has statutory responsibility, was
set up under the Development of Inventions Act 1948 to secure the develop¬
ment and exploitation of inventions in the public interest. The NRDC can
also assist research work where this is likely to lead to an invention. The limit
on the outstanding amount of Government advances to the NRDC, originally
£5 million, has been progressively increased to £50 million.
Projects so far sponsored include hovercraft, computers, advanced types of
electric motor, towed flexible barges (Dracones), diesel engines, insecticides,
fuel cells and antibiotics. NRDC is increasingly funding speculative projects
on a joint venture basis with industrial firms. NRDC support for hovercraft
development has been given mainly through a wholly owned subsidiary,
Hovercraft Development Ltd., which holds and manages the hovercraft
patents. Another subsidiary, Tracked Hovercraft Ltd., was formed in 1967 to
develop an air-cushioned tracked vehicle. NRDC is a minority shareholder
in the British Hovercraft Corporation Ltd., a company formed in 1966 to
design and build hovercraft.
Most government departments concerned with science and technology make
special arrangements for dealing with international scientific relations but the
DES, through its International Scientific Relations Division, has a number
of inter-departmental responsibilities including the recruitment and scientific
support of Britain’s scientific counsellors overseas, who are seconded to the
Diplomatic Service. In areas of non-governmental collaboration, the primary
representative of the United Kingdom is the Royal Society.
The Government is concerned with inter-governmental organisations.
These include: specialised agencies of the United Nations, for example, the
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO),
the World Health Organisation (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organisa¬
tion (FAO); nuclear energy, for example, the International Atomic Energy
Agency (IAEA), the European Nuclear Energy Agency (ENEA) and the
European Organisation for Nuclear Research (CERN); space research, for
example, ESRO; and the International Agency for Research on Cancer
(IARC). There are agreements between the United Kingdom AEA and other
atomic energy authorities, including that of the Soviet Union (and there are
permanent representatives of the United States Atomic Energy Commission
in London and of the United Kingdom AEA in Washington). Also, there are
inter-governmental agreements with Euratom, and bilateral agreements with
other countries. Britain is also represented on the three scientific committees
of the OECD.
Commonwealth The Commonwealth Scientific Committee (CSC) consisting of the heads of
Scientific the national research organisations of Commonwealth countries, formed in
Committee 1958 from the previous Standing Committee set up in 1946, meets biennially.

Operating under the CSC is an executive sub-committee, membership of
which consists of officials responsible for scientific matters in the Common¬
wealth Missions in London, and representatives from British Government
departments, the research councils and the Royal Society. There are various
specialist committees. The secretariat for the Committee and its executive
sub-committee is provided by the Commonwealth Scientific Liaison Offices.

A British Commonwealth Scientific Conference held in 1946 recommended
the continuance and extension of the scientific collaboration of the war years
by the creation of the Commonwealth Scientific Liaison Offices, a group at
present consisting of the Scientific Liaison Offices in London of Australia,
Canada and New Zealand together with the International Scientific Relations
Division of the Department of Education and Science.
Commonwealth The Commonwealth Agricultural Bureaux, financed by contributions from
Agricultural all Commonwealth countries, comprise four Institutes and nine Bureaux, all
Bureaux of which except one Institute are in Britain and each of which is concerned
with a particular branch of agricultural science. They act as clearing houses
for the interchange of information of value to research workers in agricultural
science throughout the Commonwealth and increasingly throughout the
world. Seventeen Abstract Journals, one Primary Journal and an Index are
published periodically and have a combined annual circulation of about 29,000
copies. The Institutes and Bureaux also issue monographs on their own
particular subjects and deal with enquiries received from research workers in
all parts of the Commonwealth.
Ministry of The Ministry of Overseas Development’s (ODM) promotion of scientific
Overseas research in the interests of developing countries covers specialist advice from
Development Britain, advisory visits, conferences for exchange of information, training
scientists from overseas in universities and research institutions in Britain,
recruiting scientific staff from Britain, and providing support for existing
research services and research projects overseas, for example, in East Africa
and the Caribbean. Some equipment is also given to encourage scientific
training and applied research. The Anti-Locust Research Centre in London,
internationally recognised as a world centre for locust research since 1931, is
part of ODM; and so is the Tropical Products Institute in London, which
aims at improving the economic viability of the less-developed tropical
countries, especially those within the Commonwealth, by research into new
uses for tropical plant and animal products. The ODM provides over £2
million a year for research for the benefit of developing countries.
The British The principal aims of the British Council (see p. 164) in the sciences (including
Council agriculture, medicine and technology) are to foster co-operation between
British scientists and scientists of other countries, to promote among overseas
specialists a better understanding and knowledge of Britain and its scientific
achievements, and, in the developing countries, to assist in curriculum reform
at school level and in the training of teachers of science and mathematics.
Much emphasis is placed on the interchange of scientists between Britain
and other countries. Overseas tours and advisory visits by British specialists
are arranged and scientists recruited for overseas posts. In the other direction
the Council invites senior specialists to Britain for visits and discussions with
British experts, and makes awards to postgraduate students; it also administers
the programmes of a large number of senior specialists and students who

travel to Britain under the auspices of the UN specialised agencies, or under
various bilateral technical assistance schemes, or as private individuals. The
Council is also responsible for administering travel grants awarded under the
Foreign and Commonwealth University Interchange Schemes.
Information on Britain’s scientific achievements is provided either through
the Council’s overseas libraries or direct from the London headquarters
which includes specialist departments (and libraries) for medicine and science.
Material published or compiled by these London departments includes
British Medical Journal, British Medical Book List, British Medical Index
(see also Bibliography, p. 479), and publications listing facilities for educa¬

THE PROMOTION OF THE ARTS
This section describes the assistance and encouragement given to the arts
by the Government, local authorities, voluntary societies and other organisa¬
tions. Although valuable support comes from private sources, including trusts
and commercial concerns, the Government and local authorities are taking an
increasingly active part. The Paymaster General under the general supervision
of the Secretary of State for Education and Science is responsible for the arts.
The Government considers that its role is not ‘to dictate taste or restrict the
liberty of even the most unorthodox and experimental of artists but to
support the arts so that a high level of artistic achievement can be sustained
and the best in the arts made more widely available (A Policy for the Arts, see
Bibliography, p. 480).
The main educational functions concerning the arts are carried out in
England and Wales through the Department of Education and Science, in
Scotland through the Scottish Education Department and in Northern
Ireland by the Ministry of Education. In partnership with local education
authorities and voluntary bodies, they are concerned with schools, colleges
of further education and community centres. The Department of Education
and Science is also concerned with public libraries in England and Wales
and is responsible for the Victoria and Albert Museum, and the Scottish
Education Department is responsible for the Royal Scottish Museum.
The Government aids the preservation of Britain’s cultural heritage by
means of grants which largely finance most of the national museums and
galleries; through the Ministry of Public Building and Works, which looks
after ancient monuments, and the Ministry of Housing and Local Government,
which is responsible for historic buildings; and by giving financial help to
independent bodies concerned with preservation, such as the National Trust.
General help for the arts is given through government grants for music,
drama, literature, painting and sculpture; these are channelled for the greater
part through the Arts Councils of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, which
contribute to the aspects of the arts not provided for by other agencies. Other
state-aided organisations include the British Film Institute and the Council of
Industrial Design.
Estimated government expenditure on the arts in Great Britain in 1970-71
is ^24-7 million. Direct allocations included ^9-3 million for the Arts Council
of Great Britain (j£i*i million more than in 1969-70) and about £9*8 million
for the running costs of national museums and galleries. In addition over
£3-3 million was allocated for the preservation of historic buildings and ancient
monuments.
The Arts Council of Great Britain was established in 1946 under a Royal
208

Local Support
Private
Contributions
Arts Festivals
and Regional
Arts
Associations
DRAMA
Charter. (A new charter was granted in 1967.) Its members are appointed by
the Secretary of State for Education and Science, in consultation with the
Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales. Its main objects are to develop
and improve the knowledge, understanding and practice of the arts, to increase
the accessibility of the arts to the public, and to advise and co-operate with
government departments, local authorities and other organisations.
The Arts Council of Northern Ireland, which has similar aims, receives a
grant from the Northern Ireland Government. In 1970-71 this grant
amounted to some £220,000.
The British Council (see footnote, p. 164) takes an active part in displaying
overseas the best in British drama, ballet, music and the visual arts.
Local authorities do valuable work in encouraging the arts. Under the Local
Government Act 1948 they may levy up to a sixpenny rate in England and
Wales for expenditure on entertainment in all its forms, including cultural
activities. By amending legislation (the Local Government (Scotland) Act
1966), the same rate applies to Scotland. They may also spend money on
buildings for the arts and provide and maintain museums and art galleries;
the Arts Councils are authorised to give financial help to house the arts. Many
towns support orchestras and theatres. The Greater London Council which,
as the London County Council, built the Royal Festival Hall, has agreed to
contribute equally with the Government towards the cost of the National
Theatre on the south bank of the Thames. Building work started in September
1969 and the theatre is expected to be completed in 1973.
Many voluntary bodies are concerned with promoting the arts and include
charitable trusts and foundations which give financial support. Industrial
patronage includes support from the independent television companies.
The arts benefit most when the patrons—central and local government,
voluntary bodies, industry, the universities and individuals—combine. The
outstanding example is the Edinburgh Festival Society. Other arts festivals
organised on a similar basis include those held in the City of London,
Aldeburgh, Bath, Belfast, Brighton, Cheltenham, Harrogate, King’s Lynn,
Leeds, Norwich and York.
Regional co-operation in arts patronage is growing with support from the
Government which encourages the formation of regional arts associations to
ensure that the whole range of the arts is more widely available to people
throughout the area. Such associations have been established in the north,
the north-west, Lincolnshire, the midlands, the south-west, Greater London,
southern England, north Wales and Yorkshire.
Government support for drama is given through the Arts Councils of Great
Britain and of Northern Ireland which grant subsidies to drama companies
which are registered as charities (that is, are non-profit making), provided
that such companies have given evidence of serious aims and of consistently
high standards of practical competence. The Arts Council of Great Britain
operates a scheme to promote new drama: guarantees may be offered to
managements giving the first professional production of selected new plays;
and promising authors may be awarded bursaries. Schemes are also in
operation to train stage designers, producers and those wishing to take up
theatre administration.
The British Council makes the British theatre better known abroad by
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS
209
Professional
Theatre
organising and sponsoring international tours by leading British theatre
companies and individual actors and producers, by sending overseas exhibi¬
tions of books dealing with the British theatre, and by providing newly pub¬
lished plays through its overseas libraries.
There are about 140 professional theatres in full-time use in Britain. Of these
some half are owned or rented by non-profit-making companies receiving Arts
Council subsidies, while the remainder are operated commercially. In 1969-70
Arts Council support for the theatre in Britain amounted to over ^2 million.
The centre of theatrical activity is in London where there are over 30
principal theatres in or near the West End and several more in the suburbs.
Most of the theatres are let to producing managements on a commercial basis
for each production, but there are four theatres occupied by important sub¬
sidised companies—the National Theatre Company, the Royal Shakespeare
Company, the English Stage Company and the Mermaid Theatre Company.
. The National Theatre Company was formed in 1963; it receives grants
towards its running costs from the Arts Council and from the Greater
London Council. Its repertoire consists of classical and modern plays from all
countries, and it is large enough to undertake simultaneous productions both
in London (where it plays at the Old Vic Theatre) and in the provinces or
overseas. The company will eventually occupy the new National Theatre
being built on the south bank of the Thames in London.
The Royal Shakespeare Company presents Shakespearean plays at the Royal
Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon, and international classical and
modern plays at the Aldwych Theatre, London. It will eventually have a per¬
manent London home in the proposed Barbican arts centre.
Outside London there are some 40 large commercial theatres in the main
cities of Britain and about 60 theatres occupied by subsidised ‘repertory
companies’. The commercial theatres, which accommodate pre- and post-
West End tours by the major London productions and by companies specially
formed for touring, have been declining in numbers, and several have now been
purchased by local authorities.
Compensating for this decline, there has been a growth in the activities of
the repertory companies, which receive financial support from the Arts
Council and also from the local authorities. The repertory companies employ
many leading dramatists, producers, designers and actors, and standards are
high. Some companies have the use of their own theatres, while others rent
from local authorities. Over a dozen new repertory theatres have been built
since 1958 including Coventry’s Belgrade Theatre, Leicester’s Phoenix
Theatre, the Nottingham Playhouse, the Yvonne Arnaud Theatre, Guildford,
the Octagon Theatre, Bolton, and the Thorndike Theatre, Leatherhead.
Northern Ireland has five professional theatres, whose productions are
eligible for grants from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland. The Ulster
Group Theatre in Belfast specialises in Ulster comedy, the Belfast Arts
Theatre presents international drama and lighter theatrical entertainment,
while the Lyric Players Theatre, a non-profit-making organisation, presents
Irish and international drama in a small theatre recently built with Arts
Council support.
All plays produced in Great Britain are subject to the provisions of the
Theatres Act 1968. This repealed the Theatres Act 1843 which gave the Lord
Chamberlain (the senior officer of the Royal Household) powers to censor
stage plays. There is now no censorship, but the new Act makes it a criminal
offence to present or direct an obscene performance of a play in public or in
210

and Trade Unions

and Study

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
private (including theatre clubs), an obscene performance being defined as
one which tends ‘to deprave and corrupt persons who are likely ... to attend
it’. Provision is made in the Act for a defence against a charge of obscenity on
the grounds that the performance is for the public good in the interests of,
for example, drama, opera or literature.
Most managers and artists are members of professional organisations such
as the Theatres’ Advisory Council, the London Theatre Council, the Pro¬
vincial Theatre Council, the Society of West End Managers, the Theatrical
Managers’ Association, the Council of Repertory Theatres, British Actors’
Equity (the actors’ trade union) and the League of Dramatists. The trade
union of theatre staffs is the National Association of Theatrical and Kine
Employees.
There are thousands of amateur dramatic societies in Britain with an active
membership of some half a million. They are encouraged by local education
authorities, by other public bodies, and by four special organisations—the
British Drama League, the Standing Conference of Drama Associations, the
Scottish Community Drama Association and the Association of Ulster Drama
Festivals. Amateur companies which stage productions in their own theatres
belong to the Little Theatre Guild of Great Britain; for instance, the People’s
Theatre in Newcastle upon Tyne and the Questor’s Theatre, Ealing.
Most universities have active amateur drama clubs and societies; an
International Festival of University Theatre, inaugurated by Bristol in 1959,
is held annually.
Training for the theatre is provided mainly in drama schools. Among the
most important are the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (which provides a
two-year course in all branches of stage work), the Central School of Speech
and Drama, the Rose Bruford Training College, the London Academy of
Music and Dramatic Art, the Webber-Douglas School, the Guildhall School
of Music and Drama and the Arts Educational Schools, all of which are in or
near London; and the Old Vic School in Bristol. In Scotland there is the
Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama in Glasgow which is grant-aided
by the Scottish Education Department. An increasing number of universities
offer courses in drama.
The Society for Theatre Research brings together those interested in the
history and technique of the British theatre. The International Theatre
Institute has a British centre in London. The main purpose of the institute is
to foster international goodwill and understanding by interchange of students,
theatrical companies, personnel and theatrical information.
Young people’s theatre has been developing in recent years. In 1970, under
the aegis of the National Theatre, the Young Vic was opened as a permanent
theatre for the young. The National Youth Theatre has a permanent home in
London and the Unicorn Theatre for Young People operates at the Arts
Theatre. There are about 12 companies, including Theatre Centre and the
Polka Company, which tour schools and theatres throughout the country. In
the provinces nearly 30 repertory companies provide programmes for children.
Nottingham has its own Youth Theatre Workshop and Birmingham has the
Midlands Arts Centre for Young People, which attracted over 73,000 young
people to performances in its two theatres in 1969-70.
Many schools and youth clubs put on plays and provide some education in
drama. Drama centres for the London education service are provided at

the Cockpit Youth Arts Centre and at the Curtain Theatre; there are youth
theatres in the London boroughs of Camden and Hillingdon.
In 1969-70 the Arts Council’s grants totalled .£186,500 in support of
young people’s theatre activities. The National Council of Theatre for Young
People represents all those actively concerned.
Audiences for broadcast music, concert attendances and sales of gramophone
records serve to indicate the importance of music in all its forms in British
cultural life. In 1969 nearly 60 million long playing records were produced,
mostly for the home market. Top’ music has achieved very great popularity
particularly with young people and concerts of folk music also attract large
audiences, while jazz, light music and brass bands maintain substantial fol¬
lowings. A more widespread interest in ‘serious’ music is reflected both in the
size of attendances at orchestral concerts and performances of opera, ballet
and chamber music, and in sales of gramophone records.
Through the Arts Council of Great Britain, the Government encourages
interest in the various forms of ‘serious’ music. The Council makes grants to a
number of orchestras, soloists, opera and ballet companies and music societies.
The British Council gives financial assistance to overseas tours by British
musicians; it sponsors recordings of work by British composers and maintains
103 libraries of British music (scores and records) in 67 countries overseas
and, at its London headquarters, a reference library of records, scores and
books on music.
In Britain many libraries have collections of records and musical scores
which are available on loan to the public. The City of Westminster houses the
Central Music Library which lends to other libraries and to individuals.
z\nother well-known music collection is the Henry Watson Music Library at
the Manchester Central Library.
The National Music Council, representative of many aspects of British
musical activity, is affiliated to the International Music Council, which is
associated with UNESCO.
Seasons of orchestral concerts are promoted every year in many of the large
towns and cities of Britain. In London the principal concert halls are the
Royal Festival Hall on the south bank of the Thames, adjacent to which are
the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Purcell Room which were opened in 1967
for smaller-scale performances; the Royal Albert Hall, Kensington, where the
annual summer season of Promenade Concerts is given; and the Wigmore Hall,
an important recital centre.
Among the leading British orchestras are the London Philharmonic, the
London Symphony, the Royal Philharmonic, the New Philharmonia, the
Royal Liverpool Philharmonic, the Halle (Manchester), the City of Birming¬
ham Symphony, the Bournemouth Symphony, the Scottish National and the
BBC Symphony, Northern and Scottish orchestras. There are also specialised
string and chamber orchestras such as the Northern Sinfonia, the Philomusica
of London, the English Chamber Orchestra and the London Mozart Players.
Many of these receive financial aid from the Arts Council of Great Britain and
local authorities; some of them also receive assistance from commercial
television and other business organisations. In Northern Ireland the Ulster
Orchestra receives financial aid from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland.
The principal choral societies in Britain are the Royal Choral, the BBC
Choral, the Huddersfield Choral, the Halle Choir, the Liverpool Philharmonic

Professional

Opera and

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Choir, the London Philharmonic Choir, the New Philharmonia Chorus, the
Bach Choir, the Edinburgh Royal Choral Union and the Belfast Philharmonic
Society. These and many other choral societies are associated with famous
orchestras in major choral works; most of them, together with hundreds of
similar choral and orchestral societies and music clubs, are affiliated to the
National Federation of Music Societies, through which they are supported
with funds provided by the Arts Council. Among societies which specialise
in encouraging the performance of the work of living musicians are the
Society for the Promotion of New Music, the Music Section of the Institute
of Contemporary Arts, and Macnaghten Concerts.
Music festivals in Britain, originating with the Three Choirs Festival held
annually in Gloucester, Worcester or Hereford in rotation, have been in
existence for over 200 years. The famous Edinburgh International Festival
lasts three weeks; other festivals such as that at King’s Lynn, last a week or
less. Among the better known are the Royal National Eisteddfod of Wales; the
Llangollen International Eisteddfod; the National Gaelic Mod, held at a
different place in Scotland each year; the Cheltenham Festival, largely devoted
to contemporary British music; the Aldeburgh Festival; the Bath Festival;
the Coventry Festival; the Haslemere Festival; the biennial York Festival;
and the Leeds and Norwich Festivals, which include important choral music,
and which are held triennially. An annual international festival of folk song
and dancing is held by the English Folk Dance and Song Society.
Interest in amateur music-making is encouraged by the work of County
Music Committees (some of which are voluntary and some sub-committees
of local education authorities), which are aided by the Carnegie United
Kingdom Trust and united in the Standing Conference for Amateur Music.
The Rural Music Schools Association is concerned with music-making by
amateurs in country districts; it brings together professional musicians,
teachers, administrators and amateurs. The National Federation of Music
Societies, which receives an annual grant from the Arts Council, assists
amateur groups with the cost of engaging professional soloists.
Professional organisations which look after the interests of music and
musicians include the Musicians’ Union, the Incorporated Society of Musi¬
cians, the Composers’ Guild, and the Songwriters’ Guild.
Regular seasons of opera and ballet are given at the Royal Opera House,
Covent Garden, London, leased by the Government on behalf of the Royal
Opera House, Covent Garden, Limited, which was formed in 1944 to make
the famous opera house the home of a national opera and ballet, and which
receives a grant from the Arts Council. The Royal Opera House has its own
company (The Royal Opera) and a ballet company (The Royal Ballet). The
opera company numbers about 200 and has a permanent orchestra. The Royal
Ballet has a high international reputation and has made many overseas tours.
It has a regular London season, tours abroad and performs in the provinces
for 12 weeks each year. There is also a smaller group of 25 dancers, which
performs in the regions as well as touring abroad.
Seasons of opera and operetta in English are also given by the Sadler’s Wells
Company which plays in modernised premises at the London Coliseum from
August to March each year. The Company then makes a provincial tour
during April and May. Its former home, the Sadler’s Wells Theatre, pro¬
vides a London stage for visiting opera and dance companies from the
provinces and from abroad.

At Glyndebourne, in Sussex, an opera season, for which an international cast
is specially assembled, is held every summer. Other opera companies include
the English Opera Group, noted for its performances of chamber operas by
Benjamin Britten and other composers; the New Opera Company, formed by
members of the Cambridge Opera Group to produce new operas in London;
the Handel Opera Society; the Intimate Opera Company, which performs
works for very small casts in any hall available; and the Welsh National Opera
Company. Scottish Opera presents annual seasons in several Scottish towns.
Opera in Northern Ireland is promoted by the Northern Ireland Opera Trust
with financial support from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland. The Arts
Council of Great Britain presents three small operatic groups (Opera for All)
which specialise in introducing opera to audiences in small towns. There are
also a number of amateur opera societies.
Among other ballet companies are London’s Festival Ballet, the Ballet
Rambert (Britain’s oldest ballet company) and the Scottish Theatre Ballet
which specialises in contemporary works. The work of the Patricia Mulholland
Irish Ballet Company in Northern Ireland, which is sponsored by the Arts
Council of Northern Ireland, combines traditional music, dancing and mime.
Professional training in music is given at colleges of music, of which the Royal
Academy of Music and the Royal College of Music in London, and the Royal
Scottish Academy of Music and Drama in Glasgow are grant-aided. Other
leading colleges include the Trinity College of Music and the Guildhall School
of Music and Drama, both in London, the Royal Manchester College of
Music and the Birmingham School of Music.
The London Opera Centre for Advanced Training and Development
provides some rehearsal and other facilities for the Royal Opera House,
Covent Garden. Its courses last two or three years. The leading ballet schools
are the Royal Ballet School, the Rambert Ballet School and the Royal
Academy of Dancing which, with many private schools, have played an impor¬
tant part in raising British ballet to its present high standard. Other schools
offering general education combined with drama and/or ballet are run by the
Arts Educational Trust and the Italia Conti School.
Young people are encouraged to take an interest in music, opera and ballet.
There are frequent concerts for children and the National Youth Orchestra of
Great Britain, the National Youth Orchestra of Wales and the London
Schools’ Symphony Orchestra are noted for their high standard of perfor¬
mance. A Youth and Music organisation, affiliated to the international
Jeunesses Musicales, encourages opera, ballet and other performances for
young people.
In schools, more children are learning to play musical instruments; and
nearly 160,000 candidates a year (children and other students) take the exami¬
nations of the Associated Board of the Royal Schools of Music. The most
popular instrument with candidates is the piano (some 55 per cent) followed
by the violin, the clarinet and the cello.
The Royal Ballet sponsors a small group, Ballet for All, to give lecture-
demonstrations to the public and to schools.
Although cinema attendance has been steadily declining in Great Britain since
its peak of 1,635 million in 1946 to about 220 million in 1969, and the number
of licensed cinemas has declined from 4,709 to 1,601 over the same period,
British films, actors and creative and technical talent are appreciated both at

BRITAIN I97i: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
home and abroad and frequently achieve success at international film events.
Television offers very large potential audiences for films and provides
opportunities of employment for technicians and actors.
London is one of the most important centres for the making of films for
international markets and export earnings are an important part of total
earnings. The Film Production Association of Great Britain is the trade
association to which the majority of feature film producers belong.
The documentary tradition in short film production in Britain goes back to
1929, when a group of directors began making factual films of a distinctive
and imaginative kind on behalf of the Government, and later for commercial
organisations. The war years saw a big expansion in this field and, since then,
British documentary technicians have continued to produce high quality
factual films which have won numerous international awards. The British
Industrial and Scientific Film Association promotes the use of films in
industry, science and commerce. The Federation of Specialised Film Associa¬
tions, the trade association of documentary, short, industrial, advertising and
cartoon film makers, has about 75 members.
Films from abroad made in languages other than English often draw large
audiences in London and other large cities. They form a considerable part of
the repertoire of the growing number of film clubs and societies.
Although much of British main feature production is supported by United
States interests at present, the Associated British Picture Corporation (now
owned by Electrical and Musical Industries Ltd.) and the Rank Organisation
maintain a substantial interest in production, distribution and exhibition.
Most British film producers are independent but make films in association
with these major interests. There are numerous companies, many of them
small, which produce short films.
There is no state-owned film production unit in Britain, but the National
Film Finance Corporation lends money for feature film production. Its
members are appointed by the Board of Trade and its funds are limited by
statute to £13 million. The Corporation was formerly involved in financing
about half the main feature films made in British studios, but this proportion
has now fallen considerably.
There is also a levy on cinema admissions to provide a film production fund.
The money so raised is paid out in proportion to a film’s takings, so that the
more successful a film is at the box-office, the more it receives from the fund.
Started by the industry in 1950 on a voluntary basis, the scheme became
statutory in 1957.
The Government sponsors a wide range of films to inform audiences
overseas about British life and achievements, including documentary films,
television programmes and newsreels; they are produced through the Central
Office of Information (COI), which commissions their production by private
companies. These, together with films acquired from private industry and
public bodies, are distributed throughout the world, in English and many
foreign languages, by British Information Services. The British Council also
distributes overseas a wide range of specialised films mainly on the arts,
education, medicine, science and technology.
Films are also sponsored by the Government for specialised audiences on
such subjects as science, agriculture, health and industry, and for the general
public on, for example, road safety and health education.
A large number of films are sponsored by industrial concerns and other

organisations, such as the British Tourist Authority and the British Pro¬
ductivity Council. The best of these and industrial films from other countries
are available through the COFs Central Film Library and other agencies.
The Films of Scotland Committee promotes the production of Scottish
films covering the industries and cultural traditions of Scotland.
To help British films to meet the keen American competition, legislation
passed in 1927 introduced the quota system under which a certain proportion
of British films must be shown in British cinemas each year. The proportion
is considered annually by the Board of Trade after consultation with the
Cinematograph Films Council. For main feature films it has stood at 30 per
cent since 1950 and for supporting programmes it has remained at 25 per
cent since 1948.
The State takes no part in the censorship of films in Britain, but before it can
be shown a film must be licensed by the local licensing authority. There are
about 700 of these (usually the local authorities or, in some areas, magistrates).
In considering the suitability of films the authorities normally rely on the
judgment of an independent body, the British Board of Film Censors, to
which are submitted all films (other than newsreels) for public showing.
The British Board of Film Censors was set up in 1912 on the initiative of
the cinema industry, to ensure that a proper standard was maintained in the
films offered to the public. The Board, which does not use any written code of
censorship, may require cuts to be made before granting a certificate to a
film; very rarely, it refuses a certificate. Films passed by the Board are placed
into one of four categories: ‘IT (suitable to be seen by any person not less than
five years of age); ‘A’ (for persons of not less than five years of age but
containing material that some parents might prefer their children not to see);
‘AA’ (for persons of not less than 14 years of age); and ‘X’ (for persons of not
less than 18 years of age).
Film reviews appear regularly in the press and on sound and television
programmes and many organisations are interested in different aspects of the
film. There are numerous private film societies.
The Society of Film and Television Arts, formed in 1958 by the amalgama¬
tion of the British Film Academy and the Guild of Television Producers and
Directors, has as its aim to improve the standard of film and television
production and to stimulate public appreciation of the arts.
An independent National Film School is being established and is expected to
open in the autumn of 1971.
The development of the film as an art is promoted by the British Film
Institute, founded in 1933, which is financed partly by an Exchequer grant
and by the Scottish Film Council which also receives a government grant.
The Institute encourages the making and showing of good films. It also
administers the National Film Theatre in London and the National Film
Archive, runs an annual summer school, and maintains a film library from
which films may be hired, a library of books on the film and an information
service. It makes grants to the Federation of Film Societies, the British
Universities Film Council and the Society for Education in Film and
Television.
The National Film Archive contains over 18,000 films, including newsreels
and other miscellaneous items, besides scripts, art designs, posters and about
2i6 BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
750,000 photographic stills, selected to illustrate the history and the art of the
film and as significant social and historical records.
The National Film Theatre, on the south bank of the Thames in London,
has two cinemas showing films of outstanding historical, artistic or technical
interest; it holds a unique position as a cinema offering regular programmes
unrestricted by commercial considerations or by the age or nationality of the
films shown. The British Film Institute has promoted the development of
some 40 regional film theatres on the lines of the National Film Theatre and
may make grants towards their recurrent and capital costs. Grants in Northern
Ireland are made by the Arts Council of Northern Ireland.
Festivals The National Film Theatre organises an annual London Film Festival, which
includes films receiving their first showing as well as films which have been
successful in international competitive festivals. A council on which leading
British film organisations are represented organises a film festival as part of
the Edinburgh International Festival.
The Cinematograph Act 1952 (which came into force in January 1956)
provided for the making of regulations by the Home Secretary to protect the
health and welfare of children attending film shows. Cinemas which give
children’s shows require a special licence from the licensing authority, which
may impose conditions. There are about 750 children’s cinema clubs which
provide special programmes on Saturday mornings. An important contribu¬
tion to these programmes is made by the Children’s Film Foundation, which
produces and distributes entertainment films specially designed for children
and publishes at intervals a list of films particularly suitable for children and
for exhibition at children’s matinees. The Foundation is a non-profit-making
body set up by the British film industry in 1951 and, under the Cinematograph
Films Act 1957, it receives grants from the British Film Fund Agency.
VISUAL ARTS A number of modern British painters and sculptors have a high international
reputation, winning 98 international prizes since 1949 and commissions for
major works in foreign cities. The growth of interest in the visual arts at
home has been stimulated by an increasingly lively attitude towards display
on the part of museums and galleries, and by the activities of many institutions,
societies, private galleries and the growing number of local art centres.
Painting and sculpture receive state support by grants to national institu¬
tions and, indirectly, through purchase grants made to local art galleries and
museums, to local education authorities for art schools and other means of
promoting education in art. The Arts Council organises exhibitions and main¬
tains its own collection of contemporary British art. The Government is
advised on grants and policy towards museums by the Standing Commission
on Museums and Galleries and the Royal Fine Art Commissions for England
and Wales and for Scotland.
Knowledge of Britain’s fine arts is fostered overseas by the British Council’s
exhibitions and lectures. In 1969-70 fine art exhibitions organised by the
Council were shown in 32 countries and the Council was also responsible for
British participation in seven international exhibitions.
Over 900 museums and art galleries are open to the public in Britain.
There are 20 national museums and art galleries. Those in London probably
contain between them the most comprehensive collection of objects of artistic,
archaeological, scientific, historical and general interest ever to exist within

the National Gallery, the Tate Gallery, the National Portrait Gallery, the
Imperial War Museum, the National Maritime Museum, the London Museum
(to be amalgamated with the Guildhall Museum into the Museum of London),
the Wallace Collection, the British Museum (Natural History), the Geological
Museum and the Science Museum (see p. 203).
There are six national museums and art galleries in Edinburgh: the National
Museum of Antiquities of Scotland, the National Gallery of Scotland, the
Royal Scottish Museum, the National Portrait Gallery of Scotland, the
Scottish United Services Museum, and the Scottish National Gallery of
Modem Art. The National Museum of Wales, in Cardiff, has a branch at
St. Fagan’s Castle where the Welsh Folk Museum is housed; and in Northern
Ireland there is the national Ulster Museum in Belfast.
Other important collections in London include the Armouries (Tower of
London), the Public Record Office (see p. 221) and the Sir John Soane’s
Museum. In Buckingham Palace there is a small gallery for exhibition of
pictures from the extensive royal collections. Most cities and large towns and
many other towns have a museum devoted to art, archaeology and natural
history, usually owned by the municipal authority but sometimes by a local
learned society or privately by individuals or trustees. Both Oxford and
Cambridge are rich in museums, many of them, as in other towns, associated
with the universities—for example, the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford,
founded in 1683, the oldest in the country, and the Fitzwilliam Museum in
Cambridge. There are important museums and art galleries in Birmingham,
Bristol, Glasgow, Leeds, Leicester, Liverpool, Manchester, Norwich, Read¬
ing, Southampton and York. In Northern Ireland there are notable museums
and galleries in or near Belfast (the Ulster Folk Museum and the Northern
Ireland Arts Council Gallery), in Armagh City and in Londonderry.
A notable development has been the establishment of ‘period-house
museums’, for which outstanding private houses have been taken over by
national and municipal authorities, and of folk museums. Many private art
collections housed in historic family mansions, including those in the owner¬
ship of the National Trust (see p. 175), are open to the public.
In recent years several new or extensively altered museum buildings have
been opened, including those at Coventry, Derby, Doncaster, Durham (the
Gulbenkian Museum at the university), Leicester (Jewry Wall Archaeological
Museum), Liverpool, Manchester (Whitworth Art Gallery), Scunthorpe and
Sunderland. Developments are planned for museums in Belfast, Bristol,
Cardiff, Hull, London and Newcastle. County councils are playing a greater
part in the provision of museums and museum services; there are schemes in
Oxfordshire (jointly with Oxford City Council), County Durham, Stafford¬
shire, Pembrokeshire, Rutland, Worcestershire and Hampshire. New projects
are also being initiated by local associations for the arts.
A function of the Standing Commission on Museums and Galleries is to
advise the Government on the relationship between national and provincial
institutions. Close relations are fostered by the eight area museum councils
which cover the whole of Great Britain. They are grant-aided by the Govern¬
ment and help to improve technical facilities.
The Museums Association, to which museums and art galleries and their
staffs throughout the country belong and which also has many overseas
members, is an independent organisation. The Association serves as a central
