BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
body for the collection of information and the discussion of matters relating
to museum administration, and as a training and examining body for
professional qualifications.
Temporary exhibitions organised and sent on tour by the Arts Councils, the
Circulation Department of the Victoria and Albert Museum, the Science
Museum and the Art Exhibitions Bureau are a regular feature of many
museums. The Tate Gallery, the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Royal
Academy show loan exhibitions; the Whitechapel Art Gallery, the Camden
Arts Centre and the Institute of Contemporary Arts (at their new premises in
The Mall) also show temporary exhibitions. The Greater London Council
exhibits modern sculpture in one of its parks on the south bank of the Thames
periodically and in the summer of 1968 opened a new exhibition gallery, the
Hayward Gallery, administered by the Arts Council, where major exhibitions
are shown. Commercial exhibitions of works by old masters and living artists
are held throughout the year in the galleries of the art dealers of London
(largely in the Bond Street area).
The various national art exhibiting societies include the Royal Academy;
the Royal Scottish Academy; the Society of Scottish Artists; the Royal
Society of British Artists; the Royal Society of Painters in Water Colours; the
Royal Society of Portrait Painters; the Artists’ International Association; the
Women’s International Art Club; and the London Group (all associations
of professional painters). Some of these societies, notably the Royal Academy
at Burlington House, have their own galleries in London. In Northern Ireland
there are the Royal Ulster Academy of Arts, the Ulster Society of Women
Artists and the Ulster Arts Club. Among regional societies are the Newlyn
Society of Artists, the Midland Group of Artists (Nottingham), the Birming¬
ham Society of Artists and the Penwith Society of Arts, while an increasing
number of amateur art societies throughout Britain hold local exhibitions and
encourage local interest in the fine arts. There are also exhibitions of children’s
art, including the National Exhibition of Children’s Art sponsored annually
by the Sunday Mirror.
All national collections are financed from government funds, both those that
are the direct responsibility of the Department of Education and Science (the
Victoria and Albert and the Science Museums) and of the Scottish Education
Department (the Royal Scottish Museum) and those run by trustee bodies.
Besides meeting the administrative costs, provision is made for annual
purchase grants which totalled £1,937,000 in 1970 -71. 1 he Government also
provides special ad hoc purchase grants and collections may receive works of
art acquired by the Treasury in lieu of estate duty. The buildings are main¬
tained by the Ministry of Public Building and Works. Local museums and art
galleries, which are maintained from rates or endowments, can be helped in
building up their collections through the annual government grant (£152,000
in 1970-71) administered by the Victoria and Albert and Royal Scottish
Museums. Financial help and pictures are also given to museums and galleries
by certain trusts and voluntary bodies, particularly the National Art-
Collections Fund and the Contemporary Art Society.
Formal art education is given in publicly supported art colleges, university
art schools, the Royal Academy Schools and a few private art schools. There
are the colleges, art schools and classes administered by the local education
authorities; and at a senior level there is the Royal College of Art, London,
whose students have usually completed a course at a local education authority
Architecture
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS 2I9
college, and which awards its own degrees. Art is also taught at an advanced
level at the four Scottish Central (Art) Institutions administered by the
Scottish Education Department. University art schools include the Slade
School of Fine Art and Goldsmiths’ College (London), the Ruskin Drawing
School (Oxford), the Reading School of Art, the Department of Fine Art of
the University of Newcastle upon Tyne, and the School of Art of University
College, Aberystwyth.
The leading academic institutions for the teaching and study of the history
of art are the Courtauld Institute of the University of London, the Depart¬
ment of Classical Art and Archaeology in University College, London, and
the Warburg Institute, also a part of London University.
In England and Wales three-year full-time courses leading to a Diploma in
Art and Design are available to students who have successfully completed a
foundation course. The Diploma is broadly comparable to a university pass
degree, and is administered by the National Council for Diplomas in Art and
Design (an independent self-governing body set up by the Government in
1961). The Council also administers a scheme of post-diploma studies in a
small number of colleges. In Scotland each of the four schools of art awards
a diploma which is roughly equivalent to the pass degree of a university.
The Ulster College of Art and Design is the regional college for Northern
Ireland.
Art has a place in the curriculum of every type of school, and the Society
for Education through Art, among other activities, encourages the purchase
by schools of original works of art by organising an annual Pictures for Schools
exhibition. Pictures may also be borrowed from an increasing number of
public libraries (see p. 222).
Official responsibility towards the nation’s architecture is concerned with
encouraging the best in new building and preserving the best that has been
inherited from the past.
Several government departments are concerned with architecture and help
to promote good design. The Ministry of Housing and Local Government,
the Scottish Development Department, and the Northern Ireland Ministry of
Development are responsible for approving the layout and design of local
authority housing schemes, and set standards for local authority housing. The
Ministry of Housing and Local Government is responsible for the work of
the National Building Agency (see p. 272) which carries out development and
research concerning new building techniques, d he Ministry of Public Building
and Works is also responsible for the design, building and maintenance work
of all government departments; it also has a research and development
group which co-ordinates similar groups throughout the government service.
The Architects and Building Branches at the Department of Education and
Science and the Scottish Education Department carry out research for school
building programmes. The Department of Health and Social Security is
implementing a very large building programme and the Regional Hospital
Boards, through their architectural departments, are responsible for the design
and construction of a large number of hospitals and ancillary buildings.
Government departments are assisted in an advisory capacity by the Royal
Fine Art Commissions for England and Wales and for Scotland, which also
advise planning authorities and other public bodies on questions of public
amenity or artistic importance, including new building developments.
A number of professional, advisory and other societies and institutions
exist to further the interests of architecture, and the Civic Trust (see p. 175)
220
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Education and
Professional
Associations
LITERATURE
AND LIBRARIES
seeks to promote high standards in architecture and civic planning and to
encourage a wider interest in the appearance and protection of towns and the
countryside.
The Minister of Public Building and Works and the Secretaries of State
for Scotland and Wales have responsibilities for the preservation of ancient
monuments and certain historic buildings and the Minister of Housing and
Local Government (together with the Secretaries of State) is responsible for
administering the grants available for the repair and maintenance of buildings
of outstanding historic or architectural interest; in Northern Ireland these
responsibilities are vested in the Ministry of Finance.
In Britain it is illegal for a person to practise under the title of ‘architect’
unless registered with the Architects’ Registration Council of the United
Kingdom. Most students train at a full-time school of architecture; there are
35 schools recognised for exemption from certain parts of the examinations of
the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA). In addition to these schools,
which may also have part-time courses, there are five schools of art and
technical colleges which have full-time courses leading to the external
examinations of the RIBA.
The Royal Institute of British Architects, the leading professional archi-
tural institution in Britain, has a membership of over 23,000 with more than
6,000 students. Allied to it are 80 architectural societies covering the whole
of the United Kingdom and countries overseas. The RIBA has one of
the largest and most important architectural libraries in the world. It is
concerned with a wide range of activities covering professional practice,
science, technology, statistics, architectural competitions, professional and
public relations; arranges lectures and discussions on a variety of subjects;
presents exhibitions; and, through its Board of Education, controls the
training and examination of architects. The Royal Gold Medal for Architec¬
ture is awarded annually by the Queen on the recommendation of the RIBA.
Among other associations are the Incorporated Association of Architects and
Surveyors, the Institute of Registered Architects and the Faculty of Architects
and Surveyors. Societies include the Architectural Association, the Architec¬
ture Club, and several which cover particular aspects of architecture, such as
the Modular Society.
The study of literature is included in the curricula of all schools, colleges
and universities. There are free public libraries throughout the country,
private libraries and a large number of private literary societies. Book reviews
are featured in the press and on radio and television and there are numerous
periodicals concerned in whole or in part with literature.
Government help is given through the Arts Council of Great Britain
which supports literature in a number of ways, including grants for writers,
a fund to aid literary projects, and subsidies to festivals of literature and poetry.
Similar provision is made, through the Arts Council of Northern Ireland, for
bursaries, poetry readings, and aid for publications.
Recognition of outstanding literary merit is given in the form of literary
prizes, a number of which are awarded annually, for instance, the Queen’s
Gold Medal for Poetry, the James Tait Black Memorial prizes for biography
and literature, the John Llewellyn Rhys Memorial prize for young writers of
promise, the Hawthornden prize for imaginative writing, the Winston
Spencer Churchill Literary Award for an outstanding work on the history
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS
221
Libraries
Libraries in
Education
of the English-speaking peoples, the Library Association Carnegie Medal
for an outstanding book for children, and the Somerset Maugham award for
young writers.
The British Museum Library in London (over 7 million volumes) is the largest
in Britain. The National Libraries of Scotland (in Edinburgh) and Wales (in
Aberystwyth) both have over 2 million volumes. Together with the Bodleian
Library of Oxford University (3^ million volumes) and the Cambridge
University Library (4 million volumes) these comprise the ‘copyright’ libraries
of the country and are entitled to receive a copy of each new book published in
Britain: the British Museum Library must receive a copy, the other libraries
may claim one.
Together with the British Museum Library and its associated department,
the National Reference Library of Science and Invention, the principal
national libraries are the National Central Library (see p. 222) and the
National Lending Library for Science and Technology (see p. 204). The
establishment of a National Libraries Authority to co-ordinate their services
and operations and those of the British National Bibliography was recom¬
mended in 1969 by the Dainton Committee, which had been appointed to
ensure their development in the most effective way. This recommendation
was accepted in principle by the Government in April ig?0.
The Victoria and Albert Museum and the British Museum (Natural
History) in South Kensington also have large libraries and many government
departments have old-established libraries of considerable size and importance,
for example, those of the Board of Trade, Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries
and Food and the Ministry of Defence. The Public Record Office contains the
records of the superior courts of law and of most government departments, as
well as such famous historical documents as Domesday Book. The National
Register of Archives (maintained by the Historical Manuscripts Commission)
contains particulars of local and private records.
Besides the few great private collections, such as those of the John Rylands
Library, Manchester, the Signet Library, Edinburgh, and the London
Library, there are the rich resources of the learned societies and institutions
(for scientific societies and institutions, see p. 193). Examples are the libraries
of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, the Royal Commonwealth
Society, the Commonwealth Institute, the Royal Geographical Society, the
Royal Institute of British Architects (see p. 220), the Royal College of
Physicians, the British Drama League (see p. 210), the Royal College of
Music, the Royal Academy of Music, the Central Music Library (administered
by Westminster City Council), the National Library for the Blind and the
National Book League.
The great expansion in education in recent years has increased the strain on
library resources at all levels of education. The ancient university libraries of
Oxford and Cambridge are not matched by any of the more recent foundations,
although the combined library resources of the colleges and institutions of the
university of London total over 4 million volumes and the university libraries
of Edinburgh, St. Andrews, Glasgow, Birmingham, Liverpool, Manchester
and Leeds each have over half a million volumes. The total stocks of British
University libraries in 1967 amounted to over 23! million volumes. Many
universities have succeeded in building up large and important research
collections in special subjects; for example, the Barnes Medical Library at
222
Public Libraries
Library
Co-operation
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Birmingham and the Brotherton Library of English Literature at Leeds. The
new universities, including the new technological universities, are also rapidly
building collections.
The importance of good libraries is recognised at all levels of the education
system. School libraries, most of which are maintained by local education
authorities, often receive co-operation from the public library service,
including loans of books. School children are regularly introduced to the
public library system, which they can use in addition to the school library.
Britain is served by a complete network of public libraries, administered by
474 public library authorities (county councils, county borough councils,
London borough councils, municipal borough councils and urban district
councils). The authorities in Great Britain, which provide more than 10,000
service points, have a total stock of over 100 million books. (The figures do not
include the libraries in the publicly maintained schools.) Qualified and
specialist staff are available for consultation in all but the smallest service
points. Nearly one-third of the total population are members of public libraries.
Under the Public Libraries and Museums Act 1964 the Secretary of State
for Education and Science is charged with the supervision of the public
library service in England and Wales, acting on the advice of two Library
Advisory Councils, one for England, the other for Wales. Under the Act,
public library authorities are designated and have a duty to provide an
efficient and (with some limitations) free lending and reference library service
for books and periodicals. Outlying areas may be served by mobile libraries,
of which over 500 are in service, and facilities exist for people who are unable
to visit a library.
In addition to lending books, about a third of the library authorities now
lend gramophone records of various kinds and a growing number are adding
loan collections of works of art, either originals or reproductions. Nearly all
library authorities provide children’s departments and reference sections and
art, music, commercial and technical departments meet the growing and more
specific demands in these fields. Most library authorities possess a significant
collection of books and documents on the history of their localities.
The public library is often a local cultural centre. Film shows, lectures,
adult education classes, book-week exhibitions, drama groups, gramophone
recitals and children’s story hours are among the many activities. An increasing
number of libraries provide special facilities for these extension activities.
The Public Libraries and Museums Act 1964 gave statutory recognition to
the voluntary system of library co-operation in England and Wales which had
grown up since the first quarter of this century. The nine regional library
bureaux in England and Wales (consisting mainly of public libraries in each
area) aim to be largely self-sufficient in the interlending of current British
books by means of a system of co-operative subject specialisation. They
organise co-operation among themselves and through the National Central
Library, which is responsible for interlending at national and international
level and has a bookstock of its own of over 500,000 volumes built up by
purchase, gift and the operation of the British National Book Centre exchange
scheme with foreign libraries. The combined resources of libraries available
to the National Central Library, which includes university, industrial and
other non-public libraries, amount to over 100 million books and many
thousand sets of periodicals.
There is a growing number of schemes for the exchange of specialist books
and periodicals as well as information. These are organised by associations of
Library
Associations
Books
Literary and
Philological
Societies
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS 223
industrial and commercial libraries which combine their resources, normally
through the local public or technical college library.
The Scottish Central Library carries out functions similar to those of the
regional bureaux and the National Central Library. Both Central Libraries
are financed in part by Exchequer grants. In Northern Ireland access to the
stocks of all co-operating libraries is available on application to the Belfast
public libraries, Queen’s University Library and the county libraries.
The principal professional organisation is the Library Association, which was
granted a Royal Charter in 1898 to unite all people engaged or interested in
library work, to promote the better administration of libraries and, among
other functions, to hold examinations in librarianship and to issue certificates
of efficiency. The Association in 1970 had a membership of over 17,300 of
whom more than 1,300 were from overseas countries. It maintains a Register
of Chartered Librarians, publishes books and pamphlets, a Yearbook, and an
official journal The Library Association Record. The Association and its
branches, groups and sections hold regular conferences. There are also
associations of libraries of which Aslib (the Association of Special Libraries
and Information Bureaux, see p. 204) and the Standing Conference of National
and University Libraries (SCONUL) are of major importance.
New books constitute the large majority of all books published in Britain. In
1969 British publishers issued over 32,000 separate titles, of which more than
23,000 were new books and the rest reprints or new editions. In recent years
there has been a great increase in the number of paperbacked books of all kinds.
The above figures include only a small selection of government publications
by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office, which is the largest publishing organisa¬
tion in Britain. The great majority of books, however, are produced by about
300 of the principal commercial publishers. These include the university
presses, notably the Oxford University Press (including the Clarendon Press)
and the Cambridge University Press.
Using the copies deposited under copyright law in the British Museum, the
British National Bibliography is published weekly, with three, six, nine and
twelve monthly cumulations, listing in a classified order, with indexes, all new
books and new editions, excluding reprints, of books published in Britain.
Leading organisations representing the interests of those concerned with
book production and distribution are the Publishers’ Association and the
Booksellers’ Association; the Book Development Council promotes British
books overseas. The Society of Authors is a professional association of writers.
The National Book League has a membership covering all who are interested
in books; authors, publishers, booksellers, librarians and readers. It en¬
courages an interest in books and arranges exhibitions in Britain and overseas.
Knowledge of British books and periodicals overseas is greatly assisted by the
British Council through the lending and reference libraries (over 200) which
it runs or supplies, and through the many touring book and periodicals
exhibitions. (For sales and exports of books in 1969, see p. 297.)
Societies for the promotion of literature include the English Association and
the Royal Society of Literature. The British Academy for the Promotion of
Historical, Philosophical and Philological Studies, generally known as the
British Academy, is the leading society of humanistic studies and receives a
grant from the Treasury.
A number of societies sponsor poetry readings and recitals; the Poetry
H*
224
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Society, the Apollo Society and the Barrow Poets are among the best known.
Poetry also plays an important part in various annual festivals, including the
National Eisteddfod—the bardic festival held in Wales—the Stratford-upon-
Avon Festival of Poetry, the Cheltenham Festival of Literature, and the
annual poetry festival organised by the Poetry Book Society in London.
Among the specialist societies are the Early English Text Society, the
Bibliographical Society, the Harleian Society, the Saltire Society, and several
societies devoted to particular authors of which the largest is the Dickens
Fellowship. There are a number of clubs and societies, such as the Book
Society and the Poetry Book Society, which exist to distribute selected new
books to their members.
10 THE NATIONAL
ECONOMY
BACKGROUND
Britain ranks about 75th in size among the countries of the world, with
about 0-18 per cent of the world’s land area. In population, approaching
2 per cent of the world’s inhabitants, it ranks tenth. In density of population
it is fourth: of the major countries, only Japan, Belgium and the Netherlands
are more crowded; and there are nine times as many people to the square
mile in the United Kingdom as in the United States. In terms of national
income per head it ranks appreciably below the United States and also below
Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Sweden and Switzerland, and slightly
below France and the Federal Republic of Germany. In world trade, it
ranks third, accounting for nearly one-tenth of the total. It takes about a fifth
of the world’s exports of primary products, and provides about eight per cent
of the world’s exports of manufactured goods.
Britain, from its own soil, provides only about half of the food it needs,
and—apart from coal, low-grade iron ore and natural gas—it has few natural
resources; thus it is one of the world’s largest importers of such products as
wheat, meat, butter, fodder grains, fruit, tea, tobacco, wool, and timber.
In return, it is one of the world’s largest exporters of aircraft, motor vehicles,
electrical equipment, chemicals, textiles and most types of machinery. No
other major country has such a small proportion of the working population
engaged in agriculture (about 3 per cent).
The United Kingdom is also the central banker of the sterling area, an
area with a quarter of the world’s population. Many countries outside the
sterling area use sterling in their international transactions, and it is the
currency in which about one-third of the world’s trade is conducted.
Earlier During the nineteenth century Britain secured a leading position as world
Development manufacturer, merchant, carrier, banker, and investor and supported a
of the Economy rapidly increasing population at a rising standard of living. Between 1890 and
1914, industrial competition from Europe and North America grew, but its
effects on Britain’s export industries, particularly cotton textiles and coal,
were offset by the rise in world trade, by the demand for British textiles from
India and other eastern countries and by the earnings of British shipping
and financial services and the returns on Britain’s large overseas investments.
During the period from 1870 to 1890 British industrial expansion had a
clear lead over that of other countries. Between 1890 and 1914 growing
industrial competition from Europe and North America began to make itself
felt, but its effects on Britain’s staple export industries, particularly cotton
textiles and coal, were offset by the general rise in world trade, by the con¬
tinued demand for British textiles from India and other eastern countries,
and by the continued high level of overseas investment.
After the first world war Britain’s older industries met increasing
competition, for example, coal and iron and steel from other European
countries and textiles from some eastern countries where labour was cheaper.
226
Effects of
the Second
World War
The Post-war
Period
BRITAIN I97i: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
At the same time Britain failed at first to gain a compensating share of world
trade in the newer types of engineering products. Some countries sought
deliberately to protect nascent and even established industries by tariffs and
(later) quotas and exchange restrictions. The result was heavy unemployment
in Britain’s older industries, the rate of which averaged 14 per cent in the
years 1921-39, and rose well above this in the years following the collapse of
the American stock market in 1929, reaching a peak of 22 per cent in 1932,
when the associated slump in world trade was at its worst. In some districts
relying mainly on the most heavily affected industries, the rate was much
higher. Income from invisible earnings (for example on overseas investments,
shipping and insurance) and relatively cheap imports, particularly food, how¬
ever, cushioned the effects of the fall in the volume of exports.
After 1932 levels of production and employment improved, stimulated by
an increase in home investment which was aided by the policy of cheap
money, by some revival in world trade and, after i935> ^>7 armament
programme. The decade saw a strong expansion in the vehicles, electrical,
chemicals and aircraft industries, while the construction of 3 million houses
brought about a large growth in the building and ancillary industries. By
1937 average real income per head was about 14 per cent higher than in 1929.
In spite of generous aid from the United States and Canada, the second
world war ran down British domestic capital by about £3,000 million,
through shipping losses, bomb damage, and arrears of industrial maintenance
and replacements. Some £1,000 million worth of overseas investments were
sold, nearly half in North America, and new external debts of £3,000 million
were accumulated. By 1944 exports had fallen to less than one-third of their
1938 volume.
After the second world war rationing and other war-time controls were
relaxed gradually as civil production expanded and trade recovered. The
abolition of quantitative restrictions on imports, other than from the dollar
area, was largely completed by 1955. Exchange controls on transactions
between the sterling area and the rest of the world were also progressively
lifted, and in 1958 convertibility of sterling on current account for all non¬
residents was introduced.
The period since 1945 has been one of rising production and living
standards and a relatively low level of unemployment. Economic growth has
been rather slower and more intermittent than in most other western Europe
countries and there have been certain persistent economic problems, especi¬
ally a continuous, if fairly slow, rise in prices and repeated crises in the balance
of payments particularly during periods of relatively rapid economic growth.
In spite of the contribution from invisibles, there were in a number of years
substantial deficits on current account transactions with the rest of the world
and a low level of reserves meant there was little room for manoeuvre.
Successive governments sought to deal with these difficulties in three main
ways: by monetary and fiscal measures aimed at restraining the growth of
home demand; by advice and exhortation—and for a time the use of certain
limited powers—to try to restrain rises in incomes and prices; and by measures
having a direct effect on the balance of payments (see, for example, p. 386).
In 1967 a serious deterioration in the balance of payments led to a loss of
overseas confidence in sterling. To meet the situation, the Government de¬
valued sterling in November 1967 from $2.80 to $2.40 = £1. They then pro¬
ceeded to take a number of fiscal, monetary and administrative measures to
restrain increases in expenditure, prices and incomes. A major reorientation
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY
227
OUTPUT AND
EMPLOYMENT
of the economy was in fact achieved. In the 2% years following devaluation
there was a massive switch of resources into the balance of payments. The
volume of exports of goods and services increased about four times as fast
as the gross domestic product. In consequence the balance of payments
improved rapidly during 1969 and by the beginning of 1970 the surplus on
current transactions was running at an annual rate of over £500 million.
THE FRAMEWORK OF THE ECONOMY
The following sections sketch briefly the salient features of Britain’s national
economy in recent years.
In 1969 Britain’s gross national product at factor cost (the measure of the
value of total goods and services produced at home and net income from
abroad) is estimated to have totalled £38,601 million. In real terms, that is,
after allowing for price changes, the increase over the 11 years since 1959 was
about 35 per cent (see diagram p. 228).
About a third of this output can be attributed to manufacturing industry
and this proportion has remained more or less constant for the past 12 years.
The relatively rapidly expanding sectors are gas, electricity and water (from
2-6 per cent in 1958 to 3-6 per cent in 1968), services (financial, health and
educational, professional and personal—from 17! per cent to 21 per cent).
Agriculture, forestry and fishing account for a small and very slowly declining
share (about 3 per cent), and mining for a small and rapidly declining share
(about 2 per cent compared with 3! per cent in 1958). The relative con¬
tributions of the distribution sector and the transport and communications
sector have changed little in the past 12 years and are now about 11 per cent
and 8 per cent respectively.
Within the large manufacturing sector, some industries specially those
producing new, technically advanced and rapidly developing products, have
been expanding (for example, office machinery, computers, instrumentation,
aircraft and aircraft engines, and glass), while others, including traditional
industries such as cotton textiles, have been in decline. In general the speed
up of technical progress in industry has in Britain as in other industrially
advanced countries brought with it a number of human problems. There are
problems of labour supply and unemployment. In London, the south-east
and the midlands, where expansion and change have been most rapid, there
are shortages of certain types of professional, technical and craft skills and the
general unemployment rate (the ratio of those unemployed and seeking
employment to those in or seeking employment) has stayed at a very low
level. These low unemployment rates in the greatest concentrations of
population helped to keep the general unemployment rate for Britain under
2 per cent in all years from 1948 to 1967; since when it has moved up to about
zi per cent. On the other hand, in areas which were formerly largely dependent
on a single traditional industry, such as coalmining or cotton textiles, or on
certain types of heavy engineering now less in demand, there have been
serious pockets of long-term unemployment, some of which have tended to
persist in spite of special measures to encourage additional employment in
the area. The general unemployment rates in Northern Ireland, Scotland,
Wales and the northern and certain other parts of England have thus been
considerably above the national average, with that of Northern Ireland
(nearly 7 per cent) giving particular cause for concern.

Besides its relation to total available supplies, two other measures of growth
of capital investment may conveniently be given. As a proportion of gross
national expenditure (equivalent to gross national product) fixed capital
formation is now over 20 per cent as compared with 15 per cent in 1951.
The total value of fixed assets in Britain, valued at constant replacement cost,
is estimated to have increased by 80 per cent between 1948 and 1968 when
their current replacement value, net of depreciation, wras estimated at
£93-3 thousand million, of which approximately two-thirds was accounted
for by buildings and one-third by vehicles, plant, and machinery.
Of total investment in 1969, 82 per cent was accounted for by domestic
fixed capital formation, 4 per cent by physical increase of stocks and work in
progress and 4 per cent by investment overseas. Of the domestic fixed capital
formation, 37 per cent was in plant and machinery, 34 per cent in buildings
(other than dwellings) and works, 19 per cent in dwellings and 10 per cent
in vehicles. By sector, about 55 per cent wras in the private sector and about
45 per cent in the public sector, including central Government, local govern¬
ment and nationalised industries. By industry group, about 22 per cent was
in manufacturing industry, and about 15 per cent in the public services.
Within the manufacturing sector, the largest investments were in the food,
Public
Authorities
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY 22Q
drink and tobacco industries, the engineering industries and the chemical
and allied industries. The most marked trends in recent years have been the
increases in local authorities’ house building and in plant and machinery
purchases by the textile industries (reflecting the growth of synthetics), the
electricity supply industry and the Post Office.
The rising levels of investment have been financed by saving in all the
main sectors of the economy, though, despite increases in local rates and in
grants from the central Government, the current surpluses of local authorities
have been sufficient to provide for only a quarter of their capital needs so
that the rest has had to be met by short- and long-term borrowing from the
Government or elsewhere. The central Government has increased its current
surplus sufficiently to finance its own capital expenditure, make capital
grants to industry, lend large sums (mainly to public corporations) and,
since 1969, repay a substantial amount of debt. It has increased its current
surplus (before providing for depreciation) from £492 million in 1964 to
£2,902 million in 1969. The public corporations, largely because of their big
investment programmes, have, despite payment of subsidies (particularly to
the transport corporations), been heavily dependent on borrowing from the
central Government. The companies’ sector, though the largest gross saver,
is also the largest investor and though in most years it has covered its invest¬
ment from its savings, this was not so in 1969. The personal sector has shown
a large if fluctuating excess of saving over acquisition of fixed assets (mainly
dwellings). Increasingly the main forms of financial assets acquired by the
personal sector are insurance policies, interests in pension funds, building
society shares and bank deposits, while the most important and rapidly
increasing financial liabilities of this sector are loans on house mortgages
from building societies.
PUBLIC AND PRIVATE FIXED INVESTMENT 1959 AND 1969
£ million at 1963 prices
Current expenditure on goods and services by the central Government
(including the national insurance funds) and the local authorities rose by
48 per cent at current prices over the period 1964 to 1969 and in the latter
year amounted to about 21 per cent of the gross national product. The main
cause of this increase was the continuing growth of the social services,
especially education. Defence has recently accounted for a declining share
of public expenditure on goods and services—28 per cent in 1969 compared
with 35 per cent in 1964 and a post-war peak of over 50 per cent in 1953.
230
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In addition to their expenditure on goods and services, public authorities
transfer large sums to other sectors, mainly the personal sectors, by way of,
national insurance benefits, national assistance, investment and other grants,
and interest and subsidies. Central Government also make grants to local
authorities to finance about 40 per cent of their current expenditure, but this
is a transfer within the public sector and does not affect the position of the
public sector as a whole in relation to the rest of the economy.

Personal incomes before tax at current prices rose rapidly and fairly steadily
for 22 years from £9,423 million in 1947 to £38,491 million in 1969—a
logarithmic rate of about 6 per cent a year. The increase in consumer expen¬
diture per head of population at constant prices has, however, been very much
lOWer about 2 per cent per annum. The difference is accounted for mainly
by rising prices and to a lesser extent by the growth of population, a higher
incidence of direct taxation and increased personal savings.
Income from employment in 1969 totalled £27,109 million and accounted
for 70 per cent of total personal income (against 60 per cent in 1938). The
three other main sources of personal income were self employment (8 per
cent), income from property (12 per cent), and grants from public authorities
(10 per cent). The general pattern of income distribution is thus dominated
by the pattern for income from employment. The effects of property income,
which tends to add to the income of the already affluent, are relatively slight
and to some extent counter-balanced by the effect of grants from public
authorities to those in need.
British direct taxation falls heavily on the rich and this is reflected in the
distribution of income after tax. Thus in 1967 there were 562,000 incomes

The combined effect of British indirect taxation and subsidies does not appear
to be regressive. The main subsidies are on food grown in Britain and on
housing provided by local authorities and these are especially helpful to those
on low incomes, while among the most important indirect taxes are those
on cars, petrol, consumer durables and alcoholic drinks.

the pattern of that expenditure. The proportion devoted to food has been

ECONOMIC POLICY AND PLANNING
The central objective of the economic policies of successive British govern¬
ments has been secure, steady, economic growth with a high level of employ¬
ment together with a favourable balance of payments and thereby to ensure a
continuing improvement in output and living standards. This has not proved
easy to achieve (see page 226) and in the autumn of 1967 the Government,
faced with an adverse balance of payments and a run on sterling, decided to
give priority to restoring the external position, devalued sterling and pro¬
ceeded to take a number of measures which have achieved a major switch
of resources to exports and restrained the growth of imports.
The devaluation of the pound from $2.80 to $2.40 made exporting more
profitable, exports more competitive and to some extent discouraged the
growth of imports. Other measures taken to deal with the immediate situation
included the negotiations of loans from central bankers and of stand-by
facilities from the International Monetary Fund (see p. 396); a great increase
in taxation and a tightening of control over government expenditure (see
p. 360); the raising of the bank rate, the tightening of hire purchase regula¬
tions and the issue of recommendations to the banks to restrict credit; the
use of controls over overseas investment to restrict investment outside the
sterling area to cases which promised short-term benefits to the balance of
payments, while at the same time maintaining a voluntary programme for
reducing investment in the developed countries of the sterling area; a
temporary scheme of import deposits, under which importers are required
to deposit with Customs and Excise a sum proportionate to the value of the
shipment (see p. 386) for a period of 180 days interest free; and an attempt
for a time to enforce a more stringent prices and incomes policy.
At the same time policies directed to longer term improvements were main¬
tained and certain new measures were taken to improve planning and
encourage long-term economic growth. A central problem of British economic
and social policy has been to strike a balance between the needs of long¬
term planning, which call for some centralisation of control in the hands of
public authorities and large private undertakings, and the need for the
preservation of personal freedom, initiative and competition on political,
social and economic grounds.
Some of the Government’s powers and services are directed towards
combating forces that might militate against fair and competitive trading
conditions or put too much economic power in the hands of large under¬
takings which are not publicly accountable. For example, a Restrictive
Practices Court, first established in 1956 and since strengthened, may
consider a wide range of restrictive agreements between business under¬
takings and will permit their operation only if it finds them in the public
234
Aids to
Efficiency
The Machinery
of Planning
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
interest (see p. 239). A Monopolies Commission was first established in
1948 and was strengthened in 1965. On the basis of its reports the Govern¬
ment may prohibit mergers and break up undesirable monopolies. At the
same time the Government with the aid of the Industrial Reorganisation
Corporation, established in 1966, has been taking positive action to encourage
a reshaping of industry including certain mergers.
Successive governments have sought to stimulate business efficiency by
fiscal and other financial incentives and by providing a variety of services—
informational, advisory, promotional and financial.
Cash grants (in place of former tax allowances) were introduced in 1966
for capital expenditure on plant and machinery in manufacturing, extractive
or constructional industry and a separate similar scheme for hotel develop¬
ment was introduced in 1968 (see p. 251).
A measure of great long-term importance wtis the Industrial Training
Act 1964, under which Industrial Training Boards, covering wide sectors of
industry, have been appointed with powers to raise a levy on all employers
in their sector and to make grants in respect of training provided (see p. 417).
The Government also provides or supports a number of training services,
mainly for retraining, for the disabled and for supervisors (see p. 418).
Individual firms seeking to improve their efficiency, to innovate or to
introduce advanced technology into their operations, are served by a range of
government sponsored advisory services. In the technological field there are,
for example, the Industrial Liaison Service of the Ministry of Technology,
the Low-cost Automation Advisory Centres and the Production Engineering
Advisory Services (see also p. 251). Firms wishing to resolve problems of
management and industrial relations can call on the greatly expanded Man¬
power and Productivity Service of the Department of Employment and
Productivity (see p. 416).
Direct government assistance to exporters is limited to measures permis¬
sible within the terms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
(GATT). Acting within these limits, the Government has increased the
Board of Trade’s allocation for participation in trade fairs, British Weeks
and other promotions overseas; and has taken steps to improve the facilities
offered by the Export Credits Guarantee Department and to develop the work
of the British National Export Council, set up in 1964, and its subordinate
bodies, in guiding and encouraging exports.
Public procurement policy is seeking to promote industrial efficiency,
especially where there is export potential; the co-operation of nationalised
industry and the local authorities is being sought to improve standardisation
and variety control.
To tackle the problems of long-term planning effectively and democratically,
a complex system has been developed, under which extensions of the services
of public authorities and of their powers to control and influence the private
sector are combined with an elaborate system of consultation to ensure that
they move as far as possible by consent.
Among the oldest of the important consultative bodies is the National
Joint Advisory Council, which was first set up in 1939 and advises the
Secretary of State for Employment and Productivity on matters of concern
to employers and employees (see p. 427).
The National Economic Development Council (NEDC), which was set
up in 1962, brings together representatives of government, management and
trade unions and provides a forum for the discussion of future policy and
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY
235
planning of the economy. It meets regularly under the chairmanship of the
Prime Minister. Other members are the ministers of the main economic
departments, representatives of management and trade unions and the
nationalised industries, independent members, the chairman of the National
Board for Prices and Incomes (NBPI) and the Director General of the
National Economic Development Office (NEDO), the independent but
publicly financed Secretariat serving the NEDC.
NEDC has set up a number of economic development committees (EDCs)
—one each for the major manufacturing industries and some of the service
industries and retail distribution as well as some covering certain general
aspects. There are 21 such EDCs. Each is under an independent chairman
and is composed of members from management, the trade unions, NEDO, the
Treasury, the Government department responsible for the particular industry
and up to three independent members. The EDCs study and promote the
application of measures to improve efficiency and competitive power in each
industry.
In 1964 the Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) was established to
take over the economic policy functions previously exercised by the Treasury
and was given the responsibility of framing and supervising a plan for econ¬
omic development. Its national plan, aiming at a 25 per cent increase in national
product between 1964 and 1970 was published in 1965. A second planning
document, The Task Ahead: Economic Assessment to igj2 was prepared by
the DEA and published in February 1969 at a time when economic thinking
was still dominated by short-term balance of payments problems. It adopted
a flexible approach, discussing the implications for government and industrial
policy of a range of different rates of economic growth. In October 1969,
the DEA was dissolved and in January 1970 the Treasury, which had resumed
responsibility for the DEA’s general economic policy functions, prepared a
revised assessment in the light of the improved external position, of con¬
sultations with industry and trade unions and reports by the EDCs. This
fresh assessment, with some modifications to take account of the budget
proposals of 14th April 1970 was published in May 1970 {Economic Prospects
to igj2—Revised Assessment). It assumed that the annual gross national
product until 1972 would be around 3 per cent in line with the trend of
production potential though the possibility of a higher rate of growth was
also considered. The best use of these increased resources, it suggested,
would be an increase in investment by private industry of 6 per cent a year,
the maintenance of the present export surplus, a growth of consumer expen¬
diture in line with the growth of the national product and a relatively slow
growth in public expenditure (see Table 13).
Long-term planning of public expenditure has been much developed and
a comprehensive survey has been made each year since 1961, one of the
objects of which is to relate public expenditure to the expected development
of the economy. New proposals on the presentation of public expenditure
over a five-year period were published in April 1969 and in December 1969
the first White Paper with such long-term forecasts was published (see
p. 361).
Prices and
Incomes Policy
The Prices and Incomes Acts of 1966 and 1967 gave powers to the Govern¬
ment to require advance notification of proposed increases in prices and
incomes, and if it referred such increases to the National Board for Prices
and Incomes (NBPI, see below), it would impose a standstill of up to six
months from the date of reference to the NBPI. A further Act of 1968 allowed
236 BRITAIN 197I: AN OFTICIAL HANDBOOK
the Government to enforce a standstill if the NBPI’s report was adverse.
Powers under the 1967 and 1968 Acts expired at the end of 1969.
The National Board for Prices and Incomes, an independent statutory body,
was set up in April 1965 and charged with investigating all questions relating
to prices and incomes referred to it by the Government. The Board has
published over 150 reports on such references. Legislation to combine the
NBPI and the Monopolies Commission into a single body, the Commission
for Industry and Manpower, was introduced in May 1970 but could not be
passed through Parliament before its prorogation for the General Election.

Regional
Economic
Planning
The aim of regional economic planning is to secure a full and balanced
development of the country’s resources and to help achieve a faster and
steadier expansion in national output.
A system of regional economic planning councils and boards established in
Great Britain in 1965, provides the basic machinery for regional economic
planning. The regional economic planning councils consist of about 25 to 30
part-time members appointed for their wide knowledge and experience of
their regions. The councils are advisory bodies with no executive powers;
their main tasks are to study and advise on the needs and potentialities of their
regions, and to advise the central Government on long-term planning
strategy for their regions. The regional economic planning boards consist of
senior civil servants representing the main government departments con¬
cerned with aspects of regional planning in their respective areas. Their
functions are to co-ordinate the regional economic planning work of the
government departments and to co-operate with the economic planning
councils.
For purposes of regional planning England has been divided into eight
regions—Northern, Yorkshire and Humberside, East Midlands, East Anglia,
South-east, South-west, West Midlands, and North-west; Scotland has its
own economic planning council and board, and there is a Welsh Council
(supported by an economic planning board) concerned with both economic
and social affairs in Wales.
All the regional economic planning councils in England have published
Regional
Policies
Northern Ireland
Summary
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY ^
major reports on their regions; a development plan for Scotland up to 1970
was published by the Government in 1966 and one for Wales in 1967.
The present stage is one of formulating medium- and longer-term strategies,
with sub-regional studies of areas with particular problems. The strategies
take into account all the factors including the distribution of population,
industry and employment within the region and provides a framework for
local government planning.
One of the most important aims of regional planning is to use more fully the
economic resources of certain areas called development areas, which have
higher than average rates of unemployment, by attracting new industry and
encouraging the expansion of existing industry. The Local Employment
Acts i960 and 1963 were strengthened by the Industrial Development Act
1966. Inducements to industries to settle in these areas (for example, building
of advanced factories by the Board of Trade, capital grants, loans towards
working capital, retraining grants) are estimated to have provided some
400,000 jobs in each year. The investment grants are at a rate double that
for firms outside the development areas. A ‘regional employment premium’,
additional to the refund of Selective Employment Tax is paid to manu¬
facturing firms in the development areas (see pp. 252 and 365). Under the
Local Employment Act 1970, assistance to the value of about £20 million a
year can now be given to certain ‘grey’ or intermediate areas in northern
England, that is, to certain districts which were outside the development
areas but whose rates of economic growth give cause for concern (see p. 252).
On the negative side, controls over industrial location and expansion of
industry in south-east England and the midlands have been intensified,
while controls over new office buildings in the same regions were introduced
in 1965.
The Northern Ireland Government has set up an economic council, com¬
prising representatives of both sides of industry and other interests, to
examine means of furthering Northern Ireland’s economic development. As
Northern Ireland government departments have responsibilities for planning
in Northern Ireland, it was not necessary to set up a special planning board.
An economic report on Northern Ireland was published in 1965 containing
targets up to 1970.
V iewed as a whole the British economy has made considerable progress over
the past decade. Its rate of growth, if not so fast as that of some other industrial
countries, has been higher than in any earlier period over the past 50 years.
At the same time relatively full employment has been maintained and con¬
sumption and living standards have improved steadily. Moreover, modernisa¬
tion of productive industry and the distributive system have progressed
despite persistent balance of payments difficulties, accentuated by the role
sterling plays as a world reserve and trading currency, and a high level of
overseas commitments in the form of development aid and defence.
11 INDUSTRY
The Structure
of Industry
Manufacturing
ORGANISATION AND PRODUCTION
The United Kingdom was the first country in the world to become highly
industrialised, and today thirteen people work in mining, manufacturing and
building for every one engaged in agriculture. It is the world’s third largest
exporter of manufactured goods, and the range of its industrial manufactures
reflects its position as one of the most important workshops of the world.
The pattern of ownership and organisation in industry is varied. Personal,
corporate, co-operative and public enterprise all assume a number of different
forms, and all are important in the economy. Industrial enterprises vary from
the many small workshops to vast organisations such as the National Coal
Board, a public corporation with about 300,000 employees; Imperial Chemical
Industries Ltd., a limited liability company which, with its subsidiaries,
employs 145,000 persons in the United Kingdom; and the Co-operative
Wholesale Society Ltd., with about 36,000 employees.
Most manufacturing is in the hands of private enterprise. Exceptions include
fissile materials and radioactive isotopes made by the Atomic Energy
Authority, iron and steel from the plants of the British Steel Corporation,
locomotives and rolling-stock built in the workshops of British Railways, and
military equipment and supplies made in establishments of the defence
services. Staff of the Stationery Office do some printing and bookbinding.
Certain factories giving employment to the severely disabled are operated by
Remploy Ltd., a non-profit-making public company financed on the Vote of
the Department of Employment and Productivity, which appoints the
directors (see p. 415). The Government holds about 49 per cent of the
equity of a major oil company, British Petroleum Limited, and has a con¬
trolling interest in a few other companies.
The most recent survey of the size of all manufacturing establishments
employing more than ten persons, made by the Department of Employment
and Productivity, showed that in 1961 nearly a third of all employees in such
establishments were in those employing from 100 to 499 persons, while
slightly over a third were in those employing 1,000 or more. A high proportion
of the biggest establishments were in the heavy industries; the average size
of establishments in industries making consumer goods was smaller than in
manufacturing industries as a whole. Comparisons with results obtained in
earlier years suggested a slow but significant trend towards increased average
size of establishments.
The size of establishments is not in itself an indication of the size of manu¬
facturing enterprises, as a single enterprise may own several establishments,
not all of them necessarily engaged in the same or similar activities. The most
recent analysis of manufacturing enterprises by size (employment) relates to
the Report on the Census of Production for 1963. An enterprise, as defined in
the Census, normally consists of either a single firm or a parent company
together with its subsidiaries, just over 60 per cent of all employment in
British manufacturing industries in 1963 was accounted for by about 975
large private enterprises employing 1,000 or more people, the largest 100 or so
accounting roughly for a third. A further indication of company size is the
INDUSTRY
239
Building and
Civil Engineering
Mining and
Quarrying
Monopolies and
Restrictive
Practices
value of capital employed (net assets). For a few of the very largest including
the Imperial Chemical Industries group, the figure exceeds £1,500 million;
about 50 companies registered in Britain have over £100 million net assets.
In some industries a small number of big companies and their subsidiaries
are responsible for most of the total production. Examples are oil refining,
non-ferrous metal smelting, the manufacture of motor vehicles and com¬
ponents, aircraft and aero-engines, heavy electrical equipment, bicycles,
tobacco, cement, basic chemicals and computers. Shares in these companies
are usually distributed among a great number of holders and it is rare for a few
large holders to have a controlling interest. For example, five of the largest
public companies each have more than 100,000 shareholders. With intensified
competition in the economy and in many branches of industry the growing
dependence of profitable operation on concentration and an increasing scale
of production, the trend towards mergers and regroupings has gathered
momentum throughout the 1960s. Larger units of control have been estab¬
lished in almost all the leading industries, for example, motor vehicles, aircraft
frames and aero-engines, electrical engineering, electronics, machine tools,
brewing, textiles, and newspaper and magazine publishing.
A new departure was the setting up of the Industrial Reorganisation
Corporation by the Government in 1966 with resources of up to £15° million.
Its function is to participate in schemes for concentration, rationalisation and
modernisation of industry, in particular the merging and regrouping of firms
into larger units to meet the changing situation in the markets for many of the
most important products, and it has been instrumental in furthering large
mergers in motor vehicle manufacturing, the heavy electrical, computer and
a wide range of other industries. The Industrial Expansion Act 1968 extended
the Government’s powers to give financial support to industrial projects
calculated to improve efficiency; to create, expand or sustain production
capacity; to promote or support technological improvements.
An account of some of the principal manufacturing industries is given on
pp. 274-97.
In building and civil engineering, large-scale work is usually carried out by
private contractors, although the Ministry of Public Building and Works is
the largest single employer of building labour while some 45 per cent of the
industry’s output is for public authorities. Building firms may be divided into
those undertaking general building and civil engineering work and those
concerned with highly specialised work, many of which operate outside as
well as inside the building industry. Building is an industry of small firms;
almost three-quarters of the firms employ fewer than 20 employees. For
a fuller account of the building and civil engineering industries, see p. 271.
Much the most important of the British extractive industries is coalmining.
The coalmining industry of Great Britain (see p. 256) is operated as a single
co-ordinated enterprise under National Coal Board direction (see p. 256).
Nearly all other mining and quarrying (sand, gravel, chalk, limestone, salt,
tin, slate, oil shale and china clay) is undertaken by private enterprises, usually
owned and operated by limited liability companies; about 59,000 workers
are employed, excluding coalmining.
Legislation exists for scrutinising and, if desirable, for the investigation by an
independent administrative body of monopoly situations and for the judicial
examination of restrictive trading agreements.
The Restrictive Trade Practices Acts 1956 and 1968 govern the registration
and judicial examination of restrictive agreements. They require the entry in
240
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
a public register of the particulars of a wide range of restrictive agreements
(including those relating to common prices, approved lists of dealers and the
limitation of production) which affect the supply or processing of goods for
the United Kingdom market. Proposed agreements of national importance
which promote efficiency or provide for new productive capacity, can be
exempted from this requirement for a specified period by the Secretary of
State for Employment and Productivity. The Registrar of Restrictive Trading
Agreements is responsible for keeping the register and for bringing the agree¬
ments before the Restrictive Practices Court set up under the 1956 Act. The
Court, which includes laymen but is presided over by one of Her Majesty’s
judges, is, in effect, responsible for deciding whether an agreement is in
the public interest. If the parties to an agreement fail to satisfy the Court
that special circumstances set out in the legislation exist, and that the restric¬
tion is not unreasonable, having regard to the balance between the benefit it
confers and any public detriment likely to result from its operation, that
restriction must be found contrary to the public interest. Agreements are void
in respect of restrictions so found. The Court can make orders preventing the
parties from operating their agreement, or from making new arrangements
having the same effect. Agreements relating exclusively to exports are not
subject to this procedure but have to be notified to the Secretary of State for
Employment and Productivity.
Under the 1956 Act collective enforcement of resale price maintenance was
prohibited, but individual suppliers remained free to enforce resale prices in
the courts. The Resale Prices Act 1964 made minimum resale price mainten¬
ance unlawful, except in respect of classes of registered goods for which
temporary exemption has been sought under the provisions of the Act.
Where resale price maintenance is prohibited, it is also unlawful to notify to
dealers prices stated or calculated to be understood as the minimum price
which may be charged on the resale of goods in the United Kingdom, or to
seek to maintain such prices by withholding supplies. Suppliers may continue
to practise resale price maintenance on registered goods, pending a decision
by the Restrictive Practices Court as to whether a case for exemption has
been made out against the criteria in the Act. Periodically, the Registrar of
Restrictive Trading Agreements issues lists of classes of goods in respect of
which the Court has refused to make an Order exempting them from the
terms of the Act. Only one class of goods (books and maps) has so far gained
exemption under an order from the court; nearly 500 classes have been
refused exemption.
Monopolies and kindred arrangements (other than those within the scope
of the Restrictive Practices Court) may, in circumstances indicated in the
Monopolies and Mergers Act 1948 and 1965, be referred by the Board of
Trade to the Monopolies Commission for investigation and report. The
Department of Employment and Productivity, in co-operation with the pro¬
duction departments (see p. 247) concerned, take appropriate action on
reports but no Order can be made without parliamentary approval. The 1965
Act strengthened and extended the legislation on monopolies. It reorganised
and enlarged the Monopolies Commission; provided for the investigation,
at the reference of the DEP, of services as wTell as goods and of proposed or
recently completed mergers; made special provision for newspaper mergers;
and improved and extended the Government’s powers—subject to parlia¬
mentary control—for taking action on the basis of the Monopolies Com¬
mission reports including new powers to prohibit mergers and break up
undesirable monopolies and mergers.
INDUSTRY
Role of Public
Enterprise
241
Direct State participation in productive and commercial activities is effected
mainly through special statutory bodies set up to deal with a particular
activity. Such bodies, though not part of a government department, are under
a considerable but varying degree of public control (see below). The most
important of these statutory bodies are the public corporations which operate
major industries and services in the public interest. Altogether 10 per cent
of the labour force works for these bodies. Their managing boards and staffs
are chosen for their experience and competence in a particular field; they are
not civil servants, and, although accountable to Parliament for their actions
in a variety of ways, it is they and not the ministers of the sponsoring
departments who are responsible for the management of the corporations.
Certain of the corporations are self-supporting; others receive Exchequer
grants to help them carry out duties with which they have been charged.
These corporations are described in their relevant sections.
The extent to which the responsible minister has power over the working
of the boards which have been set up to run the nationalised industries varies
from industry to industry, but two features are common to almost all of them.
First, the minister appoints (and may dismiss) the chairman and members of
each board, and, secondly, he has power to give general directions as to how
the industry should be run, but does not interfere in day-to-day manage¬
ment. It is usually also laid down that the board shall give to the minister
any information, statistics and financial accounts which he may require. In
practice, as the responsible minister is kept fully informed and major policy
decisions are reached in consultation with him, there is very seldom occasion
for him to issue a formal directive.
The minister also has financial powers and responsibilities. The usual
statutory requirement is that the board is required to conduct its business so
that receipts at least balance outgoings taking one year with another. The
responsible minister is usually empowered (subject to Treasury approval) to
say what shall be done with any surplus revenues which may accrue. As
regards finance of capital expenditure, the present system is that such finance
as cannot be met from internal sources is mainly provided, in the form of
interest-earning loans, by the minister from the Exchequer, bank advances
being used only for normal requirements of short-term capital.
It is usual for the minister responsible for each nationalised industry to be
required by statute to take steps to see that the interests of the industry’s
customers are protected. This is generally done by the establishment of
representative consumers’ councils to consider complaints and suggestions
made to them, and to advise the board or the minister on the changes they
think desirable.
Financial targets have been agreed by the Government with the different
industries (or are under discussion) ranging from I2‘4 per cent gross return
on capital employed to ‘breaking even’ after interest and depreciation have
been allowed for. In addition the industries are expected to apply a test
discount rate for new investment of 10 per cent.
Government policy towards the nationalised industries is subject to the
approval of Parliament. Opportunities for parliamentary discussion are
afforded by debates, including debates on their annual reports and accounts,
and by answers to parliamentary questions, which, in principle, are admissible
only if concerned with policy rather than details of administration. A House of
Commons Select Committee on the Nationalised Industries, which examines
the reports and accounts of the nationalised industries and reports to Parlia¬
ment, has been in operation since 1957.
242
Industrial
Association
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
From the middle of the nineteenth century, private industrial undertakings
have increasingly entered into voluntary association for a number of different
purposes. Some of the more important of these are classified as: (1) the
provision of common services, the exchange of information, liaison with
the Government, and representation of their members’ point of view; (2) the
regulation of trading practices, sometimes including the regulation of prices
(see p. 240); (3) negotiation with trade unions on wages and conditions of
work. Associations for the first and third of these purposes cover, with
varying completeness, most of British industry, but there are wide sectors of
industry where there are no collective agreements to regulate trading practices.
Employers’ organisations which deal with labour matters usually consist of
firms engaged in the same type of operation or manufacturing process. Trade
associations mainly concerned with representations to the Government,
provision of common services or the regulation of trading practices are built
up round a product or an allied group of products. In an industrial sector
concerned wholly with an allied group of products, a single association may
undertake all the required functions.
There are about 75 national federations and probably altogether about
1,500 employers’ organisations (mostly regional or local, and members or
branches of the national federations) all concerned with negotiation of wages
and conditions of work. The number of manufacturers’ associations concerned
with providing common services is not known precisely, but according to a
survey carried out between 1953 and 1956 by Political and Economic Planning
(an independent research organisation) some 1,300 were in existence, varying
greatly in importance, structure and activities.
The central body representing British industry nationally is the Confedera¬
tion of British Industry (CBI). It is recognised by the Government as a
channel for consultation between government departments and representatives
of private employers as a whole. For its members it acts as an advisory and
consultative body providing them with information and statistics, ascertaining
their collective views and representing them nationally to the Government
and the public and also internationally, for example in the Council of European
Industrial Federations. CBI representatives sit on a number of government
advisory committees, on other statutory bodies and on voluntary bodies
concerned with matters affecting industry.
The CBI membership consists of some 11,500 companies and about 200
trade associations and employers’ federations. Nationalised industries have
joined as industrial associates. The CBI has a regional organisation in the
United Kingdom and is widely represented abroad.
In matters of common concern the CBI often acts jointly with the chambers
of commerce. These are open to all kinds of producers and traders and exist
to promote the interests of local industry and commerce. The Association of
British Chambers of Commerce, founded in i860, is the central organisation
to which 93 local chambers of commerce (together with 17 British Chambers of
Commerce operating abroad) are affiliated. In Scotland there is an additional
central organisation, the Scottish Chamber of Commerce, and in Northern
Ireland, the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce and Industry to which
local chambers are affiliated.
Location
The following is a summary of the geographical distribution of British industry
today, grouped by the areas covered by the regional economic planning
machinery (see p. 236).
