Greater London
and the South-east
Region
South-west
England
East Anglia
West Midlands
London, lying at the head of ocean navigation on the Thames estuary, is
Britain’s capital and main communication centre, probably still the world’s
most important financial centre, and one of the world’s three largest cities
(with Tokyo and New York) and three largest ports (with New York and
Rotterdam). It is the main centre in Britain of printing, cinema film produc¬
tion and the manufacture of clothing, food and drink, furniture, materials for
the arts, precision instruments and many other specialised products. Small
firms predominate in many of these industries and the average size of manu¬
facturing firms (particularly in the central area) is well below the national
average. London is also, especially its outer ring, important for light engineer¬
ing, chemicals and consumer goods and has some heavy engineering plants
and a number of leading research establishments.
Towards the periphery of Greater London (population 7,763,820) and in
the new urban development outside it, industry, particularly the electronics
and a variety of consumer goods industries, has expanded greatly; some
of the largest aircraft plants are in these areas, for example at Weybridge
and Hatfield, as well as factories, at Dagenham, Luton and Dunstable, of two
of the four main motor vehicle manufacturers. There are other major motor
vehicle manufacturing plants at Cowley, Oxford (110,000), some 5° miles
north-west of London. Along the lower Thames and Medway estuaries there
are large oil refineries as well as some smaller shipyards, engineering works
and major concentrations of the paper and pulp and cement industries.
A great part of the Channel coast eastwards from Poole (population 99,000)
and Bournemouth (151,500) consists of built-up areas, which from Brighton
(165,000) eastwards are partly dormitories for people working in London.
Holiday resorts fringe the coast. Portsmouth (219,000) is a naval port with
some shipbuilding and general manufactures. Southampton (210,000) is
Britain’s largest port for ocean-going liners; its industries include ship
repairing, oil refining, cable-making, electronics and synthetic rubber. Dover,
Folkestone and Newhaven are packet ports.
Devon and Cornwall have a considerable tourist trade. Bristol (428,000) is a
leading port and commercial centre with aircraft, aero-engines, tobacco, food
processing, paper, printing and other industries and important non-ferrous
metals and basic chemicals plants at Avonmouth. Gloucester (90,500), origin¬
ally an inland port and commercial town, Cheltenham (76,000), originally a
resort town, and the area between and adjacent to them produce a variety of
manufactures, including machinery, instruments and accessories, and clotn.
Swindon (98,000), besides railway workshops, has important engineering
works. Bath (85,000), originally a resort town and centre of an agricultural
district, has become noted for engineering and other manufacturing.
Besides being one of the most productive agricultural regions, the eastern
counties possess some sizeable towns. Cambridge (100,500) is a leading centre
of research-based industry; Ipswich (122,000) and Peterborough (66,500) are
noted for diesel engines, agricultural machinery and engineering generally;
and Norwich (119,000) for footwear and food manufacture. Food canning and
freezing, based mainly on locally grown produce, have developed rapidly.
The fishing ports of Great Yarmouth (51,000) and Lowestoft (50,000) have
fish processing plants, and are also becoming important bases for companies
engaged in natural gas exploitation in the North Sea.
The West Midlands conurbation, which stretches from Birmingham
(1,074,000) to Wolverhampton (265,000) and includes parts of Staffordshire,
Worcestershire and Warwickshire, has an unusually wide variety of industry,
244
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
East Midlands
North-west
England
including the manufacture of metals, electrical and engineering products of all
kinds and also jewellery, rubber products, chemicals and domestic metalware.
The largest concentrations of motor vehicle manufacture (including com¬
ponents and accessories) in Britain are in Birmingham and Coventry (335,000).
The smaller conurbation of North Staffordshire, centred on Stoke-on-Trent
(273,000), is devoted chiefly to the manufacture of pottery and china and to
coalmining, although other industries are growing in importance, while
Stafford (53,000) has heavy electrical and other engineering works.
Other industrial centres are Rugby (57,000), electrical engineering;
Worcester (71,000), machinery; Burton-on-Trent (51,000), brewing and
rubber; and Kidderminster (46,000), carpets.
The thriving industrial cities and towns of the East Midlands include Leicester
(280,000), noted for hosiery and knitwear, boots and shoes and machinery for
making these products; Derby (221,000) for general engineering, aero-engines
and man-made fibres; Nottingham (305,000) for hosiery, cycles and a variety
of other engineering products, lace, pharmaceutical products and tobacco;
Northampton, (124,000) footwear and engineering; Chesterfield (70,000),
engineering. Corby (48,000), a new town in Northamptonshire, has a steel
industry. Part of Britain’s richest and most highly mechanised coalfield lies
under the north-east of the area. Some of the towns on the coalfield, such as
Mansfield (56,000), have important manufacturing industries, particularly
textiles.
Manchester (603,000) is the commercial hub of the cotton and man-made
fibre textile industries, a very important financial and commercial centre and
a major port. It is also one of the chief centres for electrical and heavy
engineering and the production of machine tools, petro-chemicals, dyestuffs,
and pharmaceutical goods, while it has a wide range of other manufactures.
In the traditional cotton-manufacturing towns man-made fibres are also
processed alone or blended with cotton; the largest of these are Bolton
(154,000), Oldham (109,000), Rochdale (86,000), Stockport (141,000), Burnley
(77,000), Blackburn (100,000), Preston (104,000) and Bury (66,000). In the
majority of these towns engineering industries, notably the manufacture of
printing, paper making, textile and electrical machinery and heavy commercial
vehicles (especially in the Chorley-Leyland area), have been expanding while
the cotton industry has been declining. The Lancashire coalfield also lies in
the Manchester-Wigan area.
The Manchester Ship Canal, which carries a substantial volume of overseas
trade, links Manchester and Merseyside. It passes through Warrington
(72,000) with its metal industries (such as wire-drawing), Widnes (54,000) and
Runcorn (31,000) with their chemicals, and Ellesmere Port (55,000) with its
oil refinery installations, before reaching the Mersey estuary. St. Helens
(102.500) , to the north of the canal, is famous for glass manufacture.
Liverpool (689,000) is the second port of Britain, a great commercial and
insurance centre and, after London, the greatest centre for processing imported
foodstuffs and raw materials, noted especially for flour milling, soap manu¬
facture, sugar refining and rubber products. Among its older industries is
ship repairing; shipbuilding is a major industry across the river at Birkenhead
(142.500) . Many new industries, including electrical engineering, manufacture
of heavy industrial equipment and, more recently, of motor vehicles, have been
established around Liverpool. Salt, extracted in Cheshire, is used by chemical
works on Merseyside.
Barrow (64,000), in the north-west of Lancashire, is well known for ship-
Yorkshire and
Humberside
Northern England
Wales
INDUSTRY 245
building and marine engineering. Blackpool (148,000) on the coast is Britain’s
most popular holiday resort.
About three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s worsted and woollen indus¬
tries are found in the West Riding of Yorkshire. Bradford (294,500) is the
commercial centre of the wool trade and important for worsted; Wakefield
(60,000) produces both worsted and woollens; Morley (44,000) and Leeds
(506,000) have specialised in cheaper cloths, and Batley (42,000), Dewsbury
(52,000) and Spenborough (39,000) in heavy cloth, but their production is
becoming more diversified. Huddersfield (131,000) has a reputation for fine
woollens and worsteds and Halifax (94,000) for carpets. In most of the larger
centres of the wool industry a variety of engineering products are manu¬
factured. Leeds, the commercial capital of the area, has a large ready-made
clothing industry and important engineering plants. Farther south is the heavy
engineering centre of Sheffield (532,000), famous for its high quality steels,
cutlery and tools. The area’s extensive coalfields provide nearly a quarter of
Britain’s coal; Doncaster (84,000), also with tractor and nylon manufacturing,
and Barnsley (75,000) are the largest towns on the coalfield.
York (110,500) is noted for chocolates and confectionery manufacture and
has important railway workshops, and Hull (295,000), one of the world’s
largest fishing ports and with many manufacturing industries, including
engineering, vegetable oil processing, paints and sawmilling, is the most
important industrial town in the East Riding of Yorkshire.
On the south (Lincolnshire) side of the Humber lie Scunthorpe (70,000),
another important steel-making centre, and the major fishing port of Grimsby
(97,000) which has a food processing industry and also growing chemicals and
textiles industries close by at Immingham.
The greater part of this region (Northumberland, Cumberland, Westmorland,
Durham and the North Riding of Yorkshire) is an area of mountains, lakes and
moors and is relatively thinly populated. Most of its population is concen¬
trated in the coastal strip from the coalfields north of the Tyne to the Tees.
Within this area the main centres are Tyneside, including Newcastle upon
Tyne (245,000), Gateshead (100,500), Tynemouth (73,000), South Shields
(107,000), Wallsend (47,000) and Jarrow (29,000); and Teesside (393,000) and
Hartlepool (99,000). Other large towns are Sunderland (220,000), Darlington
(84,000) and, in the west, Carlisle (71,000).
The whole region is more dependent than other parts of England on
traditional heavy industries, notably coalmining, iron and steel manufacture,
shipbuilding and repairing and chemicals (the complex of chemical plants on
both banks of the Tees is probably the most extensive in Europe), which
together employ nearly a third of the male workers. This proportion has been
falling steadily as the result of the region’s efforts, with government help, to
attract new types of enterprise. It is one of the most important areas for the
manufacture of electrical plant, and the many other industries include mining
machinery, rolling mill plant, earth-moving equipment, machine tools, ropes,
paint, glass, clothing and scientific instruments. An aluminium smelter is
under construction on the Northumberland coast. Atomic energy is important
in Cumberland, with two nuclear power stations and other installations.
Nearly two-thirds of the population of Wales and Monmouthshire live in the
two counties of Glamorgan and Monmouthshire. In this area are the coal
mines which, though long worked and operating at increasing depths, still
produce nearly all Britain’s anthracite and much of its steam and other
specialised coals, and employ more workers than any branch of manufacturing
246
Scotland
Northern Ireland
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
industry. Rhondda (95,500) and Merthyr Tydfil (57,000) are the largest
centres in the coalmining area. The steel industry, with some of the most
modern plants in Europe, supplies almost all Britain’s output of tin plate and
much of its sheet steel. In the past 35 years many new industries have been
established, often on government industrial estates; they include plastics,
synthetic fibres, clothing, electronics, motor vehicle components and light
engineering.
The main urban centres are also the three major ports—Cardiff (287,000),
Newport (112,000) and Swansea (171,000). Milford Haven (14,000), a magni¬
ficent deep-water harbour recently developed, has two major oil refineries.
In North Wales a number of light industries, notably man-made fibres, are
located in the seaside resorts and some other towns, particularly Wrexham
(37,000), and there is a large steelworks in Flintshire.
About three-quarters of Scotland’s population (5-2 million) is concentrated in
the central Lowlands between the Firth of Clyde and the Firth of Forth. The
principal cities in this area are Glasgow (945,000) and Edinburgh (465,000).
Clydeside, which includes Glasgow, is a major shipbuilding and marine
engineering centre; it also has a great variety of general engineering enter¬
prises and other industries. The steel industry, sited mainly in north Lanark¬
shire, produces a wide range of products. The widely dispersed electronics
equipment industry is represented by a growing number of firms in such
centres as Glasgow, north Lanarkshire, Dundee and central Fife, as well as in
Edinburgh, where this and other modern industries are expanding alongside
the long-established engineering, printing and brewing industries. Motor car
manufacture has been established in Renfrewshire and in West Lothian there
has been a major expansion of commercial vehicle building.
Outside the central Lowland belt there is considerable industrial concen¬
tration in and around Dundee (182,000) and Aberdeen (181,000) and a number
of towns outside these areas have attracted light industries in recent years.
Dundee’s traditional manufacture, jute, has been supplemented by office
machinery, clocks and watches, refrigerators and electronic products. In
north-east Scotland is the largest concentration of whisky distilleries, while
the paper and metal industries are also important.
Most of northern Scotland is mountainous and much of southern Scotland
is hilly and rugged. These regions are sparsely populated, but the Scottish
Highlands possess significant resources of hydro-electric power (see p. 263).
There are high-quality tweed and knitwear industries both in the valley
towns of the Borders and in the Highlands and Islands. Small engineering and
electronics industries have recently been established in towns in the Borders
and the south-west. Small-scale manufacturing has also been introduced in the
Highlands, and larger enterprises include the experimental atomic reactor
establishment at Dounreay and the aluminium smelter being built at
Invergorden.
Although the area of Northern Ireland is relatively small and it lacks minerals,
there is substantial and growing industrialisation, particularly in and around
Belfast, the capital city (391,000). Britain’s largest single shipyard incorporat¬
ing the world’s biggest shipbuilding berth is in Belfast; other long-established
activities include the manufacture of textile machinery and other engineering
products; ropes, twine, tobacco and clothing. Northern Ireland has also long
been an important centre for textiles—it is particularly well known for
linen. The textile industry is now extensively diversified; Northern Ireland
is one of the most important areas in Europe for man-made fibre produc-

Relations
between the
Government
and Industry
247
tion and provides about one-fifth of Britain’s output. There has also been
extensive development in vehicle components, oil-well equipment, elec¬
tronic instruments, telephone switchgear, toys, shoes, carpets and synthetic
rubber.
The Government can influence industrial activity in a number of ways—
through fiscal and monetary policy, through the level of public expenditure,
through the placing of government contracts, through the policies of publicly
owned enterprises, by physical controls, by inducements, by exhortation and
by the provision of services, information and advice. Apart from labour
legislation (see Chapter 16) and certain export and import controls over a
small range of products (see Chapter 15), there are few physical controls over
industry—the main ones are the use of the legislation concerning monopolies
and restrictive practices already described (see p. 239) and the operation of
powers to control new industrial and office building and changes in land use
(see p. 251).
There is a close association between industry and the Government through
such channels as the National Economic Development Council, the main
forum for consultation on economic affairs between the Government,
management and the trade unions, and Economic Development Committees
(EDCs), which cover particular sectors of industry and are under the aegis of
industry. A major reconstruction of Government machinery relating to
industrial policy was announced in October 1969. The Department of Econo¬
mic Affairs was abolished, with its responsibility for medium- and long-term
economic questions passing to the Treasury, and the co-ordination of regional
policies to a new Secretary of State for Local Government and Regional
Planning. The Ministry of Technology was expanded by absorbing the former
Ministry of Power, and by the transfer from the Board of Trade of responsi¬
bility for location of industry policy and investment grants. The Board of
Trade retained responsibility for printing and publishing, distribution and the
service trades; its role in relation to exports, commercial policy and consumer
protection was not affected by the changes. Policies for productivity, prices
and incomes, and manpower are the concern of the Department of Employ¬
ment and Productivity. Other departments concerned with particular subjects
of concern to industry generally are the Treasury (fiscal and monetary policy)
and the Department of Education and Science, which is responsible for the
promotion of education and for civil science, operating in the main through the
research councils.
For particular industries a system has grown up whereby a particular
government department acts as the main point of contact, the ‘production’ or
‘sponsor department’, for each major industry. Following the changes out¬
lined above the Ministry of Technology is the sponsor department for the
mechanical and electrical engineering industries and for those manufacturing
chemicals, non-ferrous metals, ships’ electronic equipment, computers,
machine tools, telecommunications equipment, shipping, aircraft and aero¬
engines. Others include the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, the
Board of Trade, the Ministry of Public Building and Works and the Depart¬
ment of Health and Social Security.
There are separate departments of the Northern Ireland Government for
matters within the competence of the Northern Ireland Parliament. The
Ministry of Commerce deals with industry, especially the encouragement of
industrial development.

The Central Statistical Office (CSO), which is attached to the Cabinet Office,
is the central body for government statistics. Although departments them¬
selves compile statistics relating to their responsibilities and may publish
them in their own standard publications, the comprehensive statistical
publications are prepared by the CSO, which acts as co-ordinator. The
Business Statistical Office, which is responsible to the CSO for policy but is
administratively part of the Board of Trade, will eventually take over the
responsibility for compiling a wide range of statistics relating to industry and
commerce. (For the principal regular series of statistics published, see Biblio¬
graphy, p. 481.)
Industrial production (mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction,
and gas, electricity and water) was in the first half of 197° fractionally less
than a year previously, about one-third higher than in i960 and about double
the pre-war level. The course of production and employment from 1963 to
1969 is shown in Table 14.
Among manufacturing industries output rose fastest between 1963 and
1969 in the chemical and allied industries (49 per cent), in engineering and
electrical goods (37 per cent), and in paper, printing and publishing (23 per
cent); in the gas, electricity and water group there was an advance of 36 per
cent and in construction of 22 per cent.

The size of the labour force has scarcely changed in the last five years and
the increases in production have been due mainly to a variety of factors
influencing productivity, including advances in products, machinery, pro¬
cesses and methods of work; the rate of fixed capital formation; more intensive
competition and sales promotion; and improved management.
Although gross fixed capital formation at home has, as a whole, been well
maintained since 1966, the proportion devoted to manufacturing has tended
to fall. The total in 1969 amounted to 21-8 per cent of the gross domestic
product and was estimated (at current prices) to be almost double the 1959
level. Part of this rising investment is linked with the introduction of new tech¬
niques and equipment and in particular of machines and instruments which
lessen the demand for human skill and supervision though they may require
more skill from fewer people. This process of automation is giving rise to far-
reaching changes in the pattern of industry and in the internal organisation
and labour requirements of business enterprises and has already been respon¬
sible for consequential increases in production and efficiency which, in the
long run, are likely to be very large. Much investment, however, still con¬
sists of replacements, additions and improvements of a more traditional kind.

Both the long-term and the short-term growth of productivity thus depend
most directly on the decisions of individual undertakings. But though the
promotion of productivity is regarded as primarily a matter of industry,
government departments and educational and research establishments also
have an important contribution to make. Government budgeting and financial
policies also have a strong influence on the extent and direction of demand,
and government purchasing policies take account of national industrial
objectives.
Within industry employers’ organisations often provide technical assistance,
conduct market surveys, and support schemes of vocational education and
training, and many trade unions organise special training schemes and courses
to promote understanding of modern management techniques. Changes in
working methods to facilitate higher output feature in a number of produc¬
tivity agreements negotiated between management and workers. Private
consultants specialising in management and work study are available to advise
firms on measures to increase their productive efficiency, there are also many
specialist institutions, both public and private, concerned with various aspects
of productivity. The British Productivity Council (BPC) was established by
both sides of industry to stimulate interest in methods of raising productivity.
It is an independent body on which are represented the Confederation of
British Industry, the Trades Union Congress, the Association of British
Chambers of Commerce and the nationalised industries; its work is financed
by contributions from these bodies and by a government grant-in-aid. Most
of the BPC’s work is done through more than 143 local productivity com¬
mittees and associations throughout the country, but it is also responsible for
special countrywide campaigns. The local organisations arrange meetings,
inter-factory visits, courses, conferences, film shows and exhibitions.
The British Standards Institution (BSI) is a voluntary non-profit-making
body incorporated by Royal Charter. It prepares and promulgates standards
in respect of, inter alia, quality, performance, dimensions, testing methods and
codes of practice. Voluntary acceptance of such standards by manufacturers,
buyers and sellers reduces unnecessary variety and simplifies the specification
of requirements. The BSI is governed by a council consisting of representa¬
tives of the main organisations of employers and workers, professional
institutions and the larger government departments.
The Council of Industrial Design (CoID), set up in 1944 by the Government
to promote higher standards of design in British industry, is concerned with
250
Co-ordination
Management
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
all aspects of industrial design from durable consumer goods to capital goods.
The CoID, with its Scottish Committee, is a grant-aided body sponsored by
the Board of Trade; its members include industrialists, retailers, architects,
designers and educationists. At the Design Centre in the Haymarket,
London, a selective but changing display of modern British consumer goods
is maintained; exhibits are chosen from Design Index, the CoID’s illustrated
record of more than 11,000 well-designed products. Special exhibitions on
particular themes are also arranged regularly. An annual awards scheme,
Council of Industrial Design Awards, covering capital goods and engineer¬
ing equipment as well as consumer products, was introduced in 1967* The
Duke of Edinburgh also presents his annual Prize for Elegant Design. The
Scottish Committee runs the Scottish Design Centre in Glasgow, and there
are three independent regional design centres, each maintaining a duplicate
of the Index, at Liverpool, Manchester and Nottingham. The CoID organises
temporary exhibitions in regional centres and overseas; arranges regular
conferences and training courses; and undertakes industrial study tours in
Britain. It publishes a monthly magazine, Design, and maintains extensive
reference and photographic libraries.
Other bodies concerned with industrial design include the Royal Society of
Arts (see p. 194), the Society of Industrial Artists and Designers, which is the
representative professional body in Great Britain of designers engaged in
industry and commerce, and the Design and Industries Association (DIA), a
voluntary association of industrial companies, designers, and others interested
in the promotion of good design in industry. The Crafts Council of Great
Britain, the Crafts Centre of Great Britain and the Scottish Craft Centre are
all grant-aided by the Board of Trade. Their aims are to improve craft design
and to promote closer relations between craftsmen and industry.
The Ministry of Technology is responsible for co-ordinating government
policies in industrial policy. EDCs (see p. 247) are particularly concerned with
removing obstacles to efficiency; the ministry is represented on the EDCs by
its industrial advisers seconded to the department from industry. Government
grants to the BPC and the Council of Industrial Design are administered by
the Department of Employment and Productivity and the Board of Trade
respectively. The Ministry of Technology is charged with extending the intro¬
duction of automatic control systems and advanced techniques into industry,
sponsors the BSI, the British Calibration Service1 and the National Computing
Centre, supports the National Data Processing Service, and provides technical
advisory services. It is also concerned directly with research into such factors
as productivity measurement techniques, group technology, production
engineering and fatigue among operators. The Manpower and Productivity
Service of the Department of Employment and Productivity advises firms on
productivity, particularly aspects connected with manpower utilisation and
industrial relations. A number of other departments have responsibilities
which bear on productivity.
In Britain, as elsewhere, management is recognised as a subject requiring
special skills and knowledge. This is reflected both in a change in the general
educational qualifications of recruits and in the spread of systematic education
and training for management.
The British Institute of Management (BIM) is the central national manage-
t up in 1966 to provide reliable calibration facilities for industries producing
cinstruments and industrial test gear.
INDUSTRY

Encouragement
of Investment
in Industry
Government
Help for
Industry in
Development
Areas
ment body, independent, non-political and non-profit-making. Its purpose is
to study and promote scientific management, including management education
and training, throughout industry, commerce and public administration. The
BIM receives an annual government grant of about £100,000 to help it expand
services to industry. The Industrial Society works to promote better use of
human resources; it advises members and conducts conferences and courses.
Management studies and education for management are expanding rapidly
in Britain and have become a recognised feature of higher education (see
p. 162). There are graduate business schools in London and Manchester.
Training courses for higher management are held at several universities and
colleges, including the Administrative Staff College, Henley-on-Thames, and
Ashridge College of Management, Berkhamsted. The larger firms, especially
those with wide responsibilities, often provide general management courses
for senior executives, and systems of informal training within an organisation
are numerous. There are also bodies concerned with specialised branches of
management, for example, the Institute of Personnel Management, the
Institution of Works Managers, the Institute of Office Management and the
Institute of Marketing.
The growing number of professional personnel working as management
consultants—now over 3,500—and the use of the services of independent
management selection firms in the appointment of senior staff are further
indications of interest in the science of management in Britain. A government
scheme for helping smaller firms (25 to 500 employees) to pay for the services
of consultants was operated in the Bristol and Glasgow areas for several
months in 1968-69. The Government is considering whether a similar scheme
should be extended nationally.
Under the Industrial Development Act 1966 cash grants were introduced in
place of certain tax allowances for capital expenditure on plant or machinery
used in the manufacturing, extractive and construction industries. The grant
scheme, which is administered by the Ministry of Technology (see p. 56)
also covers capital expenditure on computers, ships, hovercraft and mining
works. The standard rate of grant is 20 per cent. In order to maintain a greater
incentive to investment in development areas (see below) the rate of grant is
40 per cent for plant or machinery for use in development areas. Over 40 per
cent of the total amount paid on plant and machinery, mining works and
computers goes to the development areas. A separate system of grants and
loans to encourage hotel development has been operating since 1968.
Some parts of Britain have long been less prosperous than others. Their rate of
economic expansion has been below average and their level of unemployment
above average as a result of the decline of some traditional industries or the
lack of job opportunities. For many years unemployment has remained a
persistent problem in Scotland, Wales and the north-east and some other
parts of England. This regional imbalance has been aggravated by the tendency
for new industries to concentrate in the Midlands and the south-east where, as
a result, the demand for labour is high and there are increasing problems of
congestion. An important aim of the Government’s regional policy is to
achieve a better distribution of industrial development between the different
parts of the country. The Government has in recent years taken important
measures aimed at securing balanced economic development.
Government aid to areas of high unemployment began in the 1930s and
has been developed in various ways since the end of the second world war.
252
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Since August 1966 large parts of Britain have been designated as ‘development
areas’ where industrial development is to be encouraged. They cover northern
England, Merseyside and nearly the whole of Scotland, Wales, Cornwall and
north Devon and contain a fifth of Britain’s working population. The Ministry
of Technology provides businessmen with detailed information on industrial
location within the development areas and offers a wide variety of inducements
to new or expanding businesses in these areas, the first priority being given to
smaller ‘special development areas’.
Besides the capital investment grants there is a wide range of financial and
other inducements available under the Local Employment Acts 1960-70 to
encourage industry to expand in the assisted areas. The Ministry of Tech¬
nology may build factories for leasing, in some cases with an initial rent-free
period, or sale on deferred terms; make building grants of 25 per cent (and 35
per cent in special cases) of the cost of building an industrialist’s own factory;
make grants towards the removal costs of firms moving into a development
area; and make loans for the general purposes of an undertaking (for example,
working capital, plant and machinery, etc.). In the special development areas,
operational grants may be paid to help new firms during the first three years
of their establishment.
Factory building and estate management are undertaken on the Ministry of
Technology’s behalf by the English, Scottish and Welsh Industrial Estates
Corporations; premises administered by the three Corporations total over
60 million square feet and give employment to over 250,000 people.
Assistance from other government departments includes 85 per cent capital
grants to local authorities for clearing derelict or neglected sites and for
improving basic services; and help from the DEP with the cost of training
additional labour in development areas and of transferring workers in
connection with establishing new enterprises.
Employers in the manufacturing industry in development areas are entitled
not only to refund of selective employment tax (see p. 365) but also receive
regional employment premiums of £1-50 a week for every full-time male
employee with lower rates for women, part-timers, boys and girls.
A committee set up in 1967 to investigate the needs of ‘Intermediate
Areas’—those areas with special economic problems but situated outside the
development areas—published its report in 1969. Under the Local Employ¬
ment Act 1970 certain such areas were given special assistance, similar to but
more limited than that available in the development areas under earlier Local
Employment Acts, including factory building grants, additional provisions
for industrial training and help in a clearance programme of derelict land.
Since 1948 control of new industrial building has been exercised through
the use of a system of Industrial Development Certificates. Any application
under the normal town and country planning machinery for planning
permission for industrial development involving more than 5,000 square feet
of floor space (or 3,000 square feet in the Midlands and south-east) must be
accompanied by a certificate from the Ministry of Technology certifying that
the development in question can be carried out consistently with the proper
distribution of industry. In considering applications the Ministry pays par¬
ticular regard to the need for providing appropriate employment in the
assisted areas. In practice this obligation has led to the refusal of certificates
for most projects outside the assisted areas unless it can be shown that the
project could not reasonably be undertaken in such an area or in Northern
Ireland. Subject to this priority, the control is also used to encourage dispersal
of industry to new or expanded towns taking population from the more
INDUSTRY
253
Northern Ireland
Councils to
Promote

congested areas. Under the Control of Office and Industrial Development Act
1965 the Board of Trade was given power—transferred to the Ministry of
Housing and Local Government in 1969—to control office developments of
over 10,000 square feet in most of the Midlands, and in the south-east other
than Greater London where the limit is 3,000 square feet.
Nearly 6^ per cent of workers employed in manufacturing industries in
1966 were in plants opened since 1945 by firms whose manufacturing base
was in some other region. A further 3 J per cent were in those opened by firms
whose base was in some other part of the region. The development areas (and
Northern Ireland) have made net gains of employment in the last two decades
by the movement of manufacturing industries.
Under its own legislation Northern Ireland provides for the payment of
investment grants at 40 per cent of the cost both of new plant and machinery
and of new buildings for the manufacturing, construction and extractive
industries in Northern Ireland. There is also provision for assisting firms by
means of loans to cany out major schemes of re-equipment, to move to
another area in particular need of industrial development or to undertake a
rehousing of their business in association with a major scheme of modernisa¬
tion and reorganisation. Help under the investment grants legislation is
largely made without regard to how much employment is created as a
result.
As an alternative means of assistance the Northern Ireland Government
continues to use its comprehensive and flexible powers authorised under the
Industries Development Acts for projects which offer a reasonable amount of
employment. In such cases capital assistance of 45 per cent would normally
be available instead of the 40 per cent referred to above. For those projects
which offer exceptionally attractive returns in employment or location within
Northern Ireland, the assistance offered could include tenancy of a govern¬
ment-built factory at a very low rent, grants towards operating costs in the
initial stages, and grants towards costs of removing existing machinery and
installing it in a factory in Northern Ireland. The regional employment
premium and selective employment premium apply also to Northern Ireland.
Since 1945 almost 280 new firms have been established in Northern Ireland
with government assistance, giving employment to some 80,000 people.
The Ministry of Commerce is the Northern Ireland government department
concerned with the administration of industrial development policies. The
Northern Ireland Economic Council was set up in 1965 to assist in furthering
economic growth. The chairman is the Minister of Commerce, and the
membership includes representatives of industry, commerce and the trade
unions.
Certain regions and areas in England have industrial development associations
concerned with promoting local industry. These are sponsored mainly by local
authorities, trade associations and individual firms.
Several voluntary associations are concerned with Welsh industry. The
Development Corporation for Wales, founded in 1959, is the most prominent.
In Scotland, the Highlands and Islands Development Board, set up by
statute in 1965, works to stimulate the economic and social development of
the seven ‘crofting’ counties (see p. 313). It provides grants and loans to
industrial, commercial and other enterprises; it may also acquire land,
provide management and other advisory services and set up and carry on
businesses. The Scottish Council (Development and Industry), a voluntary
association, promotes the general economic development of Scotland.

Encouragement is given to the development of rural industries. Much of this
work is done under the aegis of the Development Commission1 with finance
from the Development Fund, notably advice and guidance to small businesses
in rural areas and country towns and loans for assistance to tourism in the
rural parts of development areas. In England and Wales this service is
provided by the Council for Small Industries in Rural Areas acting in consulta¬

Committees in the counties; by the Small Industries Council for Rural Areas
of Scotland; and in Northern Ireland by the Rural Industries Development
Committee of the Northern Ireland Council of Social Services. Another
service provided by the Commission is the financing of small factories to
stimulate rural industries and to combat rural depopulation.
Under the Finance Act 1968 hotels in certain rural parts of the develop¬
ment areas qualify for a refund of selective employment tax (see p. 365).
FUEL AND POWER
The main primary sources of energy currently used in Britain are coal,
petroleum and, to a lesser extent, nuclear energy, natural gas and water power;
secondary sources produced from these are electricity, town gas and coke.
Coal, mined within the country, still represents slightly more than half
primary energy consumption, although the amount of coal used and its share
of the total energy market has been falling. Oil, on the other hand, virtually
all imported, has expanded rapidly, its share of total energy consumption
having risen from one-fifth in 1958 to over one-quarter in 1961, and to over
two-fifths in 1969. With the advent of nuclear power and North Sea natural
gas Britain has moved over from two fuels to four. A programme for nuclear
power stations has been in progress for 15 years and nuclear power now pro¬
vides a significant and increasing share of electricity supplies although it still

The fuel and power industries, with the exception of petroleum, are under
public ownership. General responsibility for the effective and co-ordinated
development of fuel and power resources lies with the Minister of Technology.
Research is undertaken by the fuel and fuel-using industries. The Minister of
Technology also has an Advisory Council on Research and Development.
The fuel and power industries in Britain employ in total about 770,000
people, or 3 per cent of the working population; their capital investment in
1970-71 will be in the region of £700 million, about one-sixth of total invest¬
ment; their annual turnover is about £4,000 million; and the value of their
net output is about 5 per cent of the national product. The nationalised
industry boards’ investment is financed through internal resources and
borrowing from the Government (long term), the clearing banks (short term),
and, in the case of gas and electricity, from overseas (long term) sources.

COAL
The National
Coal Board
Pattern and
Trends in

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The responsible ministers—the Minister of Technology in England and
Wales and for Scottish electricity the Secretary of State for Scotland—are
required by statute to set up consultative councils for each of the nationalised
fuel industries to protect the interests of consumers. National Industrial and
Domestic Coal Consumers’ Councils were set up in 1947 and Area Electricity
and Gas Consultative Councils (supported by district committees) were set up
in 1948 and 1949 respectively. Each consists of a chairman and from 20 to 30
unpaid members appointed from nominations put forward by interested
bodies, mainly local authorities.
Coal has been worked in Britain for over 700 years and an organised coal¬
mining industry has been in existence for over 300 years, some 200 years
longer than in any other country. British coal exports dominated the world
market until about 1910. By 1913—the peak production year—the industry
was producing 287 million tons of coal, exporting 94 million tons and
employing over a million workers.
In 1947 the coal mines passed into public ownership by means of the Coal
Industry Nationalisation Act 1946, which set up the National Coal Board as
a statutory corporation to manage the industry.
The National Coal Board (NCB) consists of a chairman and between eight
and eleven members appointed by the Minister of Technology. The NCB has
an almost complete monopoly to extract coal in Great Britain, and is also
empowered to license private operators to work small pits and open-cast sites.
It has no monopoly in distribution, and retail sales remain largely in private
hands, but it has, however, some retail depots and makes bulk sales to large
industrial consumers.
The NCB is responsible for the day-to-day running and the commercial
management of the industry, but is answerable to the minister (and through
him, to Parliament) for its efficiency. The minister has power to issue direc¬
tives on matters affecting the public interest, and to authorise borrowings to
finance capital investment.
At the end of March 1970 there were 299 collieries in operation. Of these,
296 were grouped into 17 areas, each controlled by a director who is respon¬
sible to the NCB. The remaining three collieries (in Kent) are controlled by a
general manager who is also responsible to the NCB.
A typical area produces nearly 10 million tons of coal a year, employs
up to 20,000 men and has a turnover of about £55 million.
Coal consumption in Britain increased by an average annual rate of nearly
4 million tons between 1947 and 1956; sales fell sharply, however, between
1956 and 1959 and large stocks of coal accumulated at pit heads. Growing
competition from oil, increasing efficiency in the use of coal and reduced
requirements of the gas, steel, railway transport, and other industries con¬
tributed to the fall in demand which is still continuing (see Table 16). Un¬
distributed stocks have recently been run down considerably and at the end
of 1969 were 18*5 million tons.
Nearly half of total output is consumed by the electricity authorities and
over one-quarter by domestic and industrial users together. Coke ovens are
other large users and the gas industry still consumed nearly 7 million tons
in 1969 despite the switch to natural gas. Consumption by the electricity
industry has increased by 38 per cent since 1961 to 76 million tons in 1969
whereas the requirements of all the other main classes of consumer have
INDUSTRY

declined. In the case of domestic users this fall has been slightly offset by
increased purchases of solid smokeless fuels.
Coal exports have declined for somewhat similar reasons and now average
about 3 million tons a year. The peak post-war figure was 19 million tons in
1949. The principal markets are in Western Europe and the Republic of
Ireland.
The fact that the British industry was developed so early has meant that many
of the best seams of coal are now worked out. There are abundant reserves of
coal with which production can be maintained well into the next century;
there is also scope for opening new collieries should these be required.
The main coal-bearing areas are: (1) the Yorkshire, Derbyshire and
Nottinghamshire field, which produces about 48 per cent of the total output,
(2) the Durham and Northumberland field, (3) the South Wales field, and
(4) the Scottish field. Other important coal-bearing areas are those of
Lancashire and the west Midlands (Staffordshire and Warwickshire).

Coal consumption has fallen steadily over the past 20 years as shown in
Table 16, and fell by 2-4 million tons in 1969. The fall in demand has been
accompanied by increases in productivity and has resulted in a rundown of
the labour force from some 700,000 to about 300,000. There were 35,000 fewer
workers in September 1969 than in September 1968. Overall productivity has
risen by half since 1961 to 2-2 tons per manshift in 1969. Coal face output has
doubled over the last 20 years to 6-8 tons per manshift in 1969. The increases
have been obtained largely by concentration on the more productive mines
and faces, by increasing mechanisation at the face, and by the use of multi¬
shift working. At mechanised faces, output now averages 7-7 tons per man¬
shift compared with 4-1 tons at non-mechanised faces. Other important
measures which have contributed to increased productivity include new tech¬
niques for obtaining information about the reserves before they are worked,
intensive training of management and men to obtain the maximum utilisation
of equipment on highly mechanised faces, the increasing use of powered sup¬
ports, the use of higher horse-power machines and improvements in the
mechanised handling of coal below ground and on the surface.
258 BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The former Ministry of Power forecast that the fall in consumption is likely
to continue but the Government is taking measures to support consumption
with the aim of holding demand at around 120 million tons by 1975. The
NCB plans to continue to improve the competitive position of coal and increase
productivity by restricting production to the most productive pits and the most
efficient faces. The labour force will, therefore, continue to decline in the near
future.
The NCB raises capital, including working capital, by borrowing from the
Minister of Technology. At present there is a statutory limit of £900 million
on such borrowing. Within certain limits the Board may also, with the per¬
mission of the Minister of Technology, borrow temporarily (by way of over¬
draft or otherwise). The greater proportion of investment, however, is financed
from internal resources.
Capital expenditure by the industry totalled £462 million from 1947 to
1955 and about ^790 million in the nine years 1956 to end-March 1964. At
the end of the 1964-65 financial year the total capital debt to the Exchequer
amounted to about £960 million. In 1965 legislation was enacted to effect a
capital reconstruction involving the writing off of ^4X5 °f the existing
debt. As a result, the total debt to the Minister at the end of March 1970
amounted to £668 million.
Under the nationalisation statute, the NCB has been required to break even
on its current account (taking one year with another) after meeting all proper
charges including provision for reserves. It has made surpluses in some years
and deficits in others. In certain areas, such as Scotland, Lancashire and Wales,
deficits have been persistent, and profits from the areas of high productivity,
for instance, the Midlands, have been inadequate to cover the losses sustained. |
By March 1966 the accumulated deficit on the current account had reached
£115-6 million; this was included in the £415 million written off. Interest
payments and depreciation provisions have been reduced as a result. In the
year ending March 1970 the NCB made an operating profit of £8-8 million,
and after payment of interest there was a deficit of £26-3 million.
To assist the redeployment of manpower and the elimination of uneconomic
colliery capacity, the Coal Industry Acts 1965 and 1967 authorise the Ministry
of Technology to make grants limited to two-thirds of relevant expenditure in
any one year up to a maximum aggregate amount of £45 million over the four
years to 1971.
Research The NCB has two research organisations: a Coal Research Establishment,
at Stoke Orchard, near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, providing facilities for
fundamental research; and a Mining Research and Development Establish¬
ment, near Bretby, Derbyshire, for the investigation of underground problems,
developing new machines and testing equipment. The NCB is financially
responsible for the British Coal Utilisation Research Association’s (BCURA)
industrial laboratories at Leatherhead, Surrey, whose work is closely inte¬
grated with that of the NCB’s own research establishments. BCURA also
undertakes contract work for Government departments and other interests.
Research associations receiving grants from the NCB and the Ministry of
Technology include the British Coke Research Association and the Coal Tar
Research Association. Much of the work of other bodies, such as the Safety in
Mines Research Establishment (SMRE), is closely related to the Board’s
problems; the SMRE carries out research on explosions and fires, pneumo¬
coniosis, engineering and metallurgy.

PETROLEUM

The petroleum industry in Britain dates back to 1850, when Dr. James Young,
a Glasgow chemist, succeeded in obtaining lamp oil and lubricants from
natural mineral oil occurring in the Derbyshire coal measures. The Scottish
shale deposits, yielding similar products, were first worked in 1858 and ceased
production in 1962.
Sources of crude oil within Britain meet only 1 ton in every 1,200 of total
United Kingdom requirements, the remainder being imported from overseas.
Annual production of crude oil from indigenous oilfields now totals about
80,000 tons. Prospecting for crude petroleum has so far led to the establish¬
ment of several small oilfields, notably in Nottinghamshire (Egmanton and
Bothamsell), in Leicestershire (Plungar), in Lincolnshire (Gainsborough) and
in Dorset (Kimmeridge). A substantial field of natural gas was also located in
1966 in north Yorkshire, near Scarborough.
Seismic prospecting in the North Sea has been going on since 1962 and full-
scale exploration activities since 1964, following the enactment of the Con¬
tinental Shelf Act 1964, and the subsequent award of a first round of licences.
Further licences were awarded in 1965) bringing the total area under licence
to 41,272 square miles (108,000 square kilometres) out of a total area on which
Britain has rights of 142,000 square miles (370,000 square kilometres). In 1970
£ further round of licences was allocated for areas in the North and Irish
seas.
Drilling, which started in 1964, has proved the existence of five major fields
of natural gas capable of commercial production, and large quantities of gas
are coming ashore from three of these (West Sole, Hewett and Leman Bank).
British and British-Dutch oil companies have been responsible for developing
the oil resources of many countries to mutual advantage, especially in the
Middle East, Far East, Africa and Caribbean areas.
Today these companies produce more than one-third of all oil entering into
international trade, with a tanker fleet (partly owned by them and partly on
charter) amounting to nearly a quarter of the world’s tanker tonnage. (United
Kingdom registered tanker tonnage is about 14 per cent of the world’s total.)
In 1969 the United Kingdom imported 93-1 million tons of crude oil valued
at £671 million, the largest single item among imported products.
Kuwait (25*5 per cent) regained from Libya its position as the largest
supplier. Other major suppliers were Saudi Arabia, Iran, Venezuela and
Nigeria.
Deliveries of petroleum products for inland consumption in 1969 totalled
about 89 million tons, having doubled since i960. Fuel oil consumption
in 1969 constituted 37-5 per cent of the total. Demand for gas and diesel oils
(excluding those used in road vehicles) rose by a further 1 million tons to
10-3 million tons in 1969. Sales of motor spirit have expanded by an annual
average of 6-4 per cent since i960 and totalled some 13 million tons in
I9^9-
The most important uses of gas and diesel oils in 1969 were for non¬
industrial central heating, agricultural tractors and the railways. Electricity
generation accounted for about 24 per cent of total fuel oil consumption,
excluding that used in oil refineries; the steel industry accounted for 14 per
cent; and non-industrial central heating for a further 12 per cent. Of the
remainder, the largest users were the cement, paper-making, general chemical,
glass, engineering, brickmaking and textile industries.
z6o
Refineries
Oil Pipelines
Research
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Before 1939 three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s supply of petroleum
products was refined overseas, as it was considered more economical to refine
at the source of production. Since the second world war the industry has
favoured the siting of refineries in the consuming areas.
At the end of 1969 rated refinery capacity in Britain amounted to 106 million
tons a year. Of the 22 refineries in operation, seven have a capacity of under
0-5 million tons. The ten largest are situated at Fawley, near Southampton
(16-5 million tons); Stanlow, in Cheshire (1075 million tons); Isle of Grain
and Shellhaven (both 10 million tons), and Coryton (7 million tons), all three
on the Thames Estuary; Teesport, Yorkshire (6 million tons); two at Milford
Haven in Pembrokeshire (6-3 million tons and 5-9 million tons); Llandarcy
near Swansea (8 million tons); and Killingholme near Grimsby (7 million
tons). Other important refineries are located at Belfast, Grangemouth,
Billingham, Heysham (Lancs.) and a third at Milford Haven. The completion
of a 4-5 million tons plant on Humberside brings the number of important
refining areas to seven. Stanlow is to be expanded by 7! million tons to become
the largest refinery in Britain.
Output of refined products (excluding refineries’ own consumption) has
risen steadily; from 4 million tons in 1948 to 25! million tons in 1954,
40 million tons in i960 and the peak total of 84 million tons in 1969. There is a
substantial external trade in refined products which tends to follow trading
and seasonal requirements and the commercial arrangements of the major oil
companies. Exports from Britain, mainly in the form of heavier products
to European countries, were valued at j£i47 milfi°n in I9^9"> imports of
refined products (including liquefied gases) amounted to £237 million.
Three main crude oil pipelines are in operation in Britain between harbours
capable of berthing very large tankers and refineries: in west Scotland, from
Finnart to Grangemouth; in South Wales, from Angle Bay, Milford Haven,
to Llandarcy; and in north-west England, from Tranmere to Heysham.
Pipelines carry refined products from refineries to major marketing areas; for
example, from Stanlow to the Manchester area, from Fawley to Staines and
Heathrow Airport, and from the Isle of Grain to Walton-on-Thames and
Heathrow Airport. A 245-mile (394 kilometres) pipeline, opened in 1969, feeds
refined products to north London and the Midlands from refineries and
installations on the Thames and Mersey; a similar line is planned from Milford
Haven to the Midlands and Manchester. Pipelines carrying petrochemical
feedstocks run from Stanlow to Carrington, near Manchester, from Fawley to
Severnside, near Bristol, and from Teesside to Fleetwood and Runcorn. The
Pipelines Act 1962 is designed to secure the orderly development of privately
owned industrial pipelines.
Research into problems of petroleum technology is carried out mainly by the
leading oil companies, which have also endowed research at the universities
on a substantial scale. Research centres are situated at Sunbury-on-Thames
(the British Petroleum Company), Thornton, in Cheshire, and Woodstock,
in Kent (Shell), and Abingdon, in Berkshire (Esso). The first of these covers
the full range of petroleum research and development, from geology and
production to product utilisation and petroleum chemicals. In general, the
remainder are concerned with the evolution of new and improved fuels and
lubricants and the development of new uses for petroleum products and of
new products based on petroleum, especially chemicals.

ELECTRICITY
SUPPLY
Present
Structure
England and

Scotland
261
A public supply of electricity was first provided in Britain in 1881, at
Godaiming, Surrey. From its earliest days a measure of public control has
been a feature of the industry. In 1919 the Electricity Commissioners were
created as a supervisory body and to promote reorganisation on a national
scale through voluntary agreement. In 1926 the Central Electricity Board
was set up to construct and operate a national grid inter-connecting individual
power stations, thus co-ordinating generation and transmission. In 1943 the
North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board (NSHEB) was established as a
public corporation to develop the water-power resources of the Highlands.
In 1948 all municipal and private undertakings (other than those in Northern
Ireland) were acquired under the Electricity Act 1947 an^ vested in the
British Electricity Authority and 14 regional boards, except in the north of
Scotland where they became the responsibility of the NSHEB. Two subse¬
quent Acts (1954 and 1957) effected a measure of decentralisation and gave
the industry its present structure. Electricity supply employs about 223,000
people, including 5,700 in Northern Ireland.
In England and Wales, electricity is generated and transmitted by the Central
Electricity Generating Board (CEGB) and distributed by 12 separate Area
Electricity Boards; co-ordination is effected by the Electricity Council. In
Scotland, two boards—the NSHEB and the South of Scotland Electricity
Board (SSEB)—both generate and distribute electricity. In Northern Ireland,
the Belfast Corporation and the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland
generate and distribute electricity, and the Londonderry Corporation
distributes only.
The Electricity Council is the central body of the supply industry with a
general responsibility for promoting electricity supply and for advising the
Minister of Technology; it is also responsible for a number of common
services, principally capital financing, research and industrial relations. The
Council consists of a chairman and two deputy chairmen, the chairman and
two designated members of the CEGB, the chairman of the 12 Area Electricity
Boards and not more than three other members. The CEGB controls the
operation and maintenance of power stations and the main transmission system
(the national grid) and supplies electricity in bulk to the 12 Area Boards. The
CEGB consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman and between six and eight
members. Each of the 12 Area Electricity Boards acquires bulk supplies of
electricity from the CEGB and is responsible for distribution networks and
sales of electricity to its area consumers.
Area Consultative Councils were set up under the Electricity Act 1947 in
the area of each Board to represent the interests of consumers; their chairmen
are ex officio members of their respective Area Boards. The Minister of
Technology appoints the chairmen, deputy chairmen and members of the
Electricity Council, the CEGB, the Area Boards and the Consultative
Councils; approves each Board’s capital development programmes and the
industry’s research programme; and approves, in consultation with the
Treasury, the industry’s borrowing requirements.
The boundary separating the areas covered by the two Scottish Boards runs
roughly from Dumbarton on the Firth of Clyde to Newburgh on the Firth of
Tay. Members of both Boards and of the respective consumer consultative
councils are appointed by the Secretary of State for Scotland; each Board
comprises a chairman and between four and eight members, one of whom is the
262
Northern Ireland
Generation
Conventional
Thermal
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
chairman of the other Board. The Secretary of State’s responsibilities in
relation to the Boards are similar to those of the Minister of Technology.
In Northern Ireland electricity is generated at power stations in Belfast and
at Ballylumford and Coolkeeragh. Those in Belfast are operated by the city
corporation and the remainder by the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland.
Generation is co-ordinated by the Northern Ireland Joint Electricity
Authority, set up by statute in 1967. The output of the stations has, since
1948, been purchased in bulk and re-sold to distributors—the Belfast
Corporation for Belfast and district, the Londonderry Corporation for the
City of Londonderry, and the Electricity Board for the rest of Northern
Ireland.
As Britain has abundant supplies of coal, together with good rail and water
transport for moving it, most of its electricity is produced by coal-fired steam
generating stations. In some areas oil or natural gas would provide cheaper
fuel but the rate of conversion from coal- to oil-fired stations is being held down
to cushion its effects both on the balance of payments and on employment of
coalminers. Hydro-electric development on any scale is comparatively recent,
water-power resources being relatively small and in remote areas. Since 1965,
nuclear energy has become increasingly important.
The output capacity of the generating stations of the electricity boards in
Great Britain at the end of 1969 totalled 51,651 megawatts (MW), an increase
of over 40 per cent since 1963.
In the years 1963 to 1969 an annual average of over 2,700 MW of generating
capacity was installed, including 4,000 MW in 1968 and 1,600 MW in 1969.
About 10,500 MW of capacity will come into operation in England and Wales
in the period 1970-72. The SSEB’s plans provide for its total capacity of
4,134 MW at the end of 1969 to be increased to 5,600 MW by 1970.
Sales of electricity in Northern Ireland (where, of the total installed
generating capacity of 1,139 MW, 600 MW is in oil-fired and the remainder in
coal-fired thermal stations) amounted to 3,370 million kilowatt-hours in 1969.
Generation by the public supply in Great Britain exceeded 214,000 million
kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 1969; conventional steam power stations provided
86 per cent of the total and hydro-electric and nuclear stations about 2 per
cent and 12 per cent respectively. The high rate of expansion of output,
which has been a feature of the industry since its earliest years, has not been
maintained during the past five years, although the total of electricity
generated in 1969 was still nearly 32 per cent higher than in 1964.
Generation of electricity outside the public supply system is relatively
small—under 20,000 million kWh in 1969. The major sources outside the
fuel industries themselves are the chemical, iron and steel and paper industries
and the nuclear power plants of the Atomic Energy Authority (AEA).
An analysis of electricity generation in Great Britain is given in Table 17.
The electricity authorities take about half the British consumption of coal and
about ten per cent of the consumption of oil. The authorities’ demand for
these fuels continues to expand. However, the growth of demand for these
fuels has been slower than was at one time expected, because of some tem¬
porary slowing down of the growth of demand for electricity and because of
the increasing thermal efficiency of the generating stations. This has led to
some rephasing of the capital programme.
Oil-fired stations of 2,000 MW are under construction at Fawley, on
Southampton Water, at Pembroke, South Wales, and at Inverkip, Renfrew-

Striking advances have been made in the design of steam-generating plant.
A cross-compound generating unit with an output capacity of 550 MW came
into operation in 1963 at Thorpe Marsh, near Doncaster. Forty-seven single¬
shaft units of 500 MW are being installed in 13 stations. The first came into
operation at the Ferrybridge ‘C’ station, Yorks, in 1966. In 1968 Ferrybridge
‘C’ became the first of the 2,000 MW stations to supply electricity from all four
of its generating sets. By the end of 1969 22 sets had been installed, of which
18 had been commissioned at six stations. Station capacities are also increasing.
By 1971, ten stations, each with capacities of 2,000 MW, with four 500 MW
single-shaft generating units, will be in service. Six larger generating units, of
660 MW, will be installed at Drax (Yorks). (For locations see map, inside
back cover.) In Scotland, a 1,200 MW station at Cockenzie was commissioned
in 1968 and one of 2,400 MW (four generating units of 600 MW) at Longannet
in 1970. A 1,980 MW station at Inverkip (three units of 660 MW) is expected
to be commissioned in 1975.
Large gas turbine units of 55 MW and 70 MW, based on aero jet engines,
have been introduced since 1965 for peak load operation. The CEGB and
SSEB have installed 919 MW of such units. Smaller gas turbines have been
introduced at new stations to safeguard the auxiliary supplies to the large new
steam units, and also to provide capacity for peak operation. Auxiliary units
of this kind in service at the end of 1969 totalled 867 MW, and by 1973 will
exceed 1,300 MW.
Hydro-electric generation is confined to Scotland and Wales, and most of the
water-power so utilised is drawn from high-level reservoirs with their own
natural catchment areas. The setting up of the NSHEB in 1943 marked the
beginning of an era of intensive water-power development in the Highlands.
264
Nuclear Power
Stations
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In 1969-70, 2,580 million units were sent out by the NSHEB from water¬
power, compared with 322 million in 1949. At the end of March 1970 there
were 54 main hydro-electric conventional stations in operation in the north
of Scotland with a total installed capacity of 1,051 MW and the largest—the
Loch Sloy station—has a capacity of 130 MW. The Cruachan pumped
storage section of the Awe scheme, with an installed capacity of 400 MW from
four reversible-pump-turbines, came into full operation at the end of 1967.
Construction of a 300 MW pumped-storage project at Foyers, Loch Ness,
began in November 1969. It will have two 150 MW reversible-pump-turbines
and is planned for completion in 1974. In addition, there are stations generat¬
ing electricity by water-power in the south of Scotland (122 MW) and in
Wales (469 MW). The latter includes the 360 MW pumped-storage station
at Ffestiniog, which was completed in 1963. (In pumped-storage schemes
electricity generated in off-peak periods is used to pump water to higher levels
from which it descends at peak periods to operate turbo-generators.)
Some 12 per cent of Britain’s public supply generation was in nuclear power
stations in 1969 and the proportion is expected to rise to about 25 per cent by
the mid-1970s. Britain accounts for some 30 per cent of world nuclear
generation.
The AEA itself has five main stations which produce electricity for the
national grid: Calder Hall, in Cumberland (198 MW electrical output);
Chapelcross, Dumfriesshire (191 MW); the Advanced Gas-Cooled Reactor
(AGR) at Windscale, Cumberland (34 MW); the experimental fast breeder
station at Dounreay, Caithness (14 MW); and the Steam Generating Heavy
Water Moderated Reactor (SGHWR) at Winfrith, Dorset (100 MW).
Others are owned and operated by the electricity authorities. Under the
first commercial programme, originally announced in 1955 but since twice
modified, eight stations with a total installed capacity of over 3,600 MW were
in operation in 1969: Berkeley, in Gloucestershire (276 MW output capacity),
and Brad-well, in Essex (300 MW), were both commissioned in 1962; Hunter-
ston ‘A’, in Scotland (300 MW), in 1964; and in the following year Hinkley
Point ‘A’, in Somerset, Trawsfyndd, in Wales (both 500 MW), and Dungeness
‘A’, in Kent (550 MW); Sizewell, in Suffolk (580 MW), was commissioned in
1966; and Oldbury, in Gloucestershire (600 MW), in 1968. A ninth station,
Wylfa, in Anglesey (1,180 MW), is due to be operating in 1970. These stations,
like Calder Hall and Chapelcross, are all magnox stations—graphite¬
moderated, carbon-dioxide cooled, using natural uranium metal fuel elements
canned in magnesium.
Under a second programme announced in 1964 and extended in 1965, a
further 8,000 MW of nuclear capacity is planned by about 1976. The first
station in this programme, Dungeness ‘B’, due to begin operating in 1972, is
based on the AGR at Windscale, which uses slightly enriched uranium
dioxide fuel canned in stainless steel, a logical development of the magnox
system. When in full operation with a net electrical output of 1,200 MW, it
will be the most powerful in the world. Three further AGR stations, Hinkley
Point ‘B’, Hunterston ‘B’ and Hartlepool are under construction, and will
come into service in 1972, 1973 and 1974 respectively. They will be the first
in Britain to produce electricity more cheaply on base load than the best
contemporary coal stations. Consent has been given for further nuclear
stations at Heysham (1,320 MW) and Sizewell (2,640 MW).
A large prototype fast reactor (PER) of 250 MW capacity is being built
at Dounreay where in October 1962 the experimental fast reactor became the

and

Capital
Investment
INDUSTRY
first of such type to produce electricity for public use and to operate at a high
power level. It is due for completion in 1972.
The Atomic Energy Authority undertakes the manufacture and reprocessing
of nuclear fuels for nuclear reactors in Britain and overseas at Springfield in
Lancashire, Capenhurst in Cheshire and Windscale in Cumberland. In
1968-69 completed export orders amounted to ^1-9 million, outstanding
orders to £19 million and new contracts to £11-4 million. Income from fuel
services in Britain amounted to ^24-6 million.
Main electricity transmission lines—the national grid—supply most of the
country. By 31st March 1969 those of the CEGB totalled 18,697 circuit miles
(30,000 kilometres), of which 5,512 miles (8,875 kilometres) were 400,000 volt,
2,174 miles (3,500 kilometres) 275,000 volt, 10,599 miles (i7>00° kilometres)
132,000 volt and the remainder were 66,000 volt and below. In Scotland there
were some 4,500 circuit miles (7,200 kilometres) of main transmission lines at
the end of March 1969, of which 1,350 circuit miles (2,170 kilometres)
operated at 275,000 volts and the remainder at 132,000 volts. Energy move¬
ments on the grid in England and Wales are controlled through the seven
operational areas, set up for that purpose and distinct from the regions in
which the generating side of the industry is organised; each area has a separate
control, and the operations are co-ordinated by a National Control in London.
The grid in Scotland is operated from the control centres at Pitlochry
(NSHEB) and at Kirkintilloch (SSEB).
To reduce the number of new transmission lines needed to meet the
country’s increasing power demands, most of the new ‘supergrid’ of main
transmission lines now operating at 275,000 volts are, since 1965, being
uprated to operate at 400,000 volts. The development of the grid system has
made the British system the largest integrated power network in the world.
Twin cross-Channel cables laid between Dungeness and Boulogne, capable
of transmitting up to 160 MW at 200,000 volts (direct current), have been
in operation since 1961; by this means advantage is taken of the differences
between France and Britain in the timing of peak loads.
A direct current transmission link to reinforce supplies in the London area
is being installed; due for completion in 1971, the scheme—the first of its
kind in the world—will have a capacity of 640 MW.
In England and Wales the Area Electricity Boards distribute to consumers
electricity acquired mainly from the CEGB, supplemented from other sources,
such as industrial plants and the nuclear power stations of the AEA. There
are over 18-1 million consumers. Industrial concerns are the biggest users of
electricity. The principal domestic uses of electricity are for lighting, cooking
and for space and water heating, but the demand for numerous other domestic
purposes is rising steadily.
The NSHEB has about 464,000 consumers, many in remote areas. The
SSEB supplies about 1-5 million consumers.
About 7 per cent of the annual gross fixed capital formation of the United
Kingdom in 1969 was attributable to the electricity supply industry. The
industry’s plans for new capital investment are based on a growth in demand
estimated at an annual average rate of 6 per cent up to 1975-76.
Capital expenditure of the electricity supply industry has been expanding
very rapidly: from £249 million in 1956 it rose to £720 million in 1966 but has
since fallen to £452 million in 1969-70. In recent years nearly half of the
industry’s capital requirements have been financed from internal resources.
