The statutory limit to borrowings by the industry in Great Britain is £5,200
million. The Gas and Electricity Act 1968 empowered the industry to borrow
(long term) from overseas sources.
The Electricity Council, in consultation with the Minister of Technology, is
responsible for drawing up a general programme of research, comprising:
direct research carried out by the Electricity Boards themselves, supported
by co-operative research with selected industrial research associations and by
research contracts placed with universities and other organisations. The
Council itself is empowered to conduct research. It is advised by the Electricity
Supply Research Council. Collaboration on research between the supply
industry and the plant manufacturers is co-ordinated by the Power Engineering
Research Steering Committee set up in 1966.
The main research establishments of the industry are run by the CEGB and
comprise the Central Electricity Research Laboratories at Leatherhead,
Surrey, the Berkeley Laboratories in Gloucestershire, concerned with nuclear
problems, and the Engineering Laboratories at Marchwood, on Southampton
Water. In 1965 the Electricity Council established a research centre at
Capenhurst, Cheshire, at which intensive research is being undertaken on
distribution problems and on appliances and methods of electricity utilisation.
Both Scottish electricity boards carry out research and experimental work
either on their own or in co-operation with other electricity authorities. The
NSHEB undertakes a wide range of research and development work, both
independently and in conjunction with the universities and manufacturers.
The SSEB has recently extended its own research activities and, with the
NSHEB, is associated with those of the Electricity Council and CEGB.
Public supply of gas in Britain dates from 1807, when Pall Mall, London,
was first lighted with gas. In 1812 the London and Westminster Gas Light
and Coke Company received a Royal Charter to supply gaslight in London.
In the early years of the industry gas was used almost exclusively for lighting,
provided by a growing number of company and municipal undertakings.
The gas industry in its present form developed in the main during the
period between the two world wars when increasing competition from
electricity had to be met, and by 1939 the industry had become mainly a
supplier of heating rather than lighting.
The Gas Act of 1948 brought the industry in Great Britain, in which about
120,000 persons are at present employed, under public ownership and control
on 1st May 1949. The assets of 991 undertakings, of which 269 belonged to
local authorities, were vested in 12 Area Gas Boards. The central body is
the Gas Council, appointed by the Minister of Technology. It is both a co¬
ordinating council and, since the enactment of the Gas Act 1965, a trading
body. It consists of a full-time chairman and deputy chairman, the 12 chair¬
men of the area boards and up to five other members. Its general duties are to
advise the Minister on questions affecting the industry and promote the
efficient performance of their duties by the area boards. It also has specific
duties relating to finance, labour relations and research.
The Area Gas Boards, which have a large measure of financial and opera¬
tional responsibility and are similar in most respects to the central bodies
of the other publicly owned corporations, are responsible for the local
manufacture of gas and its distribution to consumers. Each of the Area Gas
Boards, appointed by the Minister of Technology, consists of a full-time

chairman and deputy chairman, in some cases one or more full-time members,
and usually five or six part-time members, including the chairman of the Area
Consultative Council. There is no common pattern of organisation; each
board is fully independent and has devised its own subordinate structure.
Each is required to pay its way, taking one year with another. The operations
of the area boards have resulted, in the 21 years up to 31st March 1970, in an
aggregate disposable surplus of approximately ^93 million before taxation.
In Northern Ireland the gas supply industry remains in the hands of a
number of municipal undertakings and statutory and non-statutory companies.
The main single source of gas in Britain in 197° was natural gas which
accounted for some 50 per cent of all gas available, compared with 36 per cent
in 1969. Gas manufactured from oil accounted for 37 per cent of total gas
available in 1969 and gas from coal 9 per cent.
In 1969 the quantity of gas produced in Northern Ireland was about
21 million therms, most of it for household use.
Three-fifths of all gas sold by gas boards is for household use and the remainder
for industrial and commercial purposes. Total consumption has been rising
steadily since 1961, after a period when growth was almost negligible. For
the last three years consumption has risen by about 10 per cent each year.
Sales reached a level of nearly 5,000 million therms1 in 1969. There are about
13 million consumers, an increase of about half a million in the past seven
years.
About 40 per cent of the domestic load is used for central heating, with gas
fires and cookers each accounting for about 25 per cent.
Gas has traditionally been used extensively in industries which require the
control of temperatures to a fine degree of accuracy, for example, in the pottery
industry and in certain processes in the manufacture of iron and steel products.
Natural gas is being used as a chemical feedstock and in bulk fuel markets.
In 1969 sales of gas to industry totalled 1,070 million therms.
Production of coke at gas works in 1969 was 3 million tons (a fall of two-
thirds in four years) and at coke ovens 16-6 million tons, reflecting the use of
oil and the increasing use of natural gas.
Under the Gas Act 1948, borrowing by the Gas Council and the Area Gas
Boards was limited to £250 million. In 1954 the industry’s borrowing powers
were increased to £450 million, in i960 to £525 million, in 1963 to £650
million, in 1965 to £1,200 million and in 1968 to an interim limit of £1,600
million with provision for a further increase to £2,400 million. The Gas and
Electricity Act 1968 empowered the industry to borrow from overseas (long
term) sources.
The industry had been spending about £50 million a year on capital
investment in the period 1955 to 1961 but since 1961-62 expenditure has
increased sharply; in 1969-70 it reached £235 million and £245 million is
planned for 1970-71. Between vesting day (1st May 1949) and the end of
March 1970 about £1,500 million had been invested in fixed assets.
Much of the gas industry’s current research and development effort is
concentrated on transforming the industry from one based on manufactured
1 1 therm = 100,000 British thermal units = 25,200 kilocalories.

gas to one based on indigenous natural gas. In 1970 the Gas Council estimated
that the switch over to natural gas in Great Britain would be completed in
seven to eight years.
A phased programme of converting the 30 million gas appliances is in
progress. Investigations are being made into projects involving various
methods of storage of natural gas to meet peak load conditions. Further
storage facilities for natural gas are under construction near Coatbridge,
Scotland. A further facility is planned at Urmston, Cheshire.
Since 1964 deliveries of natural gas from the Sahara have been made in liquid
form to Britain. A pipeline system distributed the gas from a terminal on
Canvey Island to 8 of the 12 Area Gas Boards. This pipeline has been
expanded to form a national high pressure pipeline system. By March
1970, some 1,500 miles (2,400 kilometres) of the required 2,500 miles (4,000
kilometres) had been constructed. The central distribution system is fed
from the two shore terminals by four feeder mains. A third terminal is under
construction.
The first productive well in the North Sea was discovered in 1965. Five
major gasfields have now been located as well as a number of smaller struc¬
tures. The Ministry of Technology has estimated that production could exceed
3,000 million cubic feet (85 million cubic metres) per day by 1975. In 1969-70
the abstraction rate was estimated at 960 million cubic feet (27 million cubic
metres) per day.
The first pipeline to pump natural gas to the shore, at Easington in
Yorkshire, was put on flow early in 1967. The second pipeline, which comes
ashore at Bacton in Norfolk, came on flow in August 1968, and the third, also
to Bacton, in July 1969. Supplies of gas from an on-shore field at Lockton,
Yorkshire, are expected to rise to an average 75 million cubic feet (2-1 million
cubic metres) a day.
The Gas Council expects gas consumption to increase by some 20 per
cent a year up to 1975 and therefore substantial expansion is required. The
need to provide additional storage capacity, and the strengthening of the
distribution system will also give rise to substantial investment.
The Gas Council has a research committee which advises on research policy
at the four research centres. The engineering research station at Killingworth,
Northumberland, has concentrated on distribution problems. Research is
also carried out on behalf of the Gas Council at a number of universities and
colleges.
Efficiency in the use of fuel, among both industrial and domestic users, has
been assisted by various bodies representing producers and consumers and
by the technical advisory services of the fuel and power industries.
The Coal Utilisation Council consists of representatives of the National
Coal Board, solid fuel distributors and appliance manufacturers and distri¬
butors. Originally formed in 1932, it informs and advises domestic users
on the best use of solid fuel, including the choice of installation and the
operation of solid fuel appliances.
A non-profit-making company, the National Industrial Fuel Efficiency
Service, was formed in 1954 and sponsored by the fuel and power industries
to promote fuel saving in industry. In addition to consultancy work, it provides
advice and services to all non-domestic fuel users in a variety of forms, from
‘spot’ inspection to full-scale surveys and regular visits on a contract basis.

Sponsoring by the fuel and power industries ceased on 1st April 1969 but the

WATER SUPPLY
Britain’s water resources are, with progressive development, sufficient for
domestic and industrial requirements. The sources of water are often distant
from the areas where supplies are needed, however, and water undertakings
are therefore mainly concerned with abstraction, storage, treatment and
distribution. Supplies are obtained partly from surface sources such as
mountain lakes, streams impounded in upland gathering grounds and river
intakes, and partly from underground sources by means of wells, adits and
boreholes. Unlike other public services in Great Britain, such as electricity and
gas, water supply remains in the hands of a large number of undertakings.
Ministerial responsibility in England and Wales is shared by the Minister of
Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of State for Wales; in
Scotland it lies with the Secretary of State for Scotland; and in Northern
Ireland with the Minister of Development.
It was not until the nineteenth century that the provision of water supplies
became a general public service, largely due to the efforts of Edwin Chadwick
and his colleagues who demonstrated the dangers arising from inadequate
water supply and sanitation. The Public Health Act 1848 laid the basis for
a long series of statutes dealing with public health. From the middle of the
nineteenth century onwards a number of water undertakings were set up
to provide water to the expanding urban population, and the water supply
system developed rapidly, although in piecemeal fashion and with some
overlapping and waste.
Local authorities have a duty as sanitary authorities to ensure that water
supplies are adequate for the needs of their areas, and they may do this
either by operating water undertakings themselves or by ensuring that other
bodies are providing adequate supplies. Over one-fifth of the water consumed
is supplied by statutory water companies. The householder receives his
domestic water supply at a comparatively small charge, varying in different
areas, which he usually pays by way of a water rate levied, like other rates,
on the value of his house. Industrial users are charged in most cases according
to actual metered consumption.
The Minister of Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of
State for Wales have a duty to promote the conservation and proper use of
water supplies in England and Wales and are advised by the Central Advisory
Water Committee on general questions relating to water and organisation of
supplies. Since the passing of the Water Act 1945, over 800 smaller water
authorities in England and Wales have been absorbed by larger authorities or
by the creation of joint boards in order to improve the efficiency of the water
supply industry. There are now some 218 statutory water undertakings of
which about two-fifths are local authorities. A number of private proprietors
without statutory powers also provide small supplies.
The largest undertaking in Britain is the Metropolitan Water Board, which
supplies over 368 million gallons daily to 6J million people in the London
area. It consists of 39 part-time members who are the elected representatives
of the various local authorities within the Board’s area of operations, together
with one representative each from the Thames and Lee Conservancies.
270
Present Supplies
Scotland
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Public water supplies in England and Wales—reaching over 99 per cent of
the total population—now total some 2,777 million gallons a day, out of a total
estimated abstraction of 5,000 million gallons a day (excluding water used for
cooling in connection with electricity generation). Capital expenditure by
water undertakings, which averaged about £58 million a year in the period
1961-65, has risen to over £80 million a year. Interest and running costs are
largely met from annual income.
The provision of piped supplies for rural districts has been assisted by
grants under the Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Acts 1944 to 1965. By
March 1970 schemes costing over ^112 million had been completed or were
in progress with the aid of grants under these Acts.
The Water Resources Acts 1963 (which came into full operation in April
1965) and 1968 created a new administrative structure consisting of 27 river
authorities and a central Water Resources Board to meet the growing domestic,
industrial and farm irrigation needs. The river authorities, the Thames
Conservancy and the Lee Conservancy Catchment Board have a majority of
members appointed by the county and county borough councils in their areas.
The remainder are appointed by ministers mainly for their knowledge of land
drainage, fisheries, the public water supply and water in use in industry and
in agriculture. The authorities manage the water resources of river basins
and carry out other functions in respect of land drainage, flood control,
administration of fisheries and prevention of pollution. They are responsible
for assessing water resources and requirements, controlling and developing
resources and securing regulation by a system of licensing. Special arrange¬
ments exist for the Greater London area, where the full range of river authority
control is not necessary. The work of the river authorities is co-ordinated by
the Water Resources Board, an expert advisory body which reports to the
Ministry of Housing and Local Government. Its duties include the review of
national water resources and requirements, the encouragement of the transfer
of water between areas according to need, the co-ordination of proposals of
river authorities for capital investment and the initiation of research. Since
April 1969 water conservation has been financed from charges levied by river
authorities on the licensed abstractors and users of water.
The administrative arrangements for water supply and distribution in
Scotland were reorganised by the Water (Scotland) Act 1967 under which
the functions of 200 local water authorities were transferred to 13 regional
water boards in May 1968. The Act also established the Central Scotland
Water Development Board which supplies water in bulk to its seven con¬
stituent regional water boards; it does not supply direct to individual con¬
sumers. All the members of these boards are members of town or county
councils.
The water problem in Scotland is broadly similar to that in England and
Wales except that there is not the same need to allocate water between
competing interests and less reliance needs to be placed on underground
sources. The Secretary of State for Scotland is responsible for general
oversight and co-ordination and has a general duty to promote the conserva¬
tion of water resources in Scotland; and to require regional water boards to
provide supplies of wholesome water everywhere in their districts, where
this can be done at reasonable cost; at present, they supply about 97 per cent
of the total population. The Scottish Water Advisory Committee advises the
Secretary of State on general questions relating to resources and supplies.
The Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Act 1944, as amended, makes avail-

Northern

able to Scottish local authorities grant assistance up to a maximum of £60
million towards the cost of water supplies and sewerage schemes in rural areas.
Northern Ireland has abundant supplies of water for both domestic and
industrial consumption. Distribution is mainly the responsibility of local
authorities, some of which have combined to form joint boards. About 90 per
cent of the population has a piped supply and over 100 million gallons are
supplied daily. Under the Water Supplies and Sewerage Act (Northern
Ireland) 1945 the Ministry of Development may pay grants towards the cost
of water schemes. Since 1945 over ^45 million have been invested, of which
almost £22 million were government grants. New measures for the manage¬
ment of water resources in Northern Ireland are under consideration.
Information on the yield, behaviour and quantity of the nation’s surface
water resources is provided in the Surface Water Year Book of Great Britain,
published annually by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. This publication
contains particulars of the run-off and related rainfall from a large number of
rivers, streams and reservoired areas. The Water Resources Board is respon¬
sible for the collation and publication of hydrological information: the field¬
work of surface water measurement is done by river authorities, water
undertakings and other bodies. Detailed studies of the resources and use of
water in specified areas have been published in the series of hydrological
surveys which cover approximately half of England and Wales. General
information on rainfall, published annually in British Rainfall, is the re¬
sponsibility of the Meteorological Office, while advice on ground water is the
responsibility of the Water Resources Board. The Hydraulics Research Station
of the Ministry of Technology at Wallingford and the Water Research
Association’s station at Medmenham carry out research into problems of the
design and calibration of gauging weirs and flumes for the measurement of
surface water, and into other hydraulic problems.
Full-scale feasibility studies are being made of barrages across Morecambe
Bay and the Dee estuary. A preliminary ‘desk study’ has also been carried out
at Solway Firth, and one is in progress for the Wash. Barrage projects involve
dams across or within tidal estuaries to form a lake of fresh water.
Each river authority is responsible for the control of pollution of rivers
and certain tidal waters in its area and its approval must be sought before
polluting effluents are discharged. Control of pollution in the tidal Thames
is exercised by the Port of London Authority. In Scotland nine river purifica¬
tion boards have been set up. The Secretary of State for Scotland is advised
by the Scottish River Purification Advisory Committee on questions affecting
the cleanliness of Scottish rivers. In several ports the petroleum companies
co-operate in the prevention of oil pollution from tankers and refineries.
The Water Pollution Research Laboratory at Stevenage investigates
problems connected with the treatment of polluted water, the treatment and
disposal of sewage and industrial waste water, and the effects and prevention
of pollution of surface water and underground water.
CONSTRUCTION
The construction industry includes firms engaged on the construction,
alteration, repair and maintenance of buildings, highways, airfields, drainage
and sewerage systems, waterworks, docks, harbours and canals, sea defence
272
Structure
Output
Housing
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
works, electrical wiring, heating and other installation work, open-cast coal
prospecting and mining, and structural work connected with thermal and
hydro-electric power stations and telecommunications. About 1-5 million
people are engaged on construction in both the public and private sectors.
They represent about 7 per cent of the total labour force and their net output
provides about 7 per cent of the gross national product.
The construction industry is gradually adopting metric in place of Imperial
weights and measures; the change is due to be completed in 1972. Designers
have used metric terms for new projects since January 1969; contractors
started working in metric terms on some projects in January 1970.
Constructional work is carried out both by private contractors and by public
authorities which employ their own labour. Over five-sixths of the work is
done by private firms. Although there are over 75,000 firms in the industry,
about a quarter of them are one-man businesses. At the other end of the scale
are about 220 firms each with more than 600 employees.
Public authorities as a whole employ about 350,000 operatives but a very
large proportion of these are engaged on repair and maintenance work which
local authorities, for example, carry out with their own labour.
Over 40 per cent of operatives are occupied on building maintenance, valued
at over £1,100 million annually. The total labour force includes about 800,000
skilled craftsmen, who have been trained for four or five years under the
industry’s apprenticeship schemes. A further 100,000 are employed as
apprentices.
Some firms are vertically integrated, owning quarries and workshops,
mechanised plant and standard builders’ equipment; some undertake respon¬
sibility for projects from initial design to finished building. All but the
smallest projects are generally carried out under professional direction, either
by architects or, in the case of the more complicated civil engineering projects,
by consulting engineers. The functions of the latter, acting on behalf of a
client, embrace advice on the feasibility of projects, the drawing up of plans
and the supervision of the constructional work by the contractor.
The Ministry of Public Building and Works (see p. 56) is responsible for
the construction programmes undertaken directly by the Government (except
for roads and health and education projects), including work for the armed
services, both at home and overseas. It is also responsible for co-ordinating
research and development throughout the government service and seeks to
influence methods and techniques in the building industry as a whole.
The output of the industry has been rising steadily over many years. The
value of work done in 1969 amounted to £4,697 million, of which £704
million represented work carried out by the labour employed directly by
public authorities. Private contractors carried out the remaining £3,993
million (£3,167 million on new work and £826 million on repair work).
About 344,000 houses were started in 1969 and some 367,000 were completed,
of which 186,000 were for private owners. Of the £1,179 million of new
housing carried out by private contractors, £552 million, or less than half, was
for private owners and the remainder for public authorities. Industrialised
building methods employing prefabricated components are used in much of
the work.
The National Building Agency is an independent advisory body, managed
by a board of directors appointed by the Minister of Housing and Local
INDUSTRY
273
Government and the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and
financed by a government grant and the fees which it earns. Its main function
is to encourage the adoption of advanced methods of housebuilding, especially
industrialised building methods, as well as to provide technical advice and
services, in particular to local authorities.
Civ;i Britain was the first country to develop civil engineering as a large-scale
Engineering modern industry and the first to provide techniques, finance and equipment
Projects to carry out major civil engineering projects throughout the world. Prominent
figures in the early development of civil engineering included John McAdam,
pioneer in road construction; Thomas Telford, builder of roads, bridges,
canals, docks and railways; George and Robert Stephenson and Isambard
Kingdom Brunei, pioneers of railway building.
Among important construction projects in hand in the United Kingdom in
1970 were several major conventional power stations and nuclear power
stations (see p. 264), dams and reservoirs, including a £3-5 million dam on the
River Towy in Wales, hospitals, large-scale housing developments, such as
the Thamesmead (London) project to house 60,000 people, and the new town
being built at Craigavon, Northern Ireland. Projects for road construction,
bridges and tunnels included about 380 miles (608 kilometres) of motorways
under construction (see p. 339), a £6 million high-level bridge over the Clyde,
and the £28 million second Mersey Tunnel. An extension to the Victoria
underground railway line in London is under construction (see p. 346).
British constructional firms have been as active overseas as in the United
Kingdom. British consulting engineers, in particular, have built up a tradition
of knowledge and integrity which has caused their standards to become
international practice and their services to be in world-wide demand.
A British firm acts as consultant to the World Bank on the Indus Basin
irrigation scheme, the largest in the world, and several firms were involved in
the design of the Mangla Dam, Pakistan, which forms part of it. Other design
projects included a new port at Dammam, to cost between ^10 million and
£12 million, for the Saudi Arabian Government, and a £75 million new town
in Abu Dhabi.
Among important construction projects by British contractors in hand in
overseas countries during 1970 were: a £10 million sugar mill in the Philip¬
pines; a £24 million deep-water harbour and a £4 million air terminal at
Dubai in the Persian Gulf; an ^8-5 million road bridge at Rio de Janeiro; a
new capital for British Honduras; and a ^15 million tunnel under the harbour
at Hong Kong.
It has been estimated that the total value of work carried out during the
year ending in March 1970 by over too British contractors, operating in 103
countries, was £220 million, compared with £204 million in the previous year,
and that the value of new contracts obtained was £341 million, compared
with £234 million in the previous year. Members of the Association of
Consulting Engineers had projects worth about £1,726 million in hand on
1 st January 1970.
Research The Directorate-General of Research and Development in the Ministry of
Public Building and Works is responsible for co-ordinating research and
information services to increase efficiency in the building industry. The
Building Research Station which forms part of the Ministry was originally set
up in 1921, thus making Britain the pioneer of organised building research,
Overseas
Constructional
Work
274 BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
and is concerned with research into all aspects of building. It provides a
technical advisory service for construction firms. An Agreement Board, set up
by the Ministry, tests and certifies new products and methods.
The Construction Industry Research Association carries on research affect¬
ing all sections of the industry.
The Heating and Ventilating Research Association, an industrial research
organisation, deals with problems of heating and ventilation of large buildings.
The major construction firms have research departments working on plant,
materials and methods. Other bodies concerned with research include the
universities and colleges of technology. Most of the producers of primary
building materials have trade associations which maintain research institutions
chiefly devoted to seeking new and more efficient use for their materials.
MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES
Britain’s manufacturing industries supply a wide range of products, many of
which are of major importance in world trade. Output has increased by almost
one-half since 1958, and in 1969 was 3-3 per cent higher than the previous
year; output per head showed an advance of 2-3 per cent in 1969 bringing the
risesincei963t0 25*3 per cent. In 1969 this sector spent ^1,428 million on fixed
capital equipment (at 1963 prices), 70 per cent of which was spent on plant and
machinery. The number of employees in manufacturing industry (including
the unemployed and those absent from work through sickness and other
causes, but excluding employers and the self-employed) was 8-6 million in
June 1969, 37 per cent of the total number of employees.
The employment and production figures listed in Table 18 give an indica¬
tion of the relative importance of broad sectors of manufacturing industry.
Expansion has been particularly rapid in those industries utilising advanced
technologies such as electronics, the newer branches of mechanical engineer¬
ing, most branches of the chemical industry and man-made fibres. The
diagram on page 249 shows the changes in production between 1963 and 1969
in the major groups of industry.
In the subsequent sections, statistics of employees refer to numbers at
June 1969 and export statistics are taken mainly from the Overseas Trade
Accounts of the United Kingdom.
METAL The metal manufacturing industries employ 588,000 persons. Of these,
MANUFACTURE 280,000 are in the iron and steel industry, 110,000 in the manufacture of iron
castings, 60,000 in the manufacture of light metals, and 85,500 in the copper,
brass and other base metal industries. Exports of iron and steel products and
non-ferrous metals in 1969 had an aggregate value of £597 million.
Iron and Steel Britain pioneered the application of coal to the smelting of iron ore from the
seventeenth century onwards and British inventors were responsible for the
discovery of the processes which led to the great expansion of steelmaking in
the second half of the nineteenth century. Today Britain is the world’s fifth
largest steel producing nation. Output of crude steel in 1969 totalled 26-4
million ingot tons, 2*2 per cent more than in 1968. Capacity utilisation in 1969
averaged about 80 per cent, compared with 82 per cent in 1968. Pig iron
production in 1969 amounted to 16-4 million tons.
Net deliveries of finished steel amounted to 21-7 million tons in 1969. The
4-1 million tons of iron and steel products which were exported had a value
INDUSTRY
275
of £285 million; the United States (-£48-8 million), Spain (£17-3 million) and
Sweden (£16-i million) were the main overseas buyers.
The main producing districts are: Wales (29 per cent of total crude steel
output); Yorkshire and Humberside (26 per cent); Northern (18 per cent);
and Scotland (12 per cent). Wales concentrates mainly on the manufacture
of flat products, especially sheet steel and tinplate; the output of the north-east
coast and Scotland is predominantly of heavy steel products (plates, sections
and rails), but a wide strip mill for sheet production is also in operation in
Scotland. Production of special alloy steels is centred on Sheffield.

During the period 1955-67 over £i,JS° million was spent on major
development schemes. Capital expenditure reached a peak in 1961 of over
£230 million, due mainly to the strip mill expansion programme, and totalled
about £90 million in 1969, although it is expected to rise sharply in the next
few years. Between i960 and i969> steel production by the converter processes
increased from 8 per cent of output to nearly 30 per cent, by electric furnaces
from 7 per cent to 18 per cent; while the share from older open hearth
processes fell from 84 per cent to 52 per cent. The emphasis in recent years
has been on improving efficiency rather than raising total capacity and Britain
has some of the most modern plant in Europe.
Output per blast furnace has risen markedly in recent years, due both to an
increase in average size and to improvements in efficiency, such as improved
276 BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
preparation of raw materials, the injection of fuel and oxygen, and the use of
higher blast temperatures. Industry-wide scientific and technological research
is carried out by the Inter-Group Laboratories of the British Steel Corpora¬
tion. Total annual expenditure by the industry is about £10 million.
Outstanding development projects completed in the last few years include
wide strip mills at new integrated works at Newport (Monmouthshire) and
at an existing works in Scotland; a new plant at Stoke-on-Trent, which is
based entirely on continuous casting for supplies of semi-finished steel; an
advanced unit for the mass production of alloy and special carbon steels at
Sheffield; the world’s largest electric melting shop and a steelworks in which
a linked three-computer system controls production planning throughout,
both at Rotherham; and a new large-scale steel-making plant at Port Talbot
with two oxygen converters, linked with a deep-water harbour.
The iron and steel industry has been subject to some form of public
supervision since 1932. The Iron and Steel Act 1967 brought into public
ownership 13 major steel companies together producing well over 90 per cent
of Britain’s crude steel and employing some 70 per cent of the manpower in
the industry. Their shares and securities were vested in July 1967 in the
British Steel Corporation. The Corporation’s specific duties include pro¬
moting the efficient and economic supply of iron and steel products, exports
and research and development; it is statutorily responsible for the finances of
the nationalised industry. The Corporation’s Third Report on Organisation,
published in December 1969, recommended the formation of six product
divisions, four covering iron and steelmaking and two covering construc¬
tional engineering and chemicals, and this structure came into effect in
March 1970. The remaining private sector includes some 200 companies
accounting for about one-third of the value of the industry’s sales.
Iron Castings Output of iron castings totalled 376 million tons in 1969, 5-6 per cent higher
than in 1968. The main users of iron castings are the general engineering
industry, accounting for nearly one-third of the total tonnage sold and about
one-half of the industry’s turnover, the motor vehicle industry, the manufac¬
turers of pressure pipes and fittings, the building and associated industries
and the steel industry. There are about 900 firms in the iron founding
industry with some 110,000 employees. Exports are included in the total of
steel exports in the previous section.
Non-ferrous The non-ferrous metals industry is the largest in Europe and as a consumer
Metals of aluminium, copper and lead Britain is second only to the United States
among western countries. Output in 1969 included: aluminium, 33,000 long
tons of virgin metal and 223,500 long tons of unwrought alloys; refined copper,
49,000 tons of virgin copper and 147,000 tons of secondary metal; lead, 139,000
tons of secondary metal refined from scrap and 117,000 tons of virgin lead
refined from imported lead bullion; zinc, 149,000 tons of slab metal; and tin,
26,000 tons. Mining in Britain is confined to the small-scale working of tin,
although detailed investigation is taking place into the possibilities of a
considerable expansion in this field.
In 1969 exports of non-ferrous base metals were valued at £312 million.
The main products exported, including semi-finished products, were copper
and copper alloys (^1097 million), nickel and its alloys (£37-9 million),
aluminium and its alloys (£23-9 million) and tin and its alloys (£22-8 million).
The Federal Republic of Germany (£52-4 million), the United States (£34-6

million), and China (£28 million) were the largest purchasing countries.
Indirect exports are also substantial.
Nearly half of the industry is situated in the Midlands; other centres
include South Wales, London, Tyneside and Avonmouth, where one of the
world’s largest zinc smelters (capacity 120,000 tons a year) was formally
opened in May 1968. Firms are engaged in smelting, casting and fabrication
by rolling, extrusion and drawing and the techniques of powder metallurgy
and pressure diecasting are also employed. Two major aluminium smelters
(combined annual capacity 200,000 tons) are being built with government
loans at Invergorden (Scotland) and Anglesey (Wales). Together with a third,
being built at Lynemouth (Northumberland), they will provide over half of
domestic requirements by 1974.
Britain is also a major producer of the newer specialised metals including
uranium, zirconium and beryllium for the nuclear energy industry; niobium
for aircraft production; and selenium, silicon, germanium and tantalum for
electronic apparatus. Scientific and technological research for the industry as a
whole is conducted by the British Non-Ferrous Metals Research Association.
Mechanical engineering comprises a wide range of industries, including all
types of machinery, machine tools, engineers’ small tools, mechanical handling
equipment, construction equipment, industrial plant, ordnance and small
arms, watches and clocks, and scientific instruments. Vehicle engines are
included in the section on vehicles (p. 283). The number of employees is
i-2 million and the volume of production from these industries rose by 31 per
cent between 1963 and 1969. The aggregate value of the main products of all
sections other than small arms was about £4,000 million in 1969. Exports of
non-electric machinery were valued at £1,418 million in 1969, 12 per cent
more than in 1968.
There are some 300 firms, employing 34,600 people, in the agricultural
machinery industry, including three large firms employing well over 1,000
workers. In 1969 deliveries, excluding tractors, were valued at £76 million
and exports were worth £29 million; the main overseas markets were the
Republic of Ireland, France, the United States and South Africa.
The number of self-propelled combine harvesters, forage harvesters, pick¬
up balers and grain driers in use has increased in Britain in recent years.
Deliveries in 1969 included 3,500 combine harvesters, 5,000 milking machines,
13,500 pick-up balers and 1,000 grain and grass driers.
The bulk of British tractor output and exports consists of agricultural tractors.
Some 180,000 agricultural and industrial wheeled tractors were delivered in
1969, 132,000 (73 per cent) for export. In addition, 26,500 small market garden
tractors were delivered. Exports of new agricultural and track-laying tractors
were valued at £110 million in 1969; South Africa (£8-5 million), Australia
(£8 million) and Finland (£6 million) were the main buyers. Production is
dominated by two large organisations. Britain has one of the heaviest tractor
densities in the world (see p. 308).
Britain was the birthplace of the modern machine tool industry. The industry’s
output today ranges from watchmakers’ lathes weighing a few pounds to
machines weighing hundreds of tons, and to electronically controlled machine
tools giving accuracies of one-ten-thousandth part of an inch. Over 2,400
numerically controlled machine tools have been installed in Britain. The
Government, through the Ministry of Technology, is assisting the industry in
278 BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
various ways, including prc-production purchase schemes, numerical control
advisory services and the placing of research and development contracts.
Deliveries of machine tools were valued at £169 million in 1969, compared
with £153 million in 1968. Exports in 1969 had a value of £71-3 million,
20 per cent up on 1968, and of the orders on hand at the end of Decem¬
ber 1969 (£148 million), 44 per cent were for export; the Soviet Union (£11-5
million),the United States(£io-8 million), Australia(^5-5 million) and France
(£4-4 million) were the main overseas markets in 1969. Seven major groups
account for over two-thirds of the industry’s output although the high degree
of specialisation makes it possible for smaller firms to flourish. The industry
is centred mainly in the Midlands, Yorkshire and Lancashire, and to a lesser
extent near London and Glasgow. There are 70,000 persons employed.
The Machine Tool Trades Association of Great Britain is the representative
body of most manufacturers and importers, and is responsible for the
International Machine Tool Exhibitions held in Britain every four years, the
next being due in 1972. The industry is served by its own research body,
the Machine Tool Industry Research Association, and its customers by the
Production Engineering Research Association.
Industrial Britain manufactures a wide range of industrial engines. Deliveries of engines
Engines (including parts) had a value of ^135 million in 1969 and exports (including
marine engines) were worth £3^’^ million; in addition, parts exported were
valued at £28-8 million. The total brake horse-power of the 330,000 internal
combustion engines delivered was 12*1 million, ranging in size from under
3 b.h.p. to over 4,000 b.h.p. Production is concentrated among the large firms
in the industry, and a total of 35,000 people are employed.
Textile The textile machinery industry, one of the oldest of Britain’s mechanical
Machinery and engineering industries, produces machines and accessories for the manufacture
Accessories and processing of yarns and fabrics from all types of natural and man-made
fibres. In 1969, the industry’s exports (£1057 million) accounted for roughly
two-thirds of total deliveries. Principal markets were Pakistan (£97 million),
the Federal Republic of Germany (£9-6 million) and the United States
(£9-3 million). Comprising about 400 predominantly small scale firms, the
industry has some 48,000 employees and is situated mainly in Lancashire,
Yorkshire, Northern Ireland, Dundee, Leicester and Nottingham.

Almost every industry makes use of mechanical handling equipment, the
products of the industry range from individual units and accessories to
complete operating systems. The value of deliveries in 1969 was £200
million, the main products being cranes and bridge transporters, lifts,
escalators, conveyors, elevators and hoists. In addition, British firms produced
28,000 powered industrial trucks, including 1,600 fork-lift trucks. Exports
of mechanical handling equipment (including industrial and works trucks) in
1969 were valued at £69-5 million, 47 per cent more than in 1968. There are
many small firms in the industry; in all, 60,000 people are employed.
Almost the whole range of plant required by the construction industry is
produced, including crawler tractors, motor graders, scrapers, trenchers,
dozer equipment, dumpers, excavators and loading shovels, and crushing,
pulverising and screening plant. The labour force numbers 41,000.
The value of deliveries from the industry was £232 million in 1969, of

The office machinery industry has been expanding rapidly. In 1969 the value
of deliveries was £103 million including million for export. Deliveries
in 1969 included 308,000 standard typewriters and 110,000 portable type¬
writers. The value of deliveries of accounting and similar machinery was
^58-6 million, of which £31'8 million was for export, and of other office
machinery ^3i-3 million, of which £15‘9 million was for export. Exports of
all office machinery (including electronic computers and data processing
equipment) were valued at £109*7 million. The most important overseas
purchasers were the Federal Republic of Germany (£13*4 million), the
United States (£12*9 million), France (£12*6 million) and Italy (£6*5 million).
British subsidiaries or associates of United States firms are prominent in the
industry. There are 57,000 persons employed.
The manufacture of engineers’ small tools and gauges is an expanding
industry; deliveries increased in value from £55 million in 1959 to £110
million in 1969; the main products were hard metal-tipped tools (£14 million),
other metal cutting tools (£47 million), jigs and fixtures (£20 million) and
press tools, moulds, etc. (£21 million). Export deliveries in 1969 totalled
£20 million. The industry has a labour force of 74,000 persons.
British industry manufactures almost every type of industrial plant and
steelwork, and 182,000 are employed in this branch. Of particular importance
are steam-raising boilers, lime and cement kilns, gas and coke oven plant,
sintering plant, metallurgical furnaces and plant, chemical and mineral oil
refining plant, nuclear reactors, water and sewage treatment plant, and steel¬
work for bridges, buildings, etc. The industry has many large-scale enterprises.
In 1969 the aggregate value of deliveries totalled £611*5 million.
British companies delivered water tube boilers to the value of £85*8 million
in 1969; shell boilers and other boilerhouse plant accounted for a further
£56*4 million. Water tube boilers of advanced design and of large steam¬
raising capacity are produced for power stations, whereas shell boilers are used
for steam-raising and heating in factories and buildings. Exports of vapour
generating boilers in 1969 amounted to £13 million.
The steelworks plant industry provides, in association with firms producing
rolling mills, almost all Britain’s requirements as well as plant for export.
The value of deliveries in 1969 was £17*9 million; rolling mills and ancillary
equipment accounted for a further £19*9 million. This industry consists of a
small number of firms, most of which are business associates or members of a
consortium. India, Pakistan, Finland and South Africa are a few of the
countries in which British firms have undertaken major plant projects.
The manufacture of specialised equipment for the chemical and oil refining
industries has expanded rapidly in recent years. Deliveries of chemical plant
were valued at £129 million in 1968, the last year for which figures were
collected. Britain ranks second to the United States as a supplier of equip¬
ment for the petroleum industry. The range of chemical plant produced
includes distillation columns, heat exchangers, high-vacuum drying equip¬
ment, and plant for the manufacture of chemicals from all feedstocks including
petroleum.

Two major consortia, consisting of leading firms in the heavy electrical
engineering, civil engineering, boiler, instrument, and associated industries,
were formed in 1968 to build nuclear power stations for the United Kingdom
electricity authorities (see p. 264). These replaced the three groups formed
in 1959. The Atomic Energy Authority grants them non-exclusive manu¬
facturing licences and is working in close collaboration with them in research
and development.
In addition to the mechanical engineering firms described in preceding
sections, there are about 1,800 enterprises whose principal product is a type
of machinery not so far mentioned. The main products include: mining
machinery, printing and book-binding machinery, refrigeration appliances,
space heating, ventilation and air-conditioning equipment, pumps and pump¬
ing machinery, industrial valves and cocks, compressors, scales and weighing
machinery, portable power tools, food preparing machinery and many other
types of equipment. The total value of deliveries in 1969 was some £635
million. There are 366,000 workers employed in these industries.
This industry makes a wide range of equipment and appliances, extending
from domestic and commercial refrigerators of varying sizes to industrial
refrigeration equipment for cold stores, manufacture of chemicals and other
products, ice-making plant and refrigeration plant for ships. Total deliveries
of refrigerating machinery had a value of ^74 million in 1969; 880,000
domestic refrigerators were for the home market and 207,000 were exported.
The value of deliveries of space heating, ventilating and air-conditioning
equipment has been rising and in 1969 reached £937 million. Exports were
valued at j£i6'i million.
Industrial valves controlling the movement of liquids and gases are a vital I
component in many industrial processes, particularly in the chemicals, oil and
electric power industries. The value of deliveries of pumps and valves in 1969
was £165-8 million and that of air and gas compressors and exhausters £38-2
million. Exports of pumps and centrifuges totalled £67-3 million and exports
of industrial valves £37’3 million.
The value of deliveries of other major products in 1969 was: mining mach¬
inery, £78-6 million; food and drink machinery, £55-5 million; and pack-
aging machinery, £34 million. Important export products in 1969 included,
printing and bookbinding machinery (£30’1 million); paper-making mach¬
inery (£22-7 million); food and drink processing machinery (£20-3 million);
and cigarette making machinery (£15-2 million). Production of industrial :
process machinery and control instruments essential for the automation
of industry—is expanding rapidly, with deliveries totalling £67-6 million in
1969 (£41‘3 million in i960).
The industry manufactures scientific, surgical and industrial instruments;
it has a labour force of 132,000 persons. The value of deliveries of other
broad categories was: optical instruments, £12-2 million; electric, electronic,
and nucleonic instruments, £27 million; and nautical and aeronautical instru¬
ments, £25 million. The total deliveries for 1969 amounted to £199
million.
Export deliveries of scientific instruments have risen from £27-9 million in
i960 to £72-2 million in 1969. The Scientific Instrument Research Association
conducts research on behalf of the industry.

Radioisotopes are processed and marketed by the Radiochemical Centre at
Amersham, now part of the AEA (see p. 200). In the year ended March 1970
sales of radioisotopes totalled £3-8 million, of which 59 per cent was exported.
Deliveries of photographic equipment in 1969 totalled about £120 million,
including £57 million for export. The main products in 1969 were: film (other
than cinematograph film), £50 million; sensitised paper and cloth, £25 million;
and cinematograph film, £20 million. Deliveries of photographic cameras were
valued at £4 million.
The present industry is largely a post-war development. It employs 15,000
people, the great majority skilled craftsmen, and many of its factories are
located on new industrial estates in the older industrial areas, particularly in
Scotland. Output in 1969 included clocks (£7-8 million), watches (^57
million) and time switches (£10-5 million); export sales were valued at
£5-4 million.
Behind the firms manufacturing the major products outlined in this section
are about 3,800 enterprises, employing 252,000 people, whose main functions
are to supply parts and components, to conduct research and development
work, and to undertake general sub-contracting and repair work. (Some enter¬
prises are included because the mixed character of their work precludes their
classification under any single industry.) They include several large under¬
takings with more than 5,000 employees. Ball and roller bearings, and chains,
are important products; exports of the former were valued at ^18-2 million in
1969 and exports of chains at £6-6 million.
The electrical engineering industry, with a labour force of 905,000, is engaged
in the manufacture and installation of a wide variety of electrical equipment,
including all types of generating, transmission and distribution equipment;
motors; telecommunications apparatus; domestic appliances; and specialised
laboratory and electronic equipment. The volume of output rose by 44 per
cent between 1963 and 1969, and the total value of production in 1969
was estimated at over £2,100 million.
Exports of electrical machinery, apparatus and appliances in 1969 were
valued at £466 million, 14 per cent more than in 1968. Products are exported
to all parts of the world; in 1969 the United States (£34-8 million), South
Africa (£30-9 million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£27-3 million),
Australia (^27-2 million) and Canada (£23-4 million) were the main markets.
The industry’s leading representative organisation is the British Electrical
and Allied Manufacturers’ Association; scientific and technological research
on behalf of the industry as a whole is carried out by the Electrical Research
Association.
British scientists and engineers have been responsible for many of the basic
advances in the generation and transmission of electric power. The experi¬
ments of Michael Faraday pointed the way to the production of electricity
as a source of cheap and abundant power. Sir Charles Parsons produced and
patented the first turbo-dynamo, the forerunner of the giant turbo-generating
sets of today.
In 1969 deliveries of electrical machinery were valued at £460 million,
comprising £64 million worth of generating equipment, £y6 million worth of
turbines for generation, £56 million worth of transformers, £i6y million
202 BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
worth of switchgear and control gear and £97 million worth of other electrical
machinery, including electric motors.
Exports of generators, motors, converters, transformers and rectifiers
amounted to £64 million in 1969, the main purchasers being Canada (£7-8
million) and Australia (£7-3 million). Switchgear, starting and control gear
exports were valued at ^44'1 million.
About 600 firms manufacture electrical machinery, but recent mergers,
prompted and assisted by the Industrial Reorganisation Corporation (see
p. 239), have led to the creation of one of the leading electrical engineering
groups in Europe while smaller firms have been reorganised into larger units.
The total labour force numbers 199,000. Manufacture takes place in many
areas, including Manchester, Rugby, Tyneside, Stafford and Larne (Northern
Ireland).
Electrical Production of electronic equipment is one of the most rapidly expanding of
and Radio British industries. United Kingdom scientists and inventors have made many
Equipment basic contributions to electronics—the thermionic valve, the development of
radar, the first public transmission television service, and the ‘printed circuit’,
which has led to far-reaching changes in methods of production in the radio
industry. The industry employs 344,000 people.
Capital Equipment Total deliveries of electronic equipment (excluding telephone apparatus)
were valued in 1969 ^4^9 niillion, including ^19° million for export.
(Indirect exports incorporated in ships, aircraft and machinery are consider¬
able.) Computers are the most important product of the capital equipment
sector, which accounts for 30 per cent of total output. Britain has the largest
indigenous computer industry outside the United States and has supplied
over one-half of Britain’s computer installations. The merger in 1968 of the ,
two major British computer concerns created a single group, responsible for
almost all domestic output. Total deliveries, which have more than doubled
in the last three years, were valued at £151’2 million in 1969 and exports at
^62-1 million.
Deliveries of radar and navigational aids were valued at £93 million in 1969,
over six times the i960 level, and over one-third of total output was exported, j
Three-quarters of the world’s radar-fitted merchant ships use British equip¬
ment, as do most of the world’s civil airports outside the American continent.
All-weather landing systems and inertial (automatic) navigation systems are
amongst recent developments. Other important items of capital equipment
include electronic control equipment (£65 million), radio communications
equipment (£57 million) and electronic measuring and testing equipment
(£42 million).
Consumer Goods The consumer goods sector of the industry manufactures radio and television
sets and radiograms. The industry is dominated by several large firms. Output
of television sets in 1969 rose to i'9 million (including i43>00° colour tele¬
vision sets); the total sales value of ^90-6 million was almost all in the home
market. Production of radios and radiograms numbered 1-42 million in 1969
and total sales were worth £18-9 million.

and Cables for telegraph and telephone networks and for many other purposes; its
products include submarine cables and cables insulated by a great variety of
materials. It is supplying the high voltage cable to carry the expanding output
of electric power in Britain (see p. 262). The value of deliveries in 1969 was

The industry has a labour force of 53,000 persons most of whom are

Britain is one of the largest exporters of telegraph and telephone equipment.

Deliveries of other electrical goods in 1969 included domestic electrical
appliances, £202 million; electrical equipment for motor vehicles and air¬
craft, 5^111 million; batteries and accumulators, £75 million; electric lamps,
-£43 million; and other electrical goods, million. In terms of volume,
deliveries included: 1-5 million electric blankets, i‘9 million vacuum cleaners,

exports of domestic electrical equipment were valued at ,£43’5 million, in¬

United States (£4-3 million), the Federal Republic of Germany and Canada.
Exports of batteries and accumulators in 1969 were valued at £i9,2 million.
The industry has a labour force of 212,000.
The industries which manufacture vehicles and aircraft provide a significant
contribution to exports; exports of transport equipment in 1969 had a value of
£1,071 million, accounting for almost 14 per cent of total exports. The labour
force numbers 1,015,000 and includes: 507,000 in motor vehicle manufacture,
238,000 in aircraft construction and repairing, 188,000 in shipbuilding and
marine engineering, 55,000 in the manufacture of locomotives and railway
wagons and carriages, 22,000 in cycle and motor cycle manufacturing, and
5,000 in the making of perambulators and hand trucks.
In both size and value the largest section of the vehicle industry comprises the
manufacture of cars and commercial vehicles.
At one time located mainly in the Midlands and London areas, the industry,
during the last decade, has built manufacturing and assembly plants on
Merseyside, in Wales and in Scotland.
Car and commercial vehicle output is dominated by the four largest firms—
British Leyland Motor Corporation, Ford, Chrysler United Kingdom
(Rootes) and Vauxhall—which account for over 95 per cent of complete
vehicle production; the balance is in the hands of smaller, specialist producers
of heavy commercial vehicles, omnibuses, coaches, limousines and sports cars.
The principal trade association is the Society of Motor Manufacturers and
Traders (SMMT), which holds a motor show annually in London and a
Commercial Motor Exhibition every two years. The Motor Industry Research
Association carries out collective research on vehicles and components.
Car output in 1969 totalled 1*72 million units, compared with i’82 million
units in 1968. Exports in 1969 amounted to 772,000 cars with a record value
of £341 million, 22 per cent higher than in 1968. The United States (£69-8
million) was again the largest single purchaser, followed by Canada (£27
million), Switzerland and Belgium. About one-fifth (by value) of all exports
went to EFTA member countries and one-seventh to the EEC.

Production of commercial vehicles, including chassis, increased from 146,000
in 1946 to 466,000 in 1969, 14 per cent up on 1968. Exports in 1969 of new
commercial vehicles numbered 181,000 with a record total value of £168-5
million. Australia (£16 million), South Africa (£18-8 million) and EFTA
countries (£20-1 million) were the main markets for commercial vehicles.
Since 1961 Britain has been one of the world’s largest exporters of commercial
vehicles. The prototype of a gas-turbine powered commercial vehicle was
demonstrated in 1968.
Exports of parts and accessories for cars and commercial vehicles in 1969 had
a value of £202 million; engines and parts for motor vehicles were valued at a
further £68-6 million. Caravan and trailer exports totalled £13-9 million.
Deliveries of bicycles have declined in recent years, but in 1969 amounted to
i-6 million, slightly more than in 1968. Most of British manufacturing
capacity is in the hands of a single group of companies, and output is con¬
centrated in the Nottingham area. About one million cycles worth £io-8
million were sent overseas in 1969; the United States (£3-3 million) was the
largest single market. A small-wheel bicycle, developed in Britain, is the first
major technical change in the bicycle for 60 years.
Deliveries of all types of motor cycle amounted to 83,300 in 1969. The total
included 4,900 mopeds and 12,100 three-wheeled vehicles. Manufacture is
dominated by one large group. Exports of motor cycles and parts totalled
£18-3 million in 1969, with the United States much the biggest market.
The British Railways Board has its own workshops which supply British
Railways and certain other users in Britain; private firms build locomotives,
carriages and wagons for British Railways, for industrial users and for export.
Deliveries in 1969 included 3,172 electric locomotives, all of which were
for export, 4,054 other diesel locomotives, 509 coaching vehicles and 2,576
wagons. The total value of exports of railway vehicles and parts in 1969 was
£13-5 million; Pakistan (£2-1 million), Portugal, Sudan and South Africa
were the largest purchasers.
Almost all the aircraft produced by the British industry today are based on
civil and military applications of the gas-turbine aero-engine, first developed
by Sir Frank Whittle. The most notable turbo-prop aircraft in current
production and operation is the Hawker Siddeley 748, of which over 260 have
been sold or are on order. A second generation of jet airliners, the medium-
haul Trident, the longer-haul Vickers VC 10, and the BAG One-Eleven, the
world’s first jet transport designed to operate economically on short-haul
routes, have been in service for over six years. Other civil aircraft in produc¬
tion include the HS125 executive jet, the Sky van and the Islander, an
economical feeder-line aircraft. Flight trials of the Concorde, the world’s first
supersonic airliner, developed jointly by Britain and France, are in progress.
The industry produces a wide range of military aircraft, including the
Jaguar, in collaboration with France, and the Harrier vertical take-off strike
aircraft, the first overseas order for which was placed by the United States
Government in 1969. Britain, the Federal Republic of Germany and Italy are
jointly to develop a supersonic multi-rate combat aircraft (MRCA) to meet
the needs of their air forces during the late 1970s and 1980s. It is also engaged
on work on rockets, earth satellites and other aerospace requirements, includ¬
ing the Blue Streak and Black Arrow satellite launchers.

Hovercraft, a new type of transport vehicle invented in Britain, are being
increasingly used throughout the world. Almost 200 have been built in
Britain up to 1969 and a number of types, including a 170-ton version, the
SRN 4, are in production or under development.
In 1969 exports of the aerospace industry totalled a record £305 million,
4 per cent up on 1968. Exports of new aircraft and parts in 1969 (excluding
electrical equipment) had a value of j£i74'9 million, compared with £135’1
million in 1968. Leading buyers included the United States (£26 million) and
the Federal Republic of Germany (^12-7 million). In addition, exports of
instruments were worth ^4’9 million, and tyres ^i-i million.
The construction of aircraft is dominated by two large airframe manufac¬
turers and one helicopter concern; outside these groups are a few important
smaller companies. Besides extensive research work by the industry, research
on a substantial scale on problems of aircraft and their engines is carried out
by the Government, chiefly at the Royal Aircraft Establishment and the
National Gas Turbine Establishment, both at Farnborough, and the Royal
Aircraft Establishment at Bedford. The British aerospace industry has over
50 collaboration and licence agreements with overseas governments and
companies.
Exports of aero-engines and parts have provided over ^1,000 million in over¬
seas earnings since 1946, and in 1969 were valued at ^117 million: major
customers were the United States (£43'7 million), France (-^17 million) and the
Netherlands (^6-5 million). Twelve different types of British jet engines power
over 30 types of aircraft currently in production overseas. Famous engines in
production include the economical Dart turbo-prop, the Spey turbo-jet and
the revolutionary Pegasus lift-thrust engine for vertical take-off and landing
(VTOL) aircraft. Advanced technology turbofan engines, currently under
development, have secured large overseas orders as power plants for air¬
buses. The power plant for the Concorde is a further development of the
Olympus.
One company is responsible for almost all aero-engine production.
The building of large ocean-going vessels is concentrated in four main areas:
the river Clyde in Scotland, the north-east and north-west coasts of England
and Belfast in Northern Ireland. Numerous yards around the coast build
smaller vessels such as fishing vessels, yachts and harbour craft.
Co-operative research into shipbuilding and marine engineering is under¬
taken by the British Ship Research Association with its headquarters and a
research station on the river Tyne.
A gradual fall in tonnage launched from the 1955 peak of 1*5 million tons was
halted in 1964, and launchings in 1969 totalled I-04 million gross tons, 150,000
tons above the 1968 level. British launchings were the fourth largest in the
world in 1969 accounting for 5-4 per cent of the world total, compared with
5-3 per cent in 1968. Seventeen oil tankers, totalling 260,000 gross tons, were
launched in 1969. Launchings also included 22 bulk carriers totalling 451,500
gross tons and 24 cargo ships between 8,000 and 10,000 gross tons. At the
end of 1969 orders on hand for merchant vessels of 100 gross tons and over
were 285 (283 in 1968) totalling 4-8 million gross tons with a record value of
^588 million, 46 per cent higher than in 1968. Of these vessels, 68 (1-3 million
gross tons) were for export.
Since the publication in 1966 of the report of the Shipbuilding Enquiry
Committee, many British shipyards have embarked on programmes of

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
modernisation and reorganisation. In many cases this has been facilitated by
assistance from the Shipbuilding Industry Board, set up in 1967. In recent
years, modernisation in British shipyards has been paralleled by major struc¬
tural changes resulting from the proposals of the Shipbuilding Industry
Board. A series of mergers has led to the creation of two groups on Clyde¬
side, one in north-east England, one in eastern Scotland and one in southern
England. Together with one group in Belfast—where the world’s largest
building dock was recently completed—they accounted in 1969 for almost
nine-tenths of the industry’s new orders.
There are many specialist ship-repairing establishments and most of the
larger shipbuilding firms also carry out repair work; about one-quarter of
ship-repairing activity is concentrated on the north-east coast of England.
Repair yards and dry docks are situated in all the large ports.
Many of the larger shipbuilding yards maintain or have closely associated
engine building works, constructing various types of marine slow-speed diesel
engines, usually under licence. One firm designs large low-speed diesel engines
and there are two independent builders of these engines. Steam turbines of
the highest powers are also built.

The group of industries manufacturing metal products not already described
consists of a large number of companies with a total labour force of 575,000
in 1969; the main groups were bolts, nuts and screws (47,000 persons), wire
and wire manufacturers (44,000), cans and metal boxes (35,000), jewellery,
plate, and refining of precious metals (25,000), tools and implements (22,000),
cutlery (13,000), and other metal industries (388,000). The total value of
exports in 1969 was about £215 million.
Cutlery and The production of cutlery and flatware is centred mainly in the city of
Flatware Sheffield and the industry’s reputation has been built up on the skill of its
craftsmen. Mass-production methods are, however, extensively used except
in the case of some of the highest quality wares, although firms remain mainly
small. The value of sales of cutlery and flatware in 1969 was £15-5 million,
including export sales of ^4*7 million.
Domestic This industry, located mainly in the Midlands, Lancashire, Yorkshire, South
Hollow-ware Wales and London, produces a wide range of domestic utensils, such as
saucepans, buckets and dustbins, mainly from aluminium and wrought steel.
The value of sales in 1969 was £26 million, of which ^3*7 million were sales
for export.
Tools and The manufacture of hand tools is one of the oldest British industries, covering
Implements the manufacture of such tools as files, saws, hammers, axes and spades;
Sheffield, Birmingham and other Midland towns are the most important
centres. The value of sales of implements and tools, other than machine tools
and portable power tools, was j£43'5 million in 1969, of which ^13-8 million
worth were exported; the totals included sales of hand tools, at home and for
export, valued at £25 *9 million and ^13-9 million respectively.
Jewellery, Gold The making of jewellery, gold and silver ware and the refining of precious
and Silver Ware metals is an industry in which British craftsmen are heirs to a long tradition.
Most of the firms in the industry are small. The law requires that gold and
.silver plate shall not be sold until it has been hall-marked at one of the Assay

Offices situated in London, Birmingham, Sheffield and Edinburgh. The
Birmingham office, located in the main centre of the jewellery industry, is by
far the most important. The total value of sales of jewellery, goldsmiths’ and
silversmiths’ wares and electro-plated nickel silver wares in 1969 was £28
million, of which ^5*9 million was for export.
The chemicals industry, with a labour force of 480,000, comprises the manu¬
facture of: general chemicals (147,000 employees), pharmaceutical chemicals
and preparations (70,000 employees), toilet preparations (26,000 employees),
paint (36,000 employees), soap and detergents (25,000 employees), synthetic
resins, plastics materials and synthetic rubber (59,000 employees), dyestuffs
and pigments (25,000 employees), fertilisers (14,000 employees) and other
chemical industries (78,000 employees). The industry is capital intensive; its
fixed capital expenditure, excluding mineral oil refining, amounting to over
£1,188 million during the six years 1962-67, and totalling £264 million in
1969. In January 1970, a leading British company announced plans to double
its chemicals production over the next five years with a £225 million invest¬
ment programme—the largest ever undertaken in the British chemical
industry. The value of exports in 1969 was £745 million, or 10-3 per cent of
total British exports. Production in the general chemicals industries rose by
no per cent between 1958 and 1969.
Over half the output of the inorganic chemicals industry consists of a limited
number of relatively simple chemicals, such as sulphuric acid, caustic soda,
chlorine and ammonia, produced in very large quantities and serving as basic
materials for industry. Sulphuric acid has the largest production of any
chemical and 3*3 million tons were produced in 1969. The remaining output of
this sector consists of a very wide range of chemicals of varying complexity.
Substantial quantities of inorganic chemicals are used in the manufacture
of such products as fertilisers, detergents, paint, glass and metals. About
one-sixth of output is estimated to be exported directly.
Production of organic chemicals (which include coal-tar chemicals) rose
by 20-5 per cent between 1958 and 1969. To an increasing extent petroleum is
the raw material used and it is estimated that in 1969 petroleum-based
chemicals accounted for four-fifths of the total output of organic chemicals;
deliveries of feedstock for the petroleum chemical plants totalled 5-5 million
tons in 1969 compared with i-i million tons in 1959. The most important
products (by weight) in 1969 were ethylene (875,000 tons) and propylene
(478,000 tons). The main outlets for organic chemicals are plastics materials,
solvents, synthetic rubber, man-made fibres and detergents. Consumption of
dyestuffs is geared to demand by the textile industry; about 35,000 tons of
synthetic dyestuffs were produced in 1969.
Exports of chemical elements and compounds amounted to £166-5 miffion
in 1969. Major purchasers in 1969 were, the Netherlands (£22-5 million), the
United States (£10 million), France (£8-8 million) and Sweden (£7-9 million).
Tho first plastic, Parkesine (later called Celluloid), was produced and patented
in Britain in 1865 by Alexander Parkes; other British discoveries include
polyethylene. Plastics manufacture is one of the fastest growing sections of the
economy. Output of synthetic resins has increased by 234 per cent since 1958
and total production in 1969 was 1-3 million tons (an increase of 6 per cent
over 1968), of which 0-9 million tons consisted of thermoplastic resins.
Expansion in recent years has mainly been in thermoplastic materials, of

which the most important are polyethylene (used in coverings and packaging—
notably for foodstuffs), polyvinyl chloride (known as PVC and used for a
wide range of industrial purposes and consumer goods) and polystyrene
(a cheap non-inflammable material used for toys, light mouldings and many

which can be fabricated as mouldings, films and fibres. A new family of plastic
materials reinforced with carbon fibres is now in commercial production in
Britain; they are up to three times the strength but only half the weight of
steel. Rapid expansion of capacity for all the main types of plastics materials
is planned. Exports in 1969 amounted to 480,000 tons, valued at £128-4
