(£11 million), Sweden (£8-6 million) and the United States (£7-5 million).
The first general purpose synthetic rubber to be manufactured on a com¬
mercial scale in the United Kingdom was marketed in 1958. High styrene
rubbers for shoe soles and flooring, and nitrile rubbers for use where oil
resistance is required, are in large-scale production, and neoprene rubber is
manufactured in Northern Ireland. Production in 1969 amounted to 258,700
tons, most of which came from the styrene-butadiene plant at Hythe, near
Southampton. Exports of synthetic rubber and latex totalled 98,000 tons.
The development of artificial fertilisers owes much to the pioneer work of
the British scientists Sir John Lawes and Sir Joseph Gilbert. Production is
dominated by two firms and there are a number of firms marketing compound
fertilisers from the principal constituents—nitrogen, phosphorus and
potassium. To encourage use, home sales are assisted by government subsidies
to farmers (see p. 311). Output of nitrogenous fertilisers (in terms of nitrogen
content) has been increasing and in 1968-69 totalled 896,000 tons, while
437,000 tons (in terms of phosphate content) of phosphatic fertilisers were
produced; production of compound fertilisers amounted to 2-8 million tons
in 1968-69. The use of ammonium nitrate (35 per cent nitrogen), ammonium
phosphate, and, to a limited extent, urea (mostly 45 per cent nitrogen) is
resulting in more concentrated fertilisers. The value of exports of manufactured
fertilisers, mainly nitrogenous, was £5-4 million in 1969.
Manufacturers’ sales of paint and varnish during 1969 amounted to over
100-5 million gallons (including 15 million gallons of emulsion paint) valued at
£147 million. Britain is one of the largest exporters of paints in the world;
exports of pigments, paints, varnishes and related materials in 1969 amounted
to £44 million. Indirect exports in the form of surface coatings for finished
goods are considerable.
In recent years many improved techniques have been introduced, including
new ranges of synthetic resins and pigments, quick-drying paints and paints
needing only one application.
The whole range of drugs is produced in the United Kingdom, including
antibiotics, sulphonamides, anti-malarial drugs, anti-histamine products,
anaesthetics, vaccines, sera and naturally occurring drugs. Research expendi¬
ture totalled £20 million in 1969.
Notable British contributions to the development of new products include:
the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming and its evaluation by Sir
Howard Florey and E. B. Chain; the evaluation of sulphapyridine (M & B 693)
by Sir Lionel Whitby; the discovery of griseofulvin; and, more recently, the
INDUSTRY
289
isolation of the penicillin nucleus and the development of several semi¬
synthetic penicillins and the cephalosporin antibiotics. Several of the laiger
pharmaceutical companies in Britain are subsidiaries of overseas firms.
In 1969 exports of medicinal and pharmaceutical products and goods rose
by 21 per cent to the record level of j£ii7'7 °f which ^33'9
worth were antibiotics. The largest purchasers were the Republic of Ireland
(£6-3 million), Japan (£6-1 million), France (£6 million) and Belgium (£5-6
million).
Notable discoveries by the British crop protection industry include the
insecticidal activity of BHC (benzene hexachloride), the first selective weed¬
killer, MCPA, and more recently Gramoxone, a non-residual general herbicide
based on paraquat. Sales of pesticides and allied products were valued at
-£36-6 million in 1969, 10 per cent higher than in 1968; herbicides (^24*5
million) were the largest single category. Exports of insecticides, fungicides
and weedkillers in 1969 totalled £23-9 million, one-third more than in 1968.
Sales of toilet preparations were valued at £122 million in 1969, including
export sales of £18 million; home market sales of hair preparations totalled
about £30 million. Petroleum is the source of the principal raw materials
used in the manufacture of organic surface-active agents in detergents; the
other main constituent, polyphosphates, is derived from inorganic sources.
Sales of synthetic detergents amounted to 484,000 tons in 1969, including
73,000 tons for export. Deliveries of soap totalled some 277>000 tons. Sales
of polishes in 1969 were valued at ^i7’9 million, including floor and furniture
polishes worth £8*5 million. Exports of perfumery and toilet preparations,
soap and associated products were valued at £(>0‘y million.
The textile industries in June 1969 had a labour force of 756,000 persons, half
of whom are women; 53>oo° employees are engaged in the production of man¬
made fibres, 75,000 in the spinning and doubling of cotton, flax and man-made
fibres, 66,800 in the weaving of cotton, linen and man-made fibres, 159,000
in the woollen and worsted trades, 140,000 in hosiery and knitted goods,
66,000 in textile finishing and 45,000 in carpets. I he total value of textile
exports in 1969 at ^347 million was 16 per cent more than in 1968. Production
of textiles rose by 3-5 per cent in 1969 and was 16 per cent higher than in i95^-
Considerable vertical integration is taking place connected with the increasing
use of man-made fibres. Four multi-fibre, multi-process groups, founded
under the leadership of man-made fibres manufacturers, control the bulk of
Britain’s spinning and warp knitting activities.
The Textile Council for the Man-made Fibres, Cotton and Silk Industries,
financed by a levy on the industry, acts as a statutory co-ordinating body,
while scientific and technical research for the industry is carried out principally
by the Cotton, Silk and Man-made Fibres Research Association.
Cotton was Britain’s chief consumer goods industry and cotton piece-goods
its largest export during the nineteenth century. Increasing low-cost competi¬
tion has cut progressively into British markets and a global limit was placed
on imports of cotton goods from most countries during 1966-70.
Output in 1969 consisted of: 292 million lb. of single cotton yarn, 154
million lb. of spun man-made fibre and mixture single yarn, 237 million lb. of
doubled yarn, 151 million lb. of textured yarn, 723 million linear yards of
woven cotton cloth, and 589 million linear yards of man-made fibre and
290

Wool
Man-made

mixture cloth. In 1969 exports of cotton yarn (excluding man-made fibres)
were worth j£ii-4 million, exports of woven cotton fabrics were valued at £27
million, with Congo (Kinshasa) and the Irish Republic the most important
markets.
Most of the industry is located in Lancashire, the north-east of the county
being mainly concerned with weaving and the south-east with spinning.
Manchester is the commercial centre and Liverpool is the chief port of entry
for raw cotton. Under legislation to assist the reorganisation of the industry,
Exchequer funds have paid for two-thirds of the cost of removing surplus
capacity, and have also provided grants of about one-quarter towards the
cost of approved re-equipment and modernisation schemes.
The wool textile industry, one of the largest in the world, is the most ancient of
Britain’s staple industries and has been important since medieval times. There
are two main branches—woollen and worsted. The small or medium-sized
business predominates, with only a few large firms. While the West Riding of
Yorkshire is by far the most important producing area, Scotland and the West
of England remain famous as specialised producers of high-quality woollen
cloth. In recent years an increasing amount of man-made fibre has been
blended with wool.
In 1969 output included 203 million lb. of wool and hair tops and 314
million lb. of woollen yarn. Deliveries of worsted and semi-worsted yarn
amounted to 222 million lb. and of woven fabrics to 286 million square
yards. In addition, large quantities of raw wool are scoured and cleaned in
Britain. Consumption of raw wool in 1969 was 385 million lb., compared with
509 million lb. in 1959. Exports in 1969 included wool yarns (£23-3 million),
woollen fabrics (£43*4 million) and wool worsted fabrics (£24-8 million). The
main buyers of woollen fabrics were the United States (^47 million), Japan
and Canada. Raw wool (cleaned or scoured in Britain) and other animal hair
and tops exported had a value of ^50 million. Research is carried on mainly
by the Wool Industries Research Association.
Much of the early development of viscose rayon and acetate took place in
Britain. Production is spread throughout the country with Northern Ireland
of growing importance. Large firms predominate in the industry. There has
been a rapid expansion of output in recent years, the 1969 record total
of 1,221 million lb. being 48 per cent more than in 1964. Output consisted of
664 million lb. of staple fibre and 557 million lb. of filament yarn in 1969. Of
the staple fibre, 299 million lb., and of the continuous filament, 344 million lb.,
were of fully synthetic materials.
Two main types of man-made fibres are manufactured: those made from
cellulose (such as rayon) and those produced by fully synthetic processes from
chemical substances (such as nylon). Viscose rayon is still the most widely
used of all man-made fibres and output in 1969 totalled 465 million lb. The
world’s largest rayon staple factory is at Greenfield (North Wales), with an
annual output of over 200 million lb., while other large rayon plants are at
Grimsby, Preston and Wolverhampton. Almost all the rayon produced in
Britain is made by a single company and its subsidiaries.
Production of nylon, the first fully synthetic fibre, in the form of nylon 66,
started in Britain in 1941; another type of nylon (nylon 6) has been manu¬
factured since 1963. Total productive capacity for nylon has increased from
160 million lb. a year in 1964, to almost 300 million lb. at the end of 1969.
Terylene, a polyester fibre, was invented in Britain during the second world
INDUSTRY
29I
war. It is resistant to fading and is particularly suited to blending with wool.
Annual manufacturing capacity totals about 120 million lb. A group of fibres
of growing importance are the acrylic fibres: Courtelle (a British discovery)
and Acrilan are examples. Synthetic elastomerics or spandex fibres, which are
man-made textile fibres having inherent properties of stretch and recovery,
are now produced commercially.
Exports of man-made fibre yarns had a value of £607 million in 1969, and
woven fabrics £25-8 million. The Soviet Union, the Federal Republic of
Germany and the Republic of Ireland were the most important purchasers
of yarns.
Hosiery and The hosiery and knitwear industry is predominantly one of small-scale
Knitwear enterprises. The industry is widely distributed, wdth Scotland and the east
Midlands as the two most important centres. Sales of knitted goods were
valued at £437-4 million in 1969 including £151-2 million worth of outerwear
and £101 *2 million worth of socks and stockings. Exports of knitted clothing
and accessories were valued at £35-1 million in 1969; the largest buyers were
the United States, Switzerland and Canada. Exports of knitted fabrics
amounted to £21-2 million. The British Hosiery and Knitwear Export Group
co-ordinates the export activities of the industry and organises overseas
missions. The Hosiery and Allied Trades Research Association, with
laboratories at Nottingham, undertakes collective research.
Other Textiles The linen industry is concentrated in Northern Ireland (the greatest linen¬
manufacturing region in the world), with most of the remainder in Scotland.
Unen Broadly speaking, the Northern Ireland industry concentrates on yarns and
the lighter types of fabrics, while in Scotland production is largely of coarse
linens and canvas, although household types are also produced. Northern
Ireland manufacturers produced 35 million linear yards of cloth in 1969,
while weavers in Great Britain delivered 227 million square yards, including
14 million square yards of sailcloth and canvas. Exports in 1969 included
£7-9 million worth of linen fabrics and £3-6 million worth of flax yarns and
linen thread.
Jute Jute is manufactured on a large scale in the Dundee area—the centre of the
world’s oldest jute industry—and 13,400 people are employed in all. Jute is
used in the manufacture of carpets, cordage, ropes and woven into fabrics for
a wide range of uses in the packaging, carpet, upholstery, building and motor
car industries. New uses for jute, as a plastic reinforcement for example, have
been developed. In 1969, 86,400 tons of raw jute were used, and exports of
jute fabric and yarn totalled £2-4 million.
Lace Sales of finished lace goods amounted to £17 million in 1969. The most
important lace product is from the warp knitting machines, with sales valued
at £9 million. Exports were worth £5-2 million in 1969.
MISCELLANEOUS In addition to the products mentioned above, British textile firms manufacture
METAL a wide range of other goods, including many special yarns and fabrics, net,
ODUCTS household textiles such as blankets, tablecloths and curtains, and floor
coverings other than carpets. Sales of narrow fabrics (including elastic
machinery belting and ribbon) totalled £51-7 million in 1969, including export
sales of £7-5 million. Sales of floor coverings of linoleum, vinyl and other
synthetic materials were valued at £32-8 million in 1969; just under one-sixth
were for export. The cordage industry is the largest in Europe. Exports of
ropes, cordage, nets and netting in 1969 were valued at £4-1 million.

In 1969 total sales of all types of carpets and rugs amounted to 146 million
square yards, valued at £200 million. Exports in 1969 had a value of £30
million; Australia (/5-6 million) was the largest single market.
There are over 120 enterprises engaged in the manufacture of carpets,
including several large firms. In addition to the manufacture of woven carpets
such as Axminster and Wilton, about one-half of total sales by quantity in
1969 were of tufted carpets, a form of carpeting in which the pile, usually
containing a high proportion of artificial fibres, is inserted into a pre-woven
backing. Axminster-type carpets account for about 35 per cent of the value of
exports. The principal manufacturing centres include Kidderminster (in
Worcestershire), Halifax and Dewsbury (in the West Riding of Yorkshire),
Glasgow and Kilmarnock (in Scotland) and several towns in Northern
Ireland. About a third of the carpets produced (by quantity) are made pre¬
dominantly of wool and a growing proportion of traditional woven carpets
contain some man-made fibre.
There are 555,000 employees in the clothing, leather and footwear industries.
Some 391,000 are in the clothing industry, 105,000 in the footwear trade and
59,000 in leather, leather goods and fur manufacture. The aggregate value of
their exports in 1969 was ^172 million.
The British clothing industry is the largest in Europe and total deliveries
of made-up clothing have increased by 7 per cent since 1963. Exports in 1969,
excluding knitted goods, were valued at ^61 *6 million; Switzerland (^6’8
million) was the main purchaser. Substantial quantities of clothing are also
sent by parcel post.
Although there are some large firms employing mass-production methods
on an increasing scale, the typical firm is small. The principal manufacturing
centres are London, Leeds and Manchester, but several firms are also situated
on industrial trading estates throughout the country. Fashion is important in
the production of haute couture models and throughout the ready-to-wear
industry. The Clothing Export Council, representing over 200 companies,
organises promotions for various sectors of the industry.
Leather tanning is one of Britain’s oldest industries. In 1969 some 11,400 tons
of sole and other heavy leather and about 437 million square feet of upper,
lining and other light leathers were produced. Britain is one of the world’s
leading exporters with exports in 1969 valued at £31-2 million. The United
States is the largest single market (£57 million in 1969), followed by Canada
(£4 million) and the Federal Republic of Germany.
Tanneries are situated in most parts of Britain, but there are important
concentrations in Lancashire, Cheshire, Yorkshire, the north Midlands and
the London area. Many different types of leather are produced, ranging from
the heavy types for industrial uses, such as machinery belting, to high quality
leather for footwear, leather goods, gloves and clothing. The British Leather
Manufacturers’ Research Association is the foremost of its type in the world.
The British footwear industry is the third largest in the world. In 1969
manufacturers’ sales of footwear totalled 194 million pairs. Exports of all
types had a value of £33-5 million; the United States (£9-2 million), the
Soviet Union and Canada were the largest markets.
Factories are located throughout Britain. Some areas concentrate on
production of particular types; for example, the Rossendale Valley region

The food, drink and tobacco industries employ 853,000 persons in the
production of a great variety of goods. The value of their combined exports
in 1969 was £387 million. Exports of alcoholic and other beverages accounted
for £190 million; sugar, sugar preparations and honey for £28 million; cereal
and cereal preparations for £26 million; fruit and vegetables for £18 million;
and coffee, cocoa, tea and spices for £21 million.
Many of the industry’s leading firms have been involved in mergers in
recent years.
The household consumption of bread, which has been falling, averaged about
2 lb. 6 oz. (1-08 kilos) per head per week in 1969. The trend is heavily towards
concentrating production in large mechanical bakeries; well over two-thirds
of the bread is made in these bakeries, which specialise in sliced and wrapped
loaves; four groups have a dominant position. In the smaller bakeries produc¬
tion of cake and other flour confectionery is usually allied to bread production.
There are 160,000 employees in the bread and flour confectionery industry; a
further 40,000 are employed in grain-milling.
There are 53,000 employees producing biscuits, and annual output has been
over 550,000 tons in recent years. Weekly consumption of cakes and biscuits
per head in Britain was 117 oz. (0-32 kilos) in 1969. British biscuits have
gained a world-wide reputation, and, despite the problem of import restric¬
tions in several overseas markets, exports in 1969 were valued at £13 million.
The cocoa, chocolate and sugar confectionery industry, which has 89,000
employees, is composed of a small number of very large manufacturers and
many medium-sized and small firms. The main ingredients used by the
industry are sugar, cocoa beans, glucose, milk, nuts and fats. Production of
chocolate and sugar confectionery was 681,000 tons in 1969. Consumption of
chocolate and sugar confectionery in the United Kingdom is far higher than
in any other country, being equivalent to 7’6 oz. (o-2i kilos) per head per week.
The value of exports in 1969 of cocoa preparations (including chocolate)
was £18 million and of sugar confectionery, ^17 million. The United States
and Canada were the main markets for cocoa preparations. About 30 per cent
of total world exports of chocolate and sugar confectionery come from
Britain, the world’s largest exporter of these products.
Among the fruit and vegetable products manufactured are jam, marmalade,
sauces and vinegar. The labour force numbers 74,000. Output of jams and
marmalade, which fell from 329,000 tons in 1949 about 215,000 tons in
1956, has since remained little changed, totalling 191,000 tons in 1969. Straw¬
berry, raspberry, apricot and blackcurrant jams are the most popular. Exports
of jams and marmalade in 1969 were valued at £2 million.
In 1969, 788,000 tons of canned vegetables were produced. The British
Navy was using canned foods in 1813, but rapid development in the industry
did not take place until after 1935. Beans in tomato sauce (250,000 tons) and
processed and fresh peas (277,000 tons) are the vegetables most in demand
as canned products. In addition, output in 1969 included 103,000 tons of
canned and bottled fruit, and 286,000 tons of canned soup. Strawberries,
plums and rhubarb are the most important fruits used for canning, followed
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
by fruit salad, prunes and gooseberries. Sales of prepared fruit pie fillings are
increasing.
Sales of frozen foods are rising in Britain, and nearly 189,000 tons of
vegetables and 1,500 tons of fruit were preserved by this method in 1969; peas
accounted for 47 per cent of all home-produced quick-frozen vegetables. Sales
of dehydrated products, including accelerated freeze dried foods, are also
increasing.
Bacon Curing, The industry comprises the curing of bacon and ham, the canning and
Meat and Fish preserving of meat and fish, the manufacture of sausages and pies and the
Products preparation of extracts and pastes. The labour force numbers 94,000. Output
of canned meat and canned meat products in 1969 rose to 130,000 tons, and
the quantity of bacon and ham cured increased to 234,000 tons. There has
been a rapid expansion of quick-frozen fish output, and some 96,000 tons were
produced in 1969; small quantities (8,000 tons in 1969) are also canned.
Exports of fish and fish preparations had a value of £14 million in 1969 and
those of meat and meat products were worth £16 million.

The industries producing beer, spirits, wines, cider and soft drinks have a
labour force of 155,000. Exports were valued at ^190 million in 1969.
Exports of whisky (almost all of it Scotch whisky) totalled 52 million proof
gallons with a value of £168 million in 1969; almost half went to the United
States (£81 million or 27 million proof gallons). Scotch whisky was first
distilled in the fifteenth century. It is blended from 20 or more different types,
some from malted barley and some from other grains. Whisky requires several
years to mature, and the 126 million proof gallons of Scotch whisky produced
in the 1969 distilling year will not be on sale for some years. Stocks of whisky
amount to more than 700 million proof gallons, representing 10 years’ con¬
sumption. About four-fifths of annual sales are to overseas buyers.
Production of gin in Britain has risen steadily since the early 1950s. The main
distillers are in London and one company accounts for a large proportion of
total output. Although the larger manufacturers also own distilleries abroad,
exports had a value of £10 million in 1969.
There are 92,000 employees in the brewing and malting industry. Recent
mergers have led to the creation of a few major brewery groups, marketing
their products throughout the country. In 1969, 33 million bulk barrels of
beer were produced, the highest since 1945, and consumers’ expenditure on
beer amounted to £1,058 million. Exports in 1969 of malt beer were 377,000
bulk barrels, worth £4 million. Firms are experimenting with new methods,
including continuous brewing processes, and automated batch production
plants are well established.
The main raw materials used in brewing are malt, hops and some sugar.
Malt is made almost entirely from home-grown barley. Some brewers make all
or part of their own malt, others purchase it from independent maltsters who
also supply distillers, vinegar brewers and malt extract manufacturers. British
malt is used by brewers throughout the world, and exports in 1969 amounted
to 68,000 tons, worth £3 million.
The soft drinks industry has expanded markedly in the last decade although
sales are liable to be affected by the weather. Output in 1969 included
66 million gallons of concentrated liquid, and 262 million gallons of uncon¬
centrated drinks. Though there has been some amalgamation in recent years,
there are still several hundred firms supplying regional markets. There are two

The tobacco industry manufactures almost all the cigarettes and other tobacco
goods sold in Britain. In 1969 consumers’expenditure on these goods amounted
to £1,690 million (of which about three-quarters was tax revenue) and, in
addition, exports worth £34-9 million (of which cigarettes accounted for
88 per cent) were shipped to a large number of overseas markets; Hong Kong,
Kuwait, and the Federal Republic of Germany were the most important. The
main centres of production are in and around Bristol, Liverpool, London,
Manchester, Newcastle, Nottingham, Glasgow and Belfast. The two biggest
manufacturing groups account for over 90 per cent of total output. The
industry has 39,000 employees.
The tobacco industry used 306-1 million lb. (138-8 million kilos) of un¬
manufactured tobacco in 1969, all of which was imported. In 1969 the main
sources were the United States, Canada and India. Total consumption of
tobacco in Britain in 1969 amounted to 249-3 million lb. (ii3-i million kilos),
including 216-5 million lb. (98-2 million kilos) consumed in cigarettes, 28-2
million lb. (12-8 million kilos) in pipe and hand rolling tobacco and 3-6 million
lb. (i-6 million kilos) in cigars. In 1969 125,000 million cigarettes were
consumed, 3,100 million more than in the previous year; 75-5 per cent of the
total were tipped compared with 16 per cent in i960.
This group comprises the manufacture of bricks, fireclay, refractory goods,
pottery, glass, cement, abrasives, asbestos and other building materials. The
industries have a combined labour force of 346,000, which includes 60,000 in
the bricks, fireclay and refractory goods trades, 83,000 in the glass industry
and 61,500 in the pottery industry.
Firms in the industry manufacture such items as bricks, roofing tiles, chimney
pots, fireclay ware and heat-resisting products including furnace and kiln
linings. Brickmaking, one of Britain’s oldest industries, was introduced by
the Romans, and manufacturing methods vary from traditional hand fabrica¬
tion to highly mechanised systems. In 1969 about 6,734 million building
bricks were produced in Great Britain, 43 per cent of which were of the
Fletton type, made mainly in the Bedford and Peterborough areas. Refractory
goods (firebricks, silica bricks, magnesite bricks and chrome-magnesite bricks)
are manufactured mainly for home use. Exports of refractory construction
materials in 1969 were worth £8-9 million.
The pottery industry, supplying almost all home needs for domestic and
industrial pottery, is a long-established and complex industry, largely located
in the Stoke-on-Trent area of Staffordshire. Much of its raw material
is indigenous, such as china clay, ball clay and china stone from Devon and
Cornwall.
Domestic pottery, including china, earthenware, stoneware, jet and
Rockingham, accounts for about half of the industry’s output; the other main
divisions are glazed tiles, sanitary ware and electrical ware, and such specialised
industrial products as acid-proof stoneware, porous ceramics and laboratory
porcelain are also manufactured. Among famous makes of British pottery are

Wedgwood, Spode, Royal Worcester, Royal Doulton, Minton, Coalport and
Royal Crown Derby. Total sales of domestic pottery were ^58-1 million in
1969 including export sales of ^25-9 million, the highest ever; the United
States and Canada are important markets.
There has been considerable re-equipment; gas or electrically fired kilns
have replaced almost all the coal-fired kilns, and new decorating techniques
and automatic and semi-automatic machinery have been introduced.
Britain’s glass industry is the third largest in the world. The section of the
industry devoted to the manufacture of plate and sheet glass in their various
forms is organised for quantity production, much of it in the form of the
‘float’ glass process, which was developed in Britain and has been licensed
to glass makers throughout the world. Its use for internal decoration and as
a finish for internal and external walls has greatly increased in recent years.
Large quantities of safety glass are produced for the motor industry. Other
products include glass bricks, tubular glass (produced on a large scale),
mirrors, lamp and bulb glass, scientific and medical glassware, glass fibres,
and all types of glass containers (often made by fully automatic machinery).
A traditional product is hand-made lead crystal glassware of very high quality.
Direct exports of glass and glassware reached the record value of £39-4
million in 1969. Those of glass were worth £23-4 million, the most important
markets being the United States, South Africa, Australia and Canada. The
figures included X7'5 million of float glass.
Collective research is undertaken by the British Glass Industry Research
Association, and much research work is also carried out by the Department
of Glass Technology of Sheffield University.
The cement industry of the United Kingdom is chiefly concerned with the
manufacture of Portland cement. Invented by Joseph Aspdin and patented
in 1824, this material and the methods of its production have been the subject
of continuous technical improvement and intensive research. The capacity
of the industry, which has 17,000 employees, has expanded substantially.
The Dartford-Gravesend district of Kent is an important producing area.
Annual output totalled 17-1 million tons in 1969.
The paper, printing and publishing industries have 634,000 employees,
including 92,000 in the manufacture of paper and board, 64,000 in the pro¬
duction of cardboard boxes and packing cases, 143,000 in the publishing of
newspapers and periodicals, and 261,500 in other types of printing and
publishing.
The manufacture of paper in Great Britain was not firmly established until
1678, but records show that some paper was produced as far back as 1492.
The British paper and board industry is the largest in Europe. Total produc¬
tion in 1969 of all types of paper and board amounted to 4-9 million tons. Of
this, newsprint accounted for 777,000 tons, board for 1*4 million tons and
other paper for the remainder. Exports of paper, board and manufactured
paper items were valued at £78-6 million in 1969. The main purchasers were
the Republic of Ireland, South Africa and Australia.
Wood pulp is the main raw material, but large and increasing quantities of
waste paper are also used. A £20 million integrated pulp and paper mill, the
first in Britain, was opened at Fort William, in the Scottish Highlands, in
1966. Two-thirds of the timber it uses is home-grown.

There are a few very large groups in the industry and many medium-sized
and small firms. The large groups hold considerable interests abroad, includ¬
ing pulp and paper producing mills in the United States, Canada and other
parts of the Commonwealth and Europe. Sales of household paper products,
including facial tissues, have continued to rise sharply. Sales of cardboard
boxes and cartons were valued at ^129 million in 1969 while those of fibre
board packing cases totalled £126 million. Sales of manufactured stationery
totalled ^112-3 million in 1969. Wallpaper manufacturing is dominated by
one firm; a recent development has been the introduction of plastic and
plastic-coated wall coverings. Research is undertaken by the Research Associa¬
tion for the Paper and Board, Printing and Packaging Industries.
The printing industry produces an immense range of goods, from national
newspapers and periodicals to books, catalogues and greetings cards. The
industry includes many very small enterprises. Mergers in recent years have
led to the formation of large groups in the newspaper, magazine and book
publishing sections. Three large firms each employ more than 19,000 persons.
General printing, publishing, engraving and bookbinding remains essentially
an industry of small firms.
Publishers’ turnover in 1969 is estimated at £138 million, of which export
sales accounted for a record total of .£66 million. Consumers’ expenditure on
books, newspapers and magazines totalled almost £4°° million in 1968. Book
titles published in 1969 totalled nearly 32,400, over 23,200 of them new ones.
Popularity of paper-backed books has increased rapidly in recent years.
According to the overseas trade returns, exports of printed matter, manu¬
scripts and typescripts were valued at £81 million in 1969? including books
(£42-6 million), and newspapers and periodicals (£13-9 million), but these
figures do not include parcel post shipments, which are possibly as large again
as the recorded totals. The United States and Australia are the most important
overseas markets. The Book Development Council was formed in 1965 to
promote the supply and use of British books overseas. Firms have introduced
the latest developments in high-speed printing equipment, including elec¬
tronic engraving machines and advanced processes of photographic repro¬
duction, and several newspapers are now set by computer.
Other manufacturing industries include the timber and furniture group, with
301,000 employees, rubber manufacture, with 129,000 employees, and a group
of miscellaneous manufactures which embrace some 225,000 employees,
including 107,000 employed in plastics moulding and fabricating.
Britain’s rubber manufacturing industry is the oldest in the world, dating
from 1819. Macintosh invented waterproof garments, and Dunlop in 1888
devised the pneumatic tyre. Tyres and tubes represent more than half the
output of the industry but firms also make a variety of goods, the most
important being rubber footwear, conveyor belting, cables, hose, latex foam
products and other vehicle components and accessories.
In 1969 the industry’s consumption of rubber totalled 438,600 tons, com¬
prising 178,400 tons of natural rubber, 235,800 tons of synthetic rubber and
24,400 tons of reclaimed rubber; the proportion of synthetic rubber used is
increasing. In 1969, 249,000 tons of rubber were used in the production of
tyres and tyre products. Tyre manufacturers include several subsidiaries of
United States and other overseas companies. The Government has approved
in principle the proposed merger of Britain’s biggest tyre company and its

Direct export of all rubber manufactures in 1969 were worth ^72-4 million,
with Sweden, Australia and Denmark as the main markets. This figure
included tyres and tubes valued at ^38-8 million, but excluded large indirect
exports on vehicles. In addition, the industry exported about £4-8 million
worth of rubber footwear and £2-2 million of rubber gloves and other
miscellaneous products.
London is the largest centre for furniture manufacturing, but High Wycombe,
in Buckinghamshire, is important for domestic furniture.
Deliveries of domestic furniture rose by 27 per cent in volume between 1958
and 1969, and in the latter year their value was £177 million. Exports of all
furniture were worth ^23-2 million in 1969. Numerous enterprises manu¬
facture furniture in Britain (including domestic, upholstered, office, school
and other furniture) with a labour force of 90,000. The bedding industry
employs 18,000 people; sales of new bedding in 1969 were valued at £35-5
million. Many firms are small but in recent years there has been a tendency
towards concentration.
Scientific research and technical information services are provided by the
Furniture Development Council and the Furniture Industry Research
Association. The Council is concerned with the management problems of the
industry and produces an annual statistical and economic review.
The brush industry is located throughout Britain, and embraces highly
mechanised establishments as well as small craft units. The value of sales in
1969 was £22-4 million, of which £2 million was for export.
The timber industry employs 110,500 people. Britain is mainly dependent
on imported supplies of timber (valued at £218 million in 1969) but sawmill
output of home-grown timber together with the output of home-grown
pitwood totalled about 65 million cubic feet in 1969. Other products include
plywood and chipboard.
The number of people engaged in manufacturing toys and sports equipment
in Britain is 39,000. Sales of toys in 1969 were worth ^81 million and exports
had a value of £28 million. The United States and the Federal Republic of
Germany were the main overseas markets. Current trends are towards
increased production of small-scale precision models of vehicles and toys
linked to television characters.
The value of manufacturers’ sales of games was £$-6 million and that of
sports equipment £21-7 million, of which £g-6 million was for export.

AGRICULTURE
Although Britain is a densely populated, industrialised country relying on
imports for nearly half its food supply, agriculture remains one of its largest
and most important industries. It occupies 706,000 people or nearly 3 per cent
of the total working population, provides about 3 per cent of the gross
national product, and uses 48 million of the 60 million acres (19-5 million of
the 24 million hectares) of land.
In Northern Ireland 2-7 million of the 3-3 million acres (i-i million of the
1-3 million hectares) of land are in agricultural use, and the corresponding
proportions for employment and gross product are 10 per cent and 9 per cent.
THE LAND AND The soils of the country are extremely varied. Many of those in the west and
ITS USES north, overlying hard rocks, are poor and thin. The lowlands and river
valleys are usually fertile, varying in texture from clay through silt to sandy
loam. There is also some peat. Clay soils often require under-drainage. Land
used for farming is conventionally divided into improved land suitable for
cultivation (crops and grass) and rough grazing. In hill country the area of
improved land is often small, but is usually supplemented by grazing on a
comparatively large area of hill land.
In the United Kingdom as a whole there are 30 million acres (i2'2 million
hectares) under crops and grass. Improved land and rough grazing together
represent 80 per cent of the land area. The rest is mountain and forest, or put
to urban and kindred uses. The area available for farming is gradually de¬
creasing to meet the needs of housing and industry; however, the loss is more
than outweighed by the increase in output from what remains. Rough grazing,
nearly all of which is hill or mountain land with a native herbage of coarse
grasses, rushes, bracken, heather or scrub trees, has a low potential output—
usually assessed at about one-sixth of that of agricultural land—but is valuable
for sheep. In England and Wales only one-sixth of farming land is classified as
rough grazing. In Northern Ireland the proportion is about one-quarter, but
in Scotland it is about three-quarters.
For many centuries the bulk of land in Britain lay in estates ranging in size
from a few hundred acres upwards, comprising farms of varying sizes let to
tenants. Social changes of the past half-century have completely changed the
pattern of rural life in England and Scotland. Estate duties have been a
principal factor in the breaking up of estates. Most surviving estates are still
owned by private individuals or family trusts, but the Crown, local authorities,
and other corporate bodies hold considerable areas. Of the farms sold, many
have been bought by the tenants already in occupation. About half the farms
in Great Britain today are owner-occupied.
There are about 340,000 significant farming units in Britain. Just under
half are very small units, mostly farmed part-time by occupiers who have

another source of livelihood besides farming, and accounting for less than a
tenth of the industry’s total output. About half of the total output comes from
the 10 per cent of holdings classified as large farm business, capable of
employing four or more full-time men. There are estimated to be some
190,000 full-time farm businesses in Britain including about 56,000 medium¬
sized (two-four men) and 100,000 small businesses. The number is falling
by about 4,000 or 2 per cent a year.
The average size of full-time holdings in England and Wales is 160 acres
(65 hectares) of crops and grass. In Scotland the crops and grass area of the
22,300 full-time farms averages 170 acres (70 hectares) although the average
for the 32,900 part-time and other holdings is only 16 acres (6-5 hectares).
In Northern Ireland the land is divided into about 64,000 holdings, almost
all of which are owner-occupied. About 40 per cent of these holdings are
either very small or let in conacre (seasonal lettings for crops or grazing), so
that the number of effective farm businesses is about 37,000 of which half
provides a full-time occupation for the owner. The typical farm size is between
40 and 70 acres (16 and 28 hectares) of crops and grass.
Most British farms produce a variety of products; the pattern varies from
farm to farm. Dairy farming is widespread throughout Britain. In England
the farms devoted primarily to arable crops are in the eastern part of the
country—in East Anglia, Kent, Lincolnshire and the East Riding of Yorkshire.
Potato and vegetable growing on a substantial scale marks the farming of the
Fens (south Lincolnshire and Cambridgeshire), the alluvial areas around the
rivers Thames and Humber and the peaty lands in south Lancashire. Else¬
where, horticultural crops are widely dispersed amongst agricultural crops.
In Scotland the rich lowlands of the east coast are also primarily arable.
Interspersed between these arable areas, and also in the Midlands, the
south-east of England and the north-east of Scotland, there are large tracts
where much of the land is under grass and the rearing and fattening of
cattle is an important enterprise. In the south-west of Scotland dairying is
extensively practised, but most of the north-west is devoted to rearing sheep
on rough hill land. The parts of England bordering the Pennine hills and most
of Wales are also sheep-rearing areas, though a good deal of dairying, based
on purchased feedingstuffs, is also done there. In Northern Ireland mixed
farming is practised, the most important products being milk, fat and store
cattle, pigs and eggs, with sheep and stock raising in the hill areas. Oats and
barley are widely grown, mainly for livestock feeding, and the only important
cash crop is potatoes, both ware and seed.
There are three main categories of grassland in the United Kingdom-
temporary grass, permanent grass and rough grazing. Temporary grass may
be part of an arable rotation, providing a break of from one to seven years
between tillage crops, or it may be part of an all-grass system where its
advantages over permanent grass are that it can provide early and late season
grazing and often heavier crops.
Since the end of the second world war there has been an increase approach¬
ing half a million acres (202,000 hectares) in the area of temporary grass and
the total arable area is over 5 million acres (2 million hectares) more than it was
pre-war. In England and Wales nearly one-half of the 24 million acres (97
million hectares) of crops and grass (excluding over 3 million acres (1-2
million hectares) of rough grazing) is under permanent grass, one-third under
cereals and one-sixth under temporary grass. About three-quarters of all

agricultural land in Scotland is in rough grazing and of the 4-3 million acres
(1-7 million hectares) of crops and grass about one-quarter is in permanent
and two-fifths in temporary grass. Excluding about 640,000 acres (259,000
hectares) of rough grazing the crops and grass area of Northern Ireland is
about 2 million acres (o-8 million hectares) of which over half is under per¬
manent and slightly less than one-quarter under temporary grass.
Farmers everywhere are exposed to the vagaries of the weather, of pests and
diseases, and of the market; but over the past 30 years much has been done
in Britain to mitigate these risks. This has been partly due to the advance of
science, partly to self-help by farmers’ organisations, but largely to govern¬
ment action. The role of the Government as guarantor and provider of
technical and advisory services, is described on pp. 308-18.
The steady expansion in production and in yield per acre of arable land which
has taken place over the last 30 years is summarised in Table 19. Apart from
a slight decline between 1961 and 1964 and another in 1968 total cattle stocks
have risen steadily each year since 1953. The milk-producing herd reached its
peak level in 1962, thereafter suffering a two-year decline. Since 1964 the
herd has again increased each year despite heavy losses in the foot-and-mouth
epidemic of 1967-68. Numbers of sheep and lambs reached their highest level
in 1966 but have since declined slightly. Numbers of pigs and poultry have
expanded considerably over the past decade, though pig numbers showed a
temporary reduction in 1966-67. Production of wheat at nearly 3! million
tons in 1969-70 has increased by over two-thirds since the end of the second
world war, while barley production at over 8£ million tons in 1969-70 is now
more than four times the 1946 figure. There has been a marked fall in the
production of oats. Potato production is very susceptible to weather conditions
but on average adequate supplies are being maintained from a steadily
declining area. Between i960 and 1969 output of pigmeat increased by about
one-third and eggs by under one-fifth and these, together with the increase
in beef and milk output, resulted in higher consumption of feedingstuffs,
mostly from home resources. Imports of concentrated feeds fell slightly from
6 million tons in 1960-61 to 5^ million tons in 1966-67, but then rose to
6 million tons in 1969-70.
The index of agricultural net output (all holdings) at constant prices has
risen steadily. By 1953-54 it was about 56 per cent above the immediate
pre-war average. Based on the average of 1954-55 to 1956-57=100, it was
135 in 1966-67. On a rebased index, 1964-65 to 1966-67 =100, 106 is forecast
for 1969-70.
Since 1939 the population of the United Kingdom has increased by over
7^ million, or 16 per cent. In spite of this growth Britain now produces just
over half of its total food requirements or two-thirds of all that can be grown
in temperate climates; this latter figure comparing with about one-half before
the second world war. Home production of the principal foods is shown as a
percentage by weight of total supplies in Table 20.
Table 21 shows how the level of the main food supplies passing into
consumption has changed since before the second world war and within the
last decade. The main trends reflected in the table are that consumption of
bulky foods (carbohydrates), such as flour, has tended to decline, while that of
lugh-protein foods, such as meat and eggs, continues to increase with greater
availability and rising living standards.

Wheat growing is mainly confined to the East Anglia area of England.
There was a sharp fall in the area under wheat in 1969 following bad weather
during the previous winter and spring. Harvesting conditions were reasonably
good, however, and about 3-3 million tons were harvested in 1969, with
average yields estimated at 32-3 cwt. per acre (660 kg. per hectare). Just under
a half of the wheat crop is used for flour milling, the remainder going mainly
for animal feed.
Since i960 the area under barley has increased by nearly 80 per cent and
production has more than doubled due to improved yields. The important
malting and distilling market currently absorbs about one-sixth of the crop,
most of the remainder being used for animal feeding purposes.
The widespread use of combine harvesters has necessitated the installation
of drying and storage facilities on many farms. Such equipment is also widely
used on a co-operative basis.
In England and Wales the total area of fodder crops has fallen because in
many cases farmers can provide winter feed more economically by increased
grass production and improved methods of conservation. In Scotland the area
of fodder crops is declining but the area of turnips and swedes is greater than
in England.
Beet is grown mainly in East Anglia and Lincolnshire where most of the beet
sugar factories are situated. The crop is grown under contract to the British
Sugar Corporation, which takes the entire output at guaranteed prices and also
provides technical advice and assistance. Precision drilling is the usual method
of sowing and more than three-quarters of the crop is mechanically harvested.
Potatoes are grown in most parts of Britain. Early potatoes are cultivated
mainly in the south and on the west coast for immediate summer marketing.
The production of main crop potatoes (which may be stored until the
following spring) is centred on the eastern side of the country and in Northern
Ireland, which sends about one-sixth of its crop to Great Britain. Scotland
and Northern Ireland produce more than half of the requirements of seed
potatoes. Both areas also export seed potatoes. The long-term trend is for the
area planted with potatoes to diminish and for yields to increase but Britain
remains self-sufficient in main crop potatoes except in years of unusually low
yield. The area declined from 829,000 acres (335,000 hectares) in i960 to
an estimated 691,000 acres (280,000 hectares) in 1968. Wet cultivating and
sowing conditions in the 1968-69 winter and spring were the main causes of
a further fall in 1969 to 614,000 acres (248,000 hectares). The yield in 1969
was 10 tons per acre (25 tonnes per hectare), the record being io-i tons per
acre (25-3 tonnes per hectare) in 1965. Although the planting, cultivation,
harvesting and grading of the potato crop are becoming increasingly mechan¬
ised, much hand labour is still needed.
Milk is much more valuable when sold on the liquid milk market than when
converted into cheese, butter or other milk products. In Great Britain milk
is produced primarily for liquid consumption, but in Northern Ireland the
greater part of the milk is used for manufactured products. Average
consumption per head is nearly five pints per week.
Average yields per dairy cow have increased during the last decade by more
than 11 per cent and now average well over 800 gallons (3,64° litres) a year.
Freedom from tuberculosis has reduced herd wastage, and through the
artificial insemination (AI) centres, operated by the Milk Marketing Boards
and other organisations, the influence of a relatively small number of high-

potential bulls is widely disseminated. It is estimated that about two-thirds
of Britain’s total cattle are bred by AI. The Friesian breed is dominant in the
dairy herds of England, Wales and Northern Ireland, but in Scotland the
Ayrshire breed is the most numerous. Milk production has also been stimu¬
lated by advances in grassland management, intensive grazing techniques and
new methods of making high quality hay; new methods of conversion into
silage are being exploited. Most dairy farmers practise some degree of in¬
tensive grass management, but hay of the traditional type remains the basic
winter feed; it is supplemented with purchased concentrates.
Clean dairy farming methods and hygienic standards for equipment and
buildings used in milk production are prescribed by regulations made and
enforced by the appropriate ministers.

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 305
A great number of specialised breeds of livestock have been developed over
the centuries in Britain. It has been found that they meet the needs of breeders
in most countries and substantial export sales are made to buyers seeking to
replenish and improve their herds with British animals.
In the hill regions hardy herds of beef cattle are kept, especially of the
Galloway and Welsh Black breeds and their crosses; in marginal land and
lower areas the sires used are predominantly of the Aberdeen Angus and
Hereford breeds. About two-thirds of home-fed beef production derives from
the dairy herds, some females being mated to beef sires, the majority by AI.
There is a large and complex trade in store cattle (increased by animals
imported from the Irish Republic), a typical movement being from the upland
west to grazing areas in the Midlands.
Britain has outstandingly good pastures for sheep. Moreover, veterinary
research has provided vaccine and sera protection against nearly all the
epidemic diseases to which sheep are subject. More than 30 breeds and
innumerable crosses are to be found in Britain, each breed having originated
within a circumscribed area.
In the hills, and especially in the Highlands, winter conditions are usually
severe. Draft ewes and lambs are brought from the hill areas every autumn
to swell the lowland flocks, usually in two stages: first, to farms at inter¬
mediate altitudes, where they are mated with rams of a larger and more
rapidly maturing breed; then, the cross-bred progeny pass on in due course
to the more genial lowland conditions and especially to the Midlands and the
south and east of England, where they become crossed again with Down
rams for fat lamb production. The hill breeds bring in hardiness and the
lowland sires fecundity and early maturity.
Although wool is of considerable importance to the sheep farmer the main
object is the production of fat lambs; this reflects the change in the preference
of consumers away from mature sheep.
Pig production is carried on in most parts of Britain but is particularly
important in the eastern and southern counties of England. In the past pigs
were found on the majority of farms but there is now an increasing concentra¬
tion into specialist units and larger herds. The most frequently used breeds are
the Large White and the Landrace though considerable cross-breeding takes
place. Pig improvements are fostered by the Meat and Livestock Commission
and by leading commercial firms through schemes for progeny and perform¬
ance testing, litter recording and other development work. Attention is focused
on utility qualities, such as size and weight of litters, and on food consumed
per pound of liveweight gain. AI is available as a nationwide service.
Carcases are used for curing as bacon, for sale as fresh pork and for manu¬
facturing into sausages and other processed forms. In terms of pig meat, about
30 per cent is used for bacon and 70 per cent for pork and manufacturing.
Specialist techniques and intensive husbandry have been introduced over a
large part of the poultry industry and considerable concentration has occurred.
There are now several flocks of over 100,000 birds and only a small pro¬
portion of total production is in the hands of the smallest producers. About
80 per cent of the laying birds on farms are in flocks of 1,000 or more. With the
rise in the poultry population and in the yield of eggs per bird (now averaging
well over 200 eggs a year), the estimated production of eggs has more than
doubled the 1938 level and for several years nearly all eggs consumed in
Britain have been home-produced. About 285 million broilers and other
special table chickens were produced in 1969.

Horticultural crops occupy only a small fraction of the cultivated land of
the country—about 2% per cent of the area under crops and grass—but their
value in terms of output per acre is very high. The total value of horticultural
crops sold in 1969-70 is estimated at about £226 million, out of an estimated
total value of £2,115 million for all output from agricultural holdings in
Britain. The June 1969 Census of open-grown crops showed that there were
about 470,000 acres (195,000 hectares) of vegetables (excluding potatoes),
about 207,000 acres (84,000 hectares) of fruit, and 36,000 acres (14,600
hectares) of flowers and nursery stock.
Market gardening has grown up around all the large centres of population,
notably in the Lee Valley, near London, and in more rural areas with favour¬
able soil or climatic conditions—in Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, Lincoln¬
shire, Hampshire and Kent, and in a concentration of smallholdings in the
Vale of Evesham. Districts with mild climates, such as the Penzance region of
Cornwall, have been favoured for the production of selected early crops. More
recently, selected vegetable crops, particularly peas, have been grown in
rapidly increasing quantities for quick-freezing.
Specialised horticultural holdings range from a few acres up to about
300 acres (120 hectares), and many have glasshouses, frames or forcing houses.
Use of fertilisers, particularly of an organic nature, is very heavy, and much
of the field work is mechanised. The larger holdings normally have specialised
packing sheds, with washing and grading machinery, and irrigation plants.
Growers, however, often join together in co-operatives for marketing their
produce and many of these provide grading and packing facilities.
Britain has over 4,500 acres (1,820 hectares) of glasshouses, about half of the
area being used primarily for the cultivation of tomatoes, the main centres of
which are the Lee Valley in Essex and Hertfordshire, Lancashire, the East
Riding of Yorkshire, the rest of Essex and Sussex. In the Lea Valley, on a
narrow belt of gravel and brick earth, about 450 acres (182 hectares) are
covered with glass. Production of tomatoes is estimated at about 85,000 tons
annually and the value of all glasshouse crops (including flowers) is nearly
£45 million per year.
Hard fruits are grown in many parts of England and Wales, the chief risk
associated with their culture being late frosts. The main centres are in the
south, south-west and east of England, and Kent in particular. The area of
Cox’s Orange Pippin has increased in recent years but that of other dessert
varieties and of cooking apples has declined. About 23,000 acres (9,300
hectares) of varieties of cider apple are grown mainly in Devon, Herefordshire
and Somerset for the cider-making industry. In Northern Ireland there are
between 6,500 and 7,000 acres (2,630 and 2,830 hectares) of cooking apples—
Bramley’s Seedling—mostly concentrated in County Armagh. Plums and
soft fruits are grown in many counties; concentrations of plums and cherries
are found in Kent and Worcestershire, of blackcurrants in Norfolk, Kent,
Herefordshire and Worcestershire; and of strawberries in the Wisbech area
and in Kent. Raspberries are exceptional in that of some 9,000 acres (3,640
hectares) grown in Britain over four-fifths are in Scotland, mainly in the
Blairgowrie district of Perthshire and in Angus.
Hop-growing for the brewing industry is confined to two main areas, in Kent
and Sussex and in Herefordshire and Worcestershire. Capital outlay and
cultivation costs are very high, but crops per acre average about 12 cwt.,
worth some ^470. The total annual value of the crop is nearly £7 million.

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 3°7
Estimates of farm expenses and sales and the aggregate net income of agri¬
cultural producers are prepared annually by the agricultural departments
(see Table 22). They show that Britain’s farming is based on livestock; two-
thirds of farmers’ income is derived from the sale of animals or their products.
The aggregate net income of farmers rose from £393 million in 1960-61 to
£535^ million in 1969—70* The annual cost of direct support to agriculture
from public funds has averaged £255 million during the past five years.
Of farm expenses, machinery and equipment amount to about one-sixth,
feedingstuffs about one-third and wages about one-fifth. Since i960 male
agricultural earnings have risen by nearly 70 per cent, offsetting the manpower
economies made possible by mechanisation and increasing farm size.
Until 1958 rents tended to lag behind other costs. This was due partly to
the reluctance of landlords to put up the rents of satisfactory tenants, and
partly to the terms of reference given to arbitrators. These terms were
modified in the Agriculture Act 1958 and since i960 rents in England and
Wales have gone up by about 90 per cent.

The capital required for land and buildings may be provided by the farmei,
if he is an owner-occupier, or by the landlord, if the farm is let to a tenant.
In 1969 ‘fixed capital’ totalling nearly £100 million was added to the value of
land and buildings and £186 million was invested in new plant, machinery,
vehicles and stock. The bulk of the capital required to stock and run the farms
is provided by the occupiers. Bank advances are an important source of
outside capital, both fixed and working; about two-thirds of the total bank
advances to agriculture are believed to be for short-term purposes. Agricultural
merchants are also an important source or short-term credit. Mortgage loans
form the chief source of long-term credit and are provided by specialised
financial institutions (see p. 312) and private sources.

Accounts of some 2,000 farms in England and Wales, collected by university
agricultural economists in 1968-69, show average valuations of occupiers’
capital ranging from over £10 to more than £60 per acre (^4 to £24 per
hectare), or well over £100 (^40-50) for intensive holdings. In Scotland a
similar sample of 800 accounts shows a wide range in valuations per acre,
from about £3 (£1-20 per hectare) on hill sheep farms with extensive rough
grazings to between £50 and £60 per acre (£20 and £24 per hectare) on low¬
land farms. In Northern Ireland average valuations of occupiers’ capital range
from over £100 on the smaller, more intensive farms to ^50 per acre (^40 to
£20 per hectare) on the larger farms. On all types of farms investment in
machinery is a heavy item: on dairy and arable farms it averages nearly £20
per acre (^8 per hectare); on stock-rearing farms it may amount to £7 per
acre (£3 per hectare).
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world, with over half a
million tractors in 1969, or one to every 31 acres (12-6 hectares) of arable land.
Power-take-off implements now characterise arable farming; and some
69,000 combine harvesters were in use in 1969. A wide variety of machines for
harvesting and preservation of grass are employed. Milking machines are
installed on all except the smallest farms, many with mechanical means of
handling milk.
Over 90 per cent of the farms in Great Britain have an electricity supply
and accompanying equipment. There are about 1,100 farmers’ machinery
syndicates through which farmers have the use of expensive equipment
without tying up their own capital.
Research, development and testing of farm machinery are carried out by
the National Institute of Agricultural Engineering.
The range of net incomes between individual farms is very wide, varying
with the type and size of farm, quality of land, and managerial ability of the
occupier. The average net income for farms of different types is mostly within
the range of £5 to £16 per acre (£2 to £6-50 per hectare) with the exception
of pig and poultry farms and horticultural holdings, which are more in¬
tensive in their use of land. Net income per acre on dairy and arable farms
has nearly always been higher than on stock-rearing farms, which are generally
larger than the other types and are situated on poorer land.
By the beginning of the 1930s the need for some form of State assistance to
agriculture had become pressing: it was during this time that the Govern¬
ment initiated the various forms of protection and financial assistance for agri¬
culture.
During the second world war and the immediate post-war years, agri¬
cultural production was closely controlled by the State, with County War
Agricultural Executive Committees, composed of landowners, farmers and
farm workers, acting as the Government’s local agents.
Government policy today is founded on the Agriculture Act 1947 and 1957,
the Agriculture and Horticulture Act 1964 and the Agriculture Acts 1967 and
1970. The main objective, as set out in Section 1 of the 1947 Act, continues to
be ‘a stable and efficient agricultural industry capable of producing such part
of the nation’s food and other agricultural produce as in the national interest it
is desirable to produce in the United Kingdom, and of producing it at mini-
Machinery of
Government
CURRENT
SUPPORT POLICY
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 309
mum prices consistent with proper remuneration and living conditions for
farmers and workers in agriculture and an adequate return on capital invested
in the industry’. To this end, the Government is empowered to provide, for
the main agricultural products, guaranteed prices determined in the light of
annual reviews (see p. 310).
The Agriculture Act of 1957 assured farmers that the prices guaran¬
teed under the 1947 Act would not be steeply reduced, and at the same
time provided grants towards the cost of bringing fixed equipment up to
date.
The Agriculture and Horticulture Act 1964 gave the Government powers to
introduce minimum import prices for agricultural and horticultural products.
These powers have been used in the case of cereals and, in 1970, for eggs
and certain egg products. An understanding with overseas suppliers on the
sharing of the bacon market became effective in 1964 and was renewed in
1969.
In 1968 the selective expansion programme, announced in 1965, was
extended to 1973 provided expansion was based on increasing productivity.
The agricultural industry is expected both to release manpower and to
increase production to meet the major part of the growth in demand for
temperate foodstuffs.
The functions of government in relation to agriculture are mostly exercised
by the agricultural ministers, that is to say, for England and Wales the
Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and the Secretary of State for
Wales, for Scotland the Secretary of State for Scotland, and for Northern
Ireland the Home Secretary, who is the minister responsible for United
Kingdom aspects of Northern Ireland agriculture, local aspects being the
responsibility of the Northern Ireland Minister of Agriculture. The agri¬
cultural ministers are assisted by advisory committees composed of general
agriculturists, scientists and other specialists.
The headquarters of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food is
divided functionally, each division being responsible for a particular sub¬
ject or service. Its relations with individual farmers are conducted mainly
through its local offices, grouped in England in regions, each administered by a
regional controller working in close collaboration with the regional heads of
the technical services. Local offices in Wales are grouped under a Welsh Sec¬
retary with similar functions and with special responsibility for Welsh affairs.
In Scotland most of the agricultural functions of the Secretary of State are
discharged through the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries. The
Secretary of State for Scotland also appoints the members of the Crofters
Commission (see p. 313) and the Red Deer Commission, which deals with the
conservation and control of red deer.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture is responsible for imple¬
menting agricultural policy inaugurated by the Northern Ireland Government.
It is organised on similar lines to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and
Food, for which it acts as agent in the administration in Northern Ireland of
United Kingdom agricultural schemes.
In November 1966 an Economic Development Committee (see p. 235) for
agriculture was established, comprising representatives of farmers, workers
and landowners, as well as official members.
In February each year, in accordance with the 1947 Act, the agricultural
ministers review the economic condition and prospects of the industry.

Annual Review
Price
Guarantees
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Between annual reviews, a special review may be held in the event of a change
in circumstances. In holding reviews, the ministers are required to consult
with representatives of agricultural producers—in practice, the three farmers’
unions in the United Kingdom. The ministers consider such factors as pro¬
duction trends and market requirements, world market prospects, the cost of
subsidies, the trend of income in the industry as a whole, the increasing
efficiency of the industry and changes in production costs. In the light of their
conclusions from the Review, Ministers determine guaranteed prices for fat
cattle, fat sheep, fat pigs, eggs, wool, milk, cereals, potatoes and sugar beet.
These guarantees apply to livestock and livestock products for the ensuing
12 months, and to crops to be harvested in the current year. Consideration is
also given to the relevant production grants (see p. 311) which are those con¬
nected with tenant-type activities (for example, fertilisers subsidy), as opposed
to grants which are the responsibility of the landlord (for example, Farm
Improvement Scheme), and they are taken into account in calculating the total
value of the guarantees. The Government’s conclusions and its decisions on
changes in guaranteed prices and relevant production grants are published as
a White Paper.
The cost of government support to the industry in 1969-70 was about
£280 million; the estimate for 1970-71, made before the 1970 review de¬
cisions, forecast an increase to about £299 million.
The general policy of the Government is to allow free import of food into
Britain. The support system acts by means of deficiency payments to stabilise
prices to farmers at appropriate levels. These payments make up the deficit
between the open market price of a commodity and the price guaranteed by
the Government.
The deficiency payments scheme for cereals is administered directly by the
agricultural departments, and storage incentives are paid to growers who sell
their wheat and barley after the harvest period. ‘Standard quantity’1 arrange¬
ments for wheat and barley were introduced for the 1964 crop but were
abolished in 1968 and 1969 respectively. Deficiency payments for fatstock
are made weekly to producers on certified sales on a liveweight or deadweight
basis. For cattle and sheep there may also be a balancing payment at the end of
the year if the average return to producers falls short of the annual guaranteed
price.
For most of the remaining commodities and for fat pigs in Northern
Ireland, the Government operates the guarantee through the appropriate
marketing board, which takes account of any payments from or to the Govern¬
ment in deciding what to pay producers for their produce. In the case of milk
there are five boards, and the full guaranteed price is paid only on a ‘standard
quantity’ relating to the volume of liquid milk sales plus a reasonable reserve.
Milk produced in excess of the standard quantity is sold for manufacturing
considerably below the full guaranteed price. The retail price of liquid milk is
determined by the Government so as to cover the full cost of the guarantee
and, taking one year with another, there is no Exchequer subsidy. For eggs, a
1 The Agriculture Act 1947 postulates that the guarantees should be related to the
volume of agricultural produce which, in the national interest, it is desirable to produce
domestically (see p. 308). This is effected by including ‘standard quantities’ in the
guarantee arrangements for milk, eggs, pigs, potatoes and sugar beet. ‘Standard
quantity’ arrangements vary in form but, in general, the basic guaranteed price
determined in the Annual Review is related to a specific quantity of produce marketed
annually on a national basis; if this quantity is exceeded, the producers’ average
unit return falls.

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 31I
subsidy is paid to the British Egg Marketing Board on all first-quality eggs
sold to the Board through packing stations but new arrangements will be
necessary after the end of March 1971 when the Board will cease to exist (see
p. 315). The government intends to phase out the subsidy and remove eggs
from the guarantee by the end of March 1974. A deficiency payment is made
for potatoes in years in which the growers’ average price for potatoes for
human consumption (excluding new potatoes) is less than the guaranteed
price; payment for the benefit of growers is made to the Potato Marketing
Board in Great Britain and to the Ministry of Agriculture, Northern Ireland.
Surpluses are purchased by these authorities for stockfeed.
For wool a fixed price is guaranteed to the British Wool Marketing Board
for every pound of fleece wool it buys from producers. This enables it to fix in
advance a schedule of producers’ prices, based on types and quality, after
making allowance for the Board’s marketing costs.
Under the Sugar Act 1956 and the Agriculture Act 1957 the British Sugar
Corporation contracts to buy the whole of the sugar beet crop produced from
a specified acreage—at present 443,000 acres (179,000 hectares) at a scale
of fixed prices, determined as a result of the annual review and related to
sugar content. Refined sugar produced by the Corporation is sold, under
market-sharing agreements with the refiners, at a price based on the world
price.
The Sugar Board buys Commonwealth sugar under the Commonwealth
Sugar Agreement and sells it commercially. The deficits or surpluses which
result from the transactions of both the Corporation and the Board are
ultimately reflected in the Board’s accounts. When these accounts show a
deficit a surcharge is made on all sugar, imported or home-produced, entering
the British market, including the sugar content of composite sugar imports,
and when there is a surplus a distribution payment is made correspondingly,
so that taking one year with another the Board balances its accounts.
The price supports outlined above relate only to current production. To
increase productivity, however, the Government offers to farmers a wide
range of inducements, known as production grants, for improvements to land,
crops, livestock and equipment. In 1969-70 the Exchequer’s contribution in
the form of production grants was ^136 million. The form taken by these
schemes varies considerably but they fall into three main categories. Firstly,
improvements to land fertility, which include a subsidy on fertilisers and
lime and grants for field drainage, farm water supply and for ploughing certain
kinds of land; the Exchequer cost of these improvements currently runs at
nearly £45 million a year. The second type of inducement is aimed at main¬
taining breeding herds of cattle and flocks of sheep (particularly in upland
areas) and includes a calf subsidy on animals suitable for beef production;
the total cost is over £55 million a year. The third type consists of a contribu¬
tion towards farm improvements generally but with particular reference to
farm buildings, silos, roads, fences and other equipment. From March 1970
the rates of grant have been 40 per cent on items approved under the Farm
Improvement Scheme, 60 per cent on items under the Hill Land Improve¬
ment Scheme and for field drainage schemes, plus a 10 per cent supplement
for field drainage benefiting hill land. A grant is also available to farmers and
growers to encourage the keeping of farm business records as an aid to sound
management decisions.
The Agriculture Act 1970 introduced a new unified farm capital grant
scheme to replace various existing schemes.

Under the Agriculture Act 1967 the Government is empowered to make
grants to meet 60 per cent of the approved costs of voluntary amalgamations
of small farms with other land to form commercial units; and to pay lump
sums or annuities to farmers who give up such holdings for amalgamation.
Where an owner wishes to dispose of an uncommercial holding the Govern¬
ment may buy it outright for this purpose.
Horticultural produce, because it is perishable and liable to seasonal variation
in quantity and quality, does not lend itself to a system of guaranteed prices.
Hitherto the principal means of support has been tariffs on imports, but
greater emphasis has now been placed on the need to strengthen the com¬
petitive efficiency of the industry so as to reduce its dependence upon tariffs.
To this end grants of one-third are available to meet the capital cost of a wide
range of buildings, plant and equipment used in the production, storage, pre¬
paration for market and transport of horticultural produce. Additionally,
small-scale horticulturists who are prepared to undertake a three-year pro¬
gramme for improving the efficiency of their businesses may qualify for a grant
of up to £500. The cost to the Exchequer of these schemes is over £4 million
a year.
Special arrangements for the agricultural and horticultural industries have
been made under the investment incentives procedure which replaced invest¬
ment allowances in 1966. Broadly speaking, the Minister of Agriculture in
England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the Secretary of State in Scotland
are empowered to p2y grants on approved expenditure on fixed equipment,
plant and machinery, agricultural tractors and self-propelled harvesters. From
March 1970 the rates of grant have been 30 pei cent for fixed equipment, plant
and machinery and 10 per cent on agricultural tractors and self-propelled
harvesters.
A number of facilities for specific purposes enjoy government encouragement
and support.
In England and Wales finance for the purchase or improvement of agri¬
cultural land and buildings is available from the Agricultural Mortgage Cor¬
poration Ltd. The Corporation’s funds are derived mainly from public
issues of stock, but it receives a measure of government support. Similarly
in Scotland, loans for agricultural purposes secured on agricultuial land in
Scotland are granted by the Scottish Agricultural Securities Corporation
Improvement loans for carrying out improvements to agricultural land and
buildings are also available to landowners from the Lands Impro\ement
Company, whose funds are provided privately.
In Northern Ireland loans are available to farmers from the Agricultural
Loans Fund, administered by the Ministry of Agriculture and financed out
of public funds. Half of the loans issued are short-term for agricultural
machinery and the remainder are medium- or long-term loans for such
purposes as the purchase of livestock, the erection and improvement of farm
buildings and farm dwellings, and the purchase of land for amalgamation and
subsequent restructuring. _
Under the Agriculture Act 1967 the Government can make loans in Great
Britain to help finance the purchase of land acquired for approved amalgama¬
tions of small farms (see above), and approved remodelling expenditure.
