AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 313
These loans may be granted up to 90 per cent (100 per cent for certain small
amalgamations) of the valuation of the combined unit determined by the
Agricultural Mortgage Corporation Ltd. in England and Wales and the
Scottish Agricultural Securities Corporation Ltd. in Scotland, which act as
the Government’s agents.
Since 1892 county councils and county borough councils in England and
Wales have had powers to provide land for smallholdings. For financial
assistance in improving smallholdings, authorities can obtain the amalgama¬
tions and capital grants available to farmers generally and these are supple¬
mented for certain smallholdings. In England and Wales, about 12,750
smallholdings are provided by local authorities and about 900 by the Ministry.
The Minister and local authorities may make loans for working capital
to their smallholding tenants. In this way the tenants can be helped to
obtain livestock, machinery, implements and other necessary items; tenants
must, however, have available at least 25 per cent of the capital required.
Land settlement in Scotland has always been carried out by the central
Government, which now owns and maintains about 420,000 acres (170,000
hectares) of land settlement estates, comprising some 3,450 crofts and
holdings.
In the seven Scottish crofting counties—Argyll, Caithness, Inverness,
Orkney, Ross and Cromarty, Sutherland and Shetland—much of the land is
farmed by crofters, tenant farmers whose holdings are generally either rented
at a cost of not more than £50 a year or have an area not exceeding 75 acres
(30 hectares).
In these counties there are about 19,000 crofts, which produce about
one-quarter of the total agricultural output of the area. The special problems
of the crofting counties, which had for some time been suffering from a
declining population, led to the setting up, in 1955, of a Crofters Commission
whose functions are to reorganise, develop and regulate crofting in the
crofting counties, to promote the interests of crofters and to keep under review
matters relating to crofting. The Commission’s statutory powers include
supervising the letting of crofts and (if the crofters agree) the reallocation
of land to form viable and self-contained communities; it also acts as
the Secretary of State’s agent in administering development grants and
loans.
Under the 1967 Agriculture Act a Northern Pennines Rural Development
Board has been set up to advise on the special problems of the upland
areas.
Land drainage (including flood protection) in England and Wales is the
responsibility of 27 river authorities (see p. 270), two catchment boards
(which exercise the functions of river authorities) and about 370 internal
drainage boards. Local authorities also have general land drainage powers.
There are no comparable authorities in Scotland, where arterial drainage of
agricultural land is the owners’ responsibility. River authorities have powers
to maintain and improve watercourses designated as main rivers. Their work
is concerned with the improvement of land drainage by increasing the capacity
and efficiency of rivers and erecting pumping stations, the prevention of
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
inland flooding and the construction and maintenance of defences to protect
low-lying areas from tidal flooding. River authorities also have powers relating
to water resources generally, freshwater fisheries and river pollution.
Internal drainage boards are concerned with very much smaller areas and
their work is chiefly in low-lying agricultural districts. Their main function is
to keep the land drained in their area by improving the main drains and,
where necessary, by pumping from low-lying land.
River authorities and catchment boards obtain most of the funds needed for
drainage purposes from local authorities. The Government pays grants to¬
wards the cost of improvement schemes carried out by these authorities. The
grants vary from 10 per cent to 80 per cent according to the financial position
of the authority, with an additional premium for sea defence works. Internal
drainage boards levy drainage rates on owners and occupiers and also receive
Government grants at a flat rate of 50 per cent. Local authorities receive grants
ranging from 20 per cent to 50 per cent. In Scotland 50 per cent grants are
available to owners or occupiers of agricultural land.
In Northern Ireland the Ministry of Agriculture is the drainage authority
in respect of watercourses designated by the Drainage Council as main or
minor watercourses.
In Great Britain more than half, and in Northern Ireland almost all, farms are
owner-occupied. The traditional form of tenancy in England and Wales runs
from year to year; in Scotland longer leases for terms of 10 to 14 years are
more common, although most tenants farm on a year-to-year basis. The
tenancy agreement may be either written or verbal (in Scotland it must be
written if the period of the lease exceeds one year) and may (but need not)
include provisions about such matters as rights of cropping, liability for repaii
and maintenance, and compensation for tenant’s improvements.
In order to protect the respective interests of landlords and tenants and to
eliminate uncertainty as to their rights and liabilities, a code of landlord and
tenant relationships has been written into legislation. The Agriculture Acts
1947 (England and Wales) and 1948 (Scotland) lay down the basic rules of
good estate management and good husbandry for owners and occupiers
respectively. The Agricultural Holdings Acts 1948 (England and Wales) and
1949 (Scotland) as amended by the Agriculture Act 1958 and the Agriculture
(Miscellaneous Provisions) Acts of 1963 and 1968 contain more detailed
provisions concerning the rights and obligations of landlords and tenants.
The Acts provide for any tenancy of agricultural land, with the exception
of certain short-term lettings to which exemption can be given by the Minister
or Secretary of State, to continue in force from year to year until terminated
by a valid notice to quit. With certain exceptions the tenant can contest it by
serving a counter-notice; the notice to quit then becomes inoperative unless
the landlord can satisfy an independent body (in England and Wales the
Agricultural Land Tribunal and in Scotland the Scottish Land Court) that
his claim for possession is in the interests of sound estate management or good
husbandry or that the land is required for certain purposes specified in the
Acts.
The Acts lay down a code of compensation to which the tenant is entitled
on termination of the tenancy. Rent is a matter for negotiation between
landlord and tenant and may be varied by agreement at any time or, failing
agreement, by arbitration at intervals of not less than three years in England
and Wales and five years in Scotland.
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 3T5
MARKETING Agricultural products are marketed mainly through private trade channels
such as corn merchants, livestock auctions and markets, and bacon factories,
or through producers’ co-operative organisations. For certain commodities,
however, marketing arrangements are influenced by boards operating under
the Agricultural Marketing Act 1958 (which consolidated earlier legislation).
These marketing boards are producers’ organisations with statutory powers
to regulate the marketing of particular products. The schemes under which
they are constituted and operate must be approved by Parliament and
confirmed by a poll of the producers. Most of the members of the boards are
elected by the producers but a minority are appointed by the minister or
ministers concerned. Further safeguards serve to protect consumers and other
interests affected by schemes and the public interest generally.
Marketing boards fall into two broad categories: first, those which are sole
buyers of the regulated product from all producers not specially exempted
or, alternatively, those exercising a comparable influence by controlling all
contracts between producers and first buyers; and, secondly, boards which
maintain only a broad control over marketing conditions, leaving producers
free otherwise to deal individually with buyers. The boards for eggs, hops,
milk and wool fall into the first category and the potato board into the second.
The egg board will be replaced by a more broadly based Eggs Authority from
April 1971 which will be restricted to support buying and more general market
matters. Northern Ireland has its own marketing boards, based on local
legislation, for milk, pigs and seed potatoes.
The Home-Grown Cereals Authority, established under the Cereals
Marketing Act 1965 to improve the marketing of home-grown cereals,
operates a scheme of bonuses and provides market intelligence. It has reserve
trading powers.
The Meat and Livestock Commission, established under the Agriculture
Act 1967, is charged with improving the production, marketing and distribu¬
tion of livestock and meat in Great Britain. It has a range of executive
functions extending from breeding to retail distribution, one of the most
important of which is to evolve a general scheme of carcase classification. It is
not empowered to trade in either livestock or meat.
Grants of up to one-third are available for the modernisation of major
wholesale horticultural markets; Covent Garden market is being moved to a
new site at Nine Elms in south London, which should be in use in the early
I97os-
National statutory grades are being introduced to improve the competitive
position of home-grown horticultural produce as against imported supplies
and to speed its transit through distributive channels. Grades have so far been
introduced for apples, pears, tomatoes, cucumbers and cauliflowers.
The Apple and Pear Development Council publicises home-grown apples
and pears to increase sales.
Market In 1962 the Government earmarked £1$ million to assist the financing of
Development research and development in the marketing of agricultural and horticultural
Scheme produce. By March 1970 grants totalling about £1-31 million had been
approved. The grant ceiling has been raised to £2 million and the scheme
extended to March 1971 to assist marketing developments other than those of
a co-operative nature.
Co-operation The Central Council for Agricultural and Horticultural Co-operation was
established under the provisions of the Agriculture Act 1967 to promote and

BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
develop co-operation in agriculture and horticulture and to administer a
scheme of grants. The Agricultural and Horticultural Co-operation Scheme
1967 incorporates and extends grants for co-operative production and
marketing of agricultural and horticultural produce.
The day-to-day work of treating animal disease is the responsibility of the
veterinary profession in private practice. The State veterinary service,
inaugurated in 1865 and covering Great Britain, deals with situations beyond
the control of the individual veterinary surgeon. Centred on London and
Edinburgh, it is able to deal promptly with outbreaks of notifiable diseases.
For many years Britain has been free from many serious animal diseases,
including rinderpest, sheep scab, glanders and rabies. Two cases of rabies in
imported dogs occurred in 1969--70 after an absence of cases for nearly 50
years. A prohibition on imports of dogs, cats and certain exotic species of
animal was imposed but was lifted for dogs and cats in September 1970. The
campaign to eradicate swine fever has been successful. A major epidemic of
foot-and-mouth disease was experienced towards the end of 1967 but was
eradicated successfully by a stringent slaughter policy supported by other
vigorous control measures; the last case of the disease occurred in June 1968.
In i960 the whole of the United Kingdom became a bovine tuberculosis at¬
tested area. The incidence of bovine tuberculosis is now very low; all cattle are
tuberculin tested at regular intervals and reactors to the test are slaughtered,
compensation being paid to the owners. The voluntary Brucellosis (Accredited
Herds) Scheme, introduced in 1967 as a first stage towards eradication of the
disease, was replaced in 1970 by an incentives scheme which offers payments
for healthy herds rather than compensation for reacting animals. Limited
eradication projects will start in specially selected areas in 1971.
The work of the service is backed by the extensive facilities of the Central
Veterinary Laboratory at Weybridge, Surrey, and those of its subsidiary
laboratory at Lasswade, near Edinburgh. In addition, there are 21 investiga¬
tion centres with well-equipped laboratories in England and Wales. These
centres perform work requiring specialist knowledge and give advice on
disease problems to private practitioners. In Scotland a similar service is
provided by the investigation centres of the three Scottish agricultural colleges.
In Northern Ireland the veterinary services are organised similarly to those
in Great Britain but are administered separately by the Northern Ireland
Government. Animal Health Control policies and the geographical situation
have kept the country free from nearly all the major epizootic diseases. A
scheme for the eradication of brucellosis was almost complete by mid 1970.
The full-time veterinary service is supplemented by the central veterinary
laboratory at Stormont, Belfast.
The plant health services, operated by the Agricultural Departments, are
responsible for statutory controls designed to limit the spread of plant pests
and diseases present in Britain and prevent the introduction of new ones from
abroad. They also issue the health certificates required by other countries to
accompany plant material imported from Britain. Voluntary certification
schemes are operated to encourage the development of healthy vigorous and
true-to-type planting stocks, particularly of crops subject to degenerative
diseases. The Plant Pathology Laboratory at Harpenden, Hertfordshire,
provides scientific and technical advice on which statutory controls and
certification schemes are based.

The problems of controlling mammalian pests and birds are studied at the
Ministry of Agriculture’s Pest Infestation Control Laboratory at Tolworth,
Surrey and its Land Pests Department at Worplesdon, Surrey; a branch
at Slough, Buckinghamshire, studies insect infestation of stored food pro¬
ducts. The laboratories provide information to and liaise closely with Regional
Pest Officers who in turn advise local authorities, farmers and others con¬
cerned with these problems.
Safeguards against the dangers which could arise from uncontrolled use of
pesticides have been devised and are operating successfully. Regulations made
under the Agriculture (Poisonous Substances) Act 1952 provide protection
for workers using the more toxic chemicals. The voluntary I esticides Safety
Precautions Scheme, operated by the Government with the support of
industry, ensures that new pesticides intended for use in agriculture, forestry
and food storage, or new methods of using existing pesticides, are not intro¬
duced until enough experimental work has been done on their possible hazards
(including contamination of food and harm to wild life) to allow the Govern¬
ment to make recommendations for their safe use. Fheie is also a voluntary
Veterinary Products Safety Precautions Scheme on similar lines although this
will be replaced and amplified by licensing and control provisions made under
the Medicines Act 1968. The purpose of the schemes is to enable users and
advisers to choose efficient proprietary brands of agricultural chemicals fur the
control of pests and diseases, the destruction of weeds, for growth regulation
and for the control of insects and mite pests of stored grain. Products approved
for safety may then be submitted through the Agricultural Chemicals
Approval Scheme for efficiency approval.
A key role in the administration of the safety schemes is played by the
Government’s Advisory Committee on Pesticides and Other Toxic Chemicals.
Reports of this Committee, published in 1964, concluded that there was no
evidence that the use of certain persistent organochlorine pesticides presented
an immediate hazard to human beings and animals, apart from certain species
of predatory birds. In 1967 the Committee recommended that the voluntary
Safety Precautions Schemes should be replaced by compulsory licensing
arrangements. In 1969 R further report recommended the withdrawal of
certain of these chemicals including DDT, aldrin and dieldrin, and the
Government is arranging the implementation of these recommendations in
co-operation with users and manufacturers.
In England and Wales free technical advice on all agricultural and horticultural
matters, other than veterinary, is available through the Ministry’s National
Agricultural Advisory Service (NAAS), which is organised on a regional basis.
Counties, or groups of counties, have a county agricultural adviser and are
divided into districts, in each of which there is a district agricultural adviser
who can call on an extensive team of specialist advisers. In Northern Ireland
advisory work is organised by the Ministry of Agriculture, with a county
organisation similar to the NAAS. In Scotland the advisory services, also
similar in scope to the NAAS, are based on the three agricultural colleges.
The Agricultural Land* Service (ALS), through its qualified land agents,
surveyors and architects, provides a service without charge to owners and
occupiers of both agricultural and horticultural land needing advice on
problems arising from the ownership of land, and investment connected with
it. The services include general advice on the design, layout and construction
318 BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
or improvement of all types of farm and horticultural buildings as well as
roads, fences, shelter belts and effluent disposal. The ALS also provides
professional advice and services to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and
Food.
A unified service to be known as the Agricultural Development and
Advisory Service will operate from March 1971 and will comprise the NAAS,
the ALS and an integrated veterinary service.
Basic agricultural research in Britain is described on p. 199. The NAAS
operates 22 farms and horticultural stations whose functions are to investigate
local and national problems, to test research findings and integrate them into
improved production systems and to communicate them to advisers and the
industry. In England and Wales, research and advice on agricultural economics
is undertaken by 12 university Departments of Agricultural Economics. Ten
of these conduct work on farm incomes and the economics of particular
products for the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (see p. 308). In
Scotland, agricultural economists are on the staff of the three agricultural
colleges. The agricultural departments in England and Wales and Scotland
have economics and statistics units.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture also has an Economics and
Statistics Division and nine other Research Divisions dealing with different
aspects of agricultural research and development and responsible for university
teaching of agriculture.
Agricultural There are four types of institution which provide full-time education
Education in agricultural subjects: universities; non-maintained agricultural colleges;
in England and Wales, county agricultural colleges and institutes; and in
Scotland, farm schools. Ten universities in Britain provide degree and post¬
graduate training in agriculture. A National College of Agricultural Engineer¬
ing was established in i960 at Silsoe, Bedfordshire, and it offers degree and
postgraduate courses in agricultural engineering. In Northern Ireland there
are three agricultural colleges and two more are planned.
A new pattern of three-year sandwich courses leading to Ordinary and
Higher National Diplomas has been introduced at the four non-maintained
agricultural colleges and at 14 of the county agricultural colleges and institutes
in England and Wales. Similar courses are provided at two of the colleges in
Northern Ireland. The older two-year courses will be phased out in a year or
two as the new pattern becomes established. The 31 county colleges and
institutes in England and the five in Wales also provide one-year residential
courses in general agriculture or horticulture with supplementary courses
covering the various specialisms in greater depth and two of them offer a new
pattern of two-year sandwich courses leading to the award of the National
Stockmans Certificate in Poultry Practice. Local education authorities also
provide short courses, block-release, day-release and other part-time classes
for farmers, farm workers and horticulturists, as well as an advisory service for
domestic producers.
An agricultural, Horticultural and Forestry Industry Training Board was
set up in 1966 under the Industrial Training Act 1964 (see p. 417). Grants are
available to employees on recognised courses in agriculture, horticulture or
forestry. Where possible the Board arranges courses through industrial or
local authority facilities but otherwise runs its own courses. Training boards
are usually financed by a levy on employers but owing to special circumstances

There are eight farm schools in Scotland, run by local education authorities,
providing courses—mainly residential—of from one to three years’ duration
for boys and girls of from 12 to 16 years. There is one residential agricultural

Courses in land management are available at the Universities of Cambridge
and London and at the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester.
FISHERIES
The sea fishing industry is of especial importance to the economy of Scotland.
In the rest of the United Kingdom it is an important source of employment in
the major fishing ports. The industry falls into three main divisions, concerned
respectively with white fish, herring and shellfish. The major element of the
catch (about 82 per cent by weight) is white fish: the catches of herring and
shellfish, although important, are relatively small. White fish are demersal fish
(such as cod, haddock, plaice, turbot and sole) which live on or near the sea
bed, and also pelagic fish (such as pilchard, mackerel and sprats) which live
mainly in intermediate waters or near the surface. Herring is a pelagic species
and constitutes a separate fishery. Shellfish include Crustacea (such as
lobsters, nephrops and crabs) and molluscs (such as escallops, mussels, cockles
and oysters).
The white fish section of the industry is made up of three main groups:
the distant water, the near and middle water, and the inshore fisheries. The
distant waters are those round Iceland and in the west Atlantic, Greenland,
Bear Island and the north coast of Norway, and the Barents Sea; the middle
water grounds lie around the Faroe Islands; and the near water grounds are
those in the North Sea, the Irish Sea and in the coastal areas around Britain.
The herring fishing grounds are almost entirely in Scottish waters. The in¬
shore waters also yield considerable quantities of shellfish.
The principal fishing ports in England and Wales are Hull, Grimsby, Fleet-
wood, North Shields, Lowestoft and Milford Haven. In Scotland the chief
centres for white fish are Aberdeen, Granton, Fraserburgh, the Moray Firth,
the west coast and Shetland Islands; herring landings are made mainly at the
east coast port of Fraserburgh, the west coast ports of Ullapool, Mallaig,
Oban and Ayr and in the Shetland Islands. In Northern Ireland the main
fishing ports are Ardglass, Portavogie and Kilkeel.
The chief methods of catching fish are by trawling, seining, lining and ring
netting. Trawling is carried out throughout the year in the distant and near
waters for all species of demersal fish. Seining is also used for catching
demersal fish all the year round, mainly in the North Sea, the Minches, the
Firth of Clyde and the Irish Sea. There are about 550 Scottish and Northern
Ireland seiners, and about 170 operating from English ports.
The pelagic fisheries are seasonal. There is summer fishing for herring
based on the Shetlands, the east coast ports of Scotland and the north-east
coast ports of England. Other seasonal fisheries take place off the west coast
of Scotland, in the Isle of Man area and off southern Ireland.
The inshore fisheries comprise a great diversity of types of vessels and
methods of capture; in addition, there are extensive fisheries for crabs,
L*
3 20
The Fishing
Fleet
Supplies
Sea Fish
Processing
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
lobsters, shrimps, mussels, escallops, cockles and oysters, and, off Scotland,
north-east England and in the Irish Sea there are valuable catches of nephrops
(‘Norway lobsters’ or Dublin Bay prawns).
Distant water vessels, which operate mainly from Hull, Grimsby and Fleet-
wood, numbered 161 at the end of 1969. They are over 140 feet (42-5 metres)
in length and most of them make voyages of 17 to 23 days to fishing grounds
in the Arctic Circle. Partly due to the introduction of freezer trawlers and
factory vessels, there has also been fishing in the waters bordering Newfound¬
land, Labrador and Greenland. These vessels spend from one to three months
at sea and freeze, in some cases as fillets, much or all of their catch immediately
it is taken. At the same date, near and middle water vessels numbered 374; they
are between 80 and 140 feet (24-5 and 42-5 metres) long and most of them work
nearer home, making voyages of from a few days up to more than two weeks,
although some of the larger vessels fish regularly off the Faroes and seasonally
as far afield as Iceland. Included in the near water group are vessels engaged
in fishing for herring which normally make daily landings. The inshore group
consists of vessels of under 80 feet (24-5 metres) which, except for seiners, are
seldom at sea for longer than two or three days and more usually make daily
landings, often fishing within sight of land.
In the British fishing industry in 1969 there were about 18,000 fishermen
in regular employment and some 4,000 occasionally employed; about two-
fifths of the former and one-third of the latter were from Scottish ports. In
Northern Ireland there are about 500 regular fishermen.
In 1969 landings of all types of fish by British fishing vessels totalled 939,000
tons (716,000 tons of demersal fish, 173,000 tons of pelagic and 50,000 tons
of shellfish), valued at about £66 million. Imports totalled about 113,000 tons
of fresh and frozen fish (including 54,000 tons brought direct from the fishing
grounds), valued at about £22 million. Cod accounted for 46 per cent of the
total value of demersal and pelagic fish landed by British vessels; haddock
(19 per cent) and plaice (9 per cent) were the other most important sources of
earnings to the industry.
Imports of all types of fish (fresh, frozen, salted, canned or otherwise
preserved) in 1969 amounted to about 195,000 tons valued at £70 million,
including 30,000 tons of canned salmon to the value of £25 million and other
canned fish worth £13 million.
Weekly disposals of fresh, frozen and cured fish (excluding shellfish and
imported canned fish) in Britain averaged about 16,000 tons landed weight
in 1969. Consumption has been declining slightly, on an edible (fillet) weight
basis; it was ib'i lb. (7*3 kg.) per head in 1969 (see Table 21) in comparison
with a peak total of 28-7 lb. (13 kg.) in 1948.
Processing and packaging of fish—curing, kippering, canning and quick-
freezing for consumer packs—are the subject of continuing research and
development. The growth of quick-frozen fish production has altered radically
the structure of the industry. With the increase in quick-freezing (which now
processes about a quarter of all white fish landings), new export outlets have
opened up for white fish, which in 1969 accounted for about half the total
exports of fish and fish preparations, valued at £14-1 million. Exports of most
forms of fish increased in 1969.
A valuable by-product of the industry is the manufacture of fish meal for

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 321
animal food and, to a much lesser extent, for fertilisers. Home production of
white fish meal and herring meal in 1969 was 85,000 tons.
The most valuable freshwater fish are salmon and sea-trout, being worth far
more when caught by rod and line than similar fish netted at sea. Drift netting
for salmon is prohibited off the coast of Scotland and is strictly controlled
around England, Wales and Northern Ireland to protect the valuable sport
fisheries in the game rivers. A limited amount of estuary and river netting
for salmon is permitted under licence by river authorities. In England and
Wales the landed value of the salmon catch is approximately £275,000 a year,
in Scotland it amounts to over £1-5 million, and in Northern Ireland to some
£200,000. In Northern Ireland, eels worth about £300,000 a year are captured
by long lines and by eel nets placed in river weirs.
The principal inland wholesale distributing centre for fish is Billingsgate
Market in London, which handles about 300 tons a day, but other large cities
also have central fish markets. The principal method of distribution is through
wholesalers, located at the ports, who buy at the auctions and sell to inland
wholesalers; the port wholesalers prepare the fish for onward shipment. Fish
lorries, including insulated and refrigerated vehicles, transport the catch daily
from the ports to inland centres, although rail transport is still used from some
ports. Retail sales are handled by some 18,000 to 22,000 fishmongers and fish
friers; the latter use about a third of the landings of white fish.
Trawler-owning companies have entered into the marketing and distribu¬
tive system. This process has been encouraged by the growing popularity of
quick-frozen consumer packs, which are sold by other retail outlets, such as
grocers, as well as by fishmongers.
The government departments mainly responsible for the administration of
legislation concerning the fishing industry are the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food, the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland
and the Ministry of Agriculture for Northern Ireland. The safety and welfare
of crews of fishing vessels are provided for under the Merchant Shipping Acts
administered by the Board of Trade, under whose aegis a committee of
enquiry into deep-sea trawler safety reported in 1969. This led to amendment
of the Acts and other legislative provision for additional safety measures.
The Herring Industry Board was set up under the Herring Industry Act
1935 now consolidated in the Sea Fish Industry Act 1970 to reorganise,
develop and regulate the herring industry. The Board consists of a chairman
and three other members, all part-time and independent of the industry, who
are appointed jointly by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, the
Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and the Home Secretary. The
Board, whose activities are financed partly by levies and licence fees and
partly by government grants and loans, is advised by the Herring Industry
Advisory Council, consisting of 32 members representing all sections of the
industry and consumers.
The functions of the Board include the promotion of sales of herring, both
at home and abroad, and the application of the benefits of technical progress
to the industry, including the adoption of new methods of catching, processing
and distributing herring. The Board administers the government grant and
loan schemes which provide for assistance towards the purchase of new fishing
vessels, and the improvement of existing vessels. Fishermen may also obtain

loans from the Board towards the purchase of second-hand vessels under
80 feet in length and towards the cost of new nets and gear. Up to 31st March
1970 £2,167,443 in loans and £1,861,421 in grants had been advanced.
The White Fish Authority and the Committee for Scotland and Northern
Ireland of the Authority were set up in 1951 under legislation now con¬
solidated in the Sea Fish Industry Act 1970. The function of the Authority is
to reorganise, develop and regulate the white fish industry, and that of the
Committee to advise the Authority about the exercise and performance of its
functions in Scotland and Northern Ireland. The Authority is composed of a
chairman and six members, and the Scottish Committee of five members and
a chairman who is a member of the Authority. They are appointed jointly by
the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, the Secretary of State for
Scotland, the Home Secretary and (in the case of the Authority) the Secretary
of State for Wales. The White Fish Industry Advisory Council was also set up
under the 1951 Act to advise the Authority about the exercise and performance
of its functions. It normally consists of 53 members representing the various
interests of the fishing industry.
The White Fish Authority administers government grant and loan schemes
for the purchase of new fishing vessels and engines and the improvement of
existing vessels. It also administers loans for the purchase of nets and gear and
processing plants. Up to 31st March i97°> j£35 ntiHi011 in l°ans and £27
million in grants were approved for these purposes by the Authority. Its
other activities are financed by levies on first-hand sales of most white fish, and
a government grant towards research and development.
Subsidies are paid to the inshore fishing industry under the provisions of the
Sea Fish Industry Act 1970 at the rate of so much per day at sea according
to the length of the vessel or at so much per stone (6-35 kg.) of fish landed,
which varies according to the kind of fish, from certain vessels under 60 feet
(18-5 metres) in length. No subsidy is paid for shellfish. Subsidies for white
fish cost £1*2 million in 1969-70 and those for herring £240,000.
The White Fish Subsidy (Deep Sea Vessels) (United Kingdom) Scheme
1969 came into operation on 1st April 1968 for a period of three years.
Subsidies payable up to 31st July 1971 are set at a basic £2 million a year and
will be adjusted by reference to the level of profitability of the industry, subject
to a maximum total of £4 million. Payment will be related to the operating
efficiency of vessels and not to their classification. T he new arrangements
replace the previous policy of progressively decreasing operating subsidies to
deep-sea vessels.
Subsidies cost £1-67 million for the six months ending 31st January 1969
and £1-94 million for 1969-70.
FORESTRY
The estimated total area of productive woodland in Great Britain is 3'2^
million acres (1*33 million hectares), or about 6 per cent of the total land area.
If account is taken of areas of scrub and old felled areas, including those cut
down in the second world war, the total rises to 4-35 million acres (176 million
hectares), or 775 per cent of the land area; about half of the area is in England,
two-fifths in Scotland, the remainder in Wales. The high proportion of un¬
productive woodland is largely a legacy of two wars and, while rehabilitation
of these areas continues to proceed, it is unlikely that all areas (for instance,
323
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY
because of remoteness and poor site conditions) will be replanted. A measure
of the extent of rehabilitation is provided by the fact that the area of un¬
productive woodland has been reduced by 300,000 acres (121,000 hectares)
since 1945.
The area of productive forest managed by the Forestry Commission, at
i-8 million acres (073 million hectares) represents something over 50 per cent
of the total. The annual rate of productive forest expansion is currently about
55,000 acres (22,000 hectares) by the Commission mainly in Scotland, and
about 35,000 acres (14,200 hectares) by private woodland owners. The Com¬
mission’s programme includes considerable planting in upland areas, and
consists mainly of conifers because of the difficult site conditions encountered
and because over 90 per cent of industrial demand is for softwoods. The major
species used are Sitka spruce, Lodgepole pine, Scots pine and Norway spruce.
In the older woodlands and taking the country as a whole, the most common
coniferous trees are Scots pine, Sitka spruce, Norway spruce and the larches,
while, among the broadleaved, beech and oak occur widely.
Except for the period of the two world wars, when much over-felling took
place, home woodlands have until recent years made only a limited contribu¬
tion to the nation’s total requirements of wood and wood products. Some
25 per cent of the Commissioner’s woodlands are now in production. Britain
imports 90 per cent of its needs by volume and a higher proportion still by
value, the total import cost of wood and wood products including pulp and
paper being over £650 million in 1969, of which ^217 million was accounted
for by timber imports.
The Forestry Acts 1919 to 1945 established the Forestry Commission as the
national forestry authority charged with promoting the interests of forestry,
the development of afforestation and the production and supply of timber in
Great Britain (the Forestry Acts 1919 to 1963 were consolidated in the
Forestry Act 1967). As more and more of its coniferous woods reach the
production stage the Commission has assumed an increasingly important role
as a timber seller and has encouraged the setting up of some 20 new timber¬
using industries in the past 12 years. The Commission consists of a part-time
chairman, a full-time director general, three full-time executive commis¬
sioners and five part-time commissioners. The Commissioners comply with
directions given by the forestry ministers, who are the Minister of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food and the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales.
Northern Ireland has its own separate organisation (see p. 325).
The Commission’s total estate covers some 2-9 million acres (1-2 million
hectares) and includes 2-n million acres (0-85 million hectares) of forest land,
of which about i-8 million (073 million hectares) are under trees in 380
forests distributed throughout England, Scotland and Wales. All these forests
are covered by management plans, which provide for such work as planting,
road construction, thinning, fire protection and timber production, facilities
for public recreation, wild life conservation and the landscaping of plantations.
As already stated, a substantial amount of the Forestry Commission’s new
planting is carried out in Scotland, much of it in the Highland counties. The
poorer types of land are being used, such as sour, peaty soil which is unsuitable
for agricultural purposes, but has become suitable for forestry as a result of
advances in the technique of deep ploughing.
Production of coniferous timber from Commission woodlands, mainly by
way of thinnings, is expected to rise from about 1*3 million tons in 1969 to
about 2*2 million tons by 1980 and to 4 million tons by 1990. Some of this kind
324

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
of produce is meeting traditional requirements of the coal mines but much is
taken by the paper pulp industry and by factories established to make chip¬
board, fibreboard and wood wool.
The Forestry Fund was constituted under the 1919 Forestry Act; from it is
paid all the expenditure of the Forestry Commissioners and into it are paid
amounts voted annually by Parliament, together with the Commission’s
receipts from sales of produce, rentals and other sources. In the period 1st
October 1967-31st March 1969 (future statistics will be published each fiscal
year) drawings from funds voted by Parliament amounted to ^227 million,
and receipts were £9 million.
Privately owned woods comprise nearly two-thirds of the total forest area in
Great Britain and contain most of the mature and semi-mature timber. The
size of woodlands in individual ownership ranges from a few acres to several
thousand acres, and a high proportion of the private woodland area is in small
ownership—that is, owners of up to about 250 acres (100 hectares).
Impetus was given to the effective management of private woodlands by
the introduction of the Dedication of Woodlands Scheme, initiated in 1947.
Under this scheme, owners are invited to put their land permanently to
timber production and to manage their woods in accordance with a plan
agreed with the Forestry Commission, in return for the provision of planting
and management grants and technical advice. By March 1969 the total area
dedicated was 955,000 acres (386,000 hectares). In addition, there are wood¬
lands covered by the Approved Woodlands Scheme and the Small Woods
Scheme under which a planting grant, but no management grant, is paid.
More than 1 million acres (400,000 hectares) are managed under the first two
schemes. Woodland owners are represented, in their relations with the
Forestry Commission, by the Forestry Committee of Great Britain, which
co-ordinates the work of two associations of woodland owners: the Timber
Growers’ Organisation (for owners in England and Wales) and the Scottish
Woodland Owners’ Association.
There are a number of forestry co-operative societies providing for land-
owners and farmers the services of skilled staff, centralised purchasing facilities,
and a central agency for the disposal of forest produce. The Forestry Com¬
mission also co-operates with the principal forestry societies, such as the
Royal Forestry Society of England and Wales and the Royal Scottish Forestry
Society, in disseminating technical knowledge.
In 1959 the Home Grown Timber Marketing Corporation was established
by timber merchants to promote the use of home grown timber.
Under the Forestry Act 1967 the Commissioners maintain national com¬
mittees for England, Scotland and Wales, composed partly of Forestry
Commissioners and partly of persons outside the Commission. These
committees act in an advisory capacity, particularly as to the social, recreational
and amenity aspects of the Commissioners’ activities and relationships with
other land users. The Commissioners also maintain a regional advisory
committee for each Conservancy.
Other bodies have been set up to provide for consultation on the marketing
and utilisation of home grown timber. The Home Grown Timber Advisory
Committee (HGTAC) is a statutory body and includes representatives of
associations of landowners, timber merchants and processors and the trade

unions under an independent chairman. In 1949 the Forestry Commissioners
set up the Advisory Committee on Utilisation of Home Grown Timber (now
a sub-committee of the HGTAC) to advise on measures designed to promote
utilisation of produce from British woodlands.
A voluntary scheme was agreed upon in 1961 for consultation on proposals
for afforestation of land within National Parks (see p. 175). The Timber
Growers’ Organisation and the Country Landowners Association undei took
to advise their members to notify the park planning authorities about their
planting proposals.
The Forestry Commission maintains two forester training schools: in
England, at Parkend in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire; and in Scotland
at Faskally, near Pitlochry in Perthshire. Both will be closed by 1972 as the
responsibility for forester training is being assumed by the Department of
Education and Science. Northerwood House in the New Forest, Hampshire, is
the Commission’s educational centre, and is used for practical courses for
Commission staff and for university students, landowners and agents, planning
officers, school teachers and others.
An Agricultural, Horticultural and Forestry Industry Training Board and a
Furniture and Timber Industry Training Board have been set up to provide
for training in forestry for employees of private woodland owners and in the
home-grown timber trade.
Higher education in forestry is provided at several universities; a propor¬
tion of graduates is recruited by the Commission as forest officers.
The Commission’s Forest Research Station at Alice Holt Lodge, near
Farnham, Surrey, was opened in 1946. Expenditure on research work at this
station, at the Northern Research Station and in experimental areas in many
forests in Great Britain amounted to ^x-2 million in 1967-69. This sum
included grants for special forestry research work to various institutions and
to university departments including the Commonwealth Forestry Institute at
Oxford, which is also financed by the university, the Foreign and Common¬
wealth Office and overseas governments. A Northern Research Station was
opened at the Bush Estate near Edinburgh in May 1970. Research into tne
qualities of home-grown timber is carried out by the Forest Products Research
Laboratory at Princes Risborough, Bucks, and also by grant-aided research
associations.
When the Government of Northern Ireland was formed in 1922, the new
Ministry of Agriculture became the forest authority working with similar
powers and duties to those conferred on the Forestry Commission by the
Forestry Act 1919. At that time the Ministry took over some 4,000 acres
(1,625 hectares) for afforestation, of which 700 acres (285 hectares) had been
^ Forest policy is carried out under the authority of the Forestry Act
(Northern Ireland) 1953, which replaced earlier legislation. This Act provides
the Ministry with powers to acquire and manage land, and to give financial
and technical assistance for private planting. It introduced measures for the
protection of all woodlands, whether owned by the State or privately owned,
against destruction by over-cutting, fire or depredation by animals.
The State forest area has grown steadily and at a greatly accelerated pace
since the end of the second world war. By 1970 over 150,000 acres (60,750
hectares) had been acquired, of which about 99,000 acres (40,100 hectares)
had been planted. The present afforestation programme provides for the
326
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
creation, as soon as possible, of an area of 150,000 acres (61,000 hectares) of
productive forest.
Financial provision is made by sums voted annually by Parliament and
from receipts from forest produce and other sources. About 1,000 people are
employed in field labour and ancillary work. The area of exploitable private
woodlands is at present about 35,000 acres (14,200 hectares), and private
planting, which is gaining impetus, is assisted by schemes for the supply of
young trees from the Ministry’s nurseries at a low cost, by grants towards the
cost of the establishment of new plantations, and by free technical advice.
Pomeroy Forestry School at Pomeroy House, Co. Tyrone, provides training
and refresher courses for forestry workers, school teachers and others inter¬
ested in trees and forestry.
The public may visit almost all the forests, five of which have been
designated Forest Parks, and use the amenities provided.
13 TRANSPORT AND
COMMUNICATIONS
Technical
Trends
Inland and overseas transport and communications employed 6-8 per cent
of the total labour force in Great Britain in June 1969. Of the 1-5 million
persons so occupied, 32 per cent were engaged in road passenger transport
and road haulage contracting, 17 per cent in railways and 29 per cent in
postal services and telecommunications; sea and air transport absorbed
respectively 5 per cent and 4 per cent; port and inland water transport and
miscellaneous transport services and storage absorbed 13 per cent. Transport
and communications contribute about 9 per cent of the gross national
product and are responsible for a rather higher proportion of the nation’s
gross fixed capital formation.
SHIPPING
Of the world’s active sea-going tonnage of 100 gross tons1 and over nearly
12 per cent is registered in Britain, making the British merchant fleet one of
the largest in active employment. The British shipping industry is, however,
exposed to severe international competition. The position has been made
more difficult by the prevalence among competitors of such practices as flag
discrimination and the use of ‘flags of convenience’. While from 1959 to 1969
Britain’s merchant fleet increased by 15 per cent from 20*8 million to 23-8
million gross tons, the total tonnage of all other countries, excluding the
US Reserve Fleet, increased by over 100 per cent, from 90 million to 181
million gross tons. After being positive until about 1959 the balance of pay¬
ments for shipping services remained adverse until 1965, but showed an
estimated surplus of £31 million in 1969.
In a variety of ways technological change has been proceeding more rapidly
under current conditions. Vessels are becoming obsolete over a shorter period
and as they do so are being replaced by larger ships, with generally lower
building costs per ton; labour-saving devices, greater speeds and faster turn-
round facilities are reducing operating costs. The tendency to greater average
size has been the most marked in tankers and dry bulk cargo ships. Vessels are
specially built to carry ore, cement, wine and various kinds of chemicals.
Many ships have been designed to carry fully loaded road vehicles, pallets
and containers. In particular the use of containers on long door-to-door
journeys can result in speedier, safer and cheaper carriage of a wide range of
goods. Two consortia of British shipping companies are operating specially
designed deep-sea cellular container ships on services to Australia, and
another company is operating a similar service to Canada.
1 One gross ton (g.t.) = 100 cubic feet. One deadweight ton (d.w.t.) = x long ton
(2,240 lb.). Gross tonnage indicates the total capacity of the enclosed spaces on a ship.
Deadweight tonnage denotes the maximum load which a vessel can carry before
submerging the load-line.

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Of the 23-8 million gross tons of merchant shipping of 100 gross tons and
over registered, but not all owned, in the United Kingdom on 30th June 1969
tankers accounted for 10-2 million gross tons and 13 per cent of the world’s
sea-going tonnage.
Britain’s merchant fleet has been increasing rapidly in response to new
methods of handling goods. Gross tonnage of ships delivered to British
owners in 1969 is estimated at 2-4 million, about a quarter of which was
built in British yards. Over half of the fleet is diesel driven.
The Queen Elizabeth 2 (66,000 g.t.), the most advanced and one of the
largest passenger liners ever built, designed for the transatlantic route and for
cruising, went into service in 1969.
In June 1969, 19-4 million gross tons of trading vessels of 100 gross tons and
over (of an average age of 8-7 years) were both owned and registered in
Britain.1 The usual employment of this fleet has been analysed by the United
Kingdom Chamber of Shipping as follows: 6-5 million gross tons were
employed as foreign-going passenger and cargo liners; 3*9 million gross tons
as foreign-going tramps; 8-2 million gross tons as foreign-going tankers;
and o-8 million gross tons in coasting and trade with ports between the Elbe
and Brest (home trades).
About one-third of British-owned shipping registered in the United Kingdom
consists of foreign-going passenger-cargo and cargo liners, mostly the latter.
Practically all these ships are owned by large liner companies. Many operate
wide networks of scheduled cargo and passenger services which, between
them, cover every ocean. The 3-9 million gross tons of foreign-going tramp
ships are operated by a large number of private owners, some having only a
small number of ships and some only one ship.
Examples of major British liner shipping companies operating scheduled
services from the United Kingdom are: the Cunard, to North America; the
Royal Mail, to South America; the Blue Funnel, to Australia and the Far
East; the Peninsular and Oriental (P. & O.) and the British India lines, to
India, Australia and the Far East; the Union Castle, to South and East Africa;
Elder Dempster, to West Africa; Furness Withy, to North America and the
West Indies; the New Zealand line, to Australia and New Zealand; and Shaw
Savill and Albion, to Australia and New Zealand. These and the other major
liner companies have for the most part amalgamated to form a small number
of major groups, of which the largest and best known are the P. & O., the
Furness Withy, the Ocean S.S., and the British and Commonwealth groups.
Over two-thirds of the total tanker fleet belong to the oil companies,
although there are a few important independent United Kingdom tanker¬
owning companies.
A government guaranteed loan scheme to benefit British shipowners
ordering from British shipyards was introduced in 1967.
The main organisations concerned with the activities, interests and common
problems of the industry are as follows:

Lloyd’s Register is an organisation (distinct from the Society of Lloyd’s, see
p. 378) which surveys and classifies ships with particular regard to their
safety and operational efficiency. It will accept responsibility for surveying
and giving technical advice on vessels of all flags from the initial stages of
building, at regular intervals during their service, and after casualties. A
satisfactory Lloyd’s classification is a guarantee to an underwriter that he
may accept the risk of a vessel, and this forms a strong link between the
Register and the Society of Lloyd’s.
The representative body speaking for shipowners generally (excluding, for
the most part, owners of fishing vessels) is the Chamber of Shipping. There
are a number of local associations of shipowners centred around the main port
areas. Other organisations represent companies specialising in a particular
trade or type of cargo.
The British Shippers’ Council, formed in 1955, represents the shipping
interests of exporters and importers in matters of both national and inter¬
national concern.
The British Shipping Federation Limited is the employers’ organisation
concerned with labour relations and the regulation of employment throughout
the Merchant Navy. It is responsible for the administration of the Merchant
Navy Established Service Scheme, under which shipowners engaging crews
for ships of 200 gross tons and above engage them through the Merchant Navy
Establishment Administration unless they are prepared to offer two-year
company service contracts.
The National Maritime Board is composed of equal numbers of representa¬
tives of the shipowners and seafarers’ unions and is responsible for all negotia¬
tions of wages and conditions of service in the Merchant Navy.
British shipping companies operating liners have associated with each other
and with the companies of other countries operating on the same routes in a
series of ‘conferences’ designed to secure standardisation and stability of rates,
and to maintain frequency and regularity of services. The essential principle
of a conference is the establishment of a common tariff of freight rates or
passenger fares from each port of departure. Each conference meets from
time to time to review and revise existing rates, or to compile new ones. Some
of the conferences are connected by rate agreements, or have joined together
to form wider groupings. There are over 60 conferences dealing with trade to
and from the United Kingdom.
The Baltic Mercantile and Shipping Exchange, which originated in one of
London’s seventeenth-century coffee houses, is the world’s largest market
for the chartering of ships of all nationalities. Shipbrokers and merchants’
representatives meet here to arrange the chartering of dry-cargo tramp ships
for the carriage of goods to and from all parts of the world.
RELATIONS
WITH THE
GOVERNMENT
The Board of Trade is the government department responsible for most
matters connected with merchant shipping. Under the Merchant Shipping
Acts, it administers many regulations for marine safety and welfare, for
instance: certifying the load-line (or Plimsoll line) that shows that a ship is
not overloaded; ensuring that standards of safety are observed in ship con¬
struction; ensuring the provision of adequate life-saving, fire-fighting and
radio equipment; and dealing with the discipline, professional standards,
33°
Pollution of
the Sea
Traffic
Control
BRITAIN I97U AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
health and accommodation of seamen. Most of the work which these re¬
sponsibilities entail is carried out by the officers of the Marine Survey and
Mercantile Marine at the ports. There is also a Registrar-General of Shipping
and Seamen, in whose office at Cardiff a complete record of all British ships
and seamen is kept. Abroad, certain parts of the Merchant Shipping Acts
are administered by H.M. Consuls and by officers of Commonwealth
Governments.
Much of the law relating to shipping has recently been revised under the
Merchant Shipping Act 1970; in particular some disciplinary provisions have
been relaxed and arrangements for welfare and safety improved.
A committee of enquiry reported in May 1970 in favour of the establish¬
ment of a Ship Research and Development Institute, an Industrial Training
Board for Shipping, and a Statutory Marine Authority for safety control,
a code of practice for shipping conferences, and an international treaty on
shipping practices.
The discharge of oil into British territorial waters was first restricted in 1922.
Britain is a party to the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of
the Pollution of the Sea by Oil which came into force in 1958. The nations
ratifying this convention (now numbering over 40) agree to prohibit their
national fleets from discharging persistent oil within a certain distance of
any coast—originally 50 miles (80 kilometres) but under amendments in
1962 extended in many areas to 100 miles (160 kilometres) or more—and also
in extensive areas of the north-east Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean, the
whole of the North Sea, and around Australia. The provisions were given
legal effect for British ships under the Oil in Navigable Waters Act 1955
which also prohibits the discharge of any kind of oil from British and foreign
vessels into British territorial waters. Amendments to the 1954 Convention
were agreed in 1962 and came into force on 18th May 1967; the Oil in Navi¬
gable Waters Act 1963, applying the amendments to British ships, became
effective on the same date. The Convention as amended prohibits ships of
20,000 gross tons and over, built after 18th May 1967, from discharging
persistent oil anywhere at sea. Amendments accepted in 1969 will extend
the prohibition; a new Oil in Navigable Waters Bill is before Parliament. In
1969 Britain signed the International Convention Relating to Intervention
on the High Seas in Cases of Oil Pollution Casualties, enabling a state to
take action on the high seas to prevent pollution of its coastline by oil from
a damaged tanker, and the International Convention on Civil Liability for
Oil Pollution Damage, facilitating the obtaining of compensation for damage
by oil pollution.
Over 300,000 vessels pass through the Dover Strait every year. Recommended
one-way routes were marked in 1967 by navigational aids provided by the
French and British lighthouse authorities—a scheme worked out by the joint
Institutes of Navigation of France, the Federal Republic of Germany and
Britain and agreed by the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative
Organisation, a United Nations agency with headquarters in London.
Additional traffic-separation schemes in areas around British and other coasts
have since been adopted, and others are under consideration.
Lighthouses, The Board of Trade administers the Coastguard Service. This is primarily a
Pilotage and life-saving organisation which keeps watch at danger points around the coast
Rescue for vessels in distress and renders assistance either by coastguard rescue

equipment or by informing other authorities who may be able to give help.
There are some 550 regular coastguards and about 7,000 part-time auxiliary
coastguards. During the year ended 31st March 1970 life-saving action was
taken on 2,592 occasions. There is close liaison between the Coastguard
Service and the Royal National Life-boat Institution. I he latter maintains
lifeboats and fast inshore rescue boats around the coast of the United King¬
dom; it is supported entirely by voluntary contributions, and depends
largely for its operation on voluntary workers. From its foundation in 1824
to the end of 1969 the Royal National Life-boat Institution saved 91,733
lives. Lifeboats and inshore rescue boats were launched 2,373 times in 1969
and rescued 1,035 people.
The general lighthouse authority for England and Wales, the Channel
Islands and Gibraltar is the Corporation of Trinity House, which received
its first Royal Charter in the sixteenth century and is administered by a
Board of ten Elder Brethren, elected from the Royal Navy and the Merchant
Navy. Lighthouses in Scotland and Ireland are the responsibility respectively
of the Commissioners of Northern Lighthouses and the Commissioners of
Irish Lights. These authorities control over 190 lighthouses, many minor
lights and buoys, and a number of lightships, some of which are being replaced
by unattended sea marks or by light towers.
Trinity House is the chief pilotage authority, licensing some 700 pilots in
41 districts in England and Wales, including London, Southampton and
Milford Haven. In some cases the harbour authority or local council is the
pilotage authority. In Britain there are 48 pilotage authorities for the 92
pilotage districts and over 1,600 licensed pilots. The Board of Trade also has
certain responsibilities in connection with lighthouses and pilotage.
About 85,000 United Kingdom personnel and a considerably smaller number
of others are employed by the merchant fleet.
The Board of Trade holds examinations for, and issues certificates of com¬
petency to, ships’ officers as master, first mate and second mate of foreign-
going ships, or master and mate of home trade ships and as first-class engineer
and second-class engineer. Officers may not normally serve on board ships in
these grades unless they hold the appropriate, or a higher, certificate.
Radio officers are required to hold certificates of competency in radio¬
telegraphy issued by the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications on the
results of an open examination.
A seaman may not be rated as A.B. (Able Seaman) in United Kingdom
registered ships unless he bolds a certificate of competency as A.B. granted
by the Board of Trade, or an equivalent certificate. To obtain this certificate
a seaman must, among other qualifications, have served three years at sea on
deck, have obtained a certificate of efficiency as lifeboatman and have passed
a qualifying examination.
Seamen qualify by seniority for promotion to the rating of petty officer.
Service as a deck rating qualifies for the purpose of admission to the examina¬
tion for a second mate’s certificate.
The Merchant Navy Training Board promotes the instruction and studies
of apprentices, cadets and ratings who are preparing for their examinations
for the various certificates of competency.
Wages and conditions of employment are negotiated by the National Maritime
Board. Minimum wages and holidays with pay are guaranteed for both

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
officers and ratings. Moreover, the Merchant Navy Established Service
Scheme, introduced by the Board in 1947, has removed a great deal of the
uncertainty formerly associated with a seafaring life. Officers and men can
now take two-year contracts, not only with individual shipping companies but
with the industry as a whole, and get special benefits between voyages in

There are over 300 sea ports in Britain. In 1969, 183 million tons of imports,
including 112 million tons of petroleum and petroleum products, passed
through the ports and 43 million tons of exports and re-exports, including
5 million tons of coal. Coastal traffic amounted to 107 million tons, princi¬
pally petroleum and coal.
As a result both of the anticipated increase in the country’s trade and of
technological changes affecting sea-going traffic (such as the shift to larger
tankers and bulk carriers implying a need for more deep-water berths,
demand for the development of mechanical handling methods, packaging of
general cargo in standard sizes and container and ‘roll-on, roll-off’ services)
large-scale modernisation of the ports system became necessary. Conse¬
quently capital investment in ports has risen from about £18 million a year
in the early 1960s to some £50 million in 1970.
The Port of London, with 92 miles (147 kilometres) of waterway and about
4,800 acres (1,920 hectares) of dock estate, including 29 miles (47 kilometres)
of quayage, is the largest port in the Commonwealth and, with New York
and Rotterdam, is one of the three largest ports in the world. The Port of
London Authority operates three main groups of docks. Two groups of
older up-river docks were closed in 1968 and 1970 respectively, and facilities
down-river, notably at Tilbury, are being extensively developed. About
58 million tons of cargo were handled in 1969. Among the chief commodities
handled are petroleum, coal, timber and grain. Other imports include textile
fibres, scrap, sugar and meat. Vehicles, machinery and foodstuffs pre¬
dominate among exports.
Liverpool is one of Britain’s largest ports. It handles a large proportion of
Britain’s exports to the Far East. There are extensive facilities for dealing
with imports of grain, sugar, wool and other specialist cargoes. In 1969 over
26 million tons of cargo passed through the port.
Southampton, Britain’s major ocean passenger port, has a growing cargo
trade; in 1969 it handled over 28 million tons, including petroleum, fruit and
vegetables, cereals, timber and manufactured goods.
Other major ports are Hull and Immingham on the Plumber, the port of
Clyde (or Clydeport) which includes the docks at Glasgow and at Greenock
(now an expanding container port), Manchester (an inland port reached
from the Mersey via the Manchester Ship Canal), Bristol on the Bristol
Channel, and Swansea and Newport in South Wales. Other estuaries impor¬
tant for shipping are the Firth of Forth on the east coast of Scotland (Grange¬
mouth and Leith), the Tyne (Newcastle), the Tees (Middlesbrough and the
flartlepools), and the Stour and Orwell on the East Anglian coast (Harwich,
Felixstowe and Ipswich). Among the smaller ports which are growing rapidly
are Grangemouth, and Shoreham on the south coast. The major oil import¬
ing centres are I^ondon, the Medway, Milford Haven, Southampton, Liver¬
pool, Manchester, and Finnart on the Clyde; Port Talbot and Newport in
South Wales, the Tees, the port of Clyde and Liverpool are the main ore
handling ports; London, Liverpool, Bristol and Hull are among the chief

grain importers; and London, Hull, Liverpool and Garston are the main
timber ports. Dover is Britain’s most important port for short-sea voyage
passengers, and Southampton for travellers by ocean liner; Grimsby, Hull
and Aberdeen are the largest fishing ports.
A development scheme costing over ^30 million has been carried out at
Tilbury, London. In addition to a grain terminal, freightliner terminal, and
a riverside impounding station, a dock extension project, finished in 1969,
has provided 13 new deep-water berths, six of them for container traffic and
is already handling 100,000 containers a year. Another major scheme, costing
over £33 million and including deep-sea container berths, is under construc¬
tion at Seaforth, Liverpool. A ^3-5 million grain terminal is also to be built
at Liverpool. Southampton’s container facilities are being extended at a cost
of some £11 million (400,000 containers should be handled in a year by the
end of 1973)* Container facilities have also been provided at Harwich,
Greenock (port of Clyde), Felixstowe, Manchester, Newport and Grange¬
