part of an jT 11-5 million development catering also for iron ore imports. A
£20 million deep-water harbour completed at Port Talbot serves as an ore
terminal for the British Steel Corporation.
The Minister of Transport makes grants of 20 per cent of approved capital
expenditure to statutory and other harbour authorities and persons carrying
out harbour operations.
Central control by the Government over the ports’ capital expenditure
was imposed for the first time under the Harbours Act 1964, which also
provided for the establishment of a National Ports Council to advise the
Minister of Transport on development.
From 1948, ports handling about a fifth of the national sea-borne trade have
been government owned; the British Transport Docks Board (see p. 335)
owns the majority of such ports, which include Southampton, Hull, Imming¬
ham, Newport, Cardiff and Swansea. In 1969 shipping arrivals and de¬
partures at BTDB docks totalled over 108 million net registered tons
(including fishing vessels), and the total cargo handled was about 79 million
tons.
Certain ports and docks used largely in conjunction with railway services
are administered by the British Railways Board: examples are Folkestone,
Heysham, Stranraer and Parkeston Quay (at Harwich). Other ports are
controlled by public trusts on which are represented users of the port, by
local authorities and other interested bodies or by companies. Several new
estuarial authorities have been set up by means of harbour reorganisation
schemes under the 1964 Harbours Act.
About 105,000 people are employed in the operation of ports in the United
Kingdom. At the end of 1969 there were 49,000 dock workers registered with
the National Dock Labour Board, concerned primarily with loading and
unloading cargo. The remainder included administrative, clerical and
technical staff, and pilots, lightermen and customs officials.
Because arrivals and departures of ships are liable to occur at irregular
intervals without conforming to set schedules a system of largely casual
labour existed at the docks in the past. However, a start was made on ‘de-
casualisation’ in 1941 when war-time controls were imposed. In 1947 the
National Dock Labour Board was established, with members appointed by
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
the Minister of Labour and representing both employers and workpeople, to
administer a scheme under which registered workers received a guaranteed
minimum wage for attendance even when no work was available.
In September 1967 each registered dockworker was placed in employment
with a licensed employer on a permanent basis in accordance with the
recommendations of the 1965 Devlin report (see Bibliography, p. 484). Work
is proceeding on rationalisation of the industry’s pay structure and the elimina¬
tion of all remaining restrictive practices.
Most of the oil tankers coming to the United Kingdom to discharge crude oil
are berthed at special tanker terminals which are near the oil refineries and are
owned and operated by the oil companies. The maximum deadweight
tonnage of fully laden tankers that some of the most important terminals can
accommodate at present is: Finnart (Clyde) 300,000; Isle of Grain (Thames
estuary) 105,000; Coryton (London) 85,000; Tilbury Reach (London)
47,000; Thames Haven (London) 130,000; Tranmere (Liverpool) 100,000;
Milford Haven (Pembroke) 250,000; and Fawley (Southampton) 110,000.
Long pipelines connect Finnart with the refinery at Grangemouth on the
Firth of Forth, Angle Bay (Milford Haven) with the refinery at Llandarcy
(near Swansea) and Stanlow (Merseyside) with the refinery at Fleysham
(Lancashire). Facilities are being extended to accommodate larger vessels;
Coryton will be able to accept tankers of 200,000 tons (partly laden).
A deep-water oil terminal, costing over ^5 million, and serving two new
oil refineries, became operational at Immingham (Humberside) in 1969.
The hovercraft, a vehicle which rides on a cushion of air over both land and
water surfaces, has been in regular public passenger service around the coasts
of Britain since 1965. Large-capacity passenger and car ferry craft (165 tons)
were introduced in 1968 as an extension to the present cross-channel services
to France, making an all-year-round service possible. A hovercraft terminal
at Pegwell Bay, near Ramsgate, came into use in 1969.
INLAND TRANSPORT
The dense passenger and freight traffic of Great Britain1 is carried mainly
by road and rail, although coastal shipping and, to a lesser extent, inland
waterways and pipelines are important in carrying certain types of freight,
particularly bulk cargoes. A small but increasing proportion goes by air.
Part of the inland transport system of Great Britain is nationalised; namely,
the railways, passenger transport in the London area, a large proportion of
road passenger and some road haulage services, most of the inland waterways
and some of the vessels on them. Road haulage is largely, and coastal shipping
almost entirely, in the hands of private enterprise.
In the third quarter of 1969 there were 14-67 million vehicles licensed for
use on the roads. Of these 11-23 million were motor cars and i-i million
motor cycles; 2 per cent of the i-6 million road goods vehicles and 67 per cent
of the public road passenger vehicles (excluding taxis) were publicly owned.
In 1969 58 per cent of freight, in terms of ton-mileage,2 travelled by road,
20 per cent by rail, 20 per cent by coastal shipping, and 2 per cent by pipeline
and inland waterway.
1 For an account of inland transport in Northern Ireland, see p. 346.
2 Ton-mileage is calculated by multiplying the tonnage carried by the actual distance
it was transported.
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
335
Since 1945 the rapid growth of private and commercial motor traffic, causing
congestion problems of increasing severity, especially in cities and towns, and
the changing pattern of demand for transport services have led successive
Governments to undertake or commission fundamental studies of probable
trends in transport and problems which may arise therefrom. Over the
period 1966-75 an increase of over 50 per cent has been forecast for total
passenger mileage, with demand for public transport diminishing and travel
by private transport still rising fast. Total freight ton-mileage is expected to
increase substantially, although fuel traffic will fall as a result of structural
and technological change.
The Buchanan report, published in November 1963, was the result of a
study group set up to examine the problems of traffic in urban areas. It
estimated that Britain would have 40 million vehicles on its roads by a.d. 2010
and proposed radical measures to rebuild and adapt cities and roads to handle
the growth of traffic. It is now expected that the number of vehicles on the
roads will double by 1990.
The railway network has been reduced by nearly a third in recent years,
but it was decided in 1967 to fix a basic network of some 11,000 route-miles
(17,600 route-kilometres) for modernisation and development.
The present role and structure of the nationalised transport undertakings are
the result of a series of legislative measures, starting with the 1947 Transport
Act under which they were taken into public ownership. In accordance with
this Act the British Transport Commission (BTC) was established on
1 st January 1948 and assumed control of Britain’s railways, all railway-
owned steamships, docks, hotels and road transport interests, most of the
country’s canals (including all those owned by the railways), certain rivers
(as navigation authority) and the whole of the London passenger transport
system. It was also to arrange for the gradual acquisition of privately owned
long-distance road haulage firms.
Changes of policy following the coming into power of a Conservative
Government in 1951 were put into effect under the Transport Act 1953 which
modified the functions of the BTC. The Transport (Disposal of Road Haulage
Property) Act 1956 provided for the completion of the denationalisation of
road haulage, a process begun under the 1953 Act.
Over the next few years it became widely held that the BTC’s activities
were so large and diverse that they could not be run effectively as a single
undertaking. The Transport Act 1962 therefore dissolved the BTC and set
up four boards, for British Railways, London Transport, British Transport
Docks and British Waterways. Each of these was responsible to the Minister
of Transport, who appointed the members.
The shipping services operated by British Railways and certain ports and
docks used for them passed to the British Railways Board.
The hotel property of the BTC was transferred to British Transport Hotels
Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary, first of the BTC and later of the British
Railways Board.
Road passenger, haulage and other undertakings, such as British Road
Services, the Tilling Bus Group, the Scottish Omnibuses Group, Thomas
Cook and Son, were operated as companies incorporated under the Companies
Act, with their own boards; they were grouped under a Transport Holding
Company, responsible to the Minister of Transport.
Integration and modernisation of the national transport system are being
put into effect under the provisions of the 1968 Transport Act which has
33^
RAILWAYS
Organisation
under Public
Ownership
Operations
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
considerably altered the transport pattern laid down by the 1962 Act. The
Act provided for a capital reconstruction and reorganisation of British
Railways; the setting up of Passenger Transport Authorities to control and
co-ordinate local transport arrangements; three new nationalised bodies—
a National Bus Company, a Scottish Transport Group and a National Freight
Corporation; a new licensing system and safety provisions for road haulage
operators; and new grants for public transport. Most of the functions of the
Transport Holding Company have been distributed among the new bodies.
Britain was the pioneer of railways. The opening of the Stockton to Darlington
Railway in 1825, and of the Liverpool and Manchester line in 1830, when
George Stephenson’s famous ‘Rocket’ locomotive was used, began a century
of widespread railway development. The great period of railway building
was from 1840 to 1875.
The railways first came under centralised government direction during the
first world war, and afterwards some 130 private companies were amalgamated
into four large regional groups under the Railways Act 1921. Thereafter they
suffered from the prolonged industrial depression and growing competition
from road transport, and following the second world war the Transport Act
1947 brought the railways under public ownership as a single enterprise,
British Railways, operated under the overall management of a Railway
Executive established as the agent of the BTC. Under the Transport Act 1962
the British Railways Board was set up and came into existence on 1st January
1963 with sole responsibility for managing railway affairs.
In spite of technical and operational advances the Board’s financial position
remained unsatisfactory and, following a detailed review of railway policy,
the 1968 Transport Act made far-reaching changes. Capital debt was written
down from £1,627 million (of which £705 million had already been suspended
under the 1962 Act) to £365 million. Grants for rail passenger services which
are unremunerative but which are regarded as socially necessary were intro¬
duced; £61 million was so paid in 1969. Grants not exceeding a total of £50
million may be paid to the Railways Board on a gradually diminishing scale
during the years 1969 to 1973 towards the cost of maintaining surplus track
and signalling equipment pending their elimination; £15 million was paid in
1970. Deficit financing, which had been in operation since 1963, ceased in
1968 and the Board is now expected to pay its way. Other provisions of the
Act removed certain restrictions on the Board’s powers to manufacture and
to run hotels, and reduced the size of the Board.
The process of rationalisation arising from changing public transport require¬
ments is reflected in the reduction of over 5,778 miles (9,245 kilometres) of
standard-gauge route since 1961. A total of 805 million passenger journeys
was made and 200 million tons of freight traffic conveyed on British Railways
in 1969; total receipts amounted to £533 million. The Board made a profit
of £15 million following interest payments of £41 million. At the end of
1969 it employed 225,469 people.
In 1969 a subsidiary, British Transport Hotels Ltd., owned 34 hotels of
which it managed 33. It also managed the catering facilities on trains (includ¬
ing Pullman trains) in addition to station refreshment rooms.
British Railways’ subsidiary, British Rail Hovercraft Ltd., set up in 1966,
runs regular hovercraft services across the Solent to the Isle of Wight, and
across the Channel between Dover and Boulogne. Two 165-ton Mountbatten
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
337
Development
(SRN-4) hovercraft, the largest in the world, are used for cross-channel
journeys.
The Railways Board and the shipping subsidiaries of the National Freight
Corporation have between them a fleet of about 100 vessels, providing
passenger and freight services on most of the important routes between
Great Britain and the Continent and the Republic of Ireland, as well as on
many domestic routes. Ownership of domestic services in Scotland was
transferred to the Scottish Transport Group under the Transport Act 1968.
In 1955 the BTC produced a modernisation plan designed to transform
virtually all the services offered by tne railways. Fhe plan has since been
modified in the light of ensuing economic and technical developments, but
capital expenditure has been substantial over the past few years and in 1969
amounted to £60 million.
The most important developments have been the replacement of steam by
diesel and electric traction completed in 1968; the improvement of inter-city
passenger services with the emphasis on speed, reliability and comfort;
the introduction of express freight services (‘freightliners’) enabling freight to
be handled throughout transit in standard containers (now the responsibility
of Freightliners Ltd., see p. 338); and increased mechanisation in the carrying
of coal.
On main lines in 1955 there were about 18,000 steam, 7 mainline diesel
and 71 electric locomotives. At the end of 1969 there were 4,183 diesel
and 328 electric locomotives. In addition there were 3,649 diesel passenger¬
carrying multiple units and 7,332 electric multiple units.
The Board’s current programme includes the replacement of old passenger
coaches by new stock with improved amenities, and the construction of
new electric multiple unit stock to replace old vehicles. On certain sections
of the London-Bristol-South Wales line and of the London-Edinburgh line
passenger trains are permitted to run up to 100 mph (160 kmph). Similar
speeds are also in operation on the London Midland Region’s services on the
electrified line between London, Birmingham, Manchester and Liverpool.
This electrification scheme, costing some £160 million and completed in 1967,
was the largest individual capital investment project ever undertaken by
British Railways and included station reconstruction, bridgeworks, a new
colour-light signalling system and new rolling stock. A 70 per cent increase
in numbers of passengers has resulted. Electrification is to be extended by
235 route-miles (376 route-kilometres) to Glasgow at a cost of ^25 million;
a £30-4 million route rationalisation and resignalling scheme is to be as¬
sociated with it.
Motorail services (carrying both passengers and cars) increased their
traffic by 20 per cent in 1969 and have a current capacity of 107,000 cars on
22 services.
The efficiency of freight services is being improved as new vehicles come
into service and as facilities for concentrating traffic at fewer and better
equipped and sited marshalling yards and terminals are completed. The
freightliner services, now the responsibility of Freightliners Ltd. (see p. 338),
are to be developed further to bring the number of main terminals in operation
to 21. Services are operated throughout the country and to the Continent.
The first freightliner ran in November 1965.
The London International Freight Terminal, opened in 1967, links the
British Railways container port of Harwich with the main freightliner net¬
work. The first fully cellular container ships built in a British yard are being

used in British Railways container services between Harwich and Zeebrugge,
opened in 1968.
Bulk products traffic is increasing. Oil is being moved from refineries
under long-term contracts, while coal is being fed direct from collieries to
power stations in ‘merry-go-round’ trains, on which coal is loaded and dis¬
charged automatically from a new type of high-capacity wagon. Long-term
contracts are in operation for the carriage of cars, china clay, milk, grain and
newspapers. ‘Steel liner’ trains have been running from South Wales since
i967-
British Railways Board’s subsidiary, British Engineering Ltd., has 14 mam
workshops, employing some 37,000 people, mostly on repairs and construc¬
tion of rolling stock, locomotives and containers.
The Railway Technical Centre at Derby covers 20 acres (8 hectares) and
employs about 2,000 people. Work is proceeding on a large number of projects,
a major one being the development of a 150 mph (240 kph) gas turbine
‘advanced passenger train’ to run over existing tracks. With the associated
train control system it is being given government financial help.
The National Freight Corporation was set up under the 1968 Transport
Act to provide and promote the provision of integrated road and rail freight
services, making the maximum economic use of rail. The Corporation took
over all the road haulage and most of the shipping interests of the Transport
Holding Company, and from the Railways Board the depots, vehicles, ware¬
houses, containers and other equipment, though not the actual trains used,
in the freightliners and sundries services, and also the Board’s road haulage
vehicles.
Freightliners Ltd., a company jointly owned by the Freight Corporation
and the Railways Board (with 51 per cent and 49 per cent of the shares
respectively), is responsible for the marketing and management of freight-
liner services. The Railways Board makes a charge for providing and hauling
the trains, and profits are divided between the Board and the Corporation in
proportion to their holdings.
A Freight Integration Council was set up under the 1968 Act to advise
the Minister of Transport and the Secretary of State for Scotland on the
provision of integrated freight services by publicly owned bodies. It consists
of several independent members with an independent chairman, the chair¬
men of the Freight Corporation and the Railways Board, and members
representing union interests.
The British and French Governments have agreed to the construction of a
rail Channel Tunnel (either a bored tunnel or an immersed tube) provided
that finance can be raised on acceptable terms in the private sector. Proposals
made by an international group are being considered. The construction cost
is estimated at about £200 million.
The advent of the motor vehicle made it necessary for the Government to
set up a central road authority; accordingly, the Road Board was established
by the Development and Road Improvement Funds Act 1909. In 1919 the
Board’s responsibilities were taken over by the newly established Ministry of
Transport.
Roads are classified according to their traffic value. Trunk roads provide
a national network of routes for through traffic; other roads are divided for
grant purposes into principal and non-principal roads.
In June 1970 Great Britain had nearly 200,000 miles (320,000 kilometres)

of public highway. There were 9,000 miles (14,4°° kilometres) of trunk

The Minister of Transport is the highway authority for trunk roads in
England and on these roads he administers expenditure, which is provided
wholly from central government sources, although for many purposes he
employs local authorities as his agents. T he Secretary of State for Scotland
has corresponding responsibilities for roads in Scotland and the Secretary of
State for Wales for roads in Wales. Work on major trunk road schemes in
England, including motorways, is controlled by regional road construction
units, manned jointly by Ministry of Transport and county council staff.
The highway authority for principal roads is, in general, the council of the
county or county borough in whose area the roads lie. The Minister makes
specific grants towards approved expenditure on construction and major
improvement of these roads and contributions from public funds towards
maintenance and other expenditure is made through grants to local authorities.
Roads other than trunk and principal roads are entirely the responsibility
of the local authority in whose area they lie.
A large and steadily expanding road-building programme has been in progress
since 1955- Public expenditure on new and improved roads in Great Britain
is estimated at over ^42° niillion in 1970—71- The current programme
includes a considerable mileage of motorways constructed for the use of
limited classes of traffic under powers granted by the Special Roads Act 1949
(consolidated in the Highways Act 1959).
The motorways form part of a programme designed to provide a national
network of modern through routes. At the same time, work done under this
programme is eliminating some of the worst bottlenecks in uiban areas and
thus helping to give free outlets from the big cities and from other main
sources of traffic to the trunk routes.
Plans to spend over ,£4,000 million on roads in the next 15 to 20 years were
announced by the Government in May 1970.
At the end of June 1970 in England 604 miles (966 kilometres) of motorways
had been opened for traffic and construction had started or tenders had been
invited for a further 345 miles (552 kilometres). The lines of an additional
106 miles (170 kilometres) had been fixed and draft schemes published for
108 miles (173 kilometres). In Wales 23 miles (37 kilometres) are in use. In
Scotland 120 miles (192 kilometres) of motorway are planned, of which over
52 miles (83 kilometres) are in use. (See map on inside of back cover.)
A comprehensive programme of trunk road improvements is also well
advanced. Over 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometres) of all-purpose trunk roads in
Great Britain now have dual carriageways, in addition to 580 miles (928 kilo¬
metres) of principal roads.
A large programme of bridge and tunnel building has been undertaken in
recent years. The bridges include the Medway Bridge on the M2, the sus¬
pension bridge across the Firth of Forth, the Severn Bridge incorporating
major advances in suspension bridge design, and the 7,000-ft (2,100 metres)
bridge across the Firth of Tay. Tinsley Viaduct, near Sheffield, a two-level
viaduct over 3,000 ft (9,000 metres) long, was opened in two stages in 1968.
A high-level bridge over the Clyde at Erskine is under construction, a
340 BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
ten-lane bridge at Glasgow was opened in 1970, and the new £4 million
London Bridge is to be completed in 1972.
The second Blackwall Tunnel (under the Thames) costing £8 million
and the £13 million Tyne Tunnel between Wallsend (Northumberland) and
Jarrow (Durham) were opened in 1967. The j£n million Dartford-Purfleet
Tunnel (under the Thames) has been open to traffic since the end of 1963.
Work on the ^20 million Mersey crossing began in 1967; the first of the twin
tunnels is due for completion in 1971 and the second in 1974. A tunnel to
carry a London motorway under the Thames is to be built at the new town
of Thamesmead.
Research Research on roads is carried out at the Road Research Laboratory (see p. 192).
Its aims are to find more economical ways of designing, constructing and
maintaining roads and of facilitating the flow of traffic on them and to reduce
road accidents. The layout of roads, their traffic, the safety features of road
vehicles and the behaviour of road users are investigated, and new methods,
materials and processes are developed for building roads and providing them
with a smooth, safe and durable surface. The Laboratory has a Tropical
Section, which undertakes research and advises on road problems overseas.
In 1969 there were about 14*67 million motor vehicles licensed to use Great
Britain’s roads. Of these, i*6 million were goods vehicles and 100,000 were
public road passenger vehicles (that is, buses and taxicabs).
The first world war stimulated the development of motor vehicles, which
became serious competitors of the railways. Government regulation of public
road transport began with the passing of the London Traffic Act 1924,
which gave the Minister of Transport power to control the number of buses
and their journeys in London; this was followed in 1933 by the setting up of
the London Passenger Transport Board (see p. 345).
Licensing The Road Traffic Act 1930 ended the licensing of public service vehicles
(that is, buses and coaches) by local authorities and set up instead traffic areas
each under the control of three traffic commissioners (except for the London
metropolitan area, v/hich has one1) appointed by the Minister. The com¬
missioners regulate, by means of a licensing system, public road passenger
transport services, and they sanction routes and time-tables in order to secure
proper co-ordination of services and eliminate unnecessary competition; they
may control fares.
The Road and Rail Traffic Act 1933 established a system of licensing for
road haulage vehicles designed to restrict vehicle operations to proved needs.
Under the Act the licensing authority (that is, the chairman of the appropriate
body of traffic commissioners) could grant licences to public haulage vehicles,
where their services appeared to be needed and grant automatically, on
application, licences for the carriage of the licensee’s own goods.
Under the 1968 Transport Act a new licensing system, with the aims of
improving safety and promoting a fuller use of rail transport where this does
not impose higher costs on industry, is replacing the system described above.
Over 900,000 goods vehicles not exceeding 3^ tons gross loaded weight
(30 cwt. unladen) have already been exempted from licensing. Operators of
goods vehicles of over 3^ tons were issued during 1970 with operators’

In due course they or an employee will be required to hold a ‘transport

The first stage of the reduction in hours worked by drivers of goods and
public service passenger vehicles laid down by the 1968 Transport Act came
into force in March 1970, together with a new system of written records to be
kept by goods vehicle drivers and their employees. Regulations concerning
the fitness and loading of vehicles have been made more stringent under
recent legislation.
From September 1956 to January 1963 the nationalised road haulage services
were controlled by British Road Services (BRS), a division of the British
Transport Commission, and operated through five companies, which together
owned about 16,000 vehicles. Under the Transport Act 1962, these organisa¬
tions operated companies incorporated under the Companies Act, with their
own boards, and were grouped together under the Transport Holding
Company, responsible to the Minister of Transport. i he road haulage
interests of the Holding Company have been transferred to the National
Freight Corporation (see p. 338).
The number of licensed vehicles in the road goods transport industry has
shown a relatively slow growth, from 1-4 million in i960 to i-6 million in
1969. In 1969, 600,000 vehicles held carrier licences, of which 400,000 were
used solely for the owner’s own goods. Of the remaining 200,000 about
29,000 were operated by the National Freight Corporation.
The 1968 Transport Act enables Passenger Transport Authorities (PTAs)
to be set up to control and co-ordinate the different forms of transport in
any particular area. The first PTAs were set up in April 1969 south-east
Lancashire—north-east Cheshire, Merseyside, the West Midlands and
Tyneside. The constituent local authorities appoint most of the members,
but up to one-seventh may be appointed by the Minister of Transport (or
by the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales). Each appoints its own
chairman, with the Minister’s approval. The PTAs control policy and finance,
and appoint professional executives—Passenger Transport Executives—to
be responsible to them for day-to-day operations. The Executives may operate
services themselves and enter into agreements with other bodies, such as
British Railways or the National Bus Company, to operate others; they have
taken over all the former municipal bus undertakings in their areas.
The National Bus Company was formed to take over the former bus
operating and manufacturing subsidiaries of the Transport Holding Company
in England and Wales, and operates through locally based subsidiaries.
A separate Scottish Transport Group has been set up to control bus and
some shipping services in Scotland, and has taken over the relevant interests
of the Transport Holding Company, operating through subsidiaries.
342
Road Safety
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The National Bus Company and the Scottish Transport Group operate
about 21,100 and 4,700 vehicles respectively. The PTAs control 6,300
vehicles formerly operated by 20 municipal undertakings. The remainder of
the industry, excluding London Transport, comprises 4,800 operators
owning 34,000 vehicles; 79 of these operators are local authorities outside
PTA areas operating 10,000 vehicles, and 3,500 are small concerns operating
not more than five vehicles.
Capital grants are made by the Government towards the cost of investment
in public transport, at rates of up to 75 per cent of approved cost. Eligible
schemes include improvements or extensions of railway lines, new fixed track
rail and bus systems, interchanges, stations, and car parks. Grants at the rate
of 25 per cent are available towards the cost of new buses complying with
specifications approved by the Ministry of Transport. Grants may also be
paid through a new rural bus grants scheme, and for 7 years to PTA Executives
towards the cost of rail services covered by agreement with the Railways
Board.
Britain has one of the highest densities of road traffic in the world. Road ac¬
cident statistics are compiled and published by the Ministry of Transport, the
Scottish Development Department and the Welsh Office from reports made
by the police. In 1969, 7,383 people were killed on the roads and about
90,700 seriously injured. The fatal accident rate per vehicle is lower than that
in most other European countries.
Modern roads, designed for present-day traffic and segregating pedestrians
from vehicles, are safer than the roads they replace and surveys have shown
they result in a marked fall in casualties. The more important measures
directed primarily towards road safety include speed limits of 30 and 40 mph
(48 and 64 kmph) in built-up areas and 50 mph (80 kmph) on certain trunk
and important classified roads in rural areas; a 70 mph (112 kmph) speed limit
on all motorways and on ordinary main roads where no lower limit applies;
the provision of pedestrian crossings—usually illuminated by flashing beacons
and marked with conspicuous white stripes (‘zebra’ crossings); and the system
of road markings and traffic signs which are being replaced by greatly
improved signs in accordance with general European practice. The Road
Safety Act, 1967 made it an offence to drive with more than a prescribed
level of alcohol in the blood, at present 80 milligrammes of alcohol per 100
millilitres of blood.
The design of vehicles, their use on the roads, and the maintenance of their
mechanical condition are controlled by regulations. Private cars and light
vans which are three or more years old must be tested annually at private
garages authorised as test stations. Heavy goods vehicles are tested annually
at government test stations. Public service vehicles must be specially
approved before being licensed to carry passengers, and are tested at regular
intervals. Any vehicle may be stopped on the road at any time by the police
and examined. Fitting of seat belts in cars registered in or after 1965 is com¬
pulsory, and a high standard of tyre safety is enforced.
All drivers of motor vehicles, unless they have either held a full British
licence or passed the driving test in the last ten years, are required to pass the
test before being granted a full licence to drive. Until they pass the test they
must obtain a ‘provisional’ licence which necessitates their displaying ‘L’
(Learner) plates on their vehicle, and in all cases, except solo motor-cycles
and motor-cycle combinations, where vehicles are constructed to carry
passengers, learner drivers must be accompanied by a qualified driver.

Control of Traffic

(Newly arrived residents to Britain may drive under their overseas driving
licences for three months before becoming subject to these rules.) A learner
driver of a solo motor-cycle is restricted, until he passes the driving test, to a
machine not exceeding 250 cc. Professional driving instructors must be
approved by the Ministry of Transport. A scheme for special licensing and
testing of drivers of heavy goods vehicles, which lapsed in 1939, was re¬
introduced in February 1970.
The Road Traffic Acts, which embody the law relating to road users, are
enforced by the police and the courts. A person convicted of any of the 26
most serious offences is liable to be disqualified from driving for a period. The
standard of conduct for all road users and a summary of the requirements of
the law is set out in easily understandable form in the Highway Code, which
was revised in 1969. A failure to observe the code does not of itself render a
person liable to criminal proceedings but may be taken into account in any
such proceedings.
National campaigns to persuade people to take greater care on the roads
are conducted by the Ministry of Transport and the Royal Society for the
Prevention of Accidents, acting as the Government’s agent and with the
participation of the local authorities. The police and education authorities
also help by arranging courses of instruction, especially courses for children.
The Road Traffic Regulation Act 1967 empowers traffic authorities to make
orders regulating traffic and imposing parking control. With the exception of
trunk roads, which are the concern of the central Government, traffic is the
responsibility of local authorities. Extensive schemes are being undertaken
for the improvement of road safety and the relief of traffic congestion. These
include: ‘fly-overs’ at road junctions; new outlet roads from cities; and traffic
management measures, including comprehensive control of street parking,
‘one-way’ systems, peak hour ‘clearways’ prohibiting waiting on busy roads,
and ‘tidal flow’ arrangements. A Traffic Advisory Unit set up in 1965 in the
Ministry of Transport advises local authorities. In most town centres street
parking is permitted for limited periods only, and in London and some other
towns on payment at parking meters usually under the supervision of traffic
wardens. Disc schemes providing free but limited parking facilities are in
operation at Devizes, Harrogate and Ripon. Off-street facilities are being in¬
creased, including multi-storey car parks. A computer-controlled system to
regulate traffic was installed in west London in 1968. Similar systems are
operating in Glasgow and Liverpool.
In 1761 James Brindley completed the Bridgewater Canal to take coal from
the collieries owned by the Duke of Bridgewater at Worsley to Manchester.
This marked the beginning of canal building in modern Britain, with which
the names of Brindley, Telford, Rennie, Jessop and other great engineers are
associated. Canals played an important part in promoting industrial and
commercial expansion in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.
The whole canal system was practically complete by 1830. As a result of
developing competition from the railways, however, about one-third of the
canal mileage had passed to the control of the railway companies by the middle
of the nineteenth century. During the two world wars government control
of railways included railway-owned canals. Under the Transport Act 1947,
most of the country’s canals passed to the British Transport Commission in
January 1948. Under the Transport Act of 1962, control has been vested
in the British Waterways Board since January 1963. Under the Transport
M

The System
Development
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Act 1968 a grant-in-aid is being paid primarily to enable the Board to main¬
tain an extensive network of amenity waterways; in 1969-70 £1-5 million
was paid and a further ^0-5 million for the costs of improving bridges.
There are about 2,500 miles (4,000 kilometres) of navigable inland waterways
in Great Britain,1 some 2,000 miles (3,200 kilometres) of which belong to the
British Waterways Board; the remainder are mainly still in the hands of
local authorities or private companies. Many of the Board’s canals are narrow
waterways which can generally be used only by boats not exceeding 7 ft
(2-13 metres) in width, capable of carrying a load varying from 25 to 30 tons;
the remainder are broad waterways and canalised rivers, some of which can
be used by craft of up to about 750 tons capacity. The Caledonian and Crinan
Canals in Scotland are broad waterways. Of the 2,000 miles (3,200 kilometres)
of inland waterways under the control of the British Waterways Board some
340 miles (544 kilometres) are commercial waterways. A substantial additional
mileage (1,100 miles—1,760 kilometres—known as cruising waterways) is to
be maintained for recreational purposes; a statutory Inland Waterways
Amenity Advisory Council has been set up to advise the Minister of Transport
and the Board.
Engineering, commercial and estate work is directed from the Board s
headquarters in London and Watford, and through regional offices at Leeds
and Gloucester. In Scotland the canals (other than the Caledonian, which is
run by a manager) are, for engineering purposes, under the control of the
engineer-in-charge at Glasgow; estates work is supervised centrally from
London.
In 1969 traffic on the Board’s waterways amounted to just over 6-7 million
tons, of which 2-6 million tons were coal, 1-4 million tons liquids in bulk and
27 million tons general cargo. Some 97 per cent of the traffic is carried on
about 300 miles (480 kilometres) of broad waterways, which are mainly
canalised river navigations.
Although the British Waterways Board is the largest single carrying
operator, most of the traffic is handled by independent carriers or by traders
in their own craft. The Board at the end of 1969 owned 575 freight carrying
craft (including tugs) with a carrying capacity of 26,674 tons. It operates
2 docks and 26 warehouses.
The Board continues to improve facilities on its commercial waterways, most
of which link important industrial districts with ports. These waterways are
the main navigations and broad canals in the Yorkshire-Humberside area,
together with the Trent and Weaver Navigations, and the Weston Canal in
Cheshire, the Lee Navigation, part of the river Severn, including the Glouces¬
ter and Sharpness Canal, and the Caledonian and Crinan Canals. The Board
is also improving recreation facilities on its cruising waterways.
The total turnover of the British Waterways Board in 1969 amounted to
£4-8 million, of which £0-4 million arose from the Board’s own freight¬
carrying activities, £1 million from warehousing and terminal services, and
£o-S million from the docks. The sale of water for industrial and agricultural
purposes brought in ^o-8 million. British Waterways encourages pleasure
boating and receipts rose to £155,000.

LONDON

Reorganisation
The London

London is, with Tokyo and New York, one of the world’s three largest cities.
The area known as Greater London, within a radius of about 15 miles (24 kilo¬
metres) from Charing Cross, contains about 77 million people.
London’s passenger transport system, in its modern sense, began in 1829
when the first omnibus, horse-drawm, appeared on the London streets. The
first regular tram service, also horse-drawn, began in 1870. In 1863 the first
underground steam railway, the Metropolitan, was opened. It was built by
digging a great trench for the line and roofing it over. In 1870 the world’s
first tube railway, the Tower Subway, under the river Thames opened; it
was cable-operated and ran for only a few months. The first electric tube
railway in the world, the City and South London Railway, was opened in
1890, and this was followed in 1900 by the opening of the Central London
Railway. Shortly afterwards the original steam-operated underground lines
were electrified. Meanwhile horse-drawn trams were being replaced by
electric trams, and later horse-drawn buses by motor buses.
Until 1933 there were many separate undertakings providing passenger
transport facilities in London, but in that year they were all vested in a single
public corporation, the London Passenger Transport Board. In 1948, with
the establishment of the British Transport Commission, the London Trans¬
port Executive took over control as an agency of the Commission.
Under the Transport Act 1962 the London Transport Executive was
replaced by a financially independent board, the London Transport Board.
Exchequer loans financed the Board’s external capital needs. From 1965 to
1969 the Board ran a deficit, due mainly to competition from the private car
and to increasing traffic congestion. The deficit was met by Government grants.
Under the Transport (London) Act 1969, which came into effect on 1st
January 1970, the Greater London Council (GLC) replaced the Ministry
of Transport as overall planning authority for London’s internal transport
and also took over control of the central bus and underground railway services,
formerly the responsibility of the London Transport Board (LTB). Manage¬
ment of the transport facilities is performed by the new London Transport
Executive, appointed by and responsible to the GLC. The LTB’s country
bus and Green Line coach services were transferred to London Country Bus
Service Ltd., a subsidiary of the National Bus Company (see p. 336). Under
a financial reorganisation the Government has written off the entire capital
debt of the former LTB, some £250 million.
The London Transport undertaking operates all road and rail passenger
transport services in the London area with the exception of the London lines
of British Railways and the taxicabs. Some 7,600 taxicabs that ply for hire
in the streets are privately operated by companies or owner-drivers and are
licensed annually by the Metropolitan Police. There are about 12,200 licensed
cab drivers.
London Transport’s railway network stretches over 20 miles (32 kilometres)
from north to south and 35 miles (56 kilometres) from east to west. In March
1970 the total length of the railway over which London Transport trains
operated was 254 miles (406 kilometres), of which 100 miles (160 kilometres)
were underground. London Transport trains serve 276 stations and its buses
and coaches travel over 1,699 miles kilometres) of roads. To carry
traffic over all this area London Transport owns 4,311 railway cars and
6,570 buses and coaches. The total staff employed is nearly 60,000.
Improvements being carried out by London Transport have included

extension and modernisation of parts of tne Underground system, and the
introduction of automatic fare collection and automatic trains. One-man
operation of buses is being steadily extended over a period of years.
Work on a new 14-mile (22 kilometre) underground railway, has been in
progress since 1962. The main 10^-mile (17 kilometre) section from Waltham¬
stow in north-east London to Victoria Station is now in use, and an extension
to Brixton in south London should be in operation by the end of I971* There

London Transport set up an International Advisory service for city
transport in 1969.
Reorganisation of public transport in Northern Ireland was completed in
1968. Under the Transport Act (Northern Ireland) 1967 the Ulster Transport
Authority was wound up and its assets and liabilities transferred to a new
company, the Northern Ireland Transport Holding Company. Responsibility
for operating services on the 200 miles (320 kilometres) of railway track was
given to the Northern Ireland Railways Company Ltd., a subsidiary of the
Holding Compaq. The Act also provides for a licensing system for road
passenger operators.
Ulsterbus Ltd., another subsidiary of the Holding Company, has taken
over the road passenger operations of the Authority, which formerly provided
all public road passenger services, apart from those of the City of Belfast. A
number of privately owned bus companies now operate in addition.
In 1966 the Authority’s monopoly of road carriage of freight was replaced
by a licensing system. About 1,900 operators and 4>I5° vehicles have been
licensed, the biggest single operator being Northern Ireland Carriers Ltd.,
owned jointly by the Northern Ireland Transport Holding Company and
the British National Freight Corporation.
On 31st March 1970 there were 14,109 miles (22,574 kilometres) of public
roads in Northern Ireland, comprising 379 miles (606 kilometres) of trunk
roads, 1,012 miles (1,619 kilometres) of Class I roads, 1,733 m^es (2>773
kilometres) of Class II roads, 2,876 miles (4,602 kilometres) of Class III roads
and 8,109 miles (12,974 kilometres) of unclassified roads.
The Ministry of Development is directly responsible for the trunk road
system and bears the entire cost of maintenance and construction work on
these roads. In addition to major construction schemes on trunk roads, an
extensive system of motorways is planned including an urban motorway
system in Belfast. About 48 miles (77 kilometres) of motorway were in use by
the middle of 1970.
The Ministry of Development administers the Road Fund (the proceeds of
motor vehicle taxation, driving licence fees, etc.), from which grants are paid
to the local authorities (county, county borough, borough and urban district
councils) which are responsible for the other roads. The rates of grant range
from 90 per cent for major improvement works on Class I roads to 25 per cent
for maintenance work on the unclassified roads.
Gross capital expenditure on all roads in the financial year to 31st March
1969 was ^12 million, and expenditure on maintenance and minor improve¬
ments was about £7 million. Gross capital expenditure in the five-year
period 1970-74 is expected to be about £80 million, compared with about
£62 million in the five-year period to 31st March 1969. Expenditure on
maintenance and minor improvements in the five-year period to 31st March
1969 was ^31-4 million.

The Air Transport
Licensing Board
{ATLB)
British airmen were among the first to carry mails (at the time of the Corona¬
tion of King George V in 1911) and among the first to operate regular mail
and passenger services, which were inaugurated on 25th August 1919, when
a daily passenger service was opened between London (Hounslow) and Paris
(Le Bourget).
In April 1924 four small British companies merged to form Imperial Airways
Limited and this company pioneered the commercial development of inter¬
continental air routes. By 1929 there was a through service from England to
India. The first passenger service to Australia started in 1935.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation, a public corporation, took over
the undertakings of Imperial Airways Limited and British Airways Limited in
1940. British European Airways was established under the Civil Aviation
Act 1946 as a separate public corporation to cover the United Kingdom and
Europe. In addition to the two nationalised corporations, 46 independent
air transport operators hold Air Operators’ Certificates.
General responsibility for the development of United Kingdom civil aviation
rests with the Board of Trade, which has certain statutory powers and duties
in respect of the air corporations, including the power, very seldom used, to
give directions of a general character as to the exercise and performance of
their functions in relation to matters affecting the national interest. The
Board of Trade appoints the Boards of the corporations and, with the
approval of the Treasury, has power to make loans within the limits laid down
by Parliament to finance capital investment. It is responsible for approving
the lines of the corporations’ capital expenditure, and also sets, after con¬
sultation with the corporations, their financial targets and, in BOAC’s case,
approves the amount payable annually as dividend. There is close consultation
on overseas traffic rights and air safety. Day-to-day matters concerning the
corporations’ activities are the responsibility of the commercial management
of BOAC and BEA.
The Board plays an important part in the activities of the International
Civil Aviation Organisation and other international aviation bodies.
Under the post-war nationalisation legislation the air corporations had a
statutory monopoly of British scheduled services, and independent operators
were confined, broadly, to charter work. From 1949, and increasingly from
1952, the independants were allowed to develop new scheduled services,
provided they secured ministerial approval and operated, technically, as
associates of the corporations. The Civil Aviation (Licensing) Act i960
abolished the corporations’ monopoly and provided for a licensing system,
administered by an Air Transport Licensing Board, to which the nationalised
and independent operators could apply on an equal footing for licences for
scheduled or charter services, or for revocation or variation of existing licences.
The ATLB is an independent body of six to ten members appointed by the
Board of Trade. Its main function is to consider and decide on applications for
licences (or their revocation or variation). The ATLB must have regard to an
applicant’s financial resources, staffing, organisation, the need for the pro¬
posed services, the adequacy of, and possible effect on, existing services, and
any objections or representations made by interested parties. It also has the
general duty of furthering the development of British aviation. There is

provision for appeals on ATLB decisions to the Board of Trade, which
appoints independent commissioners to hear appeals publicly and report with
recommendations upon them.
A committee set up to enquire into the affairs of the civil air transport
industry reported in May 1969. Its recommendations formed the basis of
proposals put forward by the Government in November 1969} including the
establishment of a Civil Aviation Authority to take over general control of
the industry, of an Airways Board to control the state-owned airlines, of a
privately owned ‘second force’ airline formed from among the independent
operators, and of a group of regional airlines; subsidies would be available
for certain regional services. Legislation along the lines of the committee s
recommendations is under consideration. A statement in favour of the estab¬
lishment of a ‘second force’ air line was issued by the new Government in
August 1970.
The constitution and functions of BOAC and BE A are laid down in the Air
Corporations Act 1967, which consolidates, with certain exceptions, the
provisions of the Air Corporations Acts 1949 an<^ 1966, and in the Air
Corporation Act 1969. Each corporation consists of 5 to n members, includ¬
ing the chairman. The chairman of each board is a member of the other.
As a result of BOAC’s capital reconstruction in 1966, £35 million ‘Exchequer
Dividend Capital’ on which a variable dividend, related to each year’s
earnings, is payable, was created, together with a reconstruction reserve of
some £30 million and appropriate loan capital. The introduction of Public
Dividend Capital (now £65 million) is experimental. The statutory limit on
BOAC’s total borrowings is £120 million. BEA’s borrowing limit is £200
million, which can be increased by Order to £230 million.
Total capacity-ton-miles offered on all services has more than trebled since
1959, and had risen to 3,375 million capacity-ton-miles in 1969. In 1955,
2-5 million passengers entered or left the United Kingdom by air, compared
with 5’7 million who arrived or departed by sea; in 1962 there were for the
first time more air than sea passengers, and by 1969 figures had risen to
18-5 million by air and 10-5 million by sea.
BOAC is engaged on long-haul airline operations. Its scheduled services link
Britain with Europe, the Middle East, the Far East, Australasia, Africa and
North and South America, and it also provides complete round-the-world
services. It co-operates closely with airlines of several other Commonwealth
countries; it also has financial interests in eight companies operating local and
regional services in the various parts of the world adjacent to BOAC s main
routes; and in a number of hotel companies in areas attractive to business and
holiday travellers.
The capacity offered on BOAC’s own scheduled services reached 1,856
million capacity-ton-miles in the year ended March 197° having risen by
21 per cent over the previous year. Over half of this capacity was on the
western routes to North and South America. The overall load factor in
1969-70 was 51 per cent; the break-even load factor (the figure at which
operating costs are covered) was 41-8 per cent. The Corporation’s fleet, made
up entirely of pure jets, consists (June 197°) Super VC 10s (iy), VC 10s
(11), Boeing 707-436$ (18), Boeing 707-336* (8 with a further 2 on order);
and 3 Boeing 747s with another 9 on order and option on another 4.

The VC 10, introduced into service in 1964, operates alongside Boeing 707s
on world-wide routes. The Boeing 70J—336C took over transatlantic all¬
freighter operations in January 1966 and also operates all-traffic services to
Johannesburg, the Far East and Australia.
BOAC’s own passenger terminal at Kennedy International Airport, New
York, is now in use.
The Corporation is making a substantial investment over a period of ten
years on the installation of an advanced airline computer system to control
a wide variety of international activities, including accounting and flight
planning. The first stages, controlling seat reservations, came into operation
in 1968.
BOAC had another profitable year in 1969-70 when it earned an operating
surplus of £31 million and net profits of £19 million after interest on
borrowings and taxation. Of its gross traffic revenue (^198 million), ^137
million was earned in foreign currencies.
BEA operates a network of services to about 90 places in Britain, Europe,
North Africa and the Middle East. Its services in Britain include a number
which cannot be operated on a commercial basis but which meet a vital
social need, mainly the services to the Highlands and Islands of Scotland.
BEA also co-operates with other airlines in order to create ‘through travel’
facilities. It has a financial interest in several associated companies, most of
which collaborate with BEA in providing a network of services. Two major
subsidiaries are British Air Services, operating secondary domestic services,
and Airbus, a new tours company.
For the year ended 31st March 1970 the increases in capacity offered, and
passenger-miles and freight-ton-miles flown on scheduled services, were io-8
per cent, n-6 per cent and o-8 per cent respectively over the previous year:
in the same year some 8-5 million passengers were carried.
BEA’s fleet consists (March 1970) of BAC One-Elevens (18), Trident Twos
(14), Trident Ones (21), Comet 4BS (4), Viscount 802s (20), Viscount 806s (7),
Argosys (4), Vanguard 951s (5), Vanguard 953s (10), and Herons (2). Twenty-
six Trident Threes, enlarged versions of the Trident One, have been ordered
at a total cost of ^80 million.
In 1969-70 the corporation earned over ^126 million in revenue and made
a net profit of ^6*5 million. It has earned a profit in 13 out of the past 16 years.
Although the two State corporations had a statutory monopoly up to 1961
there has been a significant expansion in recent years not only of the number
of passengers and volume of freight carried but also in the diversity of services
operated by the independent operators. As well as a wide network of domestic
and international services they provide vehicle ferry services; specialised air
cargo facilities; and enable travel agents to offer low-cost all-in holidays
abroad. The independent companies compete with BEA over several domestic
routes, including the busiest internal route in Europe, from London to
Glasgow. In 1969 they carried some 8 million passengers. A large programme
of aircraft re-equipment has been carried out. Jet airliners on domestic
routes in Britain were first introduced by British United Airways in 1966.
In addition to the public transport operators there are a large number of
companies engaged in miscellaneous aviation activities such as crop-spraying,
aerial survey and photography, and flying instruction. About 30 companies
carry out air-taxi operations.

The proportion of Britain’s overseas trade carried by air is increasing steadily.
In 1956, 1*7 per cent of imports and 2-9 per cent of exports (by value) were
carried by air. In 1969 the corresponding percentages were 13-3 and 13, and
the total value of exports, imports and re-exports by air was £2,063 million.
The chief export items are expensive machinery and parts, aircraft and vehicle
parts, and electrical and electronic products; furs and skins account for a large
proportion of the total value of re-exports.
At Heathrow, London, freight traffic is increasing at an annual rate of
18 per cent and totalled 343,000 metric tons in 1969. Scheduled services of
British airlines carried about 300,000 tons of freight in 1969, compared with
196,000 tons in 1959.
The estimated number of aircraft on the United Kingdom register used for
business and private purposes is over 1,000, while approximately 860 are
owned by clubs, groups and training schools. About 15,000 private pilots
hold licences. About 130 companies use private aircraft and some 80 companies
are members of the Business Aircraft Users’ Association. There are some
4,000 glider pilots.
The Board of Trade has a general responsibility for civil aerodromes. It may
itself establish and maintain airports, and local authorities may also do so
subject to its approval. Aerodromes which are municipally or privately owned
and which are used for the public transport of passengers and/or flying
instruction are subject to government licensing, inspection and regulation.
The Board is also responsible for navigation facilities at a number of main
municipal airports.
The British Airports Authority, an independent statutory body operating
on a commercial basis, took over on 1st April 1966 the ownership and
management of London’s two major airports (Heathrow and Gatwick),
Prestwick in Scotland and Stansted in Essex. At these airports the Board of
Trade is responsible for the provision of navigation services and may direct
the Authority to take measures to control noise and vibration.
There are approximately 140 civil aerodromes in the United Kingdom;
in addition, 56 Service aerodromes are available for civil use. Those under
civil control include 12 directly controlled by the Board of Trade, 3 in the
Channel Islands and 1 in the Isle of Man administered by the local island
governments, and 40 aerodromes licensed for public use, of which 24 are
owned by municipalities. Two of the Board of Trade’s aerodromes and 28
others are designated Customs airports; limited customs facilities are avail¬
able at a further 31 aerodromes.
A Commission of Enquiry was set up in May 1968 to consider the need for
a third London airport and possible sites.
Aircraft and passenger movements at the principal airports have risen very
markedly in the last five years, and in 1969 United Kingdom civil airports
handled 28-9 million passengers. The number of movements of aircraft
engaged on commercial transport operations was 591,000.
For international scheduled services Heathrow and Gatwick are the main
airports, and Heathrow is the busiest centre of international travel in the
world. The number of passengers handled at Heathrow, 14 miles (24 kilo¬
metres) west of central London, has increased from 5*4 million in i960 to
14-3 million in 1969 of which 11-3 million were international passengers. The
British Airports Authority plans to spend nearly £80 million on improve-

merits to Heathrow and its other airports in the period ending in 1973. The
shorter of the two main Heathrow runways is being extended to 12,800 feet
(3,900 metres). An fn million passenger terminal primarily for British
short-haul airlines and Aer Lingus was completed in 1969, and extensions
are being made to several other buildings. To accommodate the rapid
expansion expected in freight movements, £25 million has been invested in
a new cargo terminal and associated developments, which came into use in
1969. New facilities costing some £13 million are being provided for handling
Boeing J4J (jumbo jet) aircraft, which began to use the airport early in 1970.
An extension of an existing London Transport rail line into Heathrow is
under consideration.
The airport at Gatwick, 28 miles (45 kilometres) south of London, was
opened in June 1958 as the second airport for the London area. Built along¬
side the main London to Brighton railway and the A23 road, Gatwick airport
was the first in the world to contain road, rail and air transport in one unit.
In 1969 it handled 3 million passengers. The existing runway is being
extended and a second runway has been proposed.
A privately owned helicopter terminal (or ‘heliport’) is in operation at
Battersea on the south bank of the Thames.
Prestwick airport in Scotland has been developed to accommodate large
jet aircraft. The freight facilities have been extended and further improve¬
ments are planned. The airport at Abbotsinch, owned and run by the Glasgow
Corporation, handled i-6 million passengers in 1969.
Manchester (Ringway), Belfast (Aldergrove) and Luton each handled over
a million passengers in 1969; Birmingham and Edinburgh (Turnhouse) each
handled over 500,000.
The role of the Government in promoting air safety lies in research and in
setting up and supervising standards for both aircraft and personnel.
Research on aircraft design and construction is done at the Ministry of
Technology’s Royal Aircraft Establishments at Farnborough and Bedford,
which are exceptionally well equipped with testing facilities.
The Board of Trade determines the policy and legislative requirements for
the safe operation of civil aircraft, analyses accidents and initiates preventive
measures and research in flight safety.
All aircraft registered in the United Kingdom must have a valid certificate
of airworthiness issued (or rendered valid) by the Board of Trade on the
recommendation of the Air Registration Board (ARB), which was set up in
1937 and consists of 18 members, four of whom are independent, including
the chairman. No aircraft built in Britain is granted a certificate of airworthi¬
ness unless it has been constructed in accordance with British Civil Air¬
worthiness Requirements, a code compiled and frequently reviewed by the
ARB. Continued airworthiness is ensured by regular inspection and by re¬
quiring aircraft to be maintained in accordance with a schedule approved by
the ARB.
Every operator of aircraft above a certain weight used for public transport
must possess an Air Operator’s Certificate which is granted by the Director of
Aviation Safety when he is satisfied that the operator is competent to secure
the safe operation of his aircraft. The Director is advised by the Board of
Trade’s flight operations inspectors (who are experienced airline pilots) on
all matters affecting the operation of aircraft, except aircraft maintenance,
which is the responsibility of the Air Registration Board.

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Each member of a flight crew must hold the appropriate official licence. Flight
operations inspectors check the standards maintained by the operators, which
must be adequate for purposes of the Air Operator’s Certificate.
In order to supplement the diminishing supply of well-trained pilots for civil
airlines from the Royal Air Force, the College of Air Training was set up at
Hamble in i960. It is sponsored by the Government and the two airways
corporations. Commercial pilots must attend a course of training approved by
the Board of Trade. Such courses have been approved at the training schools
at Carlisle, Oxford and Perth, in addition to Hamble. The corporations set up
a new engineering apprentice school at Cranebank, near Heathrow, in 1970.
An Air Transport and Travel Industry Training Board has been established
under the Industrial Training Act 1964.
Responsibility for policy, planning and execution of both civil and military
air traffic control over the United Kingdom and the surrounding seas rests
with the National Air Traffic Control Services Organisation, under the joint
control of the Board of Trade and the Secretary of State for Defence.
In 1950 a system of airways covering the main traffic routes with control zones
around the major airports was introduced. Subsequently, the airway system
has been revised and extended to meet traffic requirements. There are three
main air traffic control centres: at London for southern England, at Preston
for the north of England and Wales, and at Prestwick for Scotland and the
Atlantic Ocean to 30°W.
A variety of radar installations and other equipment provide the means by
which the system can accept the increasingly heavy load of air traffic. Britain
was the first country to use radar for the control of civil air traffic. During
the next few years virtually the whole of the airspace over Britain above
5,000 feet (1,500 metres) will be brought under surveillance by the latest
types of primary and secondary radar equipment, which will provide data to be
used in two air traffic control centres, located at West Drayton (near London)
and Prestwick. A subsidiary centre will be located at Manchester to deal with
traffic in the Manchester terminal control area. Extensive use will be made in
these centres of automatic data processing and other advanced electronic
techniques. The first stage in a £25 million development (Mediator) will
begin in 1971.
The Board of Trade provides radio navigational aids to help pilots navigate
in all weather conditions, and has installed the Instrument Landing System
(ILS) at all its major airports.
Britain has pioneered in the development of all-weather landing systems.
The Blind Landing Experimental Unit of the Royal Aircraft Establishment
at Bedford and private industry have worked towards fully automatic blind
landing, which has now been achieved with passenger-carrying aircraft,
in good visibility.
Britain is a member of Eurocontrol, a European international agency con¬
cerned with the traffic control problems arising from the increasing use of
high-flying, high-speed jet aircraft. Set up in 1963 it provides control at the
higher flight levels for civil aircraft and for military aircraft operating accor¬
ding to civil procedures.
From 1st January 1971 all new types of subsonic aircraft using British airports
are required to hold a ‘certificate of quietness’. The noise standards laid down
in the certificate follow the recommendations of the special meeting on air-
Organisation
Finance
Postal Services

craft noise held by the International Civil Aviation Organisation in Montreal
in 1969.
Noise abatement measures in force at Heathrow and Gatwick airports
include limitations on noise levels at take off, route restrictions, procedures
designed to lessen noise on the ground, and at Heathrow a limit on the
number of jet movements during summer nights.
THE POST OFFICE
The Post Office, founded in 1657, provides the postal and public telecom¬
munications services of the United Kingdom. It was formally set up as a
public authority under the Post Office Act 1969, having been a government
department.
The Post Office, previously controlled by the Postmaster General, is now
headed by a chairman and board, appointed by and responsible to the
Minister of Posts and Telecommunications. It has some 420,000 employees
and approaching 25,000 post offices.
The Post Office has authority to borrow up to £2,300 million. At 31st March
1970 it had borrowed £1,921 million. Over 90 per cent of total expenditure
on fixed assets is accounted for by telecommunications. The postal, tele¬
communications and data processing services are now managed separately.
In 1968-69 there was a profit of ^44 3 million, a profit for telecommunications
being partially offset by a loss of £5-8 million on postal services.
The development of postal communications in Britain can be traced from
the time when horsemen carried dispatches to the Tudor Court up to modern
airmail transport. The first dispatch of mails by train was made in 1830
between Liverpool and Manchester. The inauguration of the penny post
(the uniform charge for any inland distance being prepaid by means of postage
stamps, which originated in Britain) in 1840 was followed by a rapid exten¬
sion of the scope of the postal services. The registered post, ensuring addi¬
tional safety for valuable mail, was introduced in 1841. The money order
system, which had operated as a private venture from 1792 to 1838, was
supplemented in 1881 by the issue of postal orders for fixed amounts. Letter¬
boxes had been instituted in London in 1855, and in 1883 the parcel post was
introduced. In 1919 the Post Office inaugurated its own motor transport
fleet and the first mail was carried by air in Britain in 1911.
Approaching 11,000 million items of correspondence are carried annually
by the inland postal services. Each year about 7,500 tons of mail are carried
by air within the United Kingdom. Out of the 575 million items of overseas
mail carried in 1969-70, 68-2 per cent was carried by air, compared with
56 per cent in 1959-60. The air parcel service now operates to all countries
in Europe and to over 190 countries outside Europe.
Several new highly mechanised sorting office buildings were opened in
1969 and 1970. About £40 million will be spent on letter coding and automatic
letter-sorting machines. Letter segregating and facing machines are being
installed at over 60 centres. Postal address coding is being continuously
extended, and will cover over 10 million addresses by the end of 1970; the
remainder of Britain’s 18 million addresses are to be included by mid-1972.
A two-tier letter service was introduced in 1968 consisting of a more highly
priced service for first-class mail and a cheaper one for less urgent items. Some
£50 million is being invested in an improved parcels service.

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
A Postal Consultancy Service offers facilities to overseas countries to aid
them in the planning and mechanisation of their services.
At the post office counter, besides making use of its postal and telegraph
facilities, the citizen can draw his pension and his family allowance, buy a
licence for his dog, sound radio or television receiving set, renew his car
licence and buy national insurance stamps. He can also use the wide range of
facilities for savings and investments (see p. 373) offered by the Department
for National Savings, and the money transmission services of the National
Giro. In much of the work at its counters the Post Office acts as agent for
other government departments or local authorities.
All private telegraph systems in Britain were transferred to the control of
the Postmaster General in 1870. Teleprinter-working for the transmission
of inland telegrams was introduced generally in 1928 and conversion to the
present automatic switching system was completed in mid-1954. It is now
one of the most up-to-date systems in the world and gives direct connection
between any of the 350 or so larger telegraph offices. The overseas telegraph
services were shared until 1950 between the Post Office and Cable and
Wireless Ltd. This company was brought into public ownership in 1947.
The Post Office, which acquired the British services, operates all overseas
telegraph services from the United Kingdom, except those offered by foreign
telegraph companies. Cable and Wireless Ltd. continues to operate its cable
and wireless services in many dependencies and foreign countries.
Telegraph services to overseas countries are operated from Electra House in
London, the world’s largest overseas telegraph office, and from nine other
London and provincial area telegraph offices. Direct connection via the Centex
system between these British offices and the larger towns in Belgium, France,
Federal Republic of Germany, Holland, Luxembourg, Italy and Norway
minimises delivery delay. In addition, the Post Office is well to the fore in the
development of telegraph message relay techniques for services beyond Europe.
The Telex Service (opened in England in 1932) combines the speed of the
telephone with the accuracy of the printed word. Calls may be made direct
between the rapidly increasing number of telex users in Britain (about 29,000
by the end of 1969) and also to well over 300,000 subscribers throughout the
world. Britain is linked to over 140 countries by telex. For call charging
purposes Britain is divided into 50 charging areas, each with its own telex
centre. The United Kingdom telex service is fully automatic and immediate
connection is made by direct dialling to any subscriber in this country, and to
many subscribers in Europe, New Zealand, the United States, Canada and
Australia. Calls to countries without an automatic service are connected
through the International Telex Exchange in London. Inland and overseas
telex traffic is growing annually by about 20 per cent; the Post Office is plan¬
ning for a system of about 140,000 United Kingdom subscribers by 1980.
A radioteleprinter service extends the use of telex to ships at sea (see p. 357).
The demand for facilities enabling digital data for computers to be trans¬
mitted over telephone and telegraph lines has greatly increased; to meet it
the Post Office has developed a range of datel services providing for trans¬
mission at speeds of up to 50 bits per second over telegraph-type circuits
and up to 2,400 bits per second over speech-type circuits. Higher speeds
can be accommodated by special arrangement. Datel facilities are available
to a number of European countries and over speech-type circuits to the
