355
Telephone
Services
Special Teleph
Services
United States. In the year ending March 1970 the number of British datel
terminals more than doubled to some 8,700.
When the Post Office bought the property of the National Telephone Com¬
pany in 1912 it became the owner of almost the whole telephone service.
Hull Corporation was the only municipality to exercise its option of operating
its own service under licence from the Postmaster General; this service is
connected to the Post Office trunk network.
At the end of March 1970 there were 6,110 local telephone exchanges and
13 million telephones. On that date, only 103 exchanges remained to be
changed to automatic working. New exchanges are being opened at a rapid
rate—one or two a month in London. Trunk dialling by subscribers (STD)
began in Bristol in December 1958; by March 1970 the facility had been
extended to 2,738 exchanges, serving 86 per cent of all subscribers. STD
brings the advantages of quicker service, automatic accounting and cheap
long-distance calls of short duration. Telephones in London and five other
large cities have been given all-figure numbers in which exchange names
are replaced by figures, to facilitate handling of rapidly expanding domestic
and international traffic.
The first operational electronic exchange in Europe was opened at Amber-
gate, Derbyshire, in December 1966. All new small and medium-sized
exchanges are being ordered as electronic exchanges. Similar equipment for
larger exchanges has been developed and tested.
Pulse code modulation systems are being used to increase the circuit
capacity of lines on short-distance routes between exchanges. Over 231
should be installed by the end of 1970. A new time-division electronic
switching system for interconnecting routes equipped with pulse code modu¬
lation systems has been used experimentally.
International subscriber dialling operates between London, Edinburgh,
Birmingham, Glasgow, Liverpool, Manchester, and most of Western Europe.
The first major international subscriber dialling service in the world was
opened in 1970 between London and New York; it will be extended during
1971 to other parts of Britain and North America. Britain has two automatic
international telephone exchanges in use and a third under construction.
It is expected that by 1975 70 per cent of international calls will be dialled,
compared with 50 per cent in 1970.
Operator-connected calls are handled at the London Continental Exchange,
from which well over 2,000 direct telephone circuits give service to European
countries, and at the London International Exchange, which has direct links
via the transatlantic and Commonwealth cable networks, communications
satellites and high frequency radio to over 70 countries. Almost every country
can be reached from these two exchanges, via intermediate points where
necessary.
A radio tower, 620 feet (189 metres) high, in London provides microwave
radio links for carrying long-distance telephone and television circuits. There
are over 100 Post Office communications masts and towers in use, including a
tower of 500 feet (152 metres) in Birmingham.
one Several specialised services are available by telephone, including the ‘999’
emergency dialling service enabling subscribers to be connected as quickly
as possible, and free of charge, to the police, ambulance or fire brigade
services. A public radio telephone service operating in London and South
Lancashire enables users of vehicles fitted with suitable equipment to make
356 BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
or receive calls to or from any telephone in the United Kingdom network.
Recorded information services include: the speaking clock, weather forecasts,
motoring information, ‘Test match’ cricket scores, Financial Times share
index and ‘Dial a Disc’. In London a recorded service provides details in
five languages of events taking place, and a similar service, in English only, is
provided in Edinburgh during the Summer.

There are over 100,000 private circuit stations not connected with the public
exchange networks. These are associated with circuits rented for private use
for telephone conversations, teleprinter connections, photo-telegraphy, tele¬
vision, music, or for the transmission of signals which represent data for
computers or operate other devices.
Submarine The first transatlantic telephone cable, TAT 1, connecting Britain with Canada
Cables and the United States, was laid in 1956. Many submarine telephone cables
have been laid in succeeding years. Cable and Wireless Ltd., in co-operation
with the Post Office, carried out a comprehensive Commonwealth telephone
cable plan. The plan was agreed upon in 1958, and covered the construction
of three long-distance telephone cable systems: CANTAT (2,100 nautical
miles), from Scotland to Canada, was opened in 1961; COMP AC (8,130
nautical miles), connecting Canada, Hawaii, Fiji, New Zealand and Australia,
opened in 1963; and SEACOM (7,070 nautical miles), connecting Australia,
New Guinea, Guam, Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore, was completed
in stages from 1965 to 1967 and opened as a complete system in March 1967.
All three can provide 80 telephone circuits throughout, apart from the heavily
used section of SEACOM between Guam and Australia, which can provide
160. The submarine cables are linked overland across Canada and Australia
by radio microwave systems. CANTAT was the first single-cable ocean
telephone system to use the new lightweight cable and rigid two-way re¬
peaters, both developed by the Post Office.
Submarine cable systems using transistors in place of thermionic valves
have been developed by British manufacturers in consultation with the Post
Office Research Station and are used in many new systems. High capacity
submarine cable systems capable of providing 1,800 telephone circuits have
now been developed and the first systems will be brought into service during
1971.
There are 350 underwater cables in the national network, totalling over
2,000 miles (3,200 kilometres).
Satellite
Communica¬
tions
The Goonhilly satellite communication earth station in Cornwall was brought
into operation in 1962, and took part in the first experiments in satellite
communications using the Telstar and Relay satellites. After major extensions
and improvements, including the installation of a second large aerial, the
station now provides commercial telephone and television circuits via high-
capacity, geo-stationary satellites positioned over the Atlantic and Indian
Oceans. By May 1970 Britain had satellite links with 17 countries via 11
earth stations. By the end of 1971 services to 34 countries will have been
established via 25 earth stations, and a third large aerial at Goonhilly should
be nearing completion. The satellites used in the global communications
systems are provided by INTELSAT (International Communications
Satellite Consortium) of which Britain is the second largest shareholder.
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
357
In addition to the radio stations for overseas telecommunications, the Post
Office has n coast radio stations in the United Kingdom. These stations
provide radiotelegraph and radiotelephone communications with ships at sea
at ranges of up to some 500 miles (800 kilometres) and 250 miles (400 kilo¬
metres) respectively. There is also the long-distance radiotelegraph and radio¬
telephone station, Portishead Radio, which communicates with ships in all
parts of the world; facilities were improved in 1970.
These coast stations play an important part in the services concerned with
safety of life at sea. They keep continuous watch on the international radio¬
telegraph and radiotelephone frequencies for distress calls from ships or
aircraft and take immediate action to obtain assistance for any vessel in
distress. During 1969-70 the stations handled 507 urgent and SOS calls
from ships and aircraft.
In addition to the services for safety of life at sea, the stations exchange
radiotelegrams with ships and connect radiotelephone calls between telephone
subscribers ashore and suitably equipped ships; they also broadcast naviga¬
tional warnings and weather bulletins.
The stations operate a free medical advice service whereby the master of a
ship of any nationality may obtain advice from appropriate medical authorities
on the treatment to be given in cases of sickness or injury aboard ship. During
1969-70, 444 medical cases were dealt with in this service.
An Act passed in 1967 enabled the Post Office to offer its data processing
facilities developed for its own use to commerce and industry. Through the
National Data Processing Service it provides a range of commercial computer
services, from simple card punching operations to complete systems covering
development, programming and processing at one of the Post Office computer
centres.
The Post Office is spending nearly £11 million a year on research and
development, in collaboration with industry and the universities. A new
£8 million research centre is being built at Martlesham Heath, Suffolk, to
replace the centre at Dollis Hill.
14 FINANCE
PUBLIC FINANCE
Public finance is concerned with the way public authorities (that is, the
central Government and local authorities) finance their activities—how their
expenditure is decided upon and how their revenue is obtained.
Money administered by public authorities1 can be roughly divided into:
1. The funds of the central Government raised mainly by taxation which are
paid into and out of the Consolidated Fund in accordance with the
proposals of the Government as approved by Parliament (principally the
House of Commons). Additional central Government funds are raised by
borrowing and are paid into the National Loans Fund set up under the
National Loans Fund Act 1968.2
There are also funds administered for special purposes by central
Government departments and wholly or partially maintained by receipts
which do not pass through the Consolidated Fund. The most important
one is the National Insurance Fund, administered by the Secretary of
State for Social Services and used for the payment of benefits under the
National Insurance Scheme.
2. The funds of local authorities, obtained partly from rates (local taxes on
dwelling-houses and other real estate) and income from property and
trading receipts, partly from grants and loans from the central Government
and partly from loans raised in the open market (see p. 74).
The following broad account of government finance is concerned mainly
with central Government taxation and borrowing and only incidentally with
local government and other public funds.
Financial control, as exercised by the House of Commons, is based on law,
parliamentary rights and custom.
As the power of Parliament grew in late medieval and Tudor times, the
principle that taxation by the Crown required parliamentary consent was
gradually evolved. The principle was established, at the end of the constitu¬
tional struggles of the Stuart period, by the Bill of Rights 1689.
In medieval, Tudor and Stuart times, it is broadly true to say that once the
king was granted the right to raise a given sum by taxation, he was free to
spend it as he chose. In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, the House of
Commons gradually developed the modern system of controlling expenditure
through the device of Appropriation which was embodied in the Exchequer
and Audit Departments Act 1866. But by a Standing Order of the House of
Commons dating from the early eighteenth century the Crown’s consent is
required for all proposals involving new spending from the Consolidated Fund.
The House of Commons cannot, therefore, initiate expenditure, which must be
proposed by a Minister.
From the very early days of Parliament it had been established that such
1 For an account of public finance in Northern Ireland and its relationship to that of
the United Kingdom, see pp. 368.
2 Prior to April 1968 the funds from both these sources were paid into the Exchequer.
The term ‘Exchequer’ took its name from the ‘chess-board’, or table with chequered
cloth, round which the King’s financial officials sat for accounting purposes in the
twelfth century.

FINANCE
359
financial control as Parliament possessed should be exercised by the House of
Commons. This control became effective, as regards taxation, in the seven¬
teenth century, but as regards expenditure it was not effective until the
nineteenth century. The controlling power of the House of Commons is
acknowledged today in the Speech from the Throne at the opening of a new
session of Parliament, which is addressed to both Houses but contains a
special paragraph on expenditure addressed to the Commons alone.
The Commons have traditionally claimed that the Lords have no power to
modify financial provisions, though they may reject such provisions, thus,
to minimise the chance of rejection, the practice was started in 1861 of
embodying the main financial provisions for the ensuing year in a single Bill.
Since the passing of the Parliament Act 1911, however, if the Finance Bill is
certified by the Speaker to be a Money Bill, it may be presented to the Queen
for the Royal Assent and become law without the consent of the House of
Lords if it has not been passed by them within one month (see p. 38).
Today, the authority of the House of Commons has to be obtained for all
expenditure by the central Government itself and for the raising of revenue
by taxation or borrowing. All government revenue, other than the proceeds of
borrowing and sums received by government departments in the course of
their normal activities (known as appropriations-in-aid), is paid into an
account with the Bank of England (known as the Account of Her Majesty s
Exchequer) which forms the Consolidated Fund. With certain exceptions (the
main ones being government loans and national insurance benefits), all
payments by the Government come out of this account.
The following sections outline the machinery by which expenditure and
revenue are authorised and controlled, the purposes on which public money
is spent and the sources from which revenue is obtained.
ESTIMATES AND
EXPENDITURE
Classification of
Expenditure
Central government expenditure falls into three main groups:
1. The main part of government expenditure which is authorised by annual
Appropriation Acts and includes, broadly, expenditure on defence, on the
social services and on the general administration of the country. These are
called Supply Services because the House of Commons, when voting
money, is granting to the Crown ‘such aids or supplies as are required to
satisfy ... the pecuniary necessities of the Government’. It should be
noted that some of this expenditure may also depend on legislation, such
as the National Health Service Acts, which relates to a specific object of
expenditure.
2. Expenditure which is specifically authorised by Acts of Parliament other
than annual Appropriation Acts. These are the Consolidated Fund
Standing Services which represent a direct charge on the Consolidated
Fund, covering the residual cost of servicing the National Debt,1 the
financial provision made for members of the royal family, and salaries and
pensions of judges and certain high officers, such as the Speaker of the
House of Commons and the Leader of the Opposition, whose indepen¬
dence of the Government is thought to be better guaranteed by permanent
grant than by annual vote. This group also includes expenditure from the
National Insurance and similar special funds.
1 The servicing of the National Debt is charged in the first instance to the National
Loans Fund. After taking account of certain receipts by the Fund, including interest
received on loans to nationalised industries and local authorities, the residue is charged
to the Consolidated Fund.
36°
Authorisation
of Expenditure
Scrutiny of
Expenditure
The Treasury
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
3. Government lending and debt, which under the National Loans Act 1968
are channelled through the National Loans Fund. These include most of
the Government’s domestic lending to the nationalised industries, local
authorities and public corporations as well as the principal repayments and
the servicing (that is, interest and expenses) of the National Debt.
The Estimates for the Supply Services are considered by the House of
Commons during the 29 days (known as Supply days) which are allotted by
Standing Order of the House to consideration of Supply business in each
session. The choice of subject for debate on these days rests with the
Opposition. The House usually discusses general questions of policy relevant
to the Estimates, though any Estimate may be examined in detail if members
wish and if time allows (see p. 40).
Estimates for Supply Services in the financial year beginning on 1st April
are submitted to the Treasury by each department in the preceding December.
Estimated expenditure is grouped under main headings called ‘Votes’ which
are further broken down into subheads and items. If the House of Commons
approves the Estimates, the sums asked for are voted and later confirmed in
the Appropriation Act; this Act appropriates the money to specific Votes.
No department may spend money granted on one Vote for the purposes of
another. Within each Vote, ‘virement’, that is, the spending of money on one
subhead instead of on another, is permissible so far as Parliament is con¬
cerned, but only with Treasury consent.
An insufficient Estimate, or a new service not covered by the Vote, or
virement of a magnitude or character which the Treasury considers should be
brought to the attention of Parliament, requires a Supplementary Estimate.
The Treasury exercises the same power of scrutiny over this as over the
ordinary Estimates.
Control of expenditure is maintained by the Treasury, by the Comptroller
and Auditor General, and by the Public Accounts and Estimates Committees
of the House of Commons.
The power of the Treasury to control expenditure derives from the responsi¬
bility of the Chancellor of the Exchequer for financial policy.
A central function of the Treasury is to present the Estimates to the House
of Commons. In considering the Estimates submitted by departments,
the Treasury has to look at the proposals for expenditure in relation to the
results of the public expenditure surveys (see below); and to eliminate any
overlapping, uneconomic or wasteful expenditure where this has escaped the
net of departmental financial control. Apart from the scrutiny of Estimates,
throughout the year the Treasury exercises a general supervision over all
departmental expenditure. The Treasury also lays down general rules of
financial and accounting procedure for departments and prescribes the
principles on which departmental contracts shall be made and the limits
within which certain classes of losses may be written off.
In 1961 the Plowden Committee on the Control of Public Expenditure
recommended in its report (Cmnd. 1432) that regular surveys should be
made of public expenditure as a whole over a period of years ahead and in
relation to prospective resources, and that decisions involving future expendi¬
ture should be taken in the light of these surveys. Surveys, therefore, are now
made annually and have become an established part of the Government’s
machinery for the planning and control of public expenditure (see p. 235).

The Comptroller
and Auditor
General
The Public Accounts
Committee
The Estimates
Committee
361
Proposals for changes in the presentation and the procedures for consideration
by Parliament of public expenditure estimates were published in April 1969.
A White Paper (the first of an annual series) prepared in accordance with these
new proposals was published in December 1969 {Public Expenditure ig68-6g
to ig73~74, see Bibliography, p. 486) which set out the Government’s plans
for public expenditure in detail for 1969-70 and the following two years and
its allocations of expenditure on a provisional and approximate basis for
1972-73 and I973-74-
These plans and allocations covered all public expenditure—the capital and
current expenditure of central and local government and the capital expendi¬
ture of the nationalised industries and other public corporations. They gave
expression to the Government’s policy that expenditure on public services
should expand throughout the period broadly in line with the growth of the
nation’s resources. The assumption adopted was that the annual rate of growth
of national resources would be close to 3 per cent, the lower end of the range
of rates envisaged in Government planning documents (see p. 235).
Control over issues of money to departments and the audit of accounts is
exercised by the Comptroller and Auditor General, which is a permanent
Crown appointment. Since 1866 he has had two functions: as Comptroller he
controls receipts and issues of public money to and from the Consolidated
Fund and the National Loans Fund; and as Auditor General he audits
departmental accounts and submits his report on the Appropriation Accounts
and other accounts, as required by statute, to Parliament. His statutory
function is to ensure that all expenditure is properly incurred, for example,
that no payments are made which go beyond any relevant statutory authority,
and that Treasury sanction has been obtained wherever necessary. In addition,
however, he has been encouraged by successive Public Accounts Committees
(see the next paragraph) to examine departmental expenditure with a view to
drawing attention to any cases of apparent waste or extravagance.
The accounts of each department and the reports on the accounts made by
the Comptroller and Auditor General are considered by a select committee
called the Public Accounts Committee. This was first set up in 1861, on the
motion of Mr. Gladstone, for the purpose of ensuring that expenditure was
properly incurred in accordance with the purpose for which it was voted and
with any relevant Acts of Parliament. The terms of reference of the committee
are to examine the accounts and these terms have been widely interpreted by
successive committees which have investigated whether full value has been
obtained for the sums spent by departments and have examined cases in which
the administration appears to have been faulty or negligent. The committee
has therefore become a powerful instrument for the exposure of waste and
inefficiency. It embodies its findings in reports which may be debated in the
House of Commons. Its recommendations are considered by the Treasury
in consultation with departments and put into effect, so far as they are
accepted, according to Treasury instructions. A reply to each report is sub¬
mitted by the Treasury to the committee of the following session and where
the recommendations have been unacceptable to the Treasury the committee
may either accept the objections or return to the charge in subsequent reports.
This committee was originally set up in 1912 and has been reappointed
annually except during the war years. In i960 it was made a select committee
set up each session under standing orders. The committee’s functions are
to examine the Estimates, to report how, if at all, the policy implied in the
Estimates can be carried out more economically and to consider the principal
362
THE BUDGET
Budget Policy
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
variations between the Estimates of the current year and those of the previous
year and the form in which the Estimates should be presented. Usually, the
committee selects each year a few Votes for review.
Through the medium of a number of sub-committees, the committee carries
out extensive investigations into the departments or subjects under considera¬
tion. In practice the Estimates for the current year are not affected, but the
committee’s recommendations produce changes in future Estimates and
strengthen Treasury control. One of these sub-committees examines the
winter and spring Supplementary Estimates and the principal variations
between the Estimates presented and those of the previous year. The other
sub-committees are organised on functional lines, each sub-committee being
allocated a different sphere of government policy and administration. Addi¬
tional parliamentary time has been allocated for discussion of the reports of
the Estimates and the Public Accounts Committees.
‘Budget’ is an old word meaning a bag containing papers or accounts. The
use of the word in public finance originated in the expression ‘The Chancellor
of the Exchequer opened his Budget’, v/hich is applied in Parliament to the
annual speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer explaining his proposals for
balancing revenue and expenditure.
The annual Budget speech is normally the main occasion of the year for
reviewing the central Government’s finances and the economic state of the
nation, and its formal basis is the Chancellor’s proposals for raising money by
taxation. In recent years it has become the practice for Chancellors to discuss
in the Budget speech the prospects for the economy in the period ahead in
some detail. By the time the Budget is introduced (usually in April) the
Estimates of expenditure under various headings will have been presented to
Parliament and published, and the expected total of government expenditure
for the year will be known. The Chancellor estimates the yield of the revenue
on the basis of existing taxation and proposes such changes in taxation as he
considers desirable on economic grounds. These proposals are later embodied
in detail in a Finance Bill. The interval between the Budget Statement and the
Royal Assent to the Finance Bill (usually given in July) is covered by legisla¬
tion (mainly the Provisional Collection of Taxes Act 1968), whereby changes
in income tax, corporation tax, purchase tax, selective employment tax and
customs and excise duties have statutory effect before the passing of the
Finance Bill if adopted by Resolution of the House of Commons.
The Budget also takes into account the finance needed to cover government
lending. Details for the years 1967-68 to 1970-71 were given in a White Paper,
Loans from the National Loan Fund igyo-yi, issued on Budget day. For
1970-71 it is estimated that rather more than one-third of the net issues from
this Fund would be loans to nationalised industries; more than a half would
be loans to local and harbour authorities; and the remainder loans to other
public corporations, the private sector, and certain advances within the central
Government.
The original purpose of the Budget was purely financial—to provide money
for government expenditure. From an early stage, however, it was appreciated
that taxation would affect the distribution of income and property and the
level of expenditure on particular goods and services. At a later period it was
realised that taxation also affected the nation’s total expenditure and therefore
the general level of economic activity. Since the second world war, Budgets
Sources of
Revenue
Income Tax
FINANCE 363
have been consciously designed in greater or lesser degree to bring the total
demand for goods and services into balance with total national output.
The Budget affects the general level of expenditure and, therefore, the total
demand for goods and services in the following way: if there is an increase in
government expenditure without an increase in taxation then total demand for
goods and services will tend to rise; the same thing will happen if there is a
decrease in taxation without a decrease in government spending. In this way
the Budget can be used to counter unemployment. On the other hand, if
there is an increase in taxation without an increase in government expenditure,
or a decrease in government expenditure without a decrease in taxation then
the total demand for goods and services will tend to fall. Particular taxes may
be used with the intention of bringing about certain desired effects. For
example, taxes on income and capital affect the distribution of wealth because
the rates vary according to the size of the income or capital, the proportion of
a high income or capital taken in tax being much greater than the proportion
of a small one; while taxes on expenditure may influence the allocation of
resources and the pattern of trade by discouraging or encouraging the con¬
sumption of particular goods.
The main objectives of British budgetary policy in recent years have been
the achievement and maintenance of a strong balance of payments together
with a sustained rate of economic growth and a high level of employment. In
order to regulate demand more closely, successive governments have adopted
a much more flexible attitude towards fiscal policy and have not hesitated to
use budgetary measures between annual Budgets. At the same time considera¬
tion is given to the long-term strategy for taxation and to ways in which the
existing system of taxation can be improved by ensuring that its incidence is
fair. Against a background of substantial improvement in Britain’s balance of
payments position the 197° Budget was designed to maintain the strength of
the balance of payments and to guide the economy into steadily increasing
growth.
In the United Kingdom the principal taxes fall into three main categories.
First, taxes on income, which include income tax, surtax and corporation tax;
second, taxes on capital, which include estate duty, capital gains tax and the
tax on short-term gains; and third, taxes on expenditure (including taxes
on the ownership or use of certain assets)—these include not only customs and
excise duties and the purchase tax, but also the selective employment tax,
local rates, stamp duties and licence duties (for example, on motor vehicles and
dogs). Taxes on individual (but not corporate) incomes are progressive taxes,
that is, larger incomes and estates bear a proportionately higher rate of tax.
The Board of Inland Revenue collects the taxes on income and capital and
the stamp duties, the Board of Customs and Excise collects the most import¬
ant taxes on expenditure, the customs and excise taxes and the purchase tax,
while a variety of authorities are responsible for the collection of the re¬
mainder, including the Department of Health and Social Security for the
selective employment tax.
Income tax is imposed at a standard rate for the year of assessment beginning
on 6th April, which is at present 41*25 per cent. The tax imposed on an
individual is graduated by means of personal allowances and reliefs, and by
the surtax. In the case of a married couple the incomes of husband and wife are
aggregated and are treated as one income, but higher allowances are given
than for a single person. A special allowance is given against any earnings of
364
Surtax
Company
Taxation
Estate Duty
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
a married woman. Earned income bears less tax than other income as certain
fractional deductions (‘earned income relief’) are allowable.
A single person earning £ 1,000 a year pays £187 in income tax, while a
married man with the same earned income pays ^129; if he has two children
under the age of 11, his tax (after taking into account the receipt of family
allowances) falls to £66; when the children are between the ages of 11 and 16,
the tax is £46; if the children are over 16 and receiving full-time education,
only £25 is paid. The range of tax payable by a single person varies from, for
example, £26 on an earned income of £500 a year to £1,516 on an earned
income of £5,000; if the income is unearned, tax liability on £500 will be £38
and on £5,000 will be £2,441.
Most wage and salary earners pay their income tax under a PAYE (‘Pay-as-
you-earn’) scheme, under which tax is deducted at source, thus enabling them
to keep up to date on tax payments.
In general, income tax is charged on all income which originates in the
United Kingdom and on all income arising abroad of persons (including
companies) resident in the United Kingdom. The main exceptions are that
interest on certain United Kingdom government securities belonging to
persons not ordinarily resident in the United Kingdom is exempt; and
income from certain classes of possessions abroad is chargeable not on the
amount of income arising but on the amount of income remitted to the United
Kingdom. The United Kingdom has entered into agreements with many
countries providing for relief from double taxation; where such agreements
are not in force unilateral relief is allowed.
The surtax, which is essentially an income tax at higher rates, is charged on
personal incomes exceeding £2,500 a year after deducting certain personal
allowances in excess of the single person’s basic allowance. In addition, the
same earned income relief as for income tax and a special earnings allowance
(not exceeding £2,000) are deductible from earned income only. Surtax is
imposed at rates which increase progressively until, on the portion of taxable
income above £15,000, the combined rate of income tax and surtax payable
in 1970-71 (being income tax for 1970-71 and surtax for 1969-70) reaches
91-25 per cent.
Companies are liable to corporation tax on both their profits and their capital
gains. In addition, a company deducts income tax from dividends and other
distributions and pays it over to the Inland Revenue as a separate matter
from its own liability. The rate of corporation tax is fixed retrospectively in the
Budget for the past financial year; for 1969-70 it is 45 per cent. The tax is
assessed on the profits of accounting periods, the rate of tax being the rate for
the financial year in which the accounting period falls. The basic rule for the
calculation of income for corporation tax purposes is that, except for special
provisions, it is computed in accordance with income tax principles.
Estate duty is chargeable on the value of all property which passes at death.
The charge to duty is not limited to property owned by the deceased but may
extend to other property, for example, to trust funds from which the deceased
received income in his lifetime and to gifts made by the deceased within
seven years of his death (one year in the case of a gift for public or charitable
purposes). Since the 1969 Budget estates not over £10,000 are exempt from
duty; but on estates of a higher value duty is chargeable by reference to rates
ranging from 25 per cent to 85 per cent applied to successive slices of the
estate.

365
Capital gains accruing on the disposal of assets are liable to capital gains tax
or, in the case of companies, to corporation tax. Where assets were acquired
before 6th April 1965, the charge is restricted to the part of any gain attribut¬
able to the period since 6th April 1965. The rate of tax for persons other than
companies is 30 per cent, but in the case of individuals may be less, depending
on their circumstances. Certain assets are exempt from tax including the
principal private residence, chattels worth less than £1,000 (and any chattels,
except those used for the purpose of a trade, with a predictable life of less than
50 years), private motor cars, National Savings Certificates and (from 15th
April 1969) British Government and Government-guaranteed securities. The
gains of an individual for a year are exempt if, after deducting losses, they do
not exceed £50. Gains arising to individuals from the disposal of assets
within 12 months of their acquisition are in general liable as short-term gains
to income tax (and surtax) and not to capital gains tax.
The largest group of taxes on expenditure are those administered by the
Customs and Excise Department, namely, the duties on tobacco, hydrocarbon
oil, alcoholic drinks, purchase tax, protective duties, betting and certain
miscellaneous items.1 In British usage the distinction between customs and
excise depends on whether the goods are imported (customs duties) or British
produced (excise duties). These taxes are sometimes known as indirect taxes
since they are normally paid by the importer, manufacturer, or wholesaler,
who adjusts the prices charged to customers accordingly. In 1970 the tax
burden was equivalent to about £0-22^ on a gallon of petrol, £0*24 on a
packet of 20 standard plain cigarettes, £2*20 on a bottle of whisky, and £0-04!
on a pint of beer of average strength.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer has power to vary by Order by up to 10
per cent the rates of purchase tax and any of the other main groups of customs
and excise duties (that is, tobacco, alcoholic drinks, oil and the minor revenue
duties). This power, known as the ‘regulator’, requires annual renewal.
Purchase tax is charged on a wide range of goods, nearly all of them consumer
goods, at four rates, which are currently 13I per cent, 22 per cent, 36! per cent
and 55 per cent of the wholesale value. Articles subject to revenue duties of
customs and excise are in general exempt from this tax; other goods free of
purchase tax include food (other than confectionery, soft drinks, ice cream and
crisps), fuel, books and newspapers, young children’s clothing and footwear,
certain non-proprietary drugs and medicines, and some household appliances.
The principal betting duties are: the pool betting duty (which applies to
football pools and betting by coupon at fixed odds) charged at a rate of 33^ per
cent of the stake money; and the general betting duty, which is charged at the
rate of 6 per cent of stake money except for on-course betting which is charged
at 5 per cent. Gaming is taxed at different rates mainly by licence fees.
Taxes on motor vehicles are collected by the local taxation authorities (the
county or county borough councils in England and Wales and the correspond¬
ing councils in Scotland); the proceeds are paid by the local authorities into
the Consolidated Fund. The licence duty on a private motor car is £25 a year;
motor cycles and three-wheel vehicles, etc., pay £2-50, £5 or £10 a year
according to engine capacity.
The selective employment tax was introduced in the 1966 Finance Act. It
is paid by all employers throughout the United Kingdom at a rate per week

CAPITAL
PAYMENTS AND
RECEIPTS
The National
Debt
PUBLIC FINANCE
IN NORTHERN
IRELAND
BRITAIN I97i: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Capital expenditure consists chiefly of loans to the nationalised industries, the
local authorities and other public corporations, such as the New Towns
Development Corporations. These loans, less repayments, are financed from
the National Loans Fund by the surplus of revenue over expenditure (if any),
by the proceeds of government borrowing including borrowing from extra-
budgetary funds, such as the National Insurance Fund, and by the sterling
receipts (if any) accruing to the Exchange Equalisation Account.
Central government borrowing may be in the form of borrowing from the
public either through the National Savings Movement (see p. 373) or by bor¬
rowing on the market by means of new issues of securities. New issues of
government securities are made from time to time for the purpose of refinan¬
cing maturing issues (conversion issues) or to raise new money (issues for
cash). The capital requirements of the nationalised industries are met by the
central Government while those of the local authorities are met partly through
the Public Works Loan Board (see p. 74) and partly by borrowing direct from
the public, although both may also now borrow, with Treasury consent, in
foreign currencies.
The National Debt increased particularly rapidly during and immediately
after the first and second world wars. It rose from £650 million in 1914 to
£7,435 million at the end of the first world war, and from £7,131 million in
I939 t0 j£23>637 million in 1946. On 31st March 1970 the total National Debt
(provisional) was £33,071 million, of which £2,232 million was repayable
in currencies other than sterling, mainly to the United States and Canadian
Governments. Of the £30,839 million of internal debt, £4,989 million was
short-term debt, mainly in the form of 91-day Treasury bills, while the long¬
term loans included a variety of stocks, bonds, loans and certificates carrying
fixed rates of interest (ranging from 2^ to 9 per cent) and with fixed or
indeterminate dates of repayment.
The general system of public finance in Northern Ireland is, in its main
features, similar to that operating in the United Kingdom as a whole, under
which public revenues, with a few minor exceptions, are paid into the
Exchequer Account, from which no money can be withdrawn except on the
authority of Parliament. That authority is expressed in the case of Consolidated
Fund charges in permanent legislative form, and in the case of Supply Services
by annual Appropriation Acts based on estimates prepared by departments
and sanctioned by the Ministry of Finance.
The major sources of revenue flowing into the Northern Ireland Exchequer
are the main national taxes imposed by the United Kingdom Parliament over
the whole country and paid, in the first instance, into the United Kingdom
Consolidated Fund. These taxes, which are referred to in the Government of
Ireland Act 1920 as ‘reserved’ taxes (that is, reserved to the United Kingdom
Parliament), comprise the Inland Revenue group (income tax, surtax,
corporation tax and capital gains tax) and customs and excise duties on goods.
After the cost of collecting these taxes in Northern Ireland (and the cost of
some other reserved services) and an Imperial Contribution have been
retained in the United Kingdom Consolidated Fund, the balance, termed the
‘Residuary Share of Reserved Taxes’, is paid to the Northern Ireland Ex¬
chequer where it joins up with the ‘transferred’ taxes (that is, where taxation
powers have been transferred to the Northern Ireland Parliament) to form the
public income. Among items of Transferred Tax Revenue are estate duties,
FINANCE 369
stamp duties, betting duties, various excise licence duties, motor vehicle duties
and selective employment tax.
A joint Exchequer Board, representative of the Treasury and the Ministry
of Finance for Northern Ireland, constituted in accordance with the Govern¬
ment of Ireland Act 1920, determines the amount of Reserved Revenue and
the cost of Reserved Services attributable to Northern Ireland for each year,
the amount of the Imperial Contribution, and such other questions affecting
the financial relations of the two Governments as may be referred to it.
In the Northern Ireland Budget for 1970-71 (year ending 31st March),
total revenues were forecast at ^373 million and expenditure at £372 million.
After allowing for the Imperial Contribution, provisionally estimated at ^1
million, there was a Budget surplus of £85,000.
The Public Debt of Northern Ireland, totalling £319 million on 31st
March 1970 is covered by repayable advances and investments held by the
Ministry of Finance.
Outside the Exchequer system in Northern Ireland, various funds have been
established, in addition to statutory Reserve and Sinking Funds, for specific
purposes. In general, these funds follow the United Kingdom pattern, the
principal funds being those relating to National Insurance and government
loans. The latter constitutes a pool of capital money available mainly for local
and public authority borrowings; on 31st March 1970 a sum of approximately
£244 million was outstanding against such borrowers.
THE CENTRAL BANK
The British banking system is long established and well integrated. It
comprises a central bank; commercial banks which carry on the usual main
banking services; the United Kingdom offices of banks whose main business
is in other countries; merchant banks and other specialised institutions.
The Bank of England was established in 1694 by Act of Parliament and
Royal Charter as a corporate body; the entire capital stock was acquired by
the Government under the Bank of England Act 1946. As the central bank,
the Bank acts as banker to the Government, to overseas central banks and to
commercial banks; it is the note-issuing authority and the registrar for some
200 government, nationalised industry, local authority, public board and
Commonwealth government stocks. As agent for the Government the Bank
administers exchange control and the voluntary arrangements to limit invest¬
ment in the more developed countries of the sterling area. On behalf of the
Treasury it manages the Exchange Equalisation Account (EEA), which holds
Britain’s official reserves of gold and foreign exchange; using the resources of
the EEA the Bank designs its interventions in the foreign exchange market
both to prevent undue fluctuations in the exchange value of sterling and to
conserve the means of making payments abroad.
As banker to the Government in the widest sense, among other things, the
Bank examines and seeks to anticipate banking and financial problems and to
undertake the appropriate operations in the money, capital and the foreign
exchange markets; consequently the Bank has a major responsibility for
advising the Government on the formulation of monetary policy and for its
subsequent execution.
In implementing monetary policy the Bank acts almost daily in the money
market, by buying or selling Treasury bills, and similarly in the market for
government stocks. A prime concern is to maintain orderly conditions and,
when necessary, the Bank also exerts influence on interest rates; an important
370
Decimal
Currency
The Deposit
Banks
BRITAIN I97i: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
instrument in this context is Bank Rate, which is the minimum rate at which
the Bank will discount approved bills of exchange for the members of the
London Discount Market or will normally lend to them; a wide range of other
short-term interest rates is related to it.
As the recognised channel of communication between the commercial banks
and other financial institutions of the City of London on the one hand,
and the Government on the other, the Bank has been called on in recent
years to administer direct control of credit. This has been achieved by means
of ‘special deposits’ which the London clearing banks and Scottish banks are
called upon to make with the Bank; through requests to the banks and other
financial institutions not to extend credit above stipulated quantitative
ceilings; and by general guidance to them on lending policy.
The Bank of England has the sole right in England and Wales of issuing
bank notes. Notes thus issued need a 100 per cent cover in gold, securities
and coin. Very little gold is now held by the Issue Department of the Bank, by
far the major part of the note issue being covered by securities and coin;
this part is the fiduciary issue, the level of which is subject to parliamentary
control. (The Scottish and Northern Ireland banks have limited rights to
issue notes; these issues, apart from an amount specified by legislation for
each bank, must be fully covered by Bank of England notes and by coin.)
The provision of coin for circulation is the responsibility of the Royal Mint,
a government department.
On Monday, 15th February 1971 (‘D Day’) the United Kingdom, under the
Decimal Currency Acts 1967 and 1969 will begin changing to a decimal
currency system which will greatly simplify calculations affecting Britain’s
domestic and external business affairs. The £ sterling is unchanged under the
new system, but instead of the old ^sd division it will be divided into 100 new
pence. The new decimal coinage has six denominations. Three of these, in
cupro-nickel, have been brought into circulation before ‘D Day’: the lop and
5p (equivalent to 2s. and is. respectively) in 1968 and the 50p (equivalent to
10s.) in 1969. Three bronze coins—the 2p, ip and £p (equivalent to 4*8d.,
2-4d. and i-2d. respectively) will be issued on ‘D Day’.
‘D Day’ will be followed by a changeover period of not more than 18
months, during which it will be legal to conduct business (except banking) in
either ^sd or ^p and during which businesses will change over to the decimal
system on their own selected date (mainly because of the machine conversion
problem). Pennies and threepenny bits will remain legal tender during the
changeover period, and the sixpence will remain legal tender for at least two
years from ‘D Day’.
On and from ‘D Day’ all banking documents, including cheques, will have
to be written in decimal currency, and income tax and social security benefits
and deductions will be decimalised. The Post Office and a large number of
shops and businesses will also change over at once. It is expected that about
three-quarters of the nation’s business will be transacted in decimals in a
matter of weeks with the large firms leading the way.
BANKING AND PRIVATE FINANCE
The primary business of the deposit banks is the receipt, transfer and encash¬
ment of deposits. The principal deposit banks are the six London clearing
banks, four Scottish banks and two Northern Ireland banks. Recent mergers
have resulted in the formation of six banking groups, four based in London
FINANCE
371
and two in Scotland. When they have been completed there will be three
Scottish banks. The two Northern Ireland banks are owned by London
clearing banks, but two groups of banks based in the Republic of Ireland
also operate in Northern Ireland.
At the end of 1969 current and deposit accounts with the deposit banks
operating in Britain amounted to over -£1 i,8oo million, and accounted for
just under half of the total deposits (in sterling and foreign currencies) of the
banking sector, which also includes the National Giro, the accepting houses,
overseas banks, other banks and the discount market. The deposit banks
provide full hanking services throughout Britain, operating through over
14,000 branches at the end of 1969; several have interests in British overseas
and Commonwealth banks, and in other banks which have been formed
specially to compete in international markets. They have also acquired
substantial interests in hire-purchase finance houses, and some have set up
their own unit trusts.
Together with the Bank of England the London clearing banks make up
the membership of the London Bankers’ Clearing House. In 1969 cheques,
drafts, bills and bankers’ effects passing through the clearing system averaged
in value £58,266 million monthly, while the average monthly value of the
credit transfer clearing was £1,137 million.
Current account balances with the deposit banks are repayable on demand
and no interest is paid on them, but on deposit account balances interest is
paid at a rate generally 2 per cent below Bank Rate. The London clearing
banks maintain a ratio of about 8 per cent between cash reserves and total
deposits. It is also a convention among the London clearing banks that at
least 28 per cent of deposits should be held in the form of liquid assets.
The banks’ profits are largely earned through their advances to customers
partly in the form of overdrafts and partly in the form of loans (with or
without collateral security); these are normally for a short term only unless
renewed. The ratio of London clearing bank advances to total deposits
declined from about 43 per cent in 1938 to 17 per cent at the end of the
second world war but it has since risen and in July 1970 it was around 57 Per
cent. In recent years the banks have several times been asked to restrain the
growth of their lending and to ensure that, within the total, priority is given
to finance for exports and for productive investment in manufacturing industry
and agriculture: this has involved the restriction of advances to the personal
sector. In the 1970 Budget, while the priorities for lending remained un¬
changed, a modest relaxation was announced in the quantitative control over
lending and a gradual and moderate increase was envisaged over the next
12 months. The banks’ ‘liquid’ assets, that is, those that are quickly realisable,
are their loans to discount houses (money at call), and their holdings of
Treasury and commercial bills and certain export and shipbuilding credits
refinanceable with the Bank of England: they also hold a proportion of their
assets as portfolio (mainly British Government securities) or trade invest¬
ments.
The bank giro, originally introduced as the credit transfer scheme, and the
direct debiting system, by which a creditor with the prior approval of the
debtor may claim money due to him direct from the latter’s banking account,
have helped to improve the money transmission services. Another fairly
recent banking innovation has been the introduction by some banks of
automatic cash dispensing machines, which allow customers to obtain cash
at any time. Credit cards have become increasingly popular for the settlement
of accounts in retail shops. Cheque cards, which enable the card holder to
372

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
cash a cheque not exceeding ^30 at any office of the major British and Irish
banks, are also becoming more widely used.
There are also some 36 British overseas and Commonwealth banks, many of
them having their headquarters in London. They provide a comprehensive
banking service in many parts of the world and engage in the financing of
trade not only between Britain and other countries but also between third
countries. There are also currently in London about 32 United States banks,
13 Japanese banks and over 80 other foreign banks.
The Post Office National Giro was opened in October 1968 to provide a
low-cost current account banking and money transfer service which can be
operated through most post offices in Britain. All accounts and transactions
are maintained by means of a computer complex at the National Giro Centre
at Bootle, near Liverpool. Giro now has more than 200,000 accounts, one-
sixth of which are business accounts. In April 1970 a scheme was introduced
to make available personal loans from a finance company for credit-worthy
Giro customers. In May 1970 a scheme was begun to encourage the payment
of wages through Giro.
The merchant banks have helped to give London an international reputation
as a world financial centre for short-term and long-term borrowing. They
are of two kinds, and are known as accepting houses and issuing houses
according to whether they specialise predominantly in the work of acceptance
credit1 or in transactions involving the sponsoring of capital issues on behalf
of their customers. They arrange to issue and themselves underwrite long-
and short-term loans to governments of, or enterprises in, overseas countries
in sterling (where permitted by exchange control regulations) or in other
currencies which have been deposited with them; this latter type of trans¬
action, in what are called the euro-dollar markets, has increased considerably
in recent years. They are also engaged in the work of the gold and foreign
exchange markets, and they have many other functions in connection with the
financing of trade, investment management and insurance.
The London discount or money market is a distinctive part of the British
banking system. It consists of 11 discount houses and its principal function
is to marry the needs of lenders of money for short periods with those of the
borrowers of such money.
The discount houses borrow ‘at call’ from banks and other financial
institutions at a relatively low rate of interest. To them the Bank of England
acts as a lender of last resort. The clearing banks do not borrow money
directly from the Bank of England; if they need to add to their cash resources
they call in part of their loans to the discount market. If, as a result, any
particular discount house is unable to cover its needs for cash elsewhere, it is
obliged to borrow from the Bank of England, normally at Bank Rate for
seven days, but the Bank may charge a higher rate and has also at times lent
overnight, or for short periods, at the rates of interest prevailing in the market.
An important part of the money borrowed by the discount houses is
invested in British Government Treasury bills. The discount houses accept as
1 Acceptance credit has been defined as fundamentally a three-month operation
financing exports from and imports to Britain and to other markets. The expression is
derived from the method of financing trade by which commercial bills are ‘accepted’
or guaranteed by a merchant bank against documents, after which they may be
discounted for cash by a discount house.

an informal responsibility that they should cover the Government’s need to
borrow on Treasury bills, which are offered on tender each week. The clearing
banks do not buy Treasury bills at the weekly tenders except on behalf of
customers, but they purchase, from the discount market, bills which are of a
maturity required by them.
The discount houses provide a specialised market in commercial bills and
in short-dated Government bonds (that is, those with not more than five years
to run before repayment), local authority bonds, and certain other negotiable
instruments.
The National Savings Movement started in 1916 to help finance the war by
promoting savings. The present movement encourages the widespread invest¬
ment of savings in Trustee Savings Banks and the National Savings Bank
(see p. 374), formerly known as the Post Office Savings Bank, and in National
Savings securities. The movement is led by the National Savings Committee
for England and Wales and similar committees for Scotland and Northern
Ireland.1 The committees are bodies of independent persons representing
regional savings organisations and various national institutions connected

The administration of the National Savings Bank and other forms of national
savings is carried out by the Department for National Savings. Four forms
of National Savings securities are currently on sale: the National Savings
Certificate, the British Savings Bond,2 and the Premium Savings Bond and

BRITAIN 1971: an OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
National Savings Stamps and Gift Tokens. National Savings Certificates, in
units of £1, are encashable at par at any time; interest, which is free of income
tax, surtax and capital gains tax is only paid on encashment; the limit on
individual holdings is 500 units of the current issue. British Savings Bonds,
sold in units of ^5 with a maximum holding of 10,000, bear interest at 7 Per
cent and are repayable at par on one month s notice. If the Bonds are held to
maturity (five years from the date of purchase) they are repaid with a bonus of
£2 per cent tax free. Premium Savings Bonds are in units of £1 and individual
holdings are limited to £1,250. After a qualifying period of three months the
bonds give investors a chance to win tax-free prizes instead of receiving
interest. There is now a weekly draw for a prize of £25,000 and a monthly
draw for prizes ranging from £25 to £5,000. At the end of August iQ?0*
£782*8 million was invested in this form of savings. A selection of British
Government securities is held on the National Savings Register and can also
be bought or sold through the Bonds and Stock Office. Trustee Savings Banks
also deal in stock on the National Savings Register.
A contractual savings scheme was announced in the 1969 Budget for
introduction in October 1969. Known as Save as You Earn (SAYE), it
enables savings to be made in regular monthly amounts within a minimum of
£1 and a maximum of £10 in deposits with the Department for National
Savings or Trustee Savings Banks by means of deductions from pay or by
other regular payments. At the end of five years, savings will qualify for a
bonus equivalent to one year’s savings free of tax. Completed savings which
are not withdrawn will qualify for a double bonus at the end of seven years,
that is, two years’ savings. For example, contributions totalling £60 payable
over five years at a rate of £1 per month will qualify for a bonus of £12 at the
end of that period, or £24 if left on deposit for a further two years. Savers who
wish to stop payments will be able to withdraw the total sum saved (but there
cannot be partial withdrawals). Tax-free compound interest will be paid at the
rate of 3-^ per cent on amounts withdrawn after the first but before the end of
the fifth year, or at 4^ per cent where the contributions cease but the savings
are left invested for the remainder of the five years or where the saver dies
before the contributions are completed. A separate Save as You Earn scheme
(with the same £10 limit) is operated by the building societies.
The National Savings Bank, formerly known as the Post Office Savings Bank
which was set up in 1861, is the largest organisation of its kind in the world.
It provides a countrywide system for depositing and withdrawing small
savings and has over 22 million active accounts. Ordinary Accounts bear
interest at 3 per cent and the first £ 15 of interest is tax-free. (The Government
is to seek power to increase this to £21 in the 1971 Finance Bill.) Up to £20 can
be withdrawn on demand at any post office, but a few days notice is required
for larger amounts. The moneys are lodged with the National Debt Office
and are invested in government securities. Deposits up to a limit of £10,000
bearing a higher rate of interest may be made in Investment Accounts where
investors have a qualifying deposit of £50 in an Ordinary Account. All
deposits carry a government guarantee; at the end of August 197° both
accounts totalled 1,747 million.
The Trustee Savings Banks, many of which also started in the nineteenth
century, operate under their own trustees but are subject to statutory provi¬
sions and National Debt Office surveillance. There are 77 individual banks
with 1,485 Trustee Offices and over I2| million accounts. Deposits can be
made either in the Ordinary Departments, the Special Investment Depart-

ments or the Current Account Departments. The terms for deposits in the
Ordinary Departments are similar to those in the National Savings Bank.
Withdrawals can usually be made on demand though notice is required for
large sums. Deposits are invested with the National Debt Commissioners and
both capital and interest are guaranteed by the Government. The Special
Investment Departments offer a higher rate of return, which is taxable.
Deposits are limited to £10,000, but are not government guaranteed. At
the end of August 1970 total sums in the Ordinary Departments of the
Trustee Savings Banks were £1,043 niillion and in the Special Investment
Departments £1,438 million. Most Trustee Savings Banks operate cheque
services on deposits in the Current Account Departments. In January 1968
the Trustee Savings Banks set up their own unit trust (see p. 377).
At end-August 1970 National Savings totalled £8,500 million. The diagram
on p. 373 shows the distribution of National Savings between the different
outlets in 1958 and 1969.
The Co-operative Wholesale Society formed a deposit and loan department
about the year 1870, and the right of a co-operative society to engage in
banking was recognised in the Industrial and Provident Societies Act of 1876.
The primary purpose of the Co-operative Wholesale Society Bank was to
serve the co-operative movement, whose financial centre it has become, but
its clients include trade unions and other mutual societies, local authorities
and individual depositors. The bank’s headquarters are in Manchester. The
Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society, which has its headquarters in
Glasgow, has similarly engaged in banking since 1948.
It has been the policy of the commercial banks to leave the provision of many
special financial facilities to other financial institutions. These facilities,
which are supplementary to the credit facilities of the banking system, are
mainly provided through the savings banks, finance corporations, hire-
purchase finance companies, the stock exchanges, investment trusts, building
societies and the insurance market. The firms engaged in such activities are
in the main highly specialised, for example, discount and other finance houses,
stockbrokers, insurers, insurance underwriters and brokers.
Two corporations, the Finance Corporation for Industry Limited (FCI) and
the Industrial and Commercial Finance Corporation Limited (ICFC), were
set up in 1945 to assist in dealing with the problems of post-war reconstruction
and development. The corporations are ordinary limited companies with no
official representation on their boards and no recourse to public funds.
Another corporation, the Commonwealth Development Finance Company
Limited (CDFC), was established in 1953 to assist development projects in
the Commonwealth.
The FCI was formed to assist in the provision of capital (in amounts of
£200,000 and upwards) for the re-equipment and development of industry.
The FCI has an authorised and issued capital of £25 million and may
borrow up to four times this amount, making a possible total of resources of
£125 million. The share capital is held by insurance companies, by invest¬
ment trust companies and by the Bank of England. At 31st March 1970 the
capital called and paid up was 10 per cent (£2*5 million); the Bank of
England paid £5 million in advance of call in 1959. The liability of the
shareholders in respect of the uncalled capital represents security to the banks
providing loans for the corporation’s working capital. The value of its loans

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
and investments at 31st March 1970 was £30 million. It is expected that most
of the £63 million of commitments not taken up at that date will be taken
up within the next two years.
The main function of the ICFC is to invest long-term capital in British based
small and medium-sized companies which are capable of using additional
resources profitably. In addition it provides a wide range of financial and
other specialist services. It has a number of subsidiaries, including Technical
Development Capital Ltd. established in 1962 to rpovide venture capital for
the commercial development of technological innovation. The shareholders
of ICFC are the Bank of England, the English Clearing and the Scottish
Banks. At 31st March 1970 the ICFC had more than £130 million invested in
2,000 British companies.
The Commonwealth Development Finance Company is a private enterprise
institution. Established in 1953, CDFC is no longer confined to the Common¬
wealth. It aims to support business enterprise overseas by providing finance
in the form of share capital and loans on mutually acceptable terms. Its
authorised share capital is £30 million, of which about 14^ million ‘A’
ordinary shares of £1 (£0-10 paid) are held by industrial, shipping, mining
and banking interests in the United Kingdom, and n| million ‘B’ ordinary
shares of £1 (£0-50 paid) are held by the Bank of England and certain central
banks in the Commonwealth. At 31st March 1970 CDFC held investments
worth more than £27 million spread over a wide range of industries placed in
27 countries.
There are eight stock exchanges in the British Isles, including the Provincial
Brokers’ Stock Exchange which operates in 78 cities and towns throughout
Britain and the Irish Republic. The Federation of Stock Exchanges in Great
Britain and Ireland, comprising with one exception all these organisations,
was set up in July 1965 to co-ordinate their work.
The London Stock Exchange is by far the most important of these stock
exchanges and is one of the world’s two foremost free markets in securities.
Some 9,000 securities are quoted on the London Stock Exchange; at the
end of March 1970 these had a total market value of £120,040 million. About
7,900 securities of companies are quoted, including a number of leading
overseas companies. Company issues represented 45 per cent of the securities
at nominal values, and the remainder were United Kingdom and overseas
government and corporation stocks; at market values the propoition was over
four-fifths.
The London Stock Exchange is linked by cable or telephone with stock
exchanges all over the world. Therefore, a quoted company, subject to any
limitations imposed by the exchange control regulations, has a world-wide
market for its issues. This is an important factor in the raising of new capital
by government and commercial borrowers. Arbitrage transactions by brokers
 the buying or selling of a particular security on one stock exchange with the
intention of reversing it on another—play an important part in equating
price differentials between different markets and maintaining a continual
flow of business between centres.
The stock exchanges do not fix dealing prices; the terms on which bargains
are made between members reflect the interaction of supply and demand for
the securities concerned. All the stock exchanges operate under strict rules of
conduct which they formulate themselves.
FINANCE
377
There has been substantial growth in demand in the post-war period for
ordinary (equity) shares, partly in expectation that such shares will maintain
their real value or increase in value in periods of rising prices. Insurance
companies and pension funds invest a larger proportion than formerly of their
assets in these shares, and the Trustee Investments Act 1961 permits trustees,
under certain conditions, to invest up to half the funds they hold in trust in
equity shares.
The ov/nership of securities on the London Stock Exchange is much more
widespread than formerly: it is estimated that there are about 2^ million
shareholders in the United Kingdom and that their shareholdings are widely
distributed.
Through investment trusts and units trusts, investors may spread their risks
and obtain the benefit of skilled management.
The ordinary type of investment trust is constituted as a public company
registered under the Companies Acts with limited liability; its business is
to invest its capital in a range of stocks and shares. Like other companies,
it may issue several types of stocks or shares and may retain part of its profits
to build up reserves. Investment trusts grew to importance in the latter half
of the nineteenth century and have been prominent in directing capital
towards overseas investment.
Unit trusts are constituted by trust deed between a management company
and a trustee company which holds the securities. Normally, the managers
sell units to the public and invest the proceeds in a fairly wide range of
Stock Exchange securities. The costs of running the trust are defrayed partly
by an initial charge which forms part of the price of a unit, and partly by a
semi-annual service charge which is taken usually out of the income of the
trust. The level of both charges is controlled by the Board of Trade, whose
authorisation is required before units can be offered to the public; this is
only granted if the trust deed is satisfactory to them.
The first British unit trust was formed in 1931 and by 1939 there were
98 trusts, with assets estimated at ^80 million. This medium of saving has
grown considerably since 1957. At the end of June 1970 there were nearly
2b million unit holdings. The value of the funds invested in authorised trusts
has risen from £60 million in 1958 to £1,276 million in June 1970; it has more
than doubled since the end of 1966. There are now a wide variety of trusts,
both as to the range of investments covered and the ways in which they cater
for the differing needs of investors.
Although a certain amount of insurance is provided by friendly societies and
trade unions, most insurance services in Britain are in the hands of mutual or
joint stock companies or Lloyd’s underwriters.
Table 25 shows the distribution of business in terms of net premium
income in 1968, the latest year for which figures are available.
There are about 570 insurance companies incorporated in the United
Kingdom but most of the business is in the hands of about 100 companies.
This figure includes companies which became subject to the provisions of the
Insurance Companies Acts 1958-67 as a consequence of the extension of
those Acts to all classes of insurance business. Most British insurers write
several of the main classes of business although some specialise in one class,
particularly in life assurance, where about 105 companies write only that type
of business. A few specialise in re-insurance.

In addition about 170 overseas companies carry on business (and even more
companies are represented) in the United Kingdom, thus emphasising the
international nature of the London market. Some of the large British com¬
panies, however, have their administrative headquarters in the provinces.
In 1968 the total insurance funds of the British insurance companies and
collecting societies amounted to about £14,832 million, the bulk of which is in
respect of life assurance business. The accumulation of life funds has in¬
creased greatly with the growth of group pension schemes.
There is no government control over the investment policy of insurance
funds at home and these represent one of the most important sources of funds
for investment in commerce and industry. Almost a half of the total assets
of British insurance companies is now invested in equity shares and deben¬
tures.

a Including Industrial Life assurance, which is a type of life assurance in which the
premiums are collected at frequent intervals of two months or less by house-to-house

Lloyd’s is an incorporated society of private insurers in London. The name
‘Lloyd’s’ is derived from Edward Lloyd’s coffee house, established in the late
seventeenth century, where merchants with maritime and other interests
gathered to transact business. By the middle of the eighteenth century,
Lloyd’s coffee house had become the principal centre of underwriting
business and intelligence of shipping movements. Although in its earlier
history the activities of Lloyd’s were confined to the conduct of marine
insurance business, there has also been built up at Lloyd s a very considerable
world-wide market for the transaction of other classes of insurance business
in its non-marine, aviation and motor markets.
Lloyd’s is now regulated by a series of special Acts of Parliament starting j
in 1871; the affairs of the Society of Lloyd’s in its corporate capacity are
administered by the Committee of Lloyd s, which does not itself transact
insurance business.
Lloyd’s is not a company but a market for insurance, where business is
transacted by individual underwriters for their own account and risk and
in competition with each other. Insurance may only be placed through
Lloyd’s brokers, who negotiate with Lloyd’s underwriters on behalf of the
insured. Only elected underwriting members of Lloyd’s, who must transact
insurance with unlimited liability and who have met the most stringent
financial regulations laid down by the Committee of Lloyd s, are permitted to
transact business at Lloyd’s; these financial safeguards give a security behind
the Lloyd’s policy which is second to none. Since 1969 non-Commonwealth
FINANCE
379
Insurance Brokers
International
Insurance Services
Building
Societies
underwriters have been admitted to membership of Lloyd s, if they satisfy
the requirements.
Today there are about 6,000 underwriting members of Lloyd’s grouped
into some 280 syndicates and represented at Lloyd’s by underwriting agents
who accept risks on behalf of the members of their syndicates.
In conjunction with its marine insurance business Lloyd’s has built up a
world-wide organisation for the collection and diffusion of shipping intelli¬
gence.
The insurance market is completed by the insurance brokers, acting on behalf
of the insured; brokers are an essential part of the Lloyd’s market and a
valuable part of the company market. Many brokers specialise in re-insurance
business, acting as intermediaries in the exchange of contracts between
companies, both British and overseas, and often acting as London repre¬
sentatives of the latter.
Over two-thirds of the fire, accident and marine insurance business is
carried on overseas, partly by re-insurance on the London market and partly
through branches and agencies established in over 100 countries. I he basic
principle of this international business is that resources capable of meeting
any potential loss are instantly available for use in any part of the world.
Behind this large and international volume of business stand the very
substantial assets of the companies, in addition to substantial reserves of
uncalled capital, and the whole of the deposits, underwriting trust funds and
personal fortunes of Lloyd’s underwriters.
The principal function of building societies is to supply long-term loans on
the security of private dwelling-houses purchased for owner-occupation,
though loans are occasionally made on the security of commercial and
industrial premises and farms. The funds of building societies are derived
mainly from the general public who invest in shares or deposits. The amount
of share capital is not fixed; shares, which have a fixed value, are not dealt
with on the Stock Exchange but may be withdrawn in cash if notice is given.
The Building Societies Act 1962, which consolidated a number of earlier Acts,
prescribes the general way in which societies must conduct their business.
The Chief Registrar of Friendly Societies has discretionary powers to stop
a society either advertising or accepting money from investors if he considers
that the way in which the society’s business is conducted is jeopardising
investors’ money. The rapid expansion of building society activity in the
twentieth century has been accompanied by a concentration of most of the
business in the hands of a few large societies. At the end of 1969, 504 societies
were in operation, with total assets of £9,289 million. Eight of the largest
societies, however, each with assets of over £250 million, account for well
over half of the total funds. The amount advanced on mortgage in 1969 was
£i,559 million.
