OVERSEAS TRADE
Although relatively small in area and accounting for less than 2 per cent of
the world’s population, the United Kingdom is the world’s third largest
trading nation, conducting about 11 per cent of international trade in manu¬
factured goods in 1969.
For well over a century international trade has been of vital importance to
Britain’s economy. Britain relies upon imports for about half its total con¬
sumption of foodstuffs and nearly all the raw materials needed for its industries.
Its exports of goods and services together represent about a fifth of the gross
national product. It is a major supplier of machinery, vehicles, aircraft, metal
manufactures, electrical apparatus, chemicals and textiles. It is the world’s
largest market for foodstuffs, and among the largest for metals and ores,
textile raw materials, petroleum and many other products.
Changes in value, volume, composition and geographical distribution of
imports and exports are outlined in the following paragraphs.
The value of imports (including cost, insurance and freight) during the 1950s
fluctuated between £3,000 million and £4,000 million a year. Since i960
imports have risen in all years except 1961 and 1962. There was a particularly
rapid expansion in 1964 (of 14 per cent) and again in 1968 (of 21 per cent),
but a much smaller increase (of 5 per cent) in 1969, when they totalled £8,324
million (excluding US military aircraft, see note a to Table 26). Exports (valued
free on board) increased fairly steadily between 1950 and 1966; the average
annual rate of increase during this period was 6 per cent. After a slight fall in
1967, they then rose fast and for 1969 were 40 per cent above their level
in 1967.
Between 1961 and 1969 the total volume of exports and re-exports rose by
50 per cent (21 per cent since 1967) and that of imports by 46 per cent. From
1956 to 1967 Britain’s terms of trade improved slowly but fairly steadily, that
is, the rise in the average price of exports was greater than that in the price of
imports. In the seven months following sterling devaluation, sterling prices of
British exports rose about 8 per cent, but rose only a further 4 per cent in the
following 18 months to the end of 1969. They were then in terms of US dollars
still lower than in 1967. Import prices rose steadily, by about 18 per cent in all,
in the two years following devaluation.
The value and volume of exports and imports in selected years from 1959
to 1969 are shown in Table 26.

dependence on imported food supplies and the proportion of imported food¬
stuffs to total imports has fallen from 39 per cent in 1954 to 23 per cent in
1969 when imports of foodstuffs (including beverages and tobacco) were
£1,934 million. There has been a similar downward trend in the proportion

Imports of crude petroleum and lubricants are by far the biggest single
item by value—about 11 per cent of the total value of imports during the past
ten years. In 1969 their value was £902 million.
The most marked change in recent years has been the rise, in Britain as in
other industrial countries, in the proportion of imports of finished manu¬
factures, particularly capital goods. Such imports rose from nearly 7 per cent
of total imports in 1957 to 22 per cent in 1969, when three-quarters were of
capital goods. Imports of semi-manufactures have also been increasing steadily
and since 1962 have formed a larger part of the total import bill than basic
materials, partly because the countries producing the basic materials tend to
embark upon the subsequent stages of manufacture themselves. Imports of
semi-manufactured (excluding chemicals) and manufactured goods amounted
to £1,840 million and £i,834million respectively in 1969, thus each accounting
for about 22 per cent of Britain’s total imports.
More than five-sixths of Britain’s exports consist of manufactured goods.
By far the most important group are engineering products—in 1969 42 per
cent of total exports. Within this group, exports of many types of machinery,
electrical equipment, road vehicles, tractors and scientific instruments have
been increasing rapidly. The share of chemicals has grown fairly steadily,

Trade between Britain and Western Europe has been increasing in recent
years, and conversely there has been a decline in the proportion of Britain’s
exports going to primary producing countries. In 1958, 27 per cent of exports
went to Western Europe, but in 1962, for the first time, these exports began
to exceed those to the sterling area and by 1969 they formed over 39 per cent
of the total. Exports to Western Europe increased by over 19 per cent in 1969,
following a similar increase in 1968. Exports to the European Economic
Community (EEC) increased by 18 per cent in 1969 compared with 24 per
cent in 1968 and less than 1 per cent in 1967, and to the European Free Trade
Association (EFTA) they increased by over 21 per cent compared with 13 per
cent in 1968 and only 3 per cent in 1967. Both rates of increase were signi¬
ficantly higher than the average over the past decade.

to 28 per cent, compared with 30 per cent in 1967 and with 43 per cent in 1958;
there has been a similar relative fall in respect of imports. Canada, Australia,
South Africa and the Republic of Ireland, however, are still among Britain’s
most important trading partners, but since 1957 the United States has been
Britain’s largest single market and source of supply. The proportion of total
exports going to North America in 1969 was over 16 per cent, slightly less than
that of 1968. Exports to Latin America increased by 8 per cent in 1969 com¬
pared with the very high increase of 35 per cent in 1968. Britain’s trade
with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe though still small in relation
to its total trade has been growing rapidly over the past decade. Trade with
Japan continues to grow; exports rose by 31 per cent in 1969, while imports
fell by 9 per cent.
Re-exports are goods which are exported (1) in the condition in which they
were imported or (2) after having undergone minor operations—such as
simple blending, cleaning, husking, repacking—which leaves them essentially
unchanged. Traditionally, the greater part of United Kingdom re-export trade
has been in raw materials and foodstuffs, for example, wool, rubber, tea, non-
ferrous metals and fur-skins. Commodities imported from Commonwealth
countries and sent on to countries in Europe, particularly traditional re-exports
such as tea and wool, account for much of the total value. In recent years a
considerable re-export trade has developed in manufactured goods, including
machinery, aircraft and aero-engines repaired or overhauled in Britain.
In 1969 the value of re-exports was £259 million, easily a record and an
increase of 20 per cent over the 1968 level. The principal items were: fur-skins,
non-ferrous metals, electrical and other machinary and tea. Over half of the
re-exports went to countries in Western Europe.
For nearly two centuries Britain has been able to pay for part of its imports of
goods with its net earnings from invisible overseas transactions, that is, trans¬
actions in services, including the provision of finance.
Invisible transactions are divided for statistical purposes into six main
groups: government, transport (shipping and civil aviation); travel; other
services (which covers a variety of items including royalties, films and tele¬
vision transactions, financial services, and other commercial and miscellaneous
services); interest, profits and dividends; and private transfers (migrants’
funds, legacies and private gifts). Table 28 shows the breakdown of the
figures from 1964 to 1969. Some of these figures are reliable (for instance, for
government transactions), others are only approximations. The total invisible
balance in 1969 was a record £524 million (in the five years to 1967 the annual
surplus averaged £190 million). Excluding government expenditure on services
and transfers, the net balance was a surplus of ,£981 million. Private invis¬
ible receipts in 1969 rose to £4,008 million (second only to the United States).
Earnings from invisibles amounted to well over half the total from visible exports.
As shown in Table 28, in recent years there has been a considerable net
surplus on ‘other services’ and on interest, profits and dividends. About half
of Britain’s receipts under this heading comes from investments in the sterling
area. There has also been a surplus on civil aviation services throughout the
past decade. Shipping transactions have been in surplus since 1966. Travel
credits exceeded debits for the first time in 1968 and again in 1969. About
half the net deficit in respect of government expenditure relates to military
expenditure overseas; other substantial items of expenditure are grants to
developing countries and subscriptions to international organisations.

Tourism yields a substantial income from overseas; in the ten years 1960-69
overseas visitors spent around £2,300 million in Britain. For 1969 these travel
and tourist receipts, excluding fares, are estimated at about £355 million.
United Kingdom residents on holiday, or travelling for business or other
purposes overseas, spent about £329 miHion (excluding fares) in the same
year. The continuing increase in both the average expenditure per visitor
and in the number of travellers visiting Britain caused travel credits to
exceed debits in 1968 and 1969. The estimated total number of visits to the
United Kingdom in 1969, including visitors from the Republic of Ireland, was
a record figure of over 5-5 million—more than tv/ice the level of 1956 and an
increase of almost 25 per cent over the 1968 level.
Britain’s national travel organisation is the British Tourist Authority
which, following the Development of Tourism Act 1969, took over some of
the functions of the British Travel Association in January 1970. Unlike its
predecessor, which was a voluntary body deriving most of its income from a
government grant, the new organisation is a statutory body responsible for
the overseas promotion of tourism to Britain. It also has an important co¬
ordinating role in the operations of the three regional Tourist Boards for
England, Scotland and Wales which (along with the Northern Ireland Tourist
Board which is a statutory body receiving a grant from the Government of
Northern Ireland) carry out promotional work and publicity within Britain
and have powers to assist tourist projects in their respective countries. The
English, Scottish and Welsh Boards are also responsible for administering a
scheme of grant and loan assistance towards the development of new and
improved hotel accommodation.

COMMERCIAL
POLICY
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Britain’s prosperity depends on the prosperity of those who buy her exports
which in turn depends on how they sell their exports elsewhere. Thus Britain
is a strong advocate of the removal of artificial barriers to trade and to this end
has taken a leading part in the setting up and subsequent activities of such
organisations as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the General Agree¬
ment on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and the Organisation for Economic
Co-operation and Development (OECD). It has also played a full part at the
two plenary sessions of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Develop¬
ment held in 1964 and 1968 and is a member of the Trade and Development
Board which acts on behalf of the Conference between sessions.
Customs duties on imports into Britain are divided into two broad cate¬
gories: revenue duties (to which there correspond excise revenue duties on
comparable British-produced goods) and protective duties. Purchase tax is
chargeable on imported as well as home-produced goods but in the main the
charge on imports is deferred until the goods are sold by a registered to a
non-registered trader. In the financial year 1969-70 revenue duties charged
on imported goods yielded about £2,610 million, by far the greater part of
which came from tobacco and hydrocarbon oils (petroleum products). The
yield from protective duties was £228 million, or about 3 per cent of the value
of all imports.
At the beginning of the twentieth century the only customs duties were
those imposed for revenue purposes on a small range of products. Certain
duties were imposed during the first world war (the McKenna Duties), in
1921 (for strategic reasons) and in 1925 (initially for revenue purposes) but it
was not until the Import Duties Act 1932 that any serious departure was made
from the principle of free trade. This measure provided a degree of protection
for British industry and, at the same time, a basis for negotiations with foreign
countries already in possession of a tariff structure. A series of bilateral trade
negotiations between 1932 and 1939 led to some modification in the level of
protection but in the next ten years, because of government purchase and
imports controls introduced during and immediately after the second world
war, the tariff lost much of its importance. The substantial relaxation of
quantitative import controls from 1949 onwards re-established the tariff as
the main instrument of protection.
The Import Duties Act 1958 replaced existing legislation relating to the
protective tariff and brought it up to date in a single measure. The tariff was
recast into an internationally agreed form (the Brussels Nomenclature), which
came into use from 1st January 1959. Under the Customs Duties (Dumping
and Subsidies) Act 1969, the Board of Trade is empowered to impose duties
on imported goods of any description which are being dumped or subsidised
if it is satisfied that this is causing or threatening material injury to a particular
industry and that such action would be in the national interest. The Act also
empowers the Board of Trade to take provisional action where a prima-facie case
of dumping or subsidisation and consequent material injury has been made out.
An import deposit scheme was introduced for a one-year period in
November 1968 as part of measures taken to assist in bringing the balance of
payments into surplus. Importers of those classes of goods subject to the
scheme (these exclude, for example, foodstuffs and raw materials) were
required to deposit 50 per cent of the value of the goods for six months with
Customs and Excise. The scheme continued at a reduced rate of 40 per cent
from December 1969 and the deposit was further reduced twice, to 30 per
cent on 1st May 1970, and to 20 per cent on 1st September 1970. The
scheme will end on 4th December 1970.
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
387
General Agree- The United Kingdom’s protective tariff has been considerably modified in
ment on Tariffs recent years as a result of a series of international tariff negotiations held under
and Trade the auspices of the GATT, which seeks to increase the volume of world trade
by reducing tariffs and other barriers to trade, and by eliminating discrimina¬
tion in international commerce. Tariff reductions, and bindings against
increase, negotiated between countries under the GATT are applied equally
to all other GATT countries under the ‘most favoured nation’ clause.
As a result of the latest series of GATT tariff negotiations, the ‘Kennedy
Round’ (May 1964-June 1967), average reductions of over 30 per cent are to
be made by the major trading countries in their tariffs on industrial goods.
The reduction to be made in the British tariffs on dutiable industrial goods
imported from the EEC, the United States and Japan will amount to about
37 per cent, 40 per cent and 34 per cent respectively. This is closely in line
with the reductions which these countries are making, which will affect well
over 70 per cent of British exports of dutiable industrial goods to these coun¬
tries. Some reductions in the tariffs on agricultural goods are also being made.
The implementation of the British tariff reductions will be spread over
1968-72; the first cuts were made on the 1st July 1968 and 1st January 1970;
subsequent reductions are due to be made on the 1st January 1971 and 1972.
Commonwealth The principle of Imperial Preference was introduced into the United Kingdom
Preference customs duties in 1919 and at the Ottawa Conference in 1932 agreements
were concluded with independent Commonwealth countries providing for
reciprocal preferential tariff treatment over a wide range of goods. The
Import Duties Act 1932 had already provided for the duty-free entry of goods
from the United Kingdom dependencies.
Most imports into Britain from the Commonwealth preference area (which
includes the Republic of South Africa, Burma and the Republic of Ireland)
enter free of duty. Some two-fifths of the value of imports from the area enjoy
a tariff preference of about 11 per cent (defined as the difference between the
full duty rate and the preferential rate—in this case generally nil—expressed
as a percentage of the import value). It is estimated that approximately half of
Britain’s exports to the Commonwealth preference area enter free of duty and
about the same proportion enjoy an average tariff preference of 12 per cent.
In 1964 at the first United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
(UNCTAD) in Geneva, Britain declared itself prepared to extend tariff
preferences on a non-reciprocal and non-discriminatory basis to all the
developing countries if other major industrialised countries would do the
same, if the Commonwealth countries concerned would agree and provided
that preferences were not given in such a way as to impede the continuing
reduction of tariffs on a most-favoured-nation basis. The establishment of a
system of generalised preferences for manufactures and semi-manufactures
exported by developing countries was agreed in principle at the second
UNCTAD conference in New Delhi in 1968. The detailed arrangements are
still under discussion.
European
Economic
Integration
The European Free Trade Association (EFTA) was set up under the Stock¬
holm Convention of January i960 by Austria, Denmark, Norway, Portugal,
Sweden, Switzerland and Britain, with the object of creating an industrial free
trade area between the members and of working towards a wider European
settlement. Under the Convention, protective tariffs and quotas on trade in
industrial products between members of EFTA were to be eliminated by
1st January 1970. The first tariff cuts were made in July i960, and duties were
388 BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
finally removed (with certain minor exceptions) on 31st December 1966, three
years earlier than originally planned. Finland, which joined EFTA in 1961 as
an associate member, made its final cuts in December 1967. EFTA was the
first completed free trade area in the world and forms a single market of almost
100 million people. Since 1959 intra-EFTA trade has nearly trebled while
trade between EFTA and non-member countries has doubled. Iceland joined
EFTA as a full member on 1st March, 1970.
A free trade agreement between the United Kingdom and the Republic of
Ireland came into operation on 1st July 1966. On that date the United
Kingdom removed all protective import duties on goods of Republic of
Ireland origin imported from that country. After 1st July I975> with certain
exceptions, the Republic of Ireland will not apply any protective duties on
goods of United Kingdom origin.
In August 1961 the British Government applied formally to join the EEC
but negotiations were suspended in January 1963. A renewed application for
membership was made in May 1967. At the meeting of the EEC Council of
Ministers in December 1967 five of the member states favoured the opening
of negotiations with Britain, but the French Government did not agree, and
the request for accession remained on the Council’s agenda. Negotiations for
the enlargement of the EEC opened formally in Luxembourg on 30th June
1970-
Methods of The export trade and virtually all the import trade of the United Kingdom are
Trading conducted by private firms.
Methods of export trading vary considerably, according to the firm, the
industry, the product and the market. A good deal of United Kingdom export
trade, especially of the smaller manufacturing firms, is conducted through
export merchants in the United Kingdom; many firms, however, sell to
importers and consumers abroad through their own agents or resident repre¬
sentatives in the countries concerned; in other cases, sales are made through
a firm’s own branch offices, distributing organisations or subsidiary companies
established in overseas markets.
Similarly, in import trade, many large firms engaged in manufacture or
domestic trade buy directly from overseas suppliers, while smaller firms may
find it more convenient to buy through intermediaries such as import/export
houses, commission agents, and the representatives of overseas firms.
CONTROLS ON
TRADE AND
PAYMENTS
Exchange
Control
Most of the restrictions imposed on the movement of goods and services
during and immediately after the second world war have been progressively
abolished.
Exchange control is confined mainly to transactions between residents of the
United Kingdom and residents of countries outside the sterling area. The
latter may settle transactions between themselves in sterling, and any sterling
held on an external account is freely convertible into other currencies,
including dollars.
The remaining important restrictions relate to the movement of capital
from the United Kingdom to non-sterling area countries. Because of the
balance of payments deficits, exchange control requirements for investments
outside the sterling area have, since 1961, been revised and made more
stringent. Exports of goods to destinations outside the sterling area are
subject to exchange control and, in general, have to be paid for within six
months in any foreign currency (except Rhodesian currency) or by sterling
Import and
Export Control
Import Licensing
Export Controls
GOVERNMENT
ASSISTANCE
TO OVERSEAS
TRADE
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 389
from an external account. Control is also exercised over imports to ensure that
currency authorised for their payment is used for that purpose.
There are also certain restrictions on the release of gold for manufacturing
and industrial purposes, and on the buying, selling and holding of post-1837
gold coins.
Exchange control policy is the responsibility of the Treasury, but most of
the administration is, in practice, carried out by the Bank of England as agent
of the Treasury; and, in turn, the Bank of England has delegated to the
commercial banks a wide variety of powers to deal with applications.
Under the Import, Export and Customs Powers (Defence) Act 1939 the
Board of Trade is empowered to prohibit or regulate the import or export
of goods.
In accordance with its international obligations under the GATT and the
IMF, the United Kingdom Government has progressively removed quanti¬
tative restrictions from almost all its imports from the countries of the free
world. There has also been a continuing substantial relaxation of quantitative
controls on imports from the Soviet Zone. The very short list of goods on
which controls remain includes some items of special difficulty and a few
where restrictions are recognised internationally, such as arms, ammunition
and radioactive materials. They require a specific import licence and quotas
have been set up for many of them. Some quotas refer specifically to individual
countries and are usually shared out among exporters by the authorities of the
countries concerned. Others are accorded on an overall or global basis, and
are generally allocated by the United Kingdom authorities to United Kingdom
importers, usually on the basis of their share of the trade in the commodity
in the past. Apart from these quantitative controls, some further restrictions
or prohibitions are applied on health grounds (for example, on animals, plants
and drugs). There is also a general import restriction on goods from Rhodesia.
Except for the control necessary to ensure that exports to destinations outside
the sterling area are paid for in the proper manner, United Kingdom exports
are not generally subject to any government control or direction. The few
controls that are in operation are imposed to supervise exports of military
and strategic importance; to conserve materials which may be in short
supply; to assist exchange control operations in preventing the export of
capital in the form of valuable goods; to ensure the humane treatment of
horses, cattle, sheep and pigs; and to prevent the export of antiques (including
works of art) on grounds of national importance. Normally, individual licences
are required for specific consignments of goods subject to export licensing
control. Goods controlled for strategic reasons, not included in the category
of atomic energy materials and appliances, arms and ammunition, may, with
certain exceptions, be exported to the Commonwealth, the Irish Republic,
the Republic of South Africa and the United States of America without
licence. There is also a general export restriction on goods to Rhodesia.
The British Government1 assists exporters by its efforts to create conditions
favourable to the export trade and by providing credit insurance facilities and
information and advice about opportunities for trade in other countries.
1 Export promotion is also assisted by the Scottish Council (Development and Industry)
and the Development Corporation for Wales. In Northern Ireland, the Ministry of
Commerce provides a liaison service with the Board of Trade Export Services Branch
and the overseas posts.

Facilities exist for the repayment of protective duties paid on goods which
have been imported for export trade purposes.
Exporters wanting assistance and advice can consult Board of Trade offices
throughout Britain and, through these offices, the commercial posts of Her
Majesty’s Diplomatic Service overseas. There are 200 posts located in all
the principal cities and trade centres abroad and they supply the Board of
Trade with information of every kind affecting trade with their territories.
Overseas officers regularly report on local economic and commercial
conditions, pay special attention to local demand for particular commodities,
and generally assist the exporter to overcome any difficulties he encounters
in trade with the country in question, particularly those arising out of govern¬
mental regulations. These officers investigate potential markets for British
products, advise about methods of trading with particular areas, and seek out
and pass on opportunities for export business and enquiries for British goods.
Assistance is also given to United Kingdom exporters in appointing agents
and locating potential importers. From records kept up to date in London by
reports from its overseas commercial officers, the Export Services Division of
the Board of Trade can provide information concerning any country on the
prospects for exports and requirements of particular markets, government
regulations affecting trade (including import restrictions and tariffs and duties
on particular commodities), methods of trading, local tastes and preferences
in design, and the commercial standing of firms with which an exporter
contemplates business relations.
The Government’s official information services overseas are used exten¬
sively to promote Britain’s export trade.
The Overseas Marketing Corporation, financed partly by private equity
capital and partly by loan capital made available by the Board of Trade, was
set up in November 1967 to promote exports from British firms which
encounter difficulties in selling abroad because of their size or structure. It
seeks out new export opportunities overseas and ensures an adequate marketing
effort to exploit them.
The Export Credits Guarantee Department (ECGD) is a government
department, responsible to the President of the Board of Trade, which
provides insurance for exporters against the main risks in selling overseas,
and guarantees to banks providing finance for export credit. It covers more
than a third of the country’s export trade. The ECGD is required to carry
on its business on a self-supporting basis and is therefore not a charge on the
taxpayer.
The risks covered include insolvency or protracted default of the buyer,
governmental action which blocks or delays transfer of payment to the
United Kingdom exporter, imposition of new import licensing restrictions
in the buyer’s country, war between the buyer’s country and the United
Kingdom, cancellation or non-renewal of a United Kingdom export licence,
additional handling, transport or insurance charges incurred after shipment
through interruption or diversion of voyage or ‘any other cause of loss
occurring outside the United Kingdom and not within the control of the
exporter or the buyer, and not normally insurable with commercial insurers’.
Cover may commence from the date of contract or (at lower premiums) from
the date of shipment.
Policies may be comprehensive, covering all export business in all markets

(or in an agreed group of markets) on goods sold on six months’ to five years’
credit, or specific, covering large, single capital transactions sold on credit
terms of five years or more.
Over 300 exhibitions, of which about 200 were trade fairs, were held in
Britain in 1969. Some of the shows attracting the general public, such as the
Boat Show and the Motor Show, are also attended by many trade buyers from
overseas. These exhibitions provide an important means of advertising and
selling British goods.
United Kingdom products are shown at most of the large international
trade fairs throughout the world and United Kingdom manufacturers have
been prominent at the many specialised fairs held in Europe and North
America. Special displays of British consumer goods have also been presented
in hotels in North America and elsewhere.
Participation in trade fairs, ‘British weeks’ and store promotions overseas is
a form of export promotion for which the Government provides information,
financial assistance and, in certain cases, free facilities. (‘British weeks’ differ
from trade fairs and exhibitions in that they are primarily designed to promote
sales of consumer goods in shops overseas.) The amount allocated to the
Board of Trade for these purposes has risen from £60,000 in 1955-56 to nearly
£4 million in 1968-69. In 1969 the Board of Trade assisted 5,600 British
firms at 263 specialised and general trade fairs in 50 countries; and gave
practical help to two major British Weeks and six ‘British Shopping Weeks’,
and to some 68 overseas store promotions.
The British National Export Council (BNEC), a promotional body formed in
July 1964, is sponsored by the Government and by representatives of industry,
trade, finance and organised labour in Britain. Associated with it are 12 Area
Committees with the primary responsibility for developing British exports
to a particular market or group of markets: Africa, Asia, Australia, the
Caribbean, Israel, Latin America, the Middle East, New Zealand, Europe,
Canada, southern Africa and the United States.
The tasks of the BNEC are to keep all British export activity under constant
review; to stimulate exports in all markets; to advise on organisations relating
to particular markets; to provide a central point for the export effort; and
services for this purpose such as the sending overseas of export missions.
There is an annual scheme for royal recognition of outstanding export and
technological achievement by industry, namely, the Queen’s Award to
Industry; the first awards were made in 1966. In addition the BNEC gives
awards for outstanding achievements by small exporters; the first awards were
made in 1969.
In the nineteenth century, the rapid growth of British industry, commerce
and shipping under the stimulus of the industrial revolution made Britain
the market as well as the workshop of the world. It became the site for the
chief world markets in raw materials (see below), freight, insurance and
precious metals. A sound commercial banking system and a flexible system
of central bank control have been built up, while specialised institutions such
as discount houses, merchant banks, accepting houses, the stock exchanges,
investment trusts and finance corporations have evolved to satisfy particular
needs for short-term or long-term finance. The facilities provided by merchant
banks and accepting houses, for example, have long been used to finance
shipments of goods not only to and from Britain, but also between other
392

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
overseas countries. (Exchange control no longer allows the financing of trade
between two non-sterling area countries.)
At the same time, the banks which were already engaged in financing trade
were able to assist in raising finance for longer-term ventures. British capital
invested in overseas countries has furthered their development, increased
their output and exports, and provided markets for manufactured goods. A
number of specialised institutions help in providing financial services for
overseas countries.
Britain is the traditional centre for marketing many of the world’s basic
commodities. Among the more important are the Baltic Exchange (the market
for shipping and air transport, grain, seeds and vegetable oils), the London
Commodity Exchange (cocoa, coffee, copra, hides and skins, rubber and
sugar), the London Wool Exchange, the London Metal Exchange, the
Liverpool Cotton Exchange and the Liverpool Corn Exchange. A soya bean
oil futures market opened in London in 1967 an<^ a coconut oil futures
market in 1969. These markets not only cater for the import of goods for
home consumption but do much business in effecting transactions between
buyers and sellers in other countries. In addition to these formal markets,
there is scarcely any product which cannot be traded through an intermediary
in Britain. For example, London is the world’s most important philatelic
market and also the leading international centre for the sale of works of
art.
The market consists of approximately 190 authorised banks and nine firms
of foreign exchange brokers all linked together by telephone in the United
Kingdom, and by telephone, telex and cable with overseas centres. The
turnover of the market has increased progressively since the introduction in
December 1958 of external convertibility for the principal European currencies.
The Foreign Exchange Market is subject to United Kingdom exchange control
regulations governing the purchase and sale of foreign currencies.
The London Gold Market, which had remained closed from the outbreak of
war in 1939, was reopened in March 1954, under the general supervision
of the Bank of England. All authorised banks may deal in gold but, in
practice, dealings are largely concentrated in the hands of the five members
of the gold market. The five members meet twice daily to fix a price for all
transactions which customers ask to have executed at the fixing.
A gold pool was set up in 1961 to co-ordinate the gold operations in London
(including supplying gold to private buyers) of certain European central banks
and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Following heavy world-wide
speculation in gold at the end of 1967 and the beginning of 1968, the gold pool
was terminated in March 1968. Officially held gold is now used only to effect
transfers between monetary authorities where these are not replacing gold
sold in private markets.
As a result of Britain’s early lead in international trade and finance, several
countries tended not only to use sterling as their natural currency for inter¬
national transactions, but also to maintain central currency reserves in
Britain. When Britain abandoned the gold standard in 1931 these countries,
which came to be known as the ‘sterling bloc’ and later as the ‘sterling area’,
did likewise, and pegged their currency exchange rates to the pound sterling.
In 1939, after the outbreak of war, the pound sterling was no longer freely
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
393
convertible into other currencies and the sterling area became more formally
defined as a currency area for exchange control purposes. The United
Kingdom imposes no exchange control on transactions with residents of other
sterling area countries. Sterling became convertible again in December 1958
but there is still exchange control against the non-sterling area.
All the Commonwealth countries (except Canada and Rhodesia), together
with Iceland, the Irish Republic, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, the Republic of
South Africa, South West Africa, the Republic of Southern Yemen, the
British Protected States in the Persian Gulf, and Western Samoa, are members
of the sterling area. The main features of the sterling area are that the greater
part of the overseas trade of member countries is financed in sterling, while
much of their foreign reserves are held in sterling. Member countries sell their
foreign currency earnings in London in exchange for sterling and purchase for
sterling the foreign currency they require.
Within the total of the sterling balances there have been considerable
changes in ownership since the second world war, and there have also been
some sizeable fluctuations. Thus the balances of the non-sterling area have
fallen, while the balances of sterling area governments also dropped signifi¬
cantly in 1968. This drop led to the series of agreements concluded between
the United Kingdom and the countries of the sterling area in September 1968
by which each country undertook to maintain an agreed proportion of its
official reserves in sterling, and the United Kingdom undertook to provide
a dollar-value guarantee of the bulk of official sterling holdings. Most of the
agreements last for three years, and include provision for extension for a
further two years’ mutual agreement; some last for five years. At the same
time as these agreements were concluded, 12 major non-sterling area countries
and the Bank for International Settlements undertook to provide the United
Kingdom with a $2,000 million credit facility on which the United Kingdom
could draw to the extent that the sterling balances of the sterling area (both
official and private) fell below an agreed starting level. These arrangements
have succeeded in their purpose of stabilising the sterling area’s balances;
since the agreements were concluded, the official sterling balances of the
sterling area have risen, very largely reflecting a rise in the sterling area’s
official reserves of both sterling and non-sterling currencies.

Estimates of Britain’s balance of payments and its main constituent items are
given in summary since 1963 in Table 29 and in greater detail since 1967 in
Tables 30 and 31. The balance of payments statistics emphasise two in¬

covering both visible (exports and imports of goods) and invisible (trade in
services, investment income and transfers) transactions, which provides a
measure of how far Britain is paying its way abroad and thus adding to or
using up overseas assets. The second is the total currency flow. This is the
net result of all external flows, that is the current account, investment and
other capital flows (including official long-term capital transactions, invest-

international financing transactions.

Britain has traditionally had a deficit on visible trade but a surplus on

on visible trade being achieved in only two calendar years since then and a
deficit on invisibles incurred only exceptionally in the two years immediately

at the end of 1967. In 1968 the value of exports rose strongly but that of
imports rose at about the same rate, while there was a 5 per cent deterioration
in the terms of trade as an immediate result of devaluation, and the balance
of visible trade remained in heavy deficit. In 1969 exports rose faster than
imports, and there was a marked improvement in the balance of visible trade,
while net invisible earnings rose by about 70 per cent with a sharp increase
in interest, profits and dividends. The result was a large surplus on invisibles,
a small deficit in visibles, and thus a substantial surplus on current trans¬
actions as a whole. The net aggregates for the first half of 1970 show a similar
position, though most of the gross flows increased.
Total currency flow was outward in each of the years 1963-68 and inward
in 1969 and the first half of 1970. In the six years 1963-68, there was an
outward flow of £3,778 million (including a gold subscription of £44 million
to the IMF) financed mainly by official borrowing totalling £3,134 million,
but also by transfers to the reserves of the dollar portfolio, totalling £520
396
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
million and a reduction of £124 million in the reserves. Approximately one-
quarter of the outflow stemmed from current deficits. In 1969 and the first
half of 1970, there was an inward flow of .£1,885 million and this together
with the allocation to Britain by the International Monetary Fund of Special
Drawing Rights (SDR) of £171 million (which count as part of the reserves,
see below), made it possible to reduce official borrowing by £1,902 million
and add £154 million to the reserves. The inflow resulted from surpluses on
current account, a small net investment inflow, a substantial increase in the
sterling balances (which had fallen in the previous period) and a very large
positive balancing item reflecting unidentified transactions.
The general level of the reserves has not changed greatly since the early
1950s and has usually been about £1,000 million. At the end of June 1970
the reserves amounted to £1,163 milliom They were made up of £612 million
in gold, £432 million in convertible currencies and £119 million in Special
Drawing Rights.
Britain is a participant in the Special Drawing Rights scheme which came
into effect in 1970 and which is estimated to have added so far some 5 per
cent to world reserves. Special Drawing Rights are reserve assets created and
distributed by decision of the members of the IMF. Any member of the
IMF may join the scheme, and its share is based on its IMF quota. Partici¬
pants in the scheme accept an obligation to provide convertible currency,
when designated by the IMF to do so, to another participant in exchange for
SDRs up to a total amount equal to twice the net amount of their own
allocation of SDRs. Only those countries with a sufficiently strong balance of
payments are so designated by the IMF. SDRs may also be used in certain
direct payments between participants in the scheme and for payments of
various kinds to the IMF.
In recent years the United Kingdom has incurred short- and medium-term
debt to cushion the reserves against currency outflows. Britain has drawing
rights in the IMF based on its IMF quota which is due to be raised before
the end of 1970 to $2,800 million (£1,166 million). As an industrialised
country Britain is able to make drawings, subject to certain conditions, up to
125 per cent of the value of its quota. Britain has made such drawings on
several occasions. Two drawings are either wholly or partly outstanding. A
sum of $1,400 million (£583 million) drawn in 1968 was used to repay short¬
term debts to central banks; and a stand-by facility for $1,000 million
(417 million) agreed in May 1969 was drawn in instalments up to March
I97°-
Britain has also taken part since 1961 in the international network of re¬
ciprocal credit (swap) facilities arranged between central banks. Facilities
available to the United Kingdom include one of $2,000 million (£833 million)
with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Under these arrangements each
central bank is able to exchange on request its own currency for the currency
of another country up to a maximum agreed for a limited period. It agrees to
reverse the transaction at a specified date at the same rate of exchange. The
currencies so obtained can be retained in the reserves or used in exchange
operations.
United Kingdom official short- and medium-term borrowing outstanding
at the end of June 1970 totalled $3,506 million (£1,461 million) of which
$2,381 million (£992 million) represented outstanding drawings from the
IMF. The total represents a reduction of $4,565 million (£1,902 million) from
the peak level of borrowing reached at the end of 1968. Practically all of this
was a reduction on central bank and related facilities.

The significance of any inventory of Britain’s aggregate external assets and
liabilities1 is limited because a variety of claims and obligations are included
that are very dissimilar in kind, in degree of liquidity and in method of valua¬
tion. The inventory for the end of 1969 shows that Britain had a substantial
net creditor position estimated at some ^2*7 billion.
Identified external liabilities at the end of 1969 totalled some £16,685 million,
against assets of about £19,375 million. Total official short- and medium-term
financing liabilities to the IMF and other monetary authorities were £2,510
million. Inter-governmental loans to the United Kingdom and other official
liabilities, mainly a consequence of the second world war and its aftermath,
totalled £2,251 million. Of this sum £1,780 million was owed to the United
States and £361 million to Canada. Other public sector liabilities, including
overseas holdings of United Kingdom government and public corporations
sterling securities, holdings of Treasury bills and notes, local authority mort¬
gages and stocks, and foreign currency borrowing by United Kingdom public
corporations and local authorities, totalled £2,574 million. United Kingdom
banking and commercial liabilities including liabilities in sterling, overseas
sterling area currencies and foreign currencies, totalled £2,601 million.2 * * *
Liabilities in the form of overseas investment in the United Kingdom private
sector totalled £6,750 million.
Liabilities in the form of sterling balances comprise both public sector and
banking liabilities within the totals above. The sterling balances are normally
defined as the funds held in the United Kingdom by foreigners in the form of
bank deposits, deposits with local authorities and hire purchase companies,
Treasury bills and British Government securities (where these are held by
governments or banks abroad). At the end of June 1970 the total of these
balances held by residents of foreign countries was £4,729 million. Of this,
£469 million w'as the counterpart of the United Kingdom’s short- and
medium-term borrowing. Excluding this, the balances totalled £4,260 million,
of which £730 million was to residents of the non-sterling area, £3,530 million
to residents of the sterling area. The total of the sterling balances (excluding
the counterpart of borrowing) has remained broadly constant since the end of
the second world war. The balance reflect the international trading and
reserve role of sterling and in part the financial services of the City. (For
terms of measures designed to stabilise the sterling balances, see p. 392.)
Overseas liabilities arising from investment in the private sector of the British
economy rose from £3,160 million in 1962 to £6,750 million at the end of
i969-
Overseas investors in Britain are free to repatriate the proceeds of the sale
of their investments, including any capital gains that they may have accrued.
Earned profit and dividends are transferable irrespective of their size. In 1969
the inflow of direct, portfolio and other private investment, including oil,
amounted to £621 million.

new competitive standards which in turn will strengthen the economy and its

Outward Private investment abroad may take several forms: portfolio investment, that
Private is, investment in overseas securities including the loans raised by overseas
Investment countries on the London capital market; or direct investment by the establish¬
ment of subsidiary companies abroad; or by acquiring an interest in an over¬
seas enterprise.
Although investment in the developing countries of the sterling area is in
general free from control the flow of capital from Britain to Australia, South
Africa, New Zealand and the Republic of Ireland is subject to prior approval
of the Bank of England. Approval is readily given for financing projects both
in these countries and in the non-sterling area by borrowing abroad on ap¬
propriate terms, and for financing from Britain where the project is expected
to yield substantial and continuing benefits to the United Kingdom balance
of payments. There is also considerable scope for the investment of retained
profits of subsidiary companies overseas and in recent years more than 60 per |
cent of net direct investment outflow has been financed in this way from un¬
remitted profits.
Board of Trade estimates show that direct investment outflow, excluding
oil, was £410 million in 1968; £177 million of this was placed in the overseas
sterling area and £233 million in non-sterling countries. Within the latter
figure the flow to the EEC area was £73 million, to EFT A £19 million and to
Latin America £17 million. In the same year the flow to Western Europe of
£101 million was of similar magnitude to the flow to North America of £114
million. Substantial growth in direct investment outflow in 1969 raised the
previous year’s level of £410 million to £531 niillion. Oil, portfolio and other
investment outflow, combined with the £531 milli°n direct investment, 1
resulted in an aggregate private investment outflow in 1969 of £617 million.

£8,085 million at the end of 1962. Direct investment, including oil, accounted
for £8,360 million1 of the £14,060 million figure, the balance consisting of
£5,700 million of portfolio investment.

Britain’s aid programme to the developing countries consists of loans and
grants for economic and social development, technical assistance, budget
support and contributions to multilateral agencies providing financial aid and
technical assistance to these countries. In addition to this official aid pro¬
gramme, an important contribution is made to economic development by
private investment and by private voluntary organisations engaged in relief,
development and educational work.
Since 1945 total official aid disbursements have amounted to over £2,700
million. Despite recent economic difficulties they have been maintained at a
high level, the average gross annual disbursement over the four years 1966-69
having been about £211 million (see Table 32). In 1969 they amounted to
nearly £211 million, of which bilateral aid accounted for £179 million
including £44 million technical assistance; assistance provided through multi¬
lateral agencies was £32 million. Repayments of capital and payments of
interest during the year on loans made previously totalled about £60 million.
The net flow of British resources to developing countries—private invest¬
ment and private export credits as well as official aid—exceeded the target
of 1 per cent of national income, as set by the first United Nations Conference
on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) in 1964, in each of the nine years
to 1966. In 1967 the percentage was 0-94. The second UNCTAD in 1968
recommended that the target should be raised to 1 per cent of gross national
product at market prices, which represented in Britain’s case an increase of

about one-quarter. No date for attaining this objective was agreed on but the
report of the Commission on International Development in 1969 recommended
that it should be reached by 1975 and suggested that the official component of
aid flows should be raised to 0-7 per cent of donor gross national product by
1975 and in no case later than 1980. The Commission recognised however
that the increase would pose considerable problems for certain countries,
including Britain, and recommended that as a first step these countries should

Total British official and private flows in 1969 amounted to 0-97 per cent
of gross national product; official flows were 0-39 per cent. Public expenditure
on economic aid during the five years beginning in 1969-70 is to be pro¬
gressively raised to an estimated £300 million in 1973-74. This represents gross
official flows only; the volume of private flows, although influenced by govern¬
ment policies, is not determined by the Government and is difficult to predict,
as also is the future level of the gross national product.
Estimated expenditure on economic aid during the financial year 1970-71
is ^229 million, a figure which does not include special defence aid of
£6 million for Malaysia and Singapore and other defence aid of ^5-4 million.
Bilateral Bilateral financial aid in 1969 totalled ^179 million; over 48 per cent was in
Financial Aid grants and the rest in loans. Budgetary aid, £15 million in 1969, is provided in
the form of grants. Development aid is in grants or loans, depending on the
economic circumstances of the recipient countries; the greater part of it is in
loans. The terms of new development loans from Britain have been pro¬
gressively softened since 1958 and a policy of making interest-free loans to
lighten the repayment burdens of the poorer developing countries was intro¬
duced in June 1965. In 1969 the total value of loan commitments entered
into by the British Government, excluding investments by the Common¬
wealth Development Corporation (see below), was ^97 million and of this
over 91 per cent was on interest-free terms. The recipients included India,
Pakistan, Mauritius, Ghana, Turkey, Guyana, Ceylon and Indonesia.
Where loans are made on interest-bearing terms, waivers of interest for a
period of years are granted in appropriate cases, and both kinds of loan may
carry grace periods during which repayments of capital are not made. Of all
loans committed in 1969, 99 per cent of value carried grace periods averaging
6 years for capital repayments while the weighted average maturity of loans
was 24 years. Britain more than fulfils the recommendations of the Develop¬
ment Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation
and Development (OECD), made in February 1968, on easing the terms of
financial aid.
Loans and grants are used mainly for the purchase of goods, equipment and
services from Britain, although there may be a substantial element for local
costs and for procurement from third countries in appropriate cases. Between
1958 and the end of 1969, 261 loans were negotiated involving a commitment
of £816 million, of which £655 million has been disbursed. The recipients of
the largest amounts have been India and Pakistan. During the same period
bilateral grants amounted to around £889 million.
Commonwealth Historically, Britain’s aid programme began as part of the discharge of its
Countries responsibilities towards dependent territories, and the main emphasis
remains on Commonwealth countries. In 1969 £157 million (88 per cent) of
the bilateral programme was disbursed to Commonwealth countries and
dependencies.
In the past, development aid to the dependent territories was given under

the Colonial Development and Welfare (CD & W) Acts, largely in the form
of grants but also in loans. When CD & W legislation terminated on 31st
March 1970, the total amount committed under it was nearly £486 million.
The aid requirements of the remaining dependencies, which are regarded
as a first charge on aid funds, will be provided under the authority of the
Overseas Aid Act 1966. In 1969 the territories received ^18 million in
bilateral financial aid and technical assistance (10 per cent of the bilateral
programme), including about £8 million under the CD & W Acts.
An important role in development assistance is played by the Common¬
wealth Development Corporation (CDC), set up by the British Government
in 1948, which provides finance and management for development projects
in Commonwealth countries and dependencies, often in partnership with
governments or private enterprise. In 1969 the CDC’s borrowing powers
were increased and the area of its operations was extended to non-Common-
wealth countries. By the end of 1969 some £130 million had been invested
out of a total commitment of ^157 million. Of the latter, £22 million was in
the Far East, £22 million in the Caribbean and virtually all of the remainder
in Africa. New investment approved in 1969 totalled over £13 million.
Expenditure on bilateral technical assistance (the provision of skilled person¬
nel, advice and training) has increased in recent years and was £44 million,
21 per cent total aid, in 1969. The largest component of expenditure (£27-6
million in 1969) was on sending or maintaining experts, including volunteers;
the next largest was for students and trainees in Britain (£8-i million).
Under the Overseas Service Aid Scheme (OSAS) and associated schemes
Britain meets the additional costs of employing experienced expatriate British
personnel in the public services of developing countries. The schemes cost
£22 million in 1969.
At the end of 1969, of the 12,400 British persons other than volunteers who
were working in developing countries and financed by the British Govern¬
ment, about 5,000 were engaged in the field of education, 2,600 in public
works and communications, 1,500 in public administration, 1,000 in agri¬
culture and allied fields, and 1,100 in health services.
In addition, the British Volunteer Programme has continued to expand (the
first volunteers were sent overseas in 1958) and in 1969 there were 2,157
volunteers, mainly graduates or otherwise qualified, working in developing
countries, the majority of them teaching. Recruitment, training and placing
overseas is undertaken by a number of voluntary bodies; 75 per cent of the
British costs (^o-8 million in 1969) are met by the British Government.
Britain receives large numbers of students and trainees from developing
countries. Over 10,800 were financed in Britain in 1969 under regional
programmes of technical assistance, by awards under the Commonwealth
Education Co-operation Scholarships and Bursary Schemes, and under the
various schemes of the British Council.
Britain is the second largest contributor (after the United States) to the
World Bank group of institutions including the International Development
Association (IDA). The British contribution to IDA in the three years 1968-70
has been nearly ^65 million; the proposed contribution for the three years
1971-73 is nearly £130 million. Britain has contributed £46 million to the
United Nations Development Programme since its inception in 1950 and has
provided more experts and training places under multilateral schemes than
any other country. Some 1,240 British nationals were serving in developing

contributions include those to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency

INTERNAL TRADE
Britain’s internal trade can be divided into two broad categories: trade in raw
materials, capital goods and intermediate products (for example, vehicle
components) and trade in consumer goods, involving the network of distribu¬
tive trades by which home produced or imported goods reach the consumer.
(For the pattern of consumers’ expenditure see p. 232.)
There have been a number of official statistical enquiries into the distributive
trades. The latest censuses taken in Great Britain refer to the wholesale trades
in 1965 and the retail trades and certain service trades in 1966. Sample
monthly and annual enquiries are also undertaken, covering such aspects of
the distributive trades as turnover, stocks and capital expenditure. Most of the
figures given in the following pages derive from either the last published
censuses or the sample enquiries.
The first census of retail distribution and other services to be taken in
Northern Ireland relates to 1965.
Only a proportion of the trade in consumer goods passes through wholesalers:
sales are also made to consumers through producers’ own selling organisations
(including their own retail outlets and mail order businesses); and other sales
are made directly by producers to retailers. Wholesale channels are particularly
in evidence in the distribution of textiles, agricultural produce and foodstuffs.
The 1965 enquiry showed that out of a total of 23,643 business units engaged
in wholesale distribution in Great Britain, 3,435 dealt in clothing, footwear
and textiles, 2,007 in grocery and provisions, 2,630 in vegetables and fruit,
and 3,469 in other food and in drink. In addition, there were 8,282 dealers
(wholesale or retail) in coal, builders’ materials, grain or agricultural supplies,
and 9,117 dealers in other industrial materials and machinery. The value of
stocks held by wholesalers and dealers at the end of 1969 is estimated at
£1,220 million; expenditure on capital assets during the year was about
£140 million.
Methods of wholesale distribution vary according to the type of merchandise
handled. Fish, for example, is auctioned at the ports to port wholesalers (who
sell to inland wholesalers at the main distribution centres) or, increasingly, is
sold by contract to fryers and processors, or direct to retailers. Fruit and
vegetables may be sold by growers to commission agents (who dispose of the
produce either to wholesalers or direct to retailers) or the grower may deal
only with wholesale firms. The sale of some agricultural products is regulated
by statutory marketing boards (see p. 310).
London’s wholesale markets play a leading part in the distribution of
foodstuffs, particularly imported supplies. Every year Covent Garden (see
p. 315) handles about 1-2 million tons of fruit and vegetables, and over
340,000 tons of meat and poultry pass through Smithfield market; Billingsgate
is the principal distributing centre in Britain for fish. Others in London
include Leadenhall Market (poultry) and Spitalfields Market (fruit and
vegetables).
The co-operative movement in Britain has established its own wholesale
societies, the two largest being the Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd.
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
4°3
(CWS) and the Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd. (SCWS), to
serve the needs of retail societies, membership being restricted to incorporated
co-operative organisations. The CWS had sales of 3^5I9 in 19^)9 anc^
the SCWS had sales of some £90 million.
Since 1954, many wholesalers have joined, either singly or in groups, with
numbers of retailers to form voluntary groups to help to preserve the existence
of retail outlets for the wholesaler and to give to retailers the advantages of
the lower costs of large-scale trading without significant loss of independence.
The 1966 Census of Distribution showed that about 27 per cent (or 41 per
cent in terms of turnover) of independent grocers then belonged to these
chains and membership has since spread to many other kinds of business.
RETAIL TRADE

Retail businesses in Britain may be classified under three main headings:
(1) multiple traders, that is, organisations other than co-operative societies
with ten or more branches; (2) retail co-operative societies (see below); and
(3) independent retail businesses, including for this purpose the small
multiple stores (that is, chains of stores with nine or fewer branches). Busi¬
nesses in each of these categories may own department stores. Other retail
outlets include gas and electricity showrooms owned by the area gas and
electricity boards, and mail order houses (see p. 404).
The findings of the 1966 Census of Distribution (Table 34) show that, in
comparison with 1961, a larger volume of trade had been handled by rather
fewer shops. A notable feature is the continuing expansion of large multiple
firms relative to other types of shop. Independent shops, however, still account
for over half of Britain’s retail trade.
A very wide range is covered in the size of retailing establishments. Ten
shops (nine of them department stores) had sales in 1961 exceeding £5 million
or takings of more than £2,000 an hour; at the other extreme there were more
than 70,000 establishments taking less than .£2,000 a year. Some of these were
market and street traders, whose volume of business may be very small.
According to the Census of Distribution there were nearly 74,000 shops
owned by multiples (including multiple department stores) in 1966 with
a total turnover of £3,837 million. This form of organisation showed the
largest rise in numbers between 1961 and 1966 and their share in total sales
went up from 29 per cent to 34 per cent. Their turnover increased faster than
that of independent businesses between 1966 and 1969.
The share in total retail trade of co-operative stores dropped from 11 to 9 per
cent between 1961 and 1966 which was rather less than the relative decrease in
the number of stores. Between 1966 and 1969 their turnover increased slightly.
The retail co-operative societies are voluntary organisations controlled
by their members. Membership is open to anyone paying a small deposit
on a minimum share, which entitles the member to an equal voice with other
members in the society. Share investment by individual members is limited
to £1,000 (less in some societies) and only a low rate of interest is normally
paid on the shares.
In the past the trading surplus, after allocation to reserves and common
activities, has been paid out periodically to members in the form of a dividend
in proportion to their purchases. Some societies have used a system of
differential dividends by reducing prices in some departments such as food¬
stuffs. More recently a large number of societies have introduced dividend
stamps redeemable for cash, other goods, or credit to a share account, at
different redemption rates.
404 BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
At the end of 1969 there were 469 retail co-operative societies. Amalgama¬
tions are rapidly diminishing the number of societies (the total in 1958 was
1,015). The largest single society in Britain is the London Co-operative

Total sales of the retail co-operative societies in 1969 amounted to over
£1,130 million (this figure includes certain activities not covered by the
Census of Distribution figure in Table 33).
Independent Shops Independent shops have been giving ground gradually in the face of increased
competition from the larger undertakings. The proprietors of many of the
smaller shops often have other means of livelihood. Average turnover per shop
has continued to increase, though by less than for the retail trade as a whole.
None the less, even allowing for a 15 per cent increase in prices, the average
independent shop sold more goods in 1966 than in 1961.
Department Stores There were 760 department stores in Britain in 1969 with a turnover of
£653 million—about 6 per cent of the total turnover of all retail establishments.
Department stores were defined for the purposes of the census as having 25 or
more persons engaged in selling a wide range of commodities notably clothing
and household goods. Co-operative societies owned 238 department stores
in 1966; 214 were owned by multiples and 308 by independents.
Recent Trends Out of a total of over 500,000 establishments recorded by the 1966 Census
in Retail Trade of Distribution, and shown in Table 34, grocery and other food retailing
groups numbered over 227,000 establishments, and the clothing and foot¬
wear group over 83,000.
Though the total value of retail trade in Great Britain (inclusive of
electricity and gas showrooms and mail order business) rose by a quarter
between 1961 and 1966, rates of growth (measured in turnover) varied
appreciably between different types of trade. The slowest growth was in
general stores, in the food and clothing sectors, and department stores. The
fastest growth was in radio and television hire, mail order business, gas and
electricity showroom sales of durable goods, sports and leisure equipment,
chemists’ and photographic goods and sales of automatic vending machines.

However, the actual trends are blurred by the introduction into specialised
shops of other specialities, for example, clothing multiples opening food
sections, and vice versa. Though gas and electricity showroom business was
buoyant between 1961 and 1966, their combined turnover is relatively small,
amounting in 1966 to £186 million.
The real expansion in the volume of sales in Great Britain between 1961 and
1966, taking into account the exclusion of market traders (included in the 1961
Census) and a general increase in prices of 15 per cent, was about 9-6 per cent,
or an average of 1-9 per cent a year. Sales by all kinds of retail business
increased in real terms by 3 per cent between 1966 and 1969.
The Northern Ireland 1965 Census of Retail Distribution and Other
Services shows total spending of 3^385 million through 22,000 establishments.
The value increased by 14 per cent between 1965 and 1969.
The development of self-service trading has been a feature of the last two
decades. In 1969 there were some 23,000 stores operating wholly or partly
on self-service lines, compared with about 9,500 towards the end of 1961 and
less than 500 in 1950. This development has been accompanied by a trend to
larger shops in terms of both staff and floor space.
Supermarkets may be defined as self-service shops with a minimum selling
area of 2,000 square feet. There were about 870 supermarkets in 1961, accord¬
ing to the Census of Distribution, of which 524 were owned by multiples,
308 by co-operative societies and 38 by independents. It has been estimated
that by the end of 1969 over 3,300 had been opened and were handling some
25 per cent of Britain’s retail grocery trade.
New forms of automatic vending machines have come to the fore since 1955.
Over 300,000 machines are in use. Sales from automatic vending machines

totalled nearly £169 million in 1969; over £100 million was accounted for by
sales from cigarette machines. Machines now sell not only cigarettes, sweets
and stamps but also hot and cold beverages, prepared foodstuffs, stockings,
paper-back books and other commodities, including various types of fuel.
Another form is the self-service petrol pump. Organisations selling automatic
vending machines (not otherwise engaged in retail trade) numbered 56 in
1966, with sales of nearly £11 million.
Some 11,700 mobile shops1 were reported in the Census of Distribution for
1961, with sales amounting to £93 million. Nearly a quarter of this turnover
was concentrated in Scotland (where the density of population is lower than
in England) compared with a tenth of all retail sales. Co-operative societies
accounted for 39 per cent of sales through mobile food shops, against 16 per
cent in ordinary food shops. For the most part, mobile shops were concerned
with food sales; about 42 per cent were travelling grocers, and over 28 per cent
and 21 per cent respectively were greengrocers and butchers. Only a very
small proportion (about 6 per cent) were non-food shops, and these specialised
mainly in paraffin supplies and hardware.
A number of large ‘out of town’ stores are being opened, providing a range
of goods under one roof, associated with extensive car parking facilities, away
from established central shopping areas.
‘Cash and Carry’ shops represent a combination of retail supermarkets and
wholesale warehouses covering practically every form of retail trade. By bulk
purchasing and little spending on attractive surroundings they can offer large
price discounts to retail customers. The numbers of this type of store have
grown rapidly from 398 in 1967 to an estimated 592 in May 1970, with a
turnover of some £420 million a year.
All forms of consumer sales promotion have been expanding, including
reduced price offers, gift schemes, and stamp trading. The stamps, by law,
have to be marked with their cash value and redeemed for cash on request.
It has been estimated that manufacturers spent some £160 million on
promotions in 1969 compared with £117 in 1965.
A facility which is spreading in Britain is the ‘credit card’. Users are issued
with a card on production of which their signature is accepted on bills in
participating shops, hotels and restuarants. The issuers then meet the bills and
recover from the card-holder through a single account presented periodically.
Users of certain cards are also required to pay a regular subscription.
Mail Order Mail order trading has been one of the most rapidly growing forms of selling
Sales and in Britain in recent years. The 1966 Census of Distribution showed that the
Direct Selling sales of retail mail order businesses had almost doubled in five years from
£227 million to £429 million; an increase of just under ten times since 1950,
when they amounted to £46 million. Turnover continued to rise steadily
between 1966 and 1969.
Sales by manufacturers direct to the public totalled £144 million in 1961,
compared with £70 million in 1950. Mail order sales accounted for 24 per
cent of the former total, sales to employees for 11 per cent, and charges for
work done for 9 per cent. Other direct sales, including sales by door-to-door
salesmen, accounted for the balance. Included in these sales were items as
various as carpets, washing machines, brushes, books and soft drinks.

Closely connected with the distributive trades are those which offer a service
directly to the public, notably catering and hotel trades, laundries and dry
cleaners, garage and motor repair trades, hairdressers and boot and shoe
repairers.
In 1964 there were 149,000 establishments primarily concerned with catering
(defined to cover public houses, canteens and fish and chip shops, as well as
licensed hotels and restaurants, etc.) with a total turnover in that year of
£1,985 million. Hotels and holiday camps (excluding boarding houses and
unlicensed hotels) had receipts of about £286 million, of which £124 million
was from residential accommodation. Nearly half the total turnover of the
catering trades was from the sale of alcoholic drinks. Between 1964 and 1969
the catering trades’ turnover increased by 26 per cent. In addition coin-
operated machines are widely being installed in factories—some 60,000
beverage and snack machines are estimated to have been provided in industrial
sites—and in commercial premises as well as in normal retail outlets.
There were about 5,600 commercial laundry, launderette and dry cleaning
businesses with an annual turnover of about £172 million in 1966. Between
1961 and 1966 it increased by 53 per cent, but in the following three years
turnover of this group, other than launderettes and coin-operated dry cleaning
establishments, showed little change.
There were nearly 43,000 businesses in the motor trades in Britain in 1967
with 51,000 establishments. Total turnover amounted to £4,198 million.
Traders classified as new vehicle dealers had nearly 14,000 establishments
and accounted for over two-thirds of total turnover. Over 11,000 establish¬
ments were classified as being primarily petrol stations, and 11,000 were also
general repairers. Between 1967 and 1969 the motor trades turnover has
increased by about 11 per cent.
Takings in hairdressing establishments increased very rapidly between 1950
(£38 million) and 1961 (£97 million), and between 1961 and 1966 to £136
million. Between 1966 and 1969 they rose by only 4 per cent. In 1966 there
were about 48,000 hairdressing establishments.
There are some 8,700 establishments specialising in boot and shoe repairs
(excluding repairs handled through footwear shops); they had takings of £26
million in 1966.
Other establishments found in shopping areas and offering a service to the
public include those of radio and television rental companies (over 3,800
shops), licensed betting offices (over 15,700 in 1968) and over 3,500 funeral
undertaking businesses.
British industry’s current annual expenditure on packaging has been estimated
at £850 million. The expansion of self-service shops, the spread of branded
and standardised products, and developments in partly prepared foods, for
example, ready-washed vegetables and ready-made cake mixes, have been
major factors in the great changes which have taken place in packaging
methods. Paper packaging, including cartons and boxes, remains the most
extensively used (turnover of some £380 million a year), the fastest growing
sector being paper sacks. New uses are being found for tinplate (output,
£130 million a year), especially in sales of soft drinks and beer. Glass and
plastics packaging account for about £65 million and £70 million a year
respectively. The use of plastics continues to develop; output of plastics
films reached some 72,000 tons in 1969 and that of polypropylene, and other
