SAFETY, HEALTH
AND WELFARE
IN NORTHERN
IRELAND
HUMAN
RELATIONS
INDUSTRIAL
RELATIONS
of low-priced meals at the place of employment has become usual in large
undertakings and quite common in smaller ones. Many offices and shops
which are unable to provide canteen facilities for their staff have adopted
luncheon voucher schemes.
The safety, health and welfare of employees in Northern Ireland have been
the subject of legislation which, with some exceptions, is similar to that in
Great Britain and is embodied in the Factories Act (Northern Ireland) 1965
and the Office and Shop Premises Act (Northern Ireland) 1966. Many firms
voluntarily employ safety officers, and an Industrial Safety Group for the area,
supported by representatives of industry, trade unions, insurance companies
and public authorities, makes a valuable contribution in the field of industrial
accident prevention on similar lines to what is done in Great Britain.
Practically all large industrial firms and many small ones now have a personnel
department staffed by one or more specialist officers. While the form of
organisation of personnel departments varies, personnel officers are generally
responsible for advising all levels of management on every aspect of labour
relations. They also have particular duties with regard to recruitment,
selection, education and training, transfer of labour, the application of wage
agreements, the promotion of good communication and consultation and the
supervision of working conditions and employees’ amenities.
Recruitment and promotion policies are matters which each undertaking
decides for itself, although in some industries the decisions may be limited
by collective agreements or by trade practices. Great importance has recently
been attached to selection; and courses for training personnel officers in
modern interviewing techniques, including the use of test procedures, are
now well attended.
The Manpower and Productivity Service of the DEP (see p. 416) is
available to give advice on personnel policies, personnel management tech¬
niques and problems of human relations at the workplace. It also assists the
creation and support of machinery for negotiation and settlement of disputes.
Both official and voluntary organisations are concerned with promoting
better human relationships in industry. The Government has sought to
extend by research the available knowledge of the factors influencing human
relations in industry and human efficiency. Such research is sponsored or
conducted by the Social Science Research Council (see p. 203) and the
Medical Research Council (see p. 198). Voluntary organisations include
bodies which deal with management problems and provide a service to
subscribing firms; professional associations, linking individuals with a com¬
mon interest in particular functions of management; and bodies providing
specialist services, usually on a fee-paying basis.
The structure of labour relations in Britain is established mainly on a voluntary
basis, and the extensive changes currently proposed (see below) are designed
to retain the voluntary principle while modernising the conditions in which it
operates. The system will still rest on the organisation of employers and
workers into employers’ associations and trade unions. These organisations
discuss and negotiate terms and conditions of employment and other matters
affecting the workpeople at their work. In the past the emphasis has been on
detailed industry-wide agreements supplemented as necessary by informal
agreements in firms or factories, but in a major reform of attitudes and
structure emphasis is now being placed on formal agreements at firm and
LABOUR
427
Wages Councils
Employers’
Associations
factory level. In some industries, firms and factories negotiations are con¬
ducted simply by ad hoc meetings of employers’ and employees’ representatives,
which are held when necessary; in others, voluntary joint councils or com¬
mittees have been established on a permanent basis. The scope of the various
joint bodies—from the National Joint Industrial Councils for whole in¬
dustries to the Works Councils and Committees in individual workplaces—
varies widely. Some of them only negotiate. Others only discuss a wide range
of topics. But the scope of the bodies is tending in general to widen and the
distinction between discussion and negotiation to become blurred. Normally
these arrangements for collective bargaining suffice to settle all questions
which are raised, but provision is often made for matters not so settled to be
referred for settlement to independent arbitration; nowadays this provision is
seldom used. Standing arrangements exist for consultation at national level
between the Government, the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) (see
p. 428), the Trades Union Congress (TUC) (see p. 429) and the nationalised
industries through the National Joint Advisory Council, set up in 1939 to
advise the Government on matters in which employers and workers have a
common interest. It meets under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State.
I he Report of the Royal Commission on Trade Unions and Employers’
Associations (Cmnd 3^23) published in June 1968 analysed the industrial
relations system in Britain and made recommendations. In March 1969, the
Commission on Industrial Relations was established, on lines suggested by
the Royal Commission, to form a focus for the improvement of collective
bargaining machinery. Another recommendation of the Royal Commission was
implemented when early in 1969 companies with 5,000 or more employees
were invited to register with the Manpower and Productivity Service of the
DEP their procedure agreements, that is, all agreements about the machinery
for the determination of the terms and conditions of employment, the settle¬
ment of grievances and disputes and other matters which are generally the
subject of consultation between management and unions.
The Government intend to introduce legislation which will provide a new
legal framework within which the industrial relations system will operate.
In a small and decreasing number of industries and trades where the organisa¬
tion of employers or employees or both is not strong enough to provide a
basis for successful voluntary arrangements, there are statutory wage-regula¬
ting bodies, known as Wages Councils. These are composed of equal numbers
of representatives of employers and workers in the respective sectors of
industry, with additional independent members. Wages Councils may submit
proposals for fixing minimum remuneration and holidays with pay to the
Secretary of State who must then make orders giving statutory force to such
proposals, subject only to his right to return them as a whole for further
consideration. The DEP’s Wages Inspectorate helps employers and workers
to interpret the provisions of wage regulation orders and sees that they are
complied with.
Agricultural Wages Boards (there are separate Boards for England and
Wales and for Scotland) perform similar functions in relation to employment
in agriculture.
Many employers in Great Britain are members of employers’ organisations
wholly or partly concerned with labour questions. The primary aims of such
organisations are to help to establish suitable terms and conditions of em¬
ployment, including a sound wage structure and proper standards of safetv,
428
The Confederation
of British
Industry
Trade Unions
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
health and welfare; to promote good relations with employees and the
efficient use of manpower; and to provide means of settling any disputes
which may arise. Different employers’ organisations vary in the emphasis
which they put upon these different aims and in the means by which they try
to achieve them. Although the negotiation of wages and working conditions
and the settlement of disputes remain their essential function, the majority
of the organisations provide help and advice on many aspects of industrial
relations, with the aim of developing positive employment policies and
promoting productivity.
There is diversity of structure as well as function. Generally, however,
employers’ organisations are organised on an industry basis rather than a
product basis. A few are purely local in character or deal with a section of
an industry; others are national in scope and are concerned with the whole
of a particular industry. In some of the chief industries there are local or
regional organisations combined into national federations, while in others,
within which different firms are engaged on making different principal
products, there is a complex structure with national and regional federations
for these different sections of the industry as well as for the industry as a
whole. Although there are some 1,400 employers’ organisations dealing with
labour matters, most of these are federated to national organisations. There
are about 85 of these, many of which are in membership of the CBI and are
the ones that negotiate the important national collective agreements with
trade unions.
The final authority of a local or small national organisation may be a meeting
where all member firms are directly represented; but in larger organisations
some form of indirect representation is necessary, either through local
organisations or through regions or sections into which these are grouped.
The representatives thus chosen, together with a number of office holders,
form a general council or central committee, which meets perhaps once a
quarter, mainly to make major policy decisions, to elect committees and to
ratify their work. A paid staff under a director or secretary carries out the
organisation’s day-to-day work. There is usually a small working group,
consisting of senior officials and committee chairmen, which meets to deal
with urgent questions and co-ordinate the work of committees.
The central body of employers is the CBI, which deals with all matters (not
only labour relations) affecting the interests of organised employers and
represents them nationally to the Government and the public and also
internationally, for instance, in the International Labour Organisation. The
majority of national employers’ organisations, most nationalised industries
and a large number of individual companies are affiliated to the CBI. Its
representatives sit on various government advisory committees, on other
statutory bodies and on voluntary bodies concerned with labour matters.
In nearly all industries and occupations some workers—and in some industries
nearly all workers—are organised into trade unions. These have grown up
gradually and independently over a great many years and, consequently, their
form and organisation vary considerably as do their traditions and attitudes,
for example, their degree of concern with political movements. Trade unions
started more than two hundred years ago among the skilled craftsmen and
spread later to the general labouring and unskilled classes. More recently trade
unionism has increased among clerical, supervisory, technical and adminis¬
trative workers. A number of associations of professional workers, formed
primarily for the preservation and improvement of professional standards,
LABOUR
Trades Union
Congress
429
have also come to exercise many of the functions of trade unions, including
negotiations on salary and fee scales, and are legally trade unions. The
qualification for membership of some unions is occupational (for instance,
they may recruit clerks or fitters wherever employed), while in others the
qualification is industrial (that is, they seek to recruit all persons in an industry,
whatever their occupation). In a number of unions recruitment is based on a
combination of these principles. A few large unions recruit members in a
number of different occupations and industries.
At the end of 1968 the total membership of British trade unions was about
10 million. There were 534 unions, but nearly 70 per cent of all trade unionists
were in the 19 largest unions, while more than half were in the nine unions
with a membership of over 250,000. The number of trade unionists has
increased during the last decade but the number of unions has gone down
owing to amalgamations.
The basic unit of organisation in most British trade unions is the local
branch (sometimes called a lodge). Every member of the union belongs to a
branch. He may attend its meetings, make suggestions about terms and con¬
ditions of employment, discuss the work of the union, and take part in the
election of the union’s officers. The branch takes action on certain matters
considered to be entirely, or mainly, of local interest and forwards its views on
wider issues for action by the union’s national or regional bodies. The branch
draws its members from the locality and in only a few unions is it based on
the place of work. Many unions have shop stewards or other representatives
at the place of work to undertake organisation there. Where two or more
unions have members in the same workplace, shop stewards committees may
be formed to discuss matters of common concern.
In most large unions the central organisation is along the following lines:
elected officials, including a general secretary assisted by clerical and specialist
staff, are in charge of the work of the head office and are responsible to an
elected national executive council or committee which may be part-time or
full-time, and which is responsible to annual or biennial conferences of
delegates from the branches. Executive committees or councils play an
important part in the government of the unions; between conferences they
are the highest authorities and carry out policy decisions made by delegates.
Most unions also have some regional, district or area organisation.
Trade unions may affiliate to one or more federations or confederations
whose main purpose in most cases is to represent all or most of the trade
unions in an industry in negotiations with employers. The scope and authority
of these federations and confederations vary greatly.
In Britain the national centre of the trade union movement is the TUC, which
celebrated its centenary in June 1968. The TUC’s objects are to promote
the interests of its affiliated organisations and to improve the economic and
social conditions of the workers. Its membership comprises 160 organisations,
some of which are themselves federations of smaller organisations. Together
they represent about 9-4 million workpeople. The TUC deals with all general
questions which concern trade unions both nationally and internationally and
gives assistance on questions relating to particular trades or industries at the
request of the trade union concerned.
The congress of delegates, which constitutes the TUC proper, meets for a
week every year to discuss matters of general interest to trade unionists and
to employees generally. It elects annually a General Council which represents
it during the remaining 51 weeks of the year. This is responsible for carrying
430
Scottish Trades
Union Congress
State Provision
for Conciliation,
Arbitration and
Investigation
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
out congress decisions, for watching economic and social developments, for
providing educational and advisory services to unions, and for presenting to
the Government the trade union viewpoint on economic, social and industrial
issues. It is also empowered to mediate in inter-union disputes in certain
circumstances and its activities in this sphere were enlarged following a special
congress in June 1969 and subsequent agreement with the Government. The
General Council undertook to use its authority to deal with unauthorised and
unconstitutional stoppages of work, as well as the inter-union and official
disputes with which it had dealt previously.
The TUC is a non-political body but under the Trade Union Act 1913
individual trade unions can, by a ballot vote of members, decide to set up a
political fund, financed by a separate levy, which any member can refuse to
pay without loss of his normal union rights and benefits. About 100 separate
trade union organisations, including most of the largest trade unions, have
such a fund and, in most cases, it is used to support the Labour Party.
Both the TUC and many unions conduct extensive educational services for
members, mainly concerned with industrial subjects, trade unionism and
industrial relations principles and practice.
Branches of various trade unions in a locality generally affiliate to a local
trades council, which acts as a forum for the discussion of matters of common
interest and as a local agent of the TUC, by which it is registered each year.
There are just over 500 trades councils in England and Wales alone, grouped
together in 22 federations.
Affiliation to the TUC is open to all trade unions anywhere in the United
Kingdom, but Scottish trade unionists have their own national centre, the
Scottish Trades Union Congress, similar within its objects to the TUC. The
Scottish TUC, to which trade unions may affiliate in respect of their member¬
ship in Scotland (a number of unions are affiliated to both bodies), also accepts
affiliation from trades councils and has an affiliated membership of about
840,000. It holds an annual congress and has consultations with the Govern¬
ment on issues affecting Scottish trade unionists.
Matters which prove difficult to settle by negotiation are sometimes referred
by agreement to independent conciliators or arbitrators, and one way in which
the parties can find such persons is by invoking the help of the Secretary of
State. Under authority derived from the Conciliation Act 1896, and the
Industrial Courts Act 1919, the Secretary of State has certain powers to assist
industry to settle disputes which it is not found possible to resolve through an
industry’s own machinery and procedure. These powers are all intended to
supplement and not to supersede the industry’s own machinery. There is no
legal obligation on the parties to a dispute to notify the dispute to the Secretary
of State nor to place the question before a conciliator.
The Department of Employment and Productivity assists with conciliation
in industry through its Industrial Relations Division and the field staff of the
Manpower and Productivity Service, who keep in touch with the course of
relations between employers and workers at national, district and, in some
cases, factory level and assist them, if requested, to settle their problems by
joint discussion and negotiation. Conciliators have no legal powers.
Disputes which cannot be settled in this way may, at the request of both
parties, be referred to voluntary arbitration, either by a single arbitrator, or
an ad hoc Board of Arbitration, or by the Industrial Court, a permanent
tribunal established under the Industrial Courts i\ct. The court normally
Industrial
Disputes
Labour
Relations of
Public
Authorities
Central and Local
Government
LABOUR 431
consists of three members—the president, one member experienced in
representing employers and one in representing workpeople.
Like collective agreements, arbitration awards are not in themselves en¬
forceable at law, but, under the Terms and Conditions of Employment Act
1959, reports that a particular employer is not observing the recognised terms
or conditions of employment in his trade or industry may be made to the
Secretary of State by organisations which are parties to the relevant agreement
or award. If the matter is not otherwise settled, the Secretary of State must
refer it to the Industrial Court which, after hearing the case, may issue an
award requiring the employer to observe the recognised terms or conditions.
Such an award becomes an implied term of the contract of employment of
individual employees.
The Secretary of State is also empowered to appoint a Court of Inquiry or
Committee of Investigation into a dispute, whether existing or apprehended.
These procedures are primarily means of informing public opinion of the
facts of a dispute (the report of a Court of Inquiry has to be laid before
Parliament). Although the recommendations contained in the reports of such
bodies are not binding on the parties, they often provide the basis for further
negotiations leading to a settlement.
Over the past 10 years the number of working days lost each year through
stoppages of work arising from industrial disputes has been on an average
about 31 million which, taking the working population as a whole, works out
at approximately one hour per worker per year. The time lost through
stoppages of work due to industrial dispute is very much less than that lost
on account of sickness, accidents and absenteeism and Britain’s record over
the past ten years compares well with that of most other industrial countries.
Government, industry and trade unions have expressed concern both at
the number of strikes which take place without the backing of trade union
headquarters and without exhausting the agreed or customary procedures in
the industry or workplace, and at the concentration of a high proportion of
these strikes in a limited number of important industries. While the ultimate
economic impact of the strikes themselves is difficult to assess, they show that
there is still room for improvement in the industrial relations system and the
spirit in which it is operated.
While labour relations in government service and in the nationalised indus¬
tries are, in general, organised on the same principle as in private industry,
there are some special features.
Non-industrial employees in central government service, where salaries and
conditions of service are dealt with by the Civil Service Department (see p.
48), are permitted and encouraged to join the appropriate Civil Service staff
associations (trade unions) and there is a highly developed system of negotia¬
tion and joint consultation by means of the National and Departmental
Whitley Councils (see p. 65). If there is failure to reach agreement by
negotiation a department or association may, subject to certain limitations,
report the dispute to the Secretary of State for reference to the Civil Service
Arbitration Tribunal, an independent body appointed by the Secretary of
State by powers under the Industrial Courts Act 1919. Government indus¬
trial employees are similarly encouraged to belong to trade unions and
machinery exists for joint consultation. There are four Trades Joint Councils
on which representatives of the Government and the trade unions sit to
432
Nationalised
Industries
Northern
Ireland
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
consider pay and conditions of employment affecting individual grades and
certain other limited matters. A Joint Co-ordinating Committee, on which the
Government and Trades Joint Councils are represented, deals with national
pay negotiations, conditions of service and other matters of general applica¬
tion. In the main employing departments there are departmental Joint Councils
for the discussion of domestic matters. Disputes on wages or conditions of
employment that cannot be resolved by the existing machinery can be referred
to the Industrial Court for arbitration.
In local government service there are separate National Joint Councils for
the main grades of employees (such as manual, clerical and technical em¬
ployees) which deal with wages and conditions of service as well as other
matters. There are corresponding regional and district councils.
In the nationalised industries, the main corporations, though not subject to
detailed governmental control, have a statutory duty to establish satisfactory
arrangements for collective bargaining in their industries and for joint con¬
sultation with their employees; but in carrying out these duties they are free to
choose suitable arrangements. The main difference from private industry is
that the corporations are not usually members of employers’ associations
(although the majority are ‘industrial associates’ of the CBI). In some
industries they are sole or main employers, but even where part of the industry
is in private hands, as for example in road transport, the corporations are
separately and directly represented on wage-negotiating bodies.
Wages and conditions of service in the nationalised industries are generally
settled by negotiation between representatives of managements and trade
unions at the national level; in most cases there are also regional and local
bodies, similarly representative, to deal with, local implications. Most of the
industries use the facilities for arbitration offered to industry generally by the
Department of Employment and Productivity but coalmining and rail trans¬
port have their own special arrangements. Consultations at all levels, includ¬
ing the workplace level, have been arranged in all the nationalised industries
according to the traditions and needs of each industry.
Some of the nationalised industries have felt that joint consultation was
best carried out by their negotiating bodies; others have established separate
and specially constituted joint committees at all levels.
The system of labour relations in Northern Ireland is based on the same
principles as that of Great Britain and the Minister of Plealth and Social
Services has powers and duties similar to those of the Secretary of State in
Great Britain. Nearly 90 per cent of trade unionists in Northern Ireland are
members of trade unions with headquarters in Great Britain.
17 TELEVISION
AND RADIO
BROADCASTING
Broadcasting
Authorities
Broadcasting by television and radio in Britain is regulated by the Minister of
Posts and Telecommunications under the Wireless Telegraphy Acts 1949-
1967, which prohibit the sending or receiving of wireless communications,
except under licence.
Radio broadcasting services for Britain and abroad are provided by the
British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), which was established by Royal
Charter in 1927.1 Television services are provided both by the BBC and by
the Independent Television Authority (ITA), which was established by the
Television Act 1954 as a supervisory body to control the operation of com¬
mercial television in Britain. The BBC operates nationally two television
and four radio services. The ITA provides one television service.
Users of television and radio sets must obtain an annual receiving licence,
which can be bought from most post offices. There were over 18-4 million
receiving licences current in Britain in June 1970 of which more than 16
million were for television and radio combined and nearly 2-3 million (includ¬
ing a million for sets fitted in cars) for radio only. The cost of receiving
licences is £6 for television and radio combined (^n for sound and colour
television), and £1-25 for radio alone. From April 1971 ‘radio only’ licences
will be abolished, and a television broadcast receiving licence introduced
costing ^6-50 (£11-50 for colour).
The number of hours of television broadcasting is regulated by the
Minister and an arrangement has been approved which permits any one
service a maximum of 53^ hours a week (32 hours a week for BBC 2), but
with additional hours for outside broadcasts, religious and educational
programmes and broadcasts in the Welsh language. Similar regulations
control the number of hours of radio broadcasting.
Both the BBC and the ITA are constitutionally required to provide a ‘public
service’ with the purpose of disseminating information, education and
entertainment. The constitution and finances of the BBC are governed by
the Royal Charter of 1964 and by the Licence and Agreement of 1969, and
those of the ITA by the Television Act 1964 and its 1969 Licence.
The BBC and the ITA are independent authorities in the day-to-day
operations of broadcasting, including programmes and administration. The
Government, however, retains ultimate control, and the Minister of Posts and
Telecommunications, as the responsible minister, is answerable to Parliament
on broad questions of policy and may issue directions to the BBC and the
ITA on a number of technical and other subjects. Both organisations are
expected to show balance and due impartiality in their general presentation of
1 In July 1970 the Government announced its intention to permit broadcasting by
commercial radio stations (see p. 437).
434
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The British
Broadcasting
Corporation
The Independent
Television
Authority
programmes—particularly where matters of public policy or controversial
subjects are concerned—and in this connection the Minister has powers to
prohibit the broadcasting of any particular item or class of item, or to revoke
the licences of the BBC or ITA at any time. These powers, however, are
treated as major reserve powers and, in fact, no formal veto has ever been
placed on the broadcasting of a particular item. Both the BBC and the ITA
are required to prepare annual reports and accounts which are presented to
Parliament.
The Corporation consists of 12 governors (including a chairman, a vice-
chairman and separate national governors for Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland), each appointed for a period of not more than five years by the
Queen on the advice of the Government. The governors are constitutionally
responsible for the conduct of the whole broadcasting operation, including
the production and presentation of the programmes on television and radio,
and the provision and working of the necessary installations and equipment.
A number of councils advise them on such matters as religious broadcasting,
music, agriculture, school broadcasting, further education, programmes for
immigrants, science and engineering and charitable appeals. The governors
appoint the chief executive officer of the BBC—the Director General—with
whom they discuss all major matters of policy and finance. He is chairman
of the Corporation’s board of management, which also includes the managing
directors for television, radio and external broadcasting, the directors of
programmes for television and radio, the directors of personnel, finance,
public affairs, and engineering, and the editor, news and current affairs.
The National Broadcasting Councils for Scotland and Wales control the
policy and content of television and radio programmes intended primarily
for reception in their respective countries. Local radio councils, representa¬
tive of the local community, are appointed by the Minister of Posts and
Telecommunications (in consultation with the BBC) to help in the develop¬
ment and operation of local radio stations.
The services of the BBC are financed from: an annual grant voted by
Parliament for the domestic services, which is the income from the sale of
broadcast receiving licences less certain deductions for collection and other
expenses; an annual grant-in-aid voted by Parliament for the external
services; and profits from BBC publications, mainly the Radio Times, which
has a weekly sale of about 4 million copies and attracts a large advertising
revenue; and income from BBC Radio and Television Enterprises. The net
revenue from the sale of licences for the year ended March 1970 amounted
to ^94-2 million and the grant for the external services was ^11-5 million.
The cost of providing the local radio services is met by the BBC out of
licence revenue, although local authorities are encouraged to contribute.
The Independent Television Authority consists of a chairman, a deputy
chairman and, at present, nine other members (three of whom have responsi¬
bility for Scotland, Wales and Monmouthshire, and Northern Ireland
severally) whose appointment is in the hands of the Minister of Posts and
Telecommunications. The ITA owns and operates the transmitting stations,
but the production studios and equipment are owned, and the actual pro¬
grammes are provided on a regional basis by, programme companies appointed
by the ITA.
The ITA is advised by a General Advisory Council and by committees
on educational broadcasting, religious broadcasting, charitable appeals and
advertising. A specialist panel advises on medical and allied advertisements.

The chief executive officer of the ITA is the Director General. There are
also two deputy directors general, and a headquarters and regional office staff
covering all technical and administrative services. Regional officers act as
representatives of the ITA to the programme companies.
Fifteen programme companies hold six-year contracts to provide television
programmes in the 14 independent television regions of Britain (two com¬
panies share the contract for London, one providing programmes during
the week and the other at the weekend). The companies are financed from
revenue derived from commercial advertisements which are inserted into
and between programmes. The financial resources, advertising revenue,
and programme production of the companies vary considerably, depending
largely on the size of population in their areas. (There are 4-2 million homes
receiving independent television in London as against only 32,000 in the
Channel Islands.)
With the guidance and approval of the ITA, each company plans the
content of the programmes to be broadcast in its area. These consist partly
of material produced by the company itself, partly of that produced by the
other programme companies, and partly of that produced elsewhere, for
example, by the major film companies. The five largest companies (Granada,
Thames, Yorkshire, London Weekend and ATV Network Ltd.) produce a
larger proportion of their own programmes and provide more programmes
for broadcast elsewhere in the national network than do the smaller ones.
A common news service is provided by Independent Television News
Limited, a non-profit-making company in which all the programme com¬
panies are shareholders. The negotiations concerning the supply, exchange
and purchase of programmes and their co-ordinated transmission through
the independent television network take place largely on the Network
Planning Committee which consists of representatives of all the programme
companies and of the ITA.
When a company on the basis of negotiations with the other companies has
decided on a programme schedule for its area, it is required to submit this
to the ITA for approval.
The authority has wide-ranging powers to control and regulate the content
and quality of programmes, for example, it ensures that a ‘proper balance’ of
views is expressed and has drawn up a code on violence stating that special
precautions are to be taken when children are likely to be viewing. There
are also safeguards in the Television Act 1964 to prevent newspaper share¬
holdings in a programme company leading to results contrary to the public
interest. However, the ITA believes that newspapers bring valuable qualities
to the development of television and is not opposed to investment by
them.
The ITA receives no payments from licence revenue; the finance for its
operations is drawn from annual rental payments made to it by the programme
companies amounting to about £7 million in the year ended March 1970.
The programme companies also pay to the ITA for transfer to the Exchequer
a further sum (the levy) related to their advertising revenue; in 1970 this
amounted to some £23 million.
Television viewing has become by far the most popular recreational activity
in Britain. Most families now have television sets which they watch on
average over 4 hours a day. In the last decade there have been major advances
in the technical quality and diversity of the programmes. The introduction
of a second BBC television channel in 1964 both increased the choice of
436
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
BBC Television
Independent
Television
programmes available and provided television pictures of a clearer definition
than had previously been possible. The transmission of colour programmes,
v/hich began in 1967 on this new channel and has since been extended to the j
other two channels, further increased the scope of television. Some 80 per
cent of programmes transmitted on the three services during peak viewing
hours are in colour.
Radio attracts its largest audiences during the day-time when television is
not on the air. The musical interests of many young people have been
catered for by the introduction in 1967 of a fourth national radio channel
providing continuous ‘pop’ music, while local radio stations began in the
same year to provide programmes for all sections of the community with
emphasis on news, sport and local information.
In 1936 the BBC launched the world’s first regular public service of high
definition television. It now provides two services: BBC 1, which is trans¬
mitted on both 405 lines on very high frequency (VHP) and on 625 lines on
ultra high frequency (UHF); and BBC 2, which is transmitted only on
625 lines. Practically all British families live within range of BBC 1 trans- j
mitters. Three-quarters of the population are within range of BBC 2 transmit¬
ters, and some 25 million people are already equipped with sets and aerials
capable of receiving UHF transmissions.
The BBC started the first regular colour television service in Europe in
1967, on BBC 2. In November 1969 BBC 1 went into full colour. By June
1970 some 350,000 colour television sets were in use. BBC colour television
productions cover the whole range of television output: drama, documentary
programmes, feature programmes, films, sport and other outside broadcasts,
comedy and other light entertainment, children’s programmes, music, schools
broadcasts, educational programmes for adults, and religious programmes.
Through co-ordinated planning of programmes on its two television
services, the BBC is able to cater simultaneously for people of differing
interests. BBC 1 presents a high proportion of family entertainment pro¬
grammes and other programmes with a wide appeal. This allows BBC 2 to be
more experimental, to place greater emphasis on serious cultural and docu¬
mentary programmes, and to cater more for minority tastes.
All BBC 2 programmes and the majority of those on BBC 1 are broadcast
nationally. At certain times of day, programmes of regional news and interest
for different parts of the country are inserted into the BBC 1 service. An ex¬
tension and reorganisation of regional television production has been carried
out, based on proposals outlined in 1969 in the BBC plan Broadcasting in
the Seventies (see Bibliography p. 488). In the course of a year, the BBC
television service broadcasts on the national network for some 6,000 hours.
Some 16,000 of its programmes are exported annually to 88 overseas coun¬
tries, including those in Eastern Europe.
The first regular independent television (ITV) service was inaugurated in
1955 by a programme transmission from the ITA London station at Croydon.
Programmes are transmitted on 405 lines on VHF and are within the range
of almost all the population. In 1969 duplicate programmes in colour were
introduced on 625 lines on UHF. By mid-1970 over 60 per cent of the
population were within range of ITV colour transmissions.
The main items broadcast in an average week by the independent television
companies are entertainment programmes, plays and serials, discussions and
documentaries, sport, films, and children’s, religious and educational pro¬
grammes. More than one-third of viewing time is filled with ‘serious’ pro-
TELEVISION AND RADIO BROADCASTING
437
BBC Radio
Commercial Radio
BBC External
Services
grammes. There are about three short advertising intervals an hour, in and
between programmes.
The first regular radio broadcasts by the BBC began in 1927. BBC Radio
provides listeners with four alternative channels. Following changes intro¬
duced in 1970, each channel has a distinct character of its own. Radio 1,
broadcasting over 13 hours a day, provides a programme of ‘pop’ music,
while Radio 2, broadcasting over 21 hours a day, provides light music as
well as being the principal channel for the coverage of sport. Radio 3, broad¬
casting over 16 hours a day, provides continuous, mainly classical music
(much of which is in stereo) and in the evening offers, in addition, works of
artistic and intellectual interest. Radio 4, broadcasting 17 hours a day, is
the main speech programme, providing the principal news and information
service of the BBC. In addition a wide range of drama, talks and entertainment
programmes is presented as well as broadcasts to schools.
Local radio was started by the BBC as an experiment in eight towns in
1967 and has since been extended to cover 20 towns. Local stations transmit
programmes of particular interest to the community which they serve in
addition to their output from the BBC networks.
In July 1970 the Government announced its intention of permitting com¬
mercial radio stations under the general supervision of an independent
broadcasting authority. The Minister of Posts and Telecommunications is
consulting with interested parties in order to determine the future structure
of commercial radio.
The BBC broadcasts to most countries overseas. The main objectives of BBC
external broadcasts are to give unbiased news, to reflect British opinion and
to project British life and culture. The BBC broadcasts in 40 languages
(including English) for a total of over 700 hours a week. News bulletins (of
which there are more than 1,000 a week), current affairs programmes,
political commentaries and topical magazine programmes form the main
part of the output. A full service of sports commentaries and results, all
kinds of music, drama and a wide range of general entertainment program¬
mes are also included.
The languages in which the External Services broadcast and the length of
time each language is on the air are prescribed by the Government. Apart
from this the BBC has full responsibility for the broadcasting operations and is
completely independent in determining the content of news and other
programmes.
The BBC World Service broadcasts for 24 hours a day in English and is
supplemented at peak morning and evening listening times by two additional
series of programmes designed to be of special interest to Africa and Europe.
The foreign language broadcast services are divided into areas, namely,
the African, Arabic, Eastern, Far Eastern, Latin American, French (to
Europe and Africa), Central European, South European, German and East
European Services. Broadcasts range from 70 hours a week in Arabic, 33
hours in German and 30 hours in Russian to half an hour in Nepali. The
BBC’s English by Radio and Television Service is the most extensive lan¬
guage teaching laboratory in the world. Some 230 radio programmes of
English lessons are broadcast weekly with explanations in 40 other languages,
and recorded lessons are supplied to some 250 stations in 69 countries.
English by Television programmes, also produced for teaching purposes,
are shown in more than 60 countries.

Stations and
Studios
BBC
ITA
Advertising
BBC news bulletins and other programmes are rebroadcast by the domestic
radio services of many countries. Rebroadcasting takes the form of direct
relays from BBC transmissions and the use of programme material supplied
in recorded form through the BBC tape and disc transcription service.
There are about 160 rebroadcasts daily of World Service news bulletins in
some 40 countries. The Transcription Service offers programmes to more than
100 countries.
Another part of the external services is the Monitoring Service which
listens to and reports on foreign broadcasts supplying a daily flow of signi¬
ficant news and comment from overseas to the BBC, the Press, and govern¬
ment departments.
Programme links, both permanent and temporary, are generally rented by
the BBC from the Post Office, although some are provided by the BBC with
Post Office agreement. The operation and maintenance of the many transmit¬
ting stations from which its various programmes are sent out are, however,
solely a BBC responsibility.
For its domestic radio programmes, the BBC uses 151 studios, and for its
external services 47 (all in London). In addition, there are 40 semi-automatic
studios which can be operated by programme officials without engineering
staff. BBC television productions come from main studios at the Television
Centre in west London and other studios in various parts of London, and
from fully equipped regional studios at Belfast, Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff,
Glasgow and Manchester. Further provision of studios in the regions is
being made as part of the restructuring of regional broadcasting. Outside
broadcasting is covered by a number of mobile units.
The ITA now transmits programmes from 45 VHF and 12 UHF stations
throughout Britain, programme links being provided by the Post Office.
Independent television programmes are produced at studio centres in Aber¬
deen, Belfast, Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff, Carlisle, Dover, Glasgow, Leeds,
London, Manchester, Newcastle, Norwich, Plymouth, St. Plelier, and
Southampton. The establishment of these studios is the direct result of the
ITA’s policy of encouraging the development of regional television, and the
programmes are designed for either local or national broadcasting. A number
of new studios have also been built for colour television.
The BBC does not give publicity to any individual firm or organised interest
except when it is necessary to provide effective and informative programmes.
Under the terms of the Charter it must not broadcast sponsored programmes
or, without the consent of the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications,
broadcast any matter for payment.
Advertisements are broadcast on independent television subject to the
relevant provisions in the Television Act, in particular that there should be
no sponsoring of programmes by advertisers, that all advertisements should
be clearly distinguishable as such and recognisably separate from the pro¬
gramme, and the amount of time given to advertising should not be so great
as to detract from the value of the programmes as a medium of information,
education and entertainment. In any one hour of broadcasting the amount of
advertising time is normally limited to 7 minutes. Averaged over the day’s
programmes it must not exceed 6 minutes per hour. The ITA has drawn
up a code governing standards and practice in advertising giving guidance
about the types and methods of advertisement that may not be used. Certain

439
types of advertising are prohibited, notably that of cigarettes (under a govern¬
ment ruling of 1965) and for betting. Advertisements may not be inserted in
certain types of programmes, for example, in broadcasts to schools. The cost
of inserting advertisements in the ITV service is borne by the advertisers,
who pay the programme companies for advertising time.
Broadcasts on political issues include a daily factual and impartial account of
proceedings in Parliament, transmitted on BBC’s Radio 4 when Parliament
is in session, and there is frequent coverage of political subjects in news
bulletins and current affairs programmes on both radio and television.
Ministerial and party political broadcasts are also transmitted periodically
under rules agreed between the major political parties, the BBC and the ITA.
The Minister of Posts and Telecommunications is advised on the technical
aspects of television and VHF sound broadcasting by the Television Advisory
Committee, which consists of an independent chairman, the Director General
of the BBC, the Director General of the ITA, representatives from the radio
industry, independent members, and representatives of interested government
departments.
Research into technical problems is carried out by the scientific and
engineering staffs of the BBC, the ITA, the Post Office, the Ministry of Posts
and Telecommunications, and the radio industry. Recent developments by the
BBC include the electronic conversion of monochrome and colour television
pictures between the European and the American systems; the reproduction
of television pictures in slow motion; and the development of a sound-and-
vision system, which enables the television sound and picture to be carried
over a single 625-line vision circuit, and thus eliminates the operational
complexity and expense of a separate circuit for the sound. The ITA has
carried out research into unattended transmitter networks and has based its
new UHF network entirely on unmanned transmitters.
Inter-continental television relays by means of communication satellites began
in 1962 when the first live programme exchanges between the United States
and Europe were made via Telstar, and have increased in range and scale as
synchronous satellites, which are stationary relative to the earth and thus
permit two-way transmissions, have been commissioned.
Direct links with other continents were achieved in 1964: between Europe
and Japan, and between Britain and Australia. In 1967 the first wo rid-wide
television programme, containing live sequences from several countries in
Europe and Africa, the United States, Canada, Mexico, Australia and Japan,
was broadcast.
The BBC and the ITA (together with the Independent Television Companies
Association) are active members of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU),
which was established to advance international broadcasting projects. The
union now has 33 full members among the broadcasting organisations in
Western Europe and 55 associate members (mostly from outside Europe,
including the United States and many of the nations of the Commonwealth).
It manages Eurovision; is responsible for the technical and administrative
arrangements for co-ordinating the exchange of programmes over that
network and for intercontinental satellite links; and it maintains a technical
monitoring station, where frequency measurements and other observations
on broadcasting stations are carried out.
p
440
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The BBC is a member of the Commonwealth Broadcasting Conference.
Each national organisation extends to the others facilities, for instance, in
the use of studios, recording channels, and programme contributions. The
BBC, in addition, provides a large amount of technical aid, particularly in
training the staff of other broadcasting organisations throughout the world,
and members of the BBC’s staff are seconded for service overseas.
The BBC, Reuters, the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Canadian
Broadcasting Corporation and the New Zealand Broadcasting Corporation
are joint partners in Visnews which supplies a service of world news film to
more than 140 television organisations in over 80 countries and is the most
widely used newsfilm agency in the world. The International Television
Federation (Intertel), whose members are broadcasting organisations from
Canada, Australia, the United States and the BBC, produces high-quality
information programmes which are exchanged overseas. United Press Inter¬
national, a television newsfilm agency, and Independent Television News
jointly provide an international service to television organisations via the
Eurovision network and by satellite.
The Government has recently established the Centre for Educational
Development Overseas (CEDO, see p. 166), which includes in its activities
training in educational television for members of broadcasting organisations
overseas. The centre receives an annual grant from the Government and the
BBC provides some technical and other facilities. Training in television
work is also provided for overseas trainees at the Thomson Centre, in Glas¬
gow, run by the Thomson Foundation, a charitable trust. The Ministry of
Overseas Development spends about .£140,000 annually on radio and
television training for overseas students in Britain.
The BBC and the ITA participate in the work of the International Tele¬
communication Union (ITU)—the United Nations specialised agency
responsible for the regulation and control of all international telecommuni¬
cation services (including radio and television), for the allocation and regis¬
tration of all radio frequencies and, through its international consultative
committees, for the promotion and co-ordination of the international study of
technical problems in broadcasting. The BBC is also represented on the
United Kingdom Committee of the International Special Committee on
Radio Interference (CISPR).
18 THE PRESS
Ownership
The British press caters for all political views, different levels of education
and a wide range of interests. It is not subject to State control or censorship.
A very large number of newspapers per person are sold in Britain every day,
and although there are relatively few national newspapers, some of them have
circulations comparable with the greatest in any other part of the world. Ten
of the national newspapers (five dailies and five Sundays) and one London
evening newspaper have circulations in the millions.
The high consumption of newspapers in Britain is partly due to the fact
that some people buy more than one newspaper each day, and partly to the
concentration of the population in a relatively small area and the highly
developed system of distribution, which means that the national newspapers
are available almost everywhere on the day of publication.
Britain imports just over half its newsprint requirements, about i| million
tons annually, while the rest is made from imported raw materials. The average
size of national morning newspapers varies between 13 and 26 pages, and that
of the Sunday newspapers between 27 and 38. The price of the national
mornings ranges from £0-02^ to £0-04 and that of the national Sunday
newspapers from ^0*03! to ^0-06. Separate sections or pages on finance,
business or industry are common, and some papers carry special supple¬
ments on particular subjects, with related advertising. The quality Sunday
newspapers have separate sections for literature and the arts, business and
industry, as well as colour magazine supplements. A colour magazine sup¬
plement is published by a morning newspaper once a week.
According to The Newspaper Press Directory1 134 daily and Sunday news¬
papers and 1,171 weekly newspapers are published in Britain. These figures
include certain specialised papers, the circulations of which are limited not
by region, but by interest; for instance, business newspapers, sporting news¬
papers, newspapers in foreign languages for groups of nationals of other lands
resident in Britain and religious newspapers.
Newspaper ownership in Britain is concentrated mainly in the hands of a
comparatively small number of large press groups, although some enterprises
are organised as limited liability companies, and individual and partner
proprietorship survives. The six major newspaper and periodical publishers
are: International Publishing Corporation Limited; Associated Newspapers
Limited; Beaverbrook Newspapers Limited; the Thomson Organisation
Limited; United Newspapers Limited and Pearson-Longman Limited.
The large national newspaper and periodical publishers are major corpora¬
tions with diversified interests over the whole field of publishing and com¬
munications, and some have shares in the independent television contracting
companies. The International Publishing Corporation and the Thomson
Organisation Limited also have newspaper interests overseas.
Although pronounced views may be expressed in newspapers and their
political leanings may be obvious, they are financially independent of any
1 Changes in the number of newspapers occur constantly; figures are based on the
1970 edition of The Newspaper Press Directory.
442

BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
political party and not obliged to follow any specific party line.1 In order to
preserve their character and traditions, a few newspapers and periodicals are
governed by arrangements which vest ownership of the undertaking in
trustees, or operate it in accordance with a deed of trust, or provide that the
transfer of shares be in the hands of trustees. Others have management arrange¬
ments intended to ensure the authority and independence of the editors.
The trend towards concentration of newspaper ownership, which began m
the early nineteen hundreds and was accentuated after the second world war,
giving rise to some public concern lest press monopoly would affect freedom
of information, was studied by two Royal Commissions on the Press, one of
which reported in 1949 and the other in 1962. The results of the recommenda¬
tions of these Commissions included the establishment and reconstitution of
the Press Council; the provision in the Television Act 1963 which stipulates
that if it appears to the Independent Television Authority at any time that
newspaper shareholdings in television programme companies have led or are
leading to results which are contrary to the public interest, the Authority may,
with the consent of the Minister for Posts and Telecommunications (formerly
the Postmaster General), notify the companies that their programmes may
cease to be transmitted; and the provision m the Monopolies and Mergers
Act 1965 under which the Department of Employment and Productivity has
powers to control the transfer of a newspaper or newspaper assets to a news¬
paper proprietor whose newspapers have an average daily circulation amount¬
ing with that of the newspaper to be taken over, to 500,000 or more copies
after (in some cases) the DEP has received a report from the Monopolies
Commission (see p. 240).
Technological advances in the newspaper industry include the introduction of
web-offset lithography (which is often combined with photo-composition and
the use of the computer in the composing room) and facsimile transmission.

Press
English
Regional
Newspapers
Ten morning papers are ‘national’ in the sense of circulating throughout
the British Isles, and there are seven national Sunday papers (see Table 37).
All the national dailies are produced in London, but those with big circulations
also print northern editions in Manchester, and the Daily Express has a
Scottish edition printed in Glasgow. The leading Scottish papers {The
Scotsman and The Glasgow Herald) have a considerable circulation outside
Scotland Each of the (two) London evening papers has ownership affiliations
with a national daily, but both have their distinctive style drawing their
readership very largely from people living in and around London.
The regional newspapers of England (85 morning or evening dailies and
Sundays and 760 newspapers appearing once or twice a week) provi e
mainly regional and local news. Some of the daily newspapers also give
extensive coverage to national affairs, and a number co-operate to provide
their own foreign news service. The leading regional newspapers have wide
regional circulations; a few have nation-wide reputations.
Generally speaking, regional evening newspapers are non-political, while
the morning newspapers are independent or conservative in outlook.
The total circulation of the regional morning and evening papers is esti¬
mated at about 8 million. Of the morning papers The journal (Newcastle)^ the
Yorkshire Post (Leeds) and the Northern Echo (Darlington) have circulations

of over 100,000 and two provincial Sudnay papers—the Sunday Sun
(Newcastle upon Tyne) and the Sunday Mercury (Birmingham)—have cir¬
culations of over 200,000. Individual circulation figures of regional evening
papers start at about 25,000; most are in the 50,000-100,000 range; a few
have circulations of between 200,000 and 400,000. Weekly papers are mainly
of local appeal; they are also a valuable medium for local advertising. Most
have circulations in the 8,000-35,000 range, but one or two have much
higher circulations—of up to 100,000.
Regional free distribution newspapers (without cover price), some of which
are published by orthodox newspaper publishers, are growing in number and
importance. Some 60 are published weekly and about the same number at
less frequent intervals. Estimated circulation is about 3 million. These news¬
papers carry about 20 per cent of editorial matter.
The London local weeklies (149) include papers for every district in Greater
London. They are assembled mainly in groups of six to eight, affiliated in
some cases to larger groups.
A number of new evening newspapers, using the latest production tech¬
nology, have recently been started in the outer metropolitan area on the
fringe of the circulation areas of the two London evening newspapers.
Scotland Scotland has five morning, seven evening and two Sunday newspapers, in
addition to the Scottish editions of the Daily Express and Sunday Express.
The leading morning papers are The Glasgow Herald and The Scotsman,
published in Edinburgh. Others are: the Daily Record published in Glasgow,
the Courier and Advertiser, published in Dundee; and the Press and Journal
of Aberdeen. Evening papers include the Evening News of Edinburgh,
Glasgow’s Evening Times and Evening Citizen, Dundee’s Evening Telegraph
and Post, Aberdeen’s Evening Express, the Paisley Daily Express and the
Greenock Telegraph. The Sunday papers are the Sunday Mail and the
Sunday Post.
Weekly and local newspapers published in Scotland number over 140.
The most widely known is the People's Journal, which has several local
editions.
Northern
Ireland
Wales
Channel
Islands and
Isle of Man
Northern Ireland has two morning newspapers, one evening paper and one
Sunday paper, all published in Belfast: they are The News-Letter (Unionist)
and the Irish News (Nationalist), the evening Belfast Telegraph and the
Sunday Nezvs. There are 42 weekly newspapers in Northern Ireland, with
circulations ranging from about 5,000 to over 25,000. The majority are
published by individual companies.
Wales has one daily morning newspaper, the Western Mail (101,666), pub¬
lished in Cardiff; it circulates mainly in southern Wales. In North Wales the
Liverpool Daily Post gives wide coverage to events in the area. Evening papers
published in Wales are the South Wales Echo, Cardiff, the South Wales Argus,
Newport, and the South Wales Evening Post, Swansea. North Wales is served
by the Liverpool Echo and to a smaller extent by the Manchester Evening News.
The weekly press (some 50 papers) includes the English language papers
(by far the largest category), some of which carry articles in Welsh; and 10
papers in Welsh, of which five are denominational.
The Channel Islands have two daily (evening) papers (one in Guernsey and
one in Jersey), a Sunday paper {Island Sun) and two weeklies, which also
circulate in Alderney and Sark. The Isle of Man Times is issued from Mondays

News Agencies
THE PRESS 445
to Wednesdays with a special weekly edition which is published on Friday:
there are four other weeklies.
There are over 4,250 periodical publications in Britain, classified as ‘general
and specialised’ and ‘trade, technical and professional’. There are also some
600 ‘house magazines’ produced by industrial undertakings, business houses
or public services for the benefit of their employees and/or clients.
General and specialised periodicals include magazines of general interest;
women’s magazines; publications for children; religious periodicals for all
denominations; fiction magazines; magazines dealing with sport, gardening,
hobbies and humour; journals specialising in various subjects such as politics,
finance and economics, science, agriculture, medicine and the arts; and the
publications of learned societies, trade unions, regiments, universities and
other associations.
The weekly periodicals with the highest sales in Britain are: Woman
(2,246,431); Woman's Own (1,854,645); Woman's Weekly (1,741,254);
Woman's Realm (1,115,653); and Weekend (1,330,607); together with the
Radio Times (3,690,439) and TV Times (3,212,697). The leading journals of
opinion are The Economist (circulation 104,551), a politically independent
publication covering topics from a wider angle than its title implies; the
New Statesman (circulation 77,539), which is a review of politics, literature
and the arts with an independent socialist political tendency; the Spectator,
which covers much the same subjects from an independent conservative
standpoint; Tribune, which has a strongly left-wing but anti-communist bias;
New Society, which covers the sociological aspects of current affairs; and
New Scientist, which reports on the progress of science and technology in
terms which the non-specialist can understand. Punch (124,079), traditionally
the leading humorous periodical, has in recent years devoted increasing
attention to public affairs.
Literary and political journals and those specialising in international and
Commonwealth affairs, published monthly or quarterly, appeal generally
speaking to the more serious type of reader.
Business magazines include technical, trade, export and professional and
semi-professional journals, the publication of which has become one of the
more important aspects of the British publishing industry. In addition to
circulating in Britain, these journals have a considerable circulation outside
the United Kingdom and are an important media for selling British goods
overseas. Their publication ranges in frequency from weekly to quarterly.
Periodicals published in England circulate throughout the United Kingdom.
Weekly papers are also published in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland:
in Wales a farming weekly (the Welsh Farm News) and several monthly and
quarterly journals in both Welsh and English; in Scotland four monthly
illustrated periodicals (Scottish Field, Scotland's Magazine, Scots Magazine
and Scotland), two weeklies devoted to farming interests (Farming News and
Scottish Farmer), a number of literary journals, of which the most famous is
probably Blackwood's, and numerous popular magazines; and in Northern
Ireland weekly, monthly and quarterly publications covering farming, the
linen industry, building, motoring, politics and social work.
There are three principal British news agencies:
Reuters Ltd. is a world news agency owned by the newspapers of the
United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand through the Newspaper
Publishers Association, the Press Association, the Australian Associated Press
446
Training for
Journalism
BRITAIN I971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
and the New Zealand Press Association, and operated on a non-profit-making
basis under the terms of a deed of trust entered into to safeguard the independ¬
ence and integrity of the news service. Founded in Aix-la-Chapelle in 1850
and transferred to London in 1851, Reuters has about 1,000 correspondents in
180 countries and territories, and links with 77 national or private news
agencies, which give it access to coverage by many thousands of local re¬
porters. Between 600,000 and 700,000 words of general news, sports, and
economic services reports are received in London every day over a global
network of leased cable and radio circuits. From these messages regionalised
news services, specially tailored to the needs of recipients in the United
Kingdom and eight main overseas regions, are transmitted to 120 countries
for distribution to information media, either direct or through national news
agencies. Reuters Economic Services supply up-to-the-minute information
to business houses throughout the world. Its computerised systems, including
Stockmaster, Videoscan and Videomaster, offer virtually instant coverage of
the important stock and commodity markets by computer interrogation or
video display. A computerised message-handling system, known as the Auto¬
matic Data Exchange, is used to speed up the handling and distribution
of news.
The Press Association Ltd., the British national news agency founded in
1868, is co-operatively owned by the principal newspapers of the United
Kingdom outside London, and the Republic of Ireland. It provides news¬
papers, the broadcasting organisations, Reuters (of which it is a major joint
owner) and other international agencies with a complete service of home
news, including general and parliamentary news, legal reports, and all
branches of financial, commercial and sports news; and includes in its services
to regional papers the world news of Reuters and the Associated Press.
Through its Photographic Department the Press Association serves London
and regional newspapers with a daily picture service, including its own world
photos and those of the Associated Press. Its Special Services Department
supplies reports of local or special interest to daily and weekly trade papers
and periodicals. All profits are used to develop the service.
The Exchange Telegraph Company Ltd. (Extel), an independent news
agency founded in 1872, is a public company with over 1,000 shareholders,
which supplies financial and sporting news to newspapers and broadcasting
organisations. Racing services are also supplied by teleprinter and telephone
to subscribers in London and the provinces from offices in all important cities
and towns.
The British press and broadcasting organisations are also served by
Associated Press Ltd., which is the British operating company of the Associa¬
ted Press of America, and by United Press International, an international
news agency with a headquarters in London.
A number of other United Kingdom, Commonwealth and foreign agencies
and news services have offices in London, and there are agencies in other
cities, specialising in various aspects of newspaper and periodical require¬
ments. Syndication of features is not as common in the United Kingdom as
in some countries, but a few agencies specialise in this type of work.
The Printing and Publishing Industry Training Board (which has 23 members
—nine employers, nine employees and five from educational interests) is
responsible for training in the printing, publishing and professional photo¬
graphy industries. Its responsibilities include the formulation of training
T HE PRESS
447
schemes, the establishment of standards, ensuring that adequate facilities exist,
and the provision of a regional advisory service.
The National Council for the Training of Journalists (NCTJ), which
represents the principal press organisations, works in consultation with the
Board. Its functions include superintending activities concerning entry into
journalism, setting and conducting examinations; and organising short
training courses and seminars for journalists.
There are two normal methods of entry to newspaper journalism: (i) by
selection for a place on a full-time course lasting for one academic year and
(2) by direct recruitment by a newspaper. Students selected for courses must
have gained two passes at the Advanced level of the General Certificate of
Education and be under the age of 20 at the beginning of a course; at the end
of their course the NCTJ assists them to find employment. All junior entrants
must also take part in a national training scheme consisting of a three-year
apprenticeship (two years for graduates) and parallel training on-the-job
(which includes two eight-week courses for direct entrants), and adult
entrants participate whenever possible. Entrants from full-time courses serve
a three-month and direct entrants a six-month probation. There are now
seven centres providing courses for reporters (five in England, one in Wales,
and one in Scotland) and one centre for photographers. The syllabus covers
practical journalism, shorthand, English, law, government and current affairs;
at the end of their apprenticeship trainees take a proficiency test which carries
a salary bonus. NCTJ approved training has been extended into the periodical
field on the basis of a special curriculum and courses are available for entrants
in London where the periodical publishing industry is mainly located.
Other training developments include a university course in management (at
Warwick University) sponsored by the Newspaper Publishers Association and
the Newspaper Society, and a one-year postgraduate course in journalism
at the University College of South Wales in Cardiff.
Under the Commonwealth Press Union Travelling Fellowship Scheme for
the training and education of young journalists throughout the Common¬
wealth, each year about eight journalists from overseas spend five months
in the United Kingdom; two months in the offices of newspapers or periodi¬
cals and three months acquiring a general idea of life in Britain. A limited
number of travelling scholarships are also awarded to British journalists to
enable them to visit Commonwealth countries overseas.
The Thomson Foundation offers scholarships and organises training
courses for journalists from all parts of the world at its Centre in Cardiff,
and provides consultants and tutors for courses for journalists overseas.
The Commonwealth Secreteriat is studying a plan for inter-Commonwealth
training arrangements in journalism and communications, based on a com¬
bination of indigenous schemes and training exchanges, and for the provision
of a special course in the United Kingdom on economics and finance for
Commonwealth journalists.

Institutions are the Newspaper Publishers Association, whose members publish national

represents the regional, local and London suburban press; the Scottish Daily
Newspaper Society, which represents the interests of daily and Sunday news¬
papers in Scotland; the Scottish Newspaper Proprietors Association, which
represents the owners of weekly newspapers in Scotland; Associated Northern
Ireland Newspapers, whose members are the proprietors of weekly newspapers

in Northern Ireland; and the Periodical Publishers Association, whose
membership embraces the independent publishers of trade and technical
publications and general magazines. On the journalists side there are the
Institute of Journalists (loj), founded in 1884 as the National Association
of Journalists, and the National Union of Journalists (NUJ), founded in 1907.
All practising journalists (including those engaged in radio, television, public
relations and freelance journalism) are eligible for membership of both these
organisations. In order to achieve joint working and prepare the ground for a
single organisation, an arrangement has been made for dual membership
without the payment of extra subscriptions. At the same time, to avoid over¬
lapping, different activities have been allocated to each organisation, the loj
being responsible for professional questions and the NUJ, primarily, for
industrial relations. Total membership is about 24,750 (NUJ about 23,000
loj about 1,750).
The main aims of the Guild of British Newspaper Editors are to sustain
the dignity of editorship, to raise and safeguard the professional status of
editors, to protect the rights and freedom of the press, and to improve the
education and training of journalists: the Guild has about 400 members. The
British Association of Industrial Editors is the professional organisation to
which most editors of house journals belong.
The Printing and Kindred Trades Federation is the federation of the
printing trade unions which include the National Graphical Association, the
Society of Graphical and Allied Trades, and the Scottish Typographical
Association.
The Press Council, established in 1953 and reconstituted in 1963, has a lay
chairman and 25 members. Its aims are: to preserve the established freedom
of the British press; to maintain the character of the British press in ac¬
cordance with the highest professional and commercial standards; to keep
under review any developments likely to restrict the supply of information of
public interest and importance; to deal with complaints about the conduct
of the press or the conduct of persons and organisations towards the press; to
report on developments in the British press which may tend towards greater
concentration or monopoly; to make representation on appropriate occasions
to the Government, to organs of the United Nations and to press organisations
abroad; to publish its adjudications and periodical reports recording its work,
and to review from time to time developments in the British press and the
factors affecting them. Reports, which include statistics of the newspaper and
periodical press and a series of articles examining the structure of the leading
press groups, are published annually.
The press in Britain has the same freedom as the individual to do and say
what it likes provided it does not transgress the law; in general, it is at liberty
to comment on matters of public interest. Apart from enactments relating
directly to such matters as the registration of newspapers for postal purposes,
there are no specific press laws but certain statutes include clauses which
apply, in particular or incidentally, to the press. These relate to such matters
as the extent of newspaper ownership in television companies; the transfer
of newspaper assets (see p. 442); restrictions on newspaper reporting of
preliminary hearings of indictable offences (in England, Wales and Northern
Ireland); the right of press representatives to be admitted to meetings of local
authorities; restrictions on the publication of (a) divorce and domestic pro¬
ceedings in courts of law, (b) advertisement and investment circulars, which
THE PRESS
449
are governed by Acts dealing with the publication of false or misleading
descriptions of goods and services and with fraud and (c) advertisements of
remedies for certain diseases, which are covered by public health legislation;
agreements between the Post Office and newspaper proprietors on telegraphic
communications, which must comply with telegraphs legislation; restrictions
on certain types of prize competition; and copyrights, which come under
copyright laws.
Of particular relevance to the work of the press are the laws on libel and
defamation; contempt of court—a newspaper may not publish comments
on the conduct of judicial proceedings which are likely to prejudice their
reputation for fairness before or during the actual proceedings nor may it
publish before or during a trial anything which might tend to influence the
result; and seditious libel, incitement to disaffection and revealing official
secrets.
Legal proceedings against the press are comparatively infrequent; the
majority of actions that do take place are libel actions brought by private
individuals. In such cases, the editor, proprietor, publisher, printer and
distributor of the newspaper, as well as the author of the article, may all be
held responsible.

Central and
