Government
Participation
In Britain, the word ‘sport’ is used generally to describe such activities as
organised outdoor games, athletics, field or country sports, indoor games and
sports, aquatic sports, and such popular pursuits as horse-racing, greyhound
racing, show jumping, riding, rock climbing, orienteering, motor racing, and
rifle shooting as well as those (for instance, archery, fencing, gliding and
skating) which, although less popular judged by the number of participants
and spectators, all have their own devotees. Those who engage in sport may be
professionals (that is, paid players) or amateurs.1 Professionals keep up the
technical standards of the sports in which they take part and spectators make
a vital contribution by their enthusiasm and their financial support; but the
sporting life of Britain derives its character principally from the amateur
element—people who devote time and energy to organising sport and to
teaching and training, as well as the many thousands of all ages who engage
in sport for pleasure alone.
The Government is not directly concerned v/ith the organisation or promotion
of sport in Britain but it provides encouragement, guidance and help through
a Minister who has special responsibility for sport; it gives financial aid to
national and local voluntary organisations towards approved expenditure on
the provision of facilities for physical recreation, and to national governing
bodies of sport in Great Britain towards the costs of their administration and
coaching schemes, participation in international events overseas and the
holding in Britain of world championships and events of similar importance.
The Government is advised on matters relating to the development of
amateur sport and physical recreation by the Sports Council, whose members
serve in a voluntary capacity and are appointed for their wide experience of
all aspects of sport and recreation. Nine regional sports councils in England,
a sports council for Scotland and a sports council for Wales, bring together
representatives of local authorities, voluntary sports organisations and the
government departments principally concerned, to consider regional require¬
ments for facilities, to promote regional co-operation on planning and to
advise government departments on regional needs and priorities. In Northern
Ireland the Ministry of Education is advised by the Youth and Sports Council.
The Sports Council works in close co-operation with all organisations con¬
cerned with sport, and provides a forum for the discussion of problems
affecting sport.
In 1969-70 direct government expenditure on sport in Great Britain
totalled some £2-54 million. This covered capital grants to national and local
voluntary organisations towards the provision of facilities, grants to national
voluntary organisations for administration, coaching and participation in
international events and grants for research projects sponsored by the Sports
Council. The greatest provision for sports facilities is made by local authorities;
the expenditure involved is taken into account in determining the aggregate

In Northern Ireland £541,000 in grants was given to public authorities
and voluntary organisations for sports facilities and coaching schemes in

The Secretary of State for Education and Science, the Secretary of State for
Scotland and the Ministry of Education for Northern Ireland require that
all publicly maintained schools shall provide for the physical education
(gymnastics, games, athletics, dancing and swimming) of their pupils. Schools
in the national systems (excepting those solely for infants) must have a
playing field, or the use of one, and most secondary schools have a gymnasium
and other amenities such as swimming pools, sports halls and halls designed
for dance and movement: in an increasing number of areas, physical education
facilities in schools are being expanded to meet the recreational needs of the
whole community. Facilities for, and instruction in, many kinds of sport are
likewise provided at the independent preparatory and public schools and at
the universities (some of which have departments of physical education).
Local authorities also provide playing fields, gymnasia, tennis courts, golf
courses, boating lakes, swimming baths and sports centres on an increasing
scale, and some arrange further education classes in various physical education
subjects. Most of the larger industrial and commercial undertakings provide
sports facilities for their employees.
The national voluntary organisations most closely concerned with the general
development of sport are the Central Council of Physical Recreation, the
Scottish Council of Physical Recreation, and the National Playing Fields
Association. The British Olympic Association, whose main functions are
connected with the participation of British teams and competitors in the
Olympic Games, is also interested in all matters likely to benefit sport or
physical recreation in Britain as a whole. In addition, each sport has its own
governing body with, in many cases, entirely separate autonomous governing
bodies in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.
The Central Council of Physical Recreation (CCPR), whose membership
represents all national bodies in England, Wales and Northern Ireland con¬
cerned with the development of post-school physical recreation, provides the
Sports Council with such services as may be agreed in the administration,
technical and research fields. It receives grants from the Ministry of Housing
and Local Government and from the Ministry of Education for Northern
Ireland. Its General Secretary is also the Director of the Sports Council.
The CCPR consists of about 300 members, over 200 of whom represent
national bodies concerned wholly or in part with the development of some
branch of physical recreation. The Council’s headquarters are in London and
it has nine regional offices in other parts of England. Its activities in Wales
are controlled by a representative Welsh committee, and in Northern Ireland
by a separate section of the Council.
Broadly, the Council’s function is to promote all forms of physical
recreation. Its activities include the organisation of courses for coaches and
instructors, classes in personal performance, lectures, displays and other
publicity events. It runs, on average, about 2,000 courses for more than
40,000 people each year. Its staff give advisory, technical and administrative
help wherever required, but particularly to the headquarters, regional, county

and local branches of the constituent organisations and to local educational

The Scottish Council of Physical Recreation (SCPR) is the counterpart in
Scotland of the CCPR, and has 146 affiliated organisations, including the
governing bodies of all the Scottish sports; it receives a grant-in-aid from
the Scottish Education Department.
The main aim of the National Playing Fields Association (NPFA) is to
stimulate the provision of playing fields, playgrounds and sports centres by
publicity and technical and financial assistance. Since its inception in 1925
it has distributed nearly £1-9 million in the form of grants for playing field and
playground schemes and about ^467,000 in the form of loans. It assists more
than 400 schemes a year.
The NPFA council is composed of representatives of the governing bodies
of various sports organisations, of the British Olympic Association and the
CCPR, and of a number of educational bodies, voluntary youth organisations,
physical education associations and local authorities. The national head¬
quarters in London employs a small full-time staff, including a technical and
research department which gives advice on all aspects of recreational
planning including the provision and layout of indoor and outdoor sports
facilities. Advice is also given on matters relating to the play and recreational
needs of children from their earliest years, and the establishment of play¬
grounds and play leadership schemes. The Association derives its funds
mainly from voluntary contributions but it also receives a small contribution
towards administrative costs from the Ministry of Housing and Local
Government.
The NPFA has branches in Scotland and Northern Ireland; there are also
branches in nearly every English and Welsh county; administration is carried
out, in the main, on a voluntary basis—in many cases in association with a
local authority or Rural Community Council.
There are six National Sports Centres in Britain, three in England, one in
Wales and two in Scotland—administered by the CCPR and the SCPR with
the help of government grants. The centres, some of which were established
by voluntary funds, provide a wide range of courses for coaches, instructors
and performers in many games, sports and other physical activities. A
National Sailing Centre at Cowes, Isle of Wight, is also administered by the
CCPR with the help of a Government grant; it provides courses on sailing,
boat handling, cruising, navigation, racing, boat maintenance and boat build¬
ing, for school and youth groups and for adults. A national rowing and
canoeing regatta centre, administered by the CCPR and financed by the
Government and Nottinghamshire County Council, is being built at Holme
Pierrepont. There are national mountaineering centres in Wales and Scotland,
a national equestrian centre and a national indoor sports centre for para¬
plegics.
The Crystal Palace National Sports Centre in London covers 36 acres; it
has a main stadium with seating for 12,000 spectators, a sports hall with
seating for 2,000 spectators, a swimming hall with pools of Olympic dimen¬
sions, a teaching pool and a gallery for 2,000 spectators, an indoor cricket
school, practice rooms suitable for all indoor activities, a hostel for 140
residents, and staff housing. These facilities, which are available for inter¬
national competitions as well as for the training of leaders, coaches and

Outdoor Games
and Sports
Football
performers, are managed by the CCPR and supported by grants from the
Greater London Council and the Government.
Outdoor games played in Britain include team games such as football,
cricket, and hockey, and games such as lawn tennis and golf, in which
individuals or couples match their skill. Judged by the number of participants
and spectators, the most popular of the team games are football and cricket;
the most popular of the individual games is lawn tennis.
Although football of a kind was played in the Middle Ages or even earlier,
as an organised game it dates from just over a century ago. One type of
football, in which only the feet are used, was adopted at Cambridge in 1848;
the other type, in which the ball is handled as well as kicked, was first played
at Rugby School, whence it derives its name, and was adopted by the
Blackheath football club in 1859.
In England the controlling body of the non-handling game, Association
Football (‘soccer’), is the Football Association (FA) formed in 1863. Its chief
function is to promote the interests of the game and to prevent infringement
of the agreed rules. It also arranges for the instruction of promising young
players (some £50,000 is spent annually on coaching); organises various
matches and competitions, including the international matches played by
England, the Amateur Cup competition, the FA Sunday Cup competition,
two national youth competitions, and the competition for its own leading
trophy, the Football Association Challenge Cup; and chooses and manages
English international teams. Over 360 clubs are registered with the FA, more
than 250 as full members and between no and 120 as associate members.
There are also some 32,000 clubs affiliated to county (that is, district or
regional) associations. The FA derives its main income from subscriptions
and admission charges to international and cup matches, and ploughs back a
large portion of the money into the game. Scotland, Northern Ireland and
Wales have their own controlling bodies: the Scottish Football Association,
the Irish Football Association and the Football Association of Wales.
The principal professional matches in England and Wales (played once or
twice weekly) are controlled by the Football League, which comprises 92
professional clubs in these countries. The funds of the League are derived
largely from contributions paid by member clubs in the form of a levy of
4 per cent of the net gate receipts from league matches, after allowable
expenses have been deducted; from annual payments from football pools
promoters for the use of league fixture lists; and from television rights.
In Scotland the Scottish Football League comprises 37 clubs; Northern
Ireland has its own League. Clubs belonging to the English and Scottish
Leagues are organised in divisions, the members of which compete against one
another for the respective league championships. Their positions in the
divisional tables are decided at the end of the season by the number of points
gained for wins or draws. During the season attendances at Football League
matches total about 30 million and gate receipts amount to about £8 million.
Several million people stake small weekly sums on the results of the league
matches by filling in what are known as ‘pools’ coupons. The odds against
winning anything in the pools are very great, but the prizes are high and
individual payments of £300,000 are occasionally made. The promoters
deduct varying amounts from the stakes for commission and expenses.
The annual competition for the FA Cup is organised on a knock-out basis
and the Cup Final is one of the most important football matches of the year
in England; it is always played at Wembley Stadium, near London, which
454
Cricket
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
can accommodate some 100,000 spectators. The Scottish Cup Final is played
at Hampden Park, Glasgow. The matches between England, Scotland, Wales
and Ireland also excite great interest, as do other international matches.
There are many more amateur association football players than there are
professionals (the comparative figures are nearly 1 million amateurs, including
schoolboys and members of the armed forces, to 7,000 or 8,000 professionals),
but with one or two notable exceptions their teams cannot compete on equal
terms, since professional teams are more systematically and intensively
trained. Amateur teams compete against each other for the Football
Association Amateur Challenge Cup.
Rugby football (‘rugger’) is played according to two different sets of rules.
Rugby Union Football is played (in England) under the auspices of the Rugby
Football Union, established in 1871. There are 15 players in a side. Inter¬
national matches between England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, and France are
played regularly at the leading rugby football grounds of each country,
including Twickenham, London—the headquarters of the Rugby Football
Union—and there are tours by international teams. Other important rugby
matches are the county championship competitions, the annual match between
the universities of Oxford and Cambridge, the Hospitals’ Cup Final, and the
Inter-Services tournament. Membership of the Rugby Union is strictly
confined to amateur clubs of which there are over 1,600 in membership, with
about 1,000 schools.
Rugby League Football—a 13-a-side game played by professionals as well
as amateurs—is played mostly in the north of England. The game’s governing
body, the Rugby Football League—instituted in 1895—has its headquarters
at Leeds and regularly sends touring teams to Australia and New Zealand.
Annual international games, professional and amateur, are played against
France. The major match of the season—the Rugby League Challenge Cup
Final—has attracted crowds of 100,000 at Wembley Stadium in recent years.
Cricket is often called the English national game. It originated as a rustic
medieval pastime; by 1550 it is known to have been played by boys at
Guildford Grammar School, and after the Restoration it became fashionable
with the nobility, who competed with each other to sponsor matches for very
large sums of money. Among the many clubs founded in the eighteenth
century was the famous Hambledon Club in Flampshire, whose members
were cricket’s elite and supported the most brilliant players of the day. In 1787
the Marylebone Cricket Club (MCC) was founded in London and, assuming
responsibility for reframing the ‘Laws of Cricket’, became the governing body
of the game in Great Britain. Its first headquarters were at a ground on the
site of the present Dorset Square, rented by a Yorkshireman called Thomas
Lord, who gave his name to this and the two succeeding grounds. The second
ground, at which MCC was established from 1811 to 1813, was on the
perimeter of Regent’s Park. The present ground, at St. John’s Wood, was
opened in 1814.
Cricket in Britain is now governed by the Cricket Council, made up of
representatives of MCC, the Test and County Board of Control (representing
first-class cricket) and the National Cricket Association (representing club
and junior cricket). MCC retains world-wide responsibility for the laws of
cricket.
The game is played in schools and universities, and most towns and villages,
as well as industrial sports clubs, have teams which play at least one match a
week from late April to early September. In the London area a large number
SPORT
455
Lawn Tennis
of pitches are provided by local authorities to augment those leased or owned
by clubs. In the Midlands and the north of England there is a network of
League cricket, contested by teams of Saturday afternoon players reinforced
by one or more professionals, often distinguished overseas players.
The focus of the season centres on a series of ‘Test matches’ played between
England and a touring team from overseas (or sometimes two teams). The
first of these matches was played in Melbourne between England and
Australia in 1877. Since then international tours have taken place regularly
between countries of Test status, who now number seven. The matches last
30 playing hours spread over five days and arouse great popular interest.
The principal grounds in England on which Test matches are played are
Lord’s; the Oval, Kennington, London, headquarters of Surrey County
Cricket Club; Old Trafford, Manchester; Trent Bridge, Nottingham;
Headingley, Leeds; and Edgbaston, Birmingham.
In addition to the Test matches a First Class County Championship,
decided on a points system, is played for by 17 counties, each playing 24
three-day matches. The counties not deemed first-class and second elevens of
the first-class counties play in a Minor Counties Championship. The Univer¬
sity Elevens of Oxford and Cambridge rank as first-class and play an annual
match at Lord’s. Since 1963 the counties have also competed in a single
innings knock-out competition for the Gillette Cricket Cup and in 1969 a
Sunday League was inaugurated.
Since 1963, the distinction between amateur and professional players in
county and Test cricket has been abolished. In 1968 the qualification rules
were relaxed to allow a limited number of top-class overseas cricketers to play
in the English county championships.
The forerunner of modern lawn tennis (the game known as jeu de paume) was
introduced into England from France in the fifteenth century and a ‘tennis
court’, built by Henry VIII, is still in use at Hampton Court. The modern
game, first played in England in 1873, quickly became very popular; in 1877
the words ‘and lawn tennis’ were added to the title of the All England Croquet
Club at Wimbledon, near London, and in the same year the first champion¬
ships were played. The Lawn Tennis Association, the controlling body of the
game in Britain, was founded in 1888. The governing body of the game in the
world (the International Lawn Tennis Federation, with headquarters in
London and Paris) was founded in 1913.
The number of people who play lawn tennis has greatly increased during
the present century, particularly since the game has spread to practically
every country in the world. In Britain the game is played in almost all girls’
schools and in very many boys’ schools where the pupils are of secondary
school age. It is also played on private courts, in parks and recreation grounds
and at several thousand tennis clubs.
The annual championships held at Wimbledon for two weeks at the end
of June and beginning of July are the main event of the lawn tennis season
in Britain and, in fact, in the world. These championships, in which men and
women of many nationalities compete, draw large crowds; there is accom¬
modation for over 30,000 spectators in the grounds of the All England Club—
14,000 can be accommodated round the centre court where the finals are
played. Other tournaments which attract a good deal of attention are: the
British Hardcourt Championships, the British Junior Championships, and
the County Championships. There are also competitions for boys’ and girls’
schools on a national basis. The most important international events are the

Davis Cup (for men) and the Federation Cup competition (for women).
Women players from Britain and the United States of America also compete
annually for the Wightman Cup.
Golf originated in Scotland, where for centuries it has borne the title of the
Royal and Ancient Game, but it did not become really well known in the other
countries of the United Kingdom until towards the end of the nineteenth
century. Since then, however, it has gained steadily in popularity (particularly
since the mid-1950s); nowadays there are golf courses in the vicinity of many
towns and villages in all parts of Britain—some owned by local authorities,
but the majority owned by golf clubs—and the question of the game’s large
land requirements is being studied by the Department of Social and Economic
Research at the University of Glasgow. The headquarters of the Royal and
Ancient Golf Club is St. Andrews, Scotland.
The main event of the golfing year is the British Open Golf Championship,
which was first played in i860; other important matches include the Walker
Cup (for amateurs) and the Ryder Cup (for professionals), both played
between Britain and America; the Amateur Championship; the World
Amateur Team Championship; and the Ladies Championship.
Variants of hockey (as distinct from ice-hockey) have been played in Britain
for at least five centuries, and some, like hurley in Ireland and shinty in
Scotland, are still played extensively. Modern hockey, however, dates from
the formation (in 1886) of the Hockey Association of England. The Inter¬
national Hockey Rules Board, comprising the Associations of England,
Scotland and Wales and the Irish Hockey Union, together with delegates from
the Federation Internationale de Hockey, representing the rest of the world,
controls the rules of the game. There are some 2,000 men’s hockey clubs
throughout Britain with at least 30,000 male adult players; some 600 boys’
schools also play the game. Although there are no professional county teams
and no cup ties in England, a county championship is held annually. In
Scotland there is a Scottish cup competition and six local league competitions
and the Welsh Hockey Association organises a Welsh cup competition.
Regular amateur international matches are also played. Men’s hockey is an
Olympic sport, and the arrangements for the British team are in the hands of
the British Olympic Hockey Board.
The controlling bodies of women’s hockey are: the All England Women’s
Hockey Association (founded 1895) to which are affiliated some 900 clubs and
2,200 schools, representing a total membership of about 72,000 adults and
1-i million schoolgirls; the Irish Ladies Hockey Union; the Scottish Women’s
Hockey Association; and the Welsh Women’s Hockey Association. The first
international women’s hockey match took place in 1896. Nowadays such a
match is played annually at Wembley Stadium (in addition to those played in
other parts of the country), where it attracts some 60,000 spectators.
Lacrosse, adapted from the game played by the Iroquois Indians of North
America, is played mainly by women—in girls’ schools, at lacrosse clubs, and
at universities. International matches, as well as regional matches between
women’s teams representing the East, West, South, North and Midlands of
England, are played under the auspices of the All England Women’s Lacrosse
Association.
The men’s game, for which the controlling body is the English Lacrosse
Union, is played in ten universities, several colleges of education and by clubs
and schools, mainly in the London, Manchester, Leeds, Sheffield and
Nottingham areas. Matches played include county matches, an annual fixture
Netball
Polo
Bowls
Croquet
Mountaineering
sport 457
between the North of England and the South, and international matches
between Australia, America, Canada and England.
Netball is a popular game for girls and women. The controlling body is the
All England Netball Association to which are affiliated the English county
associations, the netball clubs of the three Women’s Services and sections of
the national youth and university organisations for girls and women. Inter¬
county and home international matches are played regularly and inter-
Commonwealth tours are arranged.
Polo, of which the earliest records are Persian, was first played by the British
in India, and brought to England in 1869. The governing body of British
polo is the Hurlingham Polo Association to which many Commonwealth and
several overseas polo associations are affiliated. Polo players are a very
small section of the community, for the cost of keeping polo ponies is high.
However, many of the clubs now own trained ponies which are hired out to
members at moderate cost. There are about 470 players handicapped by the
Hurlingham Polo Association, but many less expert players take part in club
games for which they may be locally handicapped.
Public interest in polo has increased in recent years and large numbers of
spectators attend inter-club tournaments and matches between high-handicap
teams composed of players from several countries.
The game of bowls has been played in Britain since the thirteenth century.
Nowadays the game is regulated, as far as the English Bowling Association
is concerned, by the International Bowling Board (IBB), founded in 1905.
The Bowling Associations of Ireland, Scotland and Wales also come under
and play to the laws laid down by the IBB, but there are other bowling
associations in England—the English Bowling Federation, the Crown Green
Association and the English Women’s Bowling Association—which are not
under the IBB’s control.
During the summer bowls is played on bowling greens in the open; in
winter it is played on indoor greens, which are increasing in number. At one
time regarded as a pastime for the elderly, the game is now played by people
of all ages. Over 2,620 bowling clubs in England are affiliated to the English
Bowling Association alone. International, inter-county matches, and national
championship competitions of singles, pairs, triples and fours are played.
Croquet originated in Britain in the middle of the nineteenth century and has
developed into a game which is played by people of all ages on the lawns of
local croquet clubs and private gardens. Some 70 clubs are registered with the
Croquet Association—formed in 1896—which encourages and promotes the
development of the sport in Britain and maintains links with croquet associa¬
tions in other countries.
The popularity of mountaineering has greatly increased in recent years. The
number of clubs in the British Mountaineering Council (BMC) and the
Mountaineering Council for Scotland, the representative bodies of the sport,
is now over 190, ranging from national clubs, such as the Alpine Club (founded
in 1857, the oldest mountaineering club in the world) and the Scottish
Mountaineering Club, to small regional clubs with 20 to 30 members. A
number of local education authorities, as well as national bodies such as the
Central Council of Physical Recreation and the Outward Bound Trust,
have established mountaineering training centres in the hills. Training
courses are run jointly by the CCPR and BMC, the Youth Hostels Associa¬
tion and other bodies, and many universities and schools have mountaineering
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
sections. Membership of the known clubs is about 15,000 but several times this
number take part in climbing and mountaineering.
British mountaineers have taken a leading part in exploring most of the
great ranges of the world and in climbing their peaks; for example, the first
ascent of the Matterhorn in 1865, of Everest in 1953, and of Kangchenjunga
in 1955. In recent years frequent expeditions have gone to far-off mountains,
to Greenland, Alaska, the Andes, Patagonia, the Caucasus and the Pamirs,
as well as the Himalayas.
Ski-ing in Scotland has become very popular, especially at the winter sports
centres established in the Cairngorms, Deeside, Glencoe and Glenshee,
where ski-runs equal to those in other areas of Europe have been developed,
and ski-lifts, ski-tows and professional instruction are now available. There
are, in addition, 24 artificial ski-slopes in other parts of Britain.
Amateur athletics, which include running (track, road and cross-country),
relay racing, jumping, hurdling, throwing and race-walking, are governed by
the Amateur Athletic Association (AAA), which was founded in 1880 to
encourage amateur athletics, to improve the management of amateur athletic
meetings by the establishment of uniform regulations, and to promote annual
championship meetings. The Association, whose membership increased
rapidly, is now organised from club to national level by honorary officers
and managed by representative members appointed by the Northern, Midland,
Southern and Welsh areas and by affiliated clubs and associations (amateur
athletic clubs, schools and youth organisations), of which there are hundreds
throughout England and Wales. The AAA administers a coaching scheme
under which eight full-time national coaches, working mainly in separate
regions, lecture, demonstrate and coach in schools, youth clubs, evening
institutes, training colleges and universities and at special courses organised
by the national associations, by regional associations or by the Central Council
of Physical Recreation. Some of the work of the national coaches is directly
concerned with coaching young athletes but their main duties are to instruct
men who wish to qualify as AAA coaches, over 1,600 of whom give
voluntary services in the counties and districts of England and Wales. Scotland
and Northern Ireland have their own amateur athletic associations, with
similar functions; there are also separate women’s AAAs for each country.
International athletics and the selection of teams representing the United
Kingdom are dealt with by the British Amateur Athletic Board, which is
composed of representatives of the three national associations for men and
of the Women’s Council, and is affiliated to the International Amateur
Athletic Federation.
Track meetings are held throughout Britain from April to October. The
main events in England and Wales are: the national championships for men
and women and international matches usually held in London; area and county
championships; and the universities, Services, business houses and schools
championship meetings. Clubs usually compete in cross-country running from
October to March, and county, area and national cross-country champion¬
ships are held.
Teams representing Britain compete in the Olympic Games (held every
four years) and separate teams representing England, Wales, Scotland, and
Northern Ireland compete in the Commonwealth Games, held at four-yearly
intervals between the Olympic Games.

459
The Highland games are traditional gatherings of local people in the High¬
lands of Scotland, at which sports (including tossing the caber, putting the
weight, and throwing the hammer) and dancing and piping competitions
take place. Among the better known Highland games are the Braemar
Gathering on Deeside (traditionally attended by the royal family), the
Argyllshire Gathering at Oban, and the meeting at Aboyne. The Highland
games are a unique spectacle which attracts large numbers of spectators from
all over the world.
The most popular country sports are hunting, shooting and fishing; these are
old-established sports with a long history, and they still play a considerable
part in the life of the countryside. The organisation which looks after their
interests is the British Field Sports Society.
In Britain hunting means primarily fox hunting on horseback with a pack of
hounds; but it also includes stag hunting, which preceded fox hunting and
still goes on, mainly in Devon and Somerset; hunting the hare, either on foot
with beagles or with harriers when the followers are mounted; and otter
hunting along the banks of rivers. Hunting depends not on right but on the
goodwill of small landowners and farmers, the majority of whom support
their local hunt by allowing it to ride over their property.
Fox hunting originated some 200 years ago. Originally a sport mainly for
the landed gentry and local farmers, it has gradually widened its appeal, in
spite of the fact that it is an expensive pastime for those who ride to hounds.
The sport is not without its critics, but an ever larger number of people,
including many townsmen, take a keen interest in it. Most hunts meet two
or three times a week and it is estimated that between 25,000 and 30,000 people
ride to hounds weekly, and many others follow in cars, on bicycles or on foot.
The fox hunting season starts in early November and lasts until April;
it is preceded by cub hunting, that is, the hunting of young foxes, when
young hounds are trained. At the end of the season most hunts organise
steeplechases, known as point-to-points, which are patronised by large
crowds.
There are 200 packs of hounds in England and Wales, 13 in Northern
Ireland, and 10 in Scotland. The packs range in size from the large establish¬
ments in the Midlands of England (for instance, the Belvoir, the Cottesmore,
the Quorn and the Fernie) to small kennels in the west and north.
Hunts are financed mainly by the subscriptions of their members (£15 or
less to £50 or more), by ‘caps’ (contributions paid by non-subscribers), and
by the proceeds of such annual events as the point-to-point races and the
hunt ball. Sometimes the Master of Fox-hounds (MFH), who is in charge
of the hunt, bears a proportion of the cost.
Game shooting as an organised country sport may be said to date from the
early part of the nineteenth century; nowadays, game consists mainly of
grouse, partridge, pheasant, snipe and woodcock.
There is virtually no free shooting in any part of Britain. A shot gun
certificate, for which a fee is payable, must be obtained from the local police
by anyone who possesses, purchases or acquires a shot gun1; and it is necessary
to have a licence to kill game. Nearly all game birds are to be found on
1 A shot gun is defined in the Criminal Justice Act 1967 as ‘a smooth bore gun having
a barrel not less than 24 inches in length, not being an air-gun’. Shot guns with barrels
less than 24 inches long are subject to control under the Firearms Acts 1937 and 1965,
and a firearm certificate must be obtained from the police by anyone wishing to possess,
purchase or acquire them.

Fishing
Aquatic Sports
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
privately owned land, shot over either by the owner and his friends or by
syndicates which have leased the shooting rights. However, in some parts of
the more remote countryside, rough shooting may be enjoyed in a less formal
way. Much of the country’s wild-fowling is controlled by the Wildfowling
Association of Great Britain and Ireland, through its numerous clubs.
Grouse, partridge, pheasant and certain other birds are ‘preserved’: that
is to say, there is a ‘close season’ during which they are protected by law and
allowed to breed in security, often under the care of privately employed
gamekeepers on numerous estates. Grouse shooting takes place mostly
in Scotland, northern England and North Wales; partridge and pheasant
shooting in nearly every county in England, Wales and Scotland, the former
mainly over farm land, and the latter in or near woodland; and wildfowling on
the marshes and fenlands of the coastal areas.
The Game Conservancy formed by landowners, farmers and others
interested in game conservation and research, collects and collates information
on a national scale and makes a detailed study of factors controlling game
population.
Deer stalking, which derives its name from the fact that, in order to get
an effective shot, a very cautious approach is needed (since red deer have a
keen scent, are far-sighted, and take alarm at the slightest sound), is mainly
a sport of the Highlands of Scotland. The deer are preserved in privately
owned ‘deer forests’, ranging in size from 9,000 to over 30,000 acres (3,642
to 12,140 hectares). Deer, too, are protected during close seasons.
Fishing is the most popular of the country sports in that it is within the reach
of everyone in some form or another (from the small boy with his hook and
line to the experienced fly-fisherman), and that many more people fish in
their leisure hours than hunt or shoot.
The outstanding forms of the sport in Britain are salmon and trout fishing.
Trout streams are to be found in most parts of the country, and in Scotland
there are also many hundreds of lochs which provide good sport. Salmon
fishing may be enjoyed in England, North Wales and Northern Ireland,
but the best salmon rivers are to be found in Scotland. In England and
Wales the most widely practised form of fishing is for coarse fish such as
pike, perch, carp, roach, dace, tench, chub and bream, and the National
Federation of Anglers (NFA) has some 450,000 members in over 3,000 clubs
comprising 152 associations. Match angling—competitive fishing for coarse
fish by weight—is a feature of the many angling clubs affiliated to the NFA,
particularly in the Midlands and north of England. A national angling cham¬
pionship, composed of teams of 12 anglers, is organised annually by the
NFA, and the NFA enters a team in the International Angling Competition.
Fishing around the coasts is another popular pastime, while deep-sea
fishing for tuna and shark has gained many adherents during the past 20 years.
Coastal and deep-sea fishing is free to all (except for salmon and sea trout
fishing in Scotland) but, as a rule, freshwater fishing has to be paid for and
local enquiries made about any permit or licence required. Most coarse
fishing is let to angling clubs; trout and salmon fishermen either rent a
stretch of river, join a club, stay at an hotel with its own fishing rights, or
pay for the right to fish by the day, week or month. The cost of salmon
fishing is often high.
Aquatic sports include rowing, sailing, swimming, canoeing, punting and
water ski-ing. The first three are the most commonly practised in Britain
and are included in the Olympic events and the Commonwealth Games.
SPORT
Rowing
Sailing
Swimming
461
Rowing as a pastime is enjoyed by people from all sections of the community,
and as a sport it arouses considerable public interest. The University Boat
Race, which originated in 1820, has been rowed annually on the Thames in
the early spring since 1836. The race is between eight-oared crews from Ox¬
ford and Cambridge over a course of some 4J miles (6-84 km.) between Putney
and Mortlake and is watched by many thousands of rival supporters gathered
on both sides of the river. Interest is also shown in the Head of the River Race
from Mortlake to Putney, in March, in which more than 350 eights row in
procession—the largest assembly of racing craft in the world.
Crews from all over the world compete each July in Oxfordshire at Henley
Regatta, founded in 1839, where various kinds of races are rowed over a
straight course of 1 mile 550 yards (about 2-1 km.); for instance, for the Grand
Challenge Cup, open to eight-oared crews from any nation, the Silver Goblets
for pair oars, the Diamond Sculls for single scullers, the Ladies’ Challenge
Plate open to crews from schools and colleges and the Princess Elizabeth
Challenge Cup for eights open to schools from Britain and overseas. Many
other riverside resorts arrange summer regattas.
The oldest annual event in the English racing calendar is Doggett’s Coat
and Badge, founded in 1716 and organised since by the Worshipful Company
of Fishmongers. Originally for professional watermen and limited to six
entrants, the race is now open to amateurs (who must, however, still be
apprentice watermen); if necessary, it may be rowed in heats. The course
is from London Bridge to Chelsea.
The art of oarsmanship is taught in many schools, universities and rowing
clubs, including women’s rowing clubs, throughout Britain; and women as
well as men compete in the European rowing championships. The Amateur
Rowing Association is the governing body of the sport in England and
Wales and the Scottish Amateur Rowing Association in Scotland.
Yachting has always been a popular leisure time activity on the inland and
coastal waters of Britain, but in recent years the sport, and in particular
small boat sailing, has greatly widened its appeal. The Royal Yachting
Association (RYA), the national governing body for both sail and power
yachting, has over 1,550 clubs and 32,000 personal members. The RYA has
approved sailing schools giving courses for novices, a National Sailing Centre
where instructors are coached and tested, and is responsible for the selection
of Great Britain’s Olympic team. One of the world’s main regattas takes place
from Cowes in the Isle of Wight annually during the first week of August.
Other major events are held throughout the year at such sailing centres as
Poole, Lowestoft, Harwich, Burnham on Crouch, Plymouth, Falmouth and
the Clyde. Racing is subject to the rules of the International Yacht Racing
Union, founded in 1907.
Many children in Britain learn to swim at school, or during holidays at the
seaside, and swimming as a summer pastime is enjoyed by millions of people.
The existence of indoor swimming baths, many of them provided by local
authorities, makes all-the-year swimming possible, and instruction and
coaching is provided in some places by qualified teachers who hold certificates
for elementary or advanced teaching and coaching awarded by the Amateur
Swimming Association (ASA). The objects of the ASA are to promote
the teaching and practice of swimming, diving and water polo and to stimulate
public opinion in favour of providing proper accommodation and facilities
for them; and to draw up, publish and enforce uniform laws for the control

Racing

Greyhound Racing

and regulation of amateur swimming, diving and water polo championships
and competitions in England.
Racing is a term which, in Britain, is taken to mean, first and foremost,
horse-racing. Others forms of racing include greyhound racing, coursing,
pony-racing, trotting races and pigeon flying.
Horse-racing has been known in England since Tudor times and even earlier.
The Jockey Club (formed about 1750), which controlled flat racing, and the
National Hunt Committee (founded in 1866), which controlled steeplechasing,
amalgamated as The Jockey Club in 1968. This body exercises control over
all horse-racing in England and indirectly in many other countries, and its
rules are the basis of universal turf procedure. In 1970 The Jockey Club was
granted a royal charter.
Flat racing is carried on from late March till November, and steeplechasing
from August to June.
The classic flat races are: the Two Thousand Guineas for colts and fillies,
and the One Thousand Guineas for fillies only, both run at Newmarket; the
Derby for colts and fillies and the Oakes for fillies only, both run at Epsom;
and the St. Leger for colts and fillies, run at Doncaster. The Derby is the
outstanding event in the racing calendar; it takes place annually in late May
or early June and the scene on Epsom Downs on Derby Day is one of the
most colourful and exciting of the sporting year. The most fashionable race¬
meeting of the season is held at Ascot in Berkshire, in mid-June, and is known
as ‘Royal Ascot’, being traditionally attended by the Sovereign.
The most important steeplechase meeting is the National Hunt Festival
Meeting at Cheltenham in March. The best known single steeplechase is the
Grand National at Aintree, near Liverpool, run annually since 1839.
In England and Wales there is racing on 58 racecourses (excluding point-
to-point courses) and Scotland has six racecourses. There is a total of about
900 days’ racing annually. There are some 11,000 horses in training in Great
Britain, at an average cost of ^20-^24 a week each.
Horse racecourses must be licensed by The Jockey Club. Facilities for cash
and credit betting are available on and off the racecourse, turnover being
subject to a government betting duty. On-course facilities are provided by
bookmakers, who must have personal permits, and by totalisators operated
by the Horserace Totalisator Board, which is empowered to deduct from
money staked with the totalisator such percentage as it may determine.
Facilities for off-the-course betting are provided in licensed betting offices, of
which there are some 15,000 throughout Great Britain. People under 18 years
old are forbidden by law to place bets.
A levy both from bookmakers and the Horserace Totalisator Board is
collected by the Horserace Betting Levy Board, which distributes the revenue
for purposes conducive to the improvement of horse breeding and racing, and
for the advancement and encouragement of veterinary science and education.
The Horserace Betting Levy Board is also responsible for the work of the
National Stud at Newmarket, which concentrates on providing stallions for
British breeders.
The racing of greyhounds after a mechanical hare started in Britain in 1926,
when the first modern greyhound track was opened at Belle Vue, Manchester.
There are now about 130 licensed tracks in operation, nearly all of them near
large towns, and meetings are held two or three times a week. The licensing
Riding
Show Jumping
sport 463
authorities for greyhound racing tracks are the county and county borough
councils. Some 10 million people a year attend greyhound racing.
The main authority for the sport is the National Greyhound Racing Club,
founded in 1928; its functions include drawing up the rules of greyhound
racing and keeping strict discipline over the sport. The 53 greyhound race¬
courses which accept the rules of the Club are the largest in the country and
account for approximately 92 per cent of the total attendance and totalisator
turnover. All are members of the National Greyhound Racing Society which
controls the general policies of greyhound racing, administers the affairs of,
and acts as spokesman for, the sport.
Greyhound racing can be conducted only at a licensed greyhound racecourse
and only on 104 racing days in a licensing year (1st July-30th June). There
are some 10,500 greyhounds in training under the National Greyhound
Racing Club Rules, and the average cost for their upkeep including training
is about £2’5° a week.
Where a totalisator is operated at a greyhound racecourse, up to i2|- per cent
(variable by regulation) of the money invested can be deducted for operational
expenses, and 5 per cent must be paid to the Government in respect of general
betting duty. Bookmakers are allowed to operate at a greyhound racecourse,
but are not permitted to bet on greyhound racing at totalisator odds unless the
consent of the occupiers of the tracks at which the totalisators are operated
is given.
The classic greyhound races are held at various racecourses in London, as
follows: the Gold Collar at Catford; the Greyhound National at the White
City; the Greyhound Derby at the White City; the Greyhound Oaks at
Harringay; the Scurry Gold Cup at Clapton; the Laurels at Wimbledon; the
St. Leger at Wembley; and the Cesarewitch at West Ham.
Interest in the art of horsemanship continues to increase; there are over
2,000 riding schools in Britain, of which nearly 250 are inspected and approved
by the British Horse Society, membership of which has risen to 17,000 (with
an affiliated membership of nearly 100,000). There are 315 riding clubs for
adults, whilst the Pony Club (open to young people up to the age of 21)—with
a world-wide membership of 75,000—has 288 branches in Britain.
The British Horse Society, as the National Equestrian Federation of Great
Britain, is the authority on all matters relating to horses and ponies, including
breeding, training, riding, show jumping, horse trials and dressage, and is
responsible for preparing equestrian teams for the Olympic Games and all
international events. The Society, which runs the National Equestrian
Centre at Stoneleigh, Warwickshire, is also the parent body of the Pony Club
and the riding clubs, and organises and provides tests, lectures, publications,
courses and examinations to promote horsemanship and horsemastership.
Horse trials are held throughout Britain during the spring and summer.
The three-day trials held each year—in April at Badminton, Gloucestershire,
in May at Tidworth, Hampshire, and in September at Burghley House,
Lincolnshire—are among the outstanding equestrian events of the year.
These trials include dressage, cross-country riding and show jumping; some
45 one-day trials on similar lines are held annually.
Show jumping competitions are held each year at over 800 shows. The
main events take place during the Royal International Horse Show (held at
the Wembley Stadium, under the auspices of the British Horse Society
towards the end of July)—the outstanding contest being the individual

Boxing
Wrestling
jumping championship for the King George V Gold Cup. Jumping competi¬
tions are also a feature of the Horse of the Year Show, which takes place in
October at the Empire Pool, Wembley, and is acknowledged to be one of the
finest indoor horse shows in the world. The total membership of the British
Show Jumping Association has risen to over 8,000. The number of horses and
ponies registered is more than 6,000 and over .£150,000 is distributed annually
in prize money.
The selection of British riders and horses taking part in international
competitions (whose successes have materially contributed to the increased
popularity of show jumping) is the responsibility of the executive committee
of the Association.
Boxing as an English sport probably originated in Saxon times. Its modern
form, and the one that has been adopted in many overseas countries, dates
from 1865 when the Marquess of Queensberry drew up a set of rules which
eliminated much of the brutality that had hitherto characterised prize fighting,
and made the basis of the sport a trial of strength and skill.
Nowadays, many boys learn to box at school and in boys’ clubs, and there
are various amateur boxing competitions carried out according to the rules of
the Amateur Boxing Association (ABA), which controls all amateur boxing,
including schoolboy boxing, club and association boxing, and boxing in the
three Services.
Professional boxing is covered by the British Boxing Board of Control,
founded in 1929. The Board has strict medical regulations which provide
for the examination of boxers before each contest, and the appointment of
inspectors to ensure that the regulations are observed and that all contests are
‘vetted’ to safeguard against over-matching and exploitation.
Championships at fixed weights have been the rule in boxing contests since
the presentation of the Championship Challenge Belts by the late Lord
Lonsdale in 1909. Those organised by the ABA are decided at ten weights:
flyweight, bantamweight, featherweight, lightweight, light welterweight,
welterweight, light middleweight, middleweight, light heavyweight and
heavyweight. In professional boxing there are no light welterweight or light
middleweight categories.
Wrestling is one of the oldest sports in the world. The style most commonly
used in Britain is the ‘free’ style, which evolved from the Catch-as-Catch-Can
or Lancashire style, but Cumberland and Westmorland wrestling is still
practised in the north of England and in Scotland, and Cornish style wrestling
(in which the contestants wear rough canvas jackets by which all holds must
be taken) takes place in Cornwall. Wrestling in the free and Graeco-Roman
styles features at the Olympic Games; in the Commonwealth Games only
free style is wrestled.
Amateur wrestling in Britain is governed by the British Amateur Wrestling
Association, which is affiliated to the International Amateur Wrestling
Federation, under the rules of wrhich all wrestling is conducted. Professional
wrestling is usually in the ‘all-in’ or ‘free’ style, which is not the same as the
free style used in amateur wrestling.
Judo, an Olympic sport originating in Japan, has a large and growing follow¬
ing. In Britain it is governed by the British Judo Association, which is affiliated
to the International Judo Federation under the rules of which judo competi¬
tions are conducted. There are some 580 clubs in the Association, which has
Judo
Fencing
Motor Racing
Cycling
SPORT 465
coaching schemes assisted by the Ministry of Housing and Local Government
for some 15,000 registered individual members.
Fencing as a sport has made considerable progress throughout Britain during
the past 20 years. The Amateur Fencing Association (founded 1902) has nearly
700 clubs, and many classes are organised and financed by local authorities.
Fencing is also practised in many schools, and among the annual champion¬
ships held under the auspices of the Association are the National Schoolboys’
and Schoolgirls’ Championships, organised on a regional basis and attracting
a large number of entrants.
Motor racing is one of the most popular spectator sports in Britain; more
racing and sports cars have been built in Britain than in any other country;
and British drivers (including women drivers) have an international reputation
second to none.
British cars and British drivers take part in the international world classic
races which are the main features of the sport. They include the British
classic races—the British Grand Prix and the Tourist Trophy. There are also
many other British race meetings and rallies, as well as many day and night
rallies and trials, endurance tests, hill climbs and other events, arranged by
various driving clubs, of which there are over 1,100 in Great Britain.
The best-known motor racing circuits are those at Silverstone, Northamp¬
tonshire ; Crystal Palace, London; Brands Hatch, Kent; Snetterton, Norfolk;
Mallory Park, Leicestershire; Oulton Park, Cheshire; Thruxton, Hampshire;
Cadwell Park near Louth, Lincolnshire; Croft near Darlington, Co. Durham;
and Ingliston near Edinburgh, Scotland. The controlling body of motor
sport in Britain is the Royal Automobile Club (RAC), founded in 1897; the
RAC is represented on the Federation Internationale de 1’Automobile, which
draws up the regulations for international motor racing. Kart racing also comes
under the jurisdiction of the RAC.
In addition to motor car racing, there are motor cycle races—the most
important contest of the year is for the Isle of Man Tourist Trophy—and
motor cycle speedway racing, introduced into Britain in 1928, and governed
by the Speedway Control Board.
The internationally recognised body for cycle racing in the United Kingdom
is the British Cycling Federation which has 736 affiliated clubs and provides
third party insurance and a legal aid service for its members. It controls
track and massed start road racing in Britain, and is concerned with the cycling
events in the Olympic and Commonwealth Games and the annual world
championship. Time trials are organised by the Road Time Trials Council.
Touring by bicycle is catered for by both the British Cycling Federation
and the Cyclists’ Touring Club (CTC). The CTC is the oldest touring club
in the world and has a membership of some 20,000. Its representatives in all
parts of the United Kingdom give advice and practical help to touring
cyclists; its 50 district associations arrange holiday and week-end tours and
competitions, rallies and rides of all kinds; and its travel department gives
CTC members every facility, both at home and abroad, including the pro¬
vision of itineraries. Other benefits provided are a touring magazine, a
members handbook, legal aid and third party insurance.
Rifle Shooting The Joint Shooting Committee for Great Britain, founded in 1955, represents
its member associations—the National Rifle Association (NRA), the National
466
BRITAIN 1971: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Indoor Games
Small-Bore Rifle Association (NSRA) and the Clay Pigeon Shooting Associa¬
tion (CPSA)—in the International Shooting Union and the British Olympic
Association. The Committee sponsors all entries to international competitions.
Full-bore (7*62 mm and -303 in) rifle and pistol (high power) shooting is
organised by the NRA, founded in i860. The Imperial Meeting held
annually at Bisley Camp, Surrey, is attended by some 2,500 competitors from
Britain and other Commonwealth countries, including cadets from schools,
and lasts for just over a fortnight: the first week consists of team and individual
competitions for members of the armed forces, and there are three days for
schools only. The premier award of the meeting is the Queen’s Prize which
attracts about 1,000 entries. The NRA also organises postal matches for
British and overseas teams, and periodically sends rifle teams to shoot in other
Commonwealth countries.
Small-bore (’22) rifle and pistol shooting—carried out either on indoor
ranges of 15 to 25 yards in length or on open ranges up to 200 yards—is also
widely practised in Britain. Some 4,000 clubs throughout the country are
affiliated to the NSRA which arranges inter-club and inter-county competi¬
tions of various kinds for teams and individuals. Clubs also compete in county
and local groups. The NSRA organises a National Bisley Meeting (usually
attended by more than 2,000 competitors), a Scottish meeting (some 600
competitors), and the British Pistol Championships (some 500 competitors)
at Bisley. International small-bore rifle and pistol matches are held with teams
from overseas and British entries for the world championships and the
Olympic Games are made through the Joint Shooting Committee. The NSRA
provides coaching and advisory services.
Clay pigeon shooting clubs are situated in all parts of Great Britain; the
sport is governed by the CPSA (comprising individual shooters and clay
pigeon clubs) which represents Great Britain in major international events.
Indoor games played in Britain include billiards, table tennis and badminton,
which are enjoyed by large numbers of people, and for which facilities are
provided in social clubs of every kind, including youth clubs; and games
such as real tennis (a game which originated in thirteenth-century France),
squash rackets, rackets and fives, which are less national games than games of
the schools, universities and specialised clubs. Annual championships are
held in all these games, the controlling bodies of which are: the Billiards
Association and Control Council; the Badminton Association of England and
the Scottish Badminton Union; the Tennis, Rackets and Fives Association
and the Squash Rackets Association. Basket-ball is played in Britain both in¬
doors and outdoors, primarily by men and boys. In England there are nearly
1,000 senior clubs and the game is played in many schools. The controlling
body, The Amateur Basket Ball Association, organises championships and is
affiliated to the Federation Internationale de Basketball Amateur.
APPENDIX
CURRENCY
From 15th February 1971 a decimal system of currency will be used in Britain.
It will be based on the pound sterling divided into 100 new pence (p). There
will be six denominations: 50p; lOp; 5p; 2p; Ip; and |p. (For fuller details
see p. 370.)

BIBLIOGRAPHY
This bibliography is in no sense comprehensive: it is only intended to be a guide to
further reading on the subjects covered in this handbook.
Readers are asked to note that in Britain the Central Office of Information
reference documents marked with an asterisk may be obtained, on payment of a
small charge, from the Central Office of Information, Reference Division Distribu¬
tion Unit, Hercules Road, Westminster Bridge Road, London SE1; and overseas
they may be obtained from British Information Offices.
Certain reference pamphlets produced by the Central Office of Information can
be purchased from Her Majesty's Stationery Office and its agents overseas. These
pamphlets are listed here with their respective prices {postage extra).
Acts of Parliament referred to in the text can be obtained at varying prices from
H.M. Stationery Office and its agents overseas.

Most of the organisations concerned ivith sport publish year books covering results and
records of the previous season and future prospects; many weekly or monthly periodicals
on sport are also published. In addition some newspapers issue annual surveys of sport.
INDEX
Bold type in a sequence of figures indicates main references.
As the main purpose of this book is to inform readers overseas about Britain, organisa¬
tions and societies are generally indexed under their subject matter rather than under
Association of, British, National, Royal, etc. (that is, Accidents, Royal Society for the
Prevention of; Archives, National Register of). In cases where the first word is not
separable, however (for example, Royal Air Force, Royal Society), entries will be found
appropriately.
Items are indexed under England, Northern Ireland, Scotland or Wales only where
they are matters peculiar to these countries; otherwise they are indexed under the
relevant subject headings.

ENGLISH C H A N N
BRITAIN 1971 — published by Her Majesty's Stationery Office—is the twenty-
second official handbook in the series prepared and revised each year by the
Reference Division of the Central Office of Information with the co-operation
of other government departments and of many national organisations. It is
designed to answer questions about Britain which are continually being asked
both abroad and at home. This edition covers events up to September 1970.
